column8: I've used it several times

column5: From shady and 70 degrees to about 30 degrees the nano air is the most comfortable jacket I own.  I never seem to overheat in the nano air, it seems to be just in that sweet spot or just a tad cold (which as a high output mid layer is important).  I sized a little small on this item so it layers well under a shell for skiing and mountaineering, I'm pretty slim and a medium form fits.  A  drawback that I'd recommend Patagonia work on are the arm lengths which seem to be a little to short on the medium and way too big on the large.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I traded in my nano puff pullover for this jacket and I'm happy with that choice in every category except 1.  This jacket seems to run a bit large for its size, both in sleeve length and in the body.  It is rather baggy on me despite the nano puff fitting perfectly.  As this is a mid layer or outer layer I can understand that it leaves a little room for layers underneath, but this jacket leaves a little too much room.  I wish I could try on a medium, but I've already worn this on multiple climbing trips and it wouldn't be right to trade it in now.  It does an excellent job keeping me warm when I'm not moving while at the same time it dumps excess heat when I'm actually climbing.  This is key as I don't have to adjust layers constantly.  I also like the mechanical stretch which gives me better range of motion when reaching or contorting my body into weird positions.  I also really like the double chest pockets.  I typically wear this with a harness on so the standard pockets are inaccessible.  The 2 chest pockets are great to store my phone and snacks.  

I would absolutely recommend this jacket, I would just suggest trying it on first to make sure you are pleased with the fit.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I wear it to work, in the mountains, and around town. It basically never leaves my body during the winter. I love the feel and fit of it and it's definitely quite warm. I personally don't think it breathes *especially* well, but likely a little better than other puffies I've tried. No wear or issues to report at this time. Get yourself one!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This jacket is super awesome and I love using it for layering under my shell, when skiing.  It puts out a lot of heat!  I've also worn it in light rains, and the DWR coating kept me dry.  Get the Nouveau Green, you won't be disappointed.  I'm 5'10" 165 and the Large fit me perfectly.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This puffy is probably one of my favorite articles of clothing.  It's super warm but still very breathable.  It's had no problems facing Joshua tree rock and plants.  It's pretty great for a skiing mid layer as well.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I own an Arcteryx Atom LT and have compared these two pieces. I bought this thinking it would be a good high activity insulation piece in cold weather. I've used it while charging up hill on mountain hikes or backpacking trips. My initial impressions are that either it doesn't breath like it claims, or it's just too warm. In 30 degree weather I got very warm and quickly found myself wanting to switch to a fleece instead of the Nano Air. 

The cuffs are shaped awkwardly in that they don't taper like the comparable options from other brands, so you end up with too long of sleeves that bunch up into big puffy masses around your wrists. 

The lack of any hood adjustment on a $300 synthetic jacket is a big oversight. 

Overall I like the jacket, but not for $300. It's a good insulation piece at a relatively poor value. Can't help but feel like I paid for the brand name, which isn't even embroidered. Details matter when you pay a lot for a simple piece!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I've had my Primo Down for 7 years.  It is the best ski jacket I have ever owned- light, warm, durable, super comfortable.  My wife even copied me and bought her own...
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
If you're looking for a down filled jacket with gore tex, this is it!

What's good:
*Gore-tex shell
*800 fill down

What's Great:
*the current discounted price ($385)
*backcountry.com is the best place to buy winter gear. their customer service is awesome, their shipping is fast and their prices are unreal. 

What you need to know:
*The sizing of this jacket is 1 size off. I ordered the medium and my sales manager who's 6'2 and in great shape thought it was a perfect size for him. Even the arm length is a size off. If you you're a husky guy or need to layer then get the size you always get for jackets. 

I ended with the small and it fits exactly how i thought the medium was supposed to; perfectly. (roomy but not baggy)
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
Patagonia appears to set out with the absolute best materials like gore-tex and down and then cripples the jacket with technical problems.   The gore-tex fabric is really thick and warm on this jacket, and the warmth from the down is excellent for a light jacket that moves well.

The zipper on the Primo down and regular Primo are very difficult to move up and down, jerking and catching frequently.  The pocket zippers are almost unusable.  Also the hood does not come out nearly far enough to protect your face.   New England winter means windy precip and this hood does not protect your face at all, it does not cover the sides of your face.

The zippers and hood are fatal flaws for an expedition jacket, I would look to another brand if you need to rely on this jacket in the backcountry to protect you from hypothermia and frostbite.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Bomb proof. Super Light. Great mobility for aggressive skiing or late night apre! Definitely runs on the smaller side, but once you dial in the fit you are styling
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Fantastically warm yet lightweight jacket. Very comfortable fit though I'm glad I followed the other reviews and sized down - I bought a M (which turned out to be the right size for me), when I'd normally wear large (5"11, 175 lbs). My only complaint is that the zippers on the 2 front chest pockets catch on the material inside the pockets. These 2 pockets are basically unuseable as a result because the zipper gets caught every time when pulling it up and down. Strangely, all the other zippers on my jacket don't have this issue. A shame because it is otherwise a great jacket, even for the price.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This is a great jacket for those super cold days out on the mountain.  Lots of nice features such as gore-tex shell, powder skirt, and lots of pockets.  Works great for casual use as well.

Purchased this for my brother for his bday + Christmas gift.   He needed something to get through the nasty Chicago winters but also something he can use when hitting the mountains in Colorado and Utah.   It looked a little big on him but he is lean and lanky so most clothes fit that way.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
Ordered the green one. Looks absolutely amazing but... What the hell is up with Patagonia's need for seemingly changing their sizing every damn year? Ordered an M size and not only are the sleeves too long, but it is also very wide, and bulky. I tried it outside and if I don't use the drawcords at the hips, lot of cold air entered. Not good. I own a Piolet jacket from 2014 in size L, and it's the same size as the Primo Down in M. Both of them are regular fit. I have returned mine to exchange for an S size to see if it fits better. Unfortunately, Patagonia Europe move very slowly, and so, after three weeks, I have not yet received the money to my account, so I can order a new size.

The quality of the jacket seemed good, but I would recommend anyone contemplating ordering online to be very sure of the fit of this jacket. 

UPDATE: So I took a chance and ordered a size small... it went back to Patagonia the next day. Almost perfect but chest/shoulders was a little tight and that didn't work for me. It's a shame, because I really wanted to like this jacket - it looks fantastic. In the end, though, I didn't feel the love, and at that price, I just couldn't motivate sticking with it. Again, too bad Patagonia's sizing policy is as it is with some products.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I just got the coat and tried it on. I always wear a medium and in the chest/shoulders this coat was fine. But the sleeves were so long they covered my entire hands. So I sent it back. It's a beautiful coat with obvious high quality so I wasn't happy about having to send it back. I can't size down as a small wouldn't fit in the chest. Since I never wore it outside I can't rate it further. Minus 1 star for weird sizing.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: Been using mine a lot these past few weeks as the temperature starts to drop in Colorado. This is one stop protection from the elements with a goretex shell and premium down on the inside. This is very lightweight considering the protection this provides. Patagonia stylish and with a lifetime warranty you won't need any other jacket but this one. Backcountry shipped it super fast and was hassle free. Treat yourself to the best. This is the primo edition!!! #goatworthy
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I just purchased this jacket before a ski trip out to Vail. This jacket is very light and yet protects from wind and cold temp (teens). 
The removable powder skirt is great for use off the slopes and the pit zips allow temp regulation when you ski the back bowls hard.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Great jacket for the cold blooded skier. This jacket has no business being as warm as it is for how light it is...wow. It can be comfortably worn for extended periods of time between -10F to 40F with just a t-shirt on.. 

 I am 6'4 185lbs and this is the first medium jacket I have ever owned....and it fits so perfect. My tall and slender figure is hard to fit because sleeves are usually to short for a medium but the chest (I have a 40.5" chest) on large jackets are usually to bulky.

As for the flaws.  The hood cords are finicky but excellent hood if adjusted properly.    The main zipper takes some serious breaking in. The zipper garage at the top of the main zipper has to be physically held out to zip up in order to not catch.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Stretch Nano Storm Insulated Jacket - Men's
column5: I have had the nano air for years and always loved it, however, there are a few drawbacks to the nano air and I didn’t love having to use it as a mid layer more often than a stand alone. The stretch nano storm fills the void that no other jacket comes close to, variable insulation with a waterproof shell! It retains the amazing features of the nano air, comfy stretchy and breathable, while adding a little warmth and waterproofing. Very happy with the stretch fabric although it does feel a little on the thin side I haven t experienced any issues with it thus far.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Stretch Nano Storm Insulated Jacket - Men's
column5: So, I really like the Nano Air (I have one without the hood), but the wind goes right through it. This is so much better for me. Wind and rain are stopped, but it is still fairly breathable and has a nice stretch to move with you. Pit vents are extremely useful for when it doesn't dump heat fast enough. Useful pockets are a nice addition as well.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Stretch Nano Storm Insulated Jacket - Men's
column5: It's pretty simple... if you like Nano Air and want an insulated, water-resistant jacket, you're gonna like the Nano Storm.  I'm a huge fan of the Nano insulation.  I know it can be considered bulkier and less than flattering... but I love it.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Stretch Nano Storm Insulated Jacket - Men's
column5: I am 5'11" 200lb. And got the XL because I like roomy. It is a great winter windproof rain resistant jacket but wonderfully lightweight. If we get a plunger here in Vermont I simply add a fleece beneath and hit the outdoors without a shiver. Highly recommend this jacket and buying from backcountry because they are great people to deal with. There. My two cents.

column2: Stretch Nano Storm Insulated Jacket - Men's
column5: Patagonia's new Stretch Nano Storm jacket is essentially a Nano-Air Hoody encapsulated in a breathable tech shell with a longer, ski inspired cut. I have had this jacket for a couple months now and am amazed how much I've used it. From running errands on cold/rainy days to Snowmobiling in 0 F temps, it really delivers. It is comfortable due to the soft interior lining, and breathes very well - the Stretch Nano Storm is a true do-it-all jacket and will serve you well on the slopes or around town for 8 months out of the year. I am 6'2" 185 and like the large, but could fit in a medium if I wanted a more technical alpine fit.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Stretch Nano Storm Insulated Jacket - Men's
column5:
This jacket is built for beer bellies and/or tall people.

5'10 175-180lbs and the medium is way too long, it's also bulky from the torso down. I get the 'alpine' cut is longer, but this should fit  a person of my stature better. This jacket would look much better on someone who's 6'0-6'2 and lean or someone who's excessively overweight in the midsection at my height.  I'd consider trying a small but the shoulders will likely be too small.

column2: Stretch Nano Storm Insulated Jacket - Men's
column5: Well finally got to try this baby out in 40 degree weather and a heavy rain with a 30 mph wind and let me tell u with just a R1 underneath I was very cozy. Not sure I'm crazy about the length but overall the jacket is very nice looks good and so far storm proof
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I'm 5'11" and and 175lbs. I ended up with the large - I likely could have gotten away with the medium also, but the fit of the large works well and isn't too tight fitting. I use this for trail running, mountain biking, hiking, and its great for travel as it packs up tight.

Pros: 
- Its seriously small when its packed up - it packs into its own pocket. Its barely bigger than the size of an avocado. Its easy to pack into itself, but has room that makes me think it could be even smaller if need be.
- The hood is great and can fit up and over a beanie no problem.
-  Like Kyle mentions below, it does fit in a fanny pack for mountain biking just fine. I'll one up him as I use the smaller Dakine Hot Laps pack and still have room for a tube, tools, and snacks in addition to the jacket. This is a cold wind / sporadic weather jacket that you can pull out of a nook of a backpack.

Cons:
- No other pockets than the small chest one, which I suppose is why its such a small jacket.
- Its got a DWR coating, but isn't a technical jacket. 

Let me know if you have any other questions with it on intended use or sizing and I'd be happy to help! My direct line is 801.204.4547 or my email cojohnson@backcountry.com and I'd be happy to help!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
To say that the Houdini Jacket is lightweight is an understatement. At sub 4 oz. it is definitely one of the lightest emergency shells out there. I keep it in the bottom of my mountain bike pack on every ride, which happens to be the DAKINE Low Rider Hip Pack. That's right, it easily fits in a fanny pack. It has saved me a couple times already from some inclement fall weather, both in Colorado and Zion National Park. I cannot foresee a future ride, hike, or any adventure where I don't take the Houdini with me. I am 6'1", 190 lbs. and the large fits me perfectly. I would highly recommend this to any one, it will magically appear from the bottom of your pack when you need it most.
Feel free to contact me directly with any additional questions on the Houdini, mountain bike gear, or any Patagonia products. 
Kyle L. - Expert Gearhead - klivingston@backcountry.com - 801-736-4337
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I certainly agree with other reviewers that this runs small, and a Large was too tight.  The XL, however, fit absolutely perfect and is as nice-looking as it is functional.  I have the Navy Blue/Paintbrush Red combo, and it was the perfect jacket for being outdoors in the fall weather in northern Michigan.  In both the high 50s/lower 60s temperature and slight rain, it could not have functioned any better!  What are you waiting for?  Do yourself a favor and get this jacket!!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Bought this as a gift because I love my one so much!
Great spring jacket for pretty much all activities. It's a great wind-breaker and perfect for light showers. Doesn't quite stand up to full-on downpours.
Packs away into nothing and easily fits into a pack or the pocket of another top.
Agree with other reviews that it fits slightly slimmer than other Patagonia gear.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: It’s almost a cliche to say it at this point, but the Houdini is just awesome.  Perfect for runs in the cold, wind, and even a little light rain.  Breathes great, yet strangely helps keep you warm when it’s chilly.  Just enough to block the wind.  Love it.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Everybody could use this.- an essential piece.  It packs so small.  I use it for hiking, camping, and biking.  Super lightweight, and a nice light or just-in-case shell to own.  I would recommend.  Slimmer fit than some other patagonia stuff- I still went with a medium and it works great!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I'm a student and I hate rain, so I always have this jacket with me. It's lightweight enough that it doesn't add any bulk in my pack or when i'm wearing it. It makes for a good wind breaker on windy days and is water repellant enough to stop a light shower, but I wouldn't trust it to hold back a deluge. This jacket is worth more than its weight.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Most of what you could say about this jacket has been said, so Ill just say it again. It works well, its tiny, it weighs nothing. you can literally always have it with you.

The Houdini has quickly become an essential piece of gear.  It weighs almost nothing and packs down so small it can fit just about anywhere.  It functions as good or better than my highest hope for blocking the wind, adding a small but necessary layer of protection (and even a little warmth; but not overly so, at all!), and being fairly universal in it's applications.  I can wear this at night around town or at 11,000ft in the mountains and it always performs.  I looked at and tried on several light weight wind jackets and this is absolutely the best that I found.  Couldn't be happier.  I'll carry with me during the full year, all 4 seasons.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: 彈性外衣加上防潑水，非常適合22~28度的潮濕天氣，平常騎機車穿，遇到小雨也不害怕。非常輕薄，收納也很容易，隨身攜帶完全沒有負擔。以如此輕薄的外套而言，防風性也算是不錯。唯一的缺點是沒有口袋，要放東西比較不方便。
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
The appropriately named houdini surely is magic because it seem to disappear in your pack. Seriously, this thing packs down so small that I take it almost everywhere I go.  It's great for hiking, mountain biking, climbing, or just rocking around town if it gets a little cold or breezy.  Although it's not waterproof I quite often use this as my raincoat when it's hot out because it breathes so well and sheds light rain.  This is definitely one of the most versatile piece of outdoor apparel I own and I'd highly recommend it to all!  

Note: The fit on the jacket is more of a runner fit so it fits slightly smaller and slimmer than some of Patagonia's other jackets.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Weighing in at a blistering 3.6 oz. the Houdini is an essential lightweight piece for any outdoorsmen/outdoorswomen. The past few days in Park City have offered some variable spring weather conditions making this piece clutch to have in my fishing and biking packs. 

Windproof, water-resistant and sleek - the Patagonia Houdini is definitely a must have. Whether you are biking, fishing, climbing or just enjoying the outdoors the Houdini is the piece you'll forget you have in your pack, but be so thankful you did when you need it. 

I'm 5'10 180 and fit perfectly into the large. The Alpine Houdini runs larger, but this bad boy is true to size! 

Hit me up if you have any questions on the Houdini or any other piece of Patagonia gear out there... the brand is rapidly taking over most of my closet/gear space these days.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Very decent wind proof jacket
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I was looking for a super light jacket to be worn to cover my tattoos at work.  I have so many short sleeve shirts that I wanted to be able to wear still yet still stay within my company's policy on tattoos.  After reading a ton of reviews I narrowed it down to the Patagonia and the Outdoor Research.  The deciding factor was that the Patagonia came in all black, unlike the OR.  I've been very pleased and I wear it 3-4 days a week.  It's extremely light weight and is as breathable as a nylon jacket can be in the southern heat and humidity.
As for fit, I'm 6'2" and 240 lbs.  I typically have an issue with sleeves being too short, however I was surprised that this jacket fit great (XL)!  It fits snug but not too tight if it's zipped up.  I mainly wear it unzipped.
Only negative I would say would be the hood.  I would like to be able to stow it in the collar.  It tends to get caught by the breeze and blown around.  However, it is thin enough that it could be folded inside the jacket, against my back.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This jacket is so small you can zip it into itself and store it in a pocket when not needed, I'm not sure how they managed to design such a lightweight yet protective jacket; hats off to Patagonia!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Packable jacket that I hoped would fit the bill for layering up while biking.  It is a "Slim Fit" per the tag. I am 6', 205# and the XL is going back today.  I"m not sure how it performs or if I am reordering now that I know the return policy here is you pay for the shipping.  I'll shop local EMS and bike shop I think.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: Extremely lightweight, like others have said its not going to keep you dry in an all out downpour. Its does exactly what a lightweight does, offers you a reasonable amount of protection. Not very hard to get into the stuff pocket in my opinion but it is snug. Sizing is accurate in my opinion as well, for me as a runner I want the jacket to be form fitting and not flapping in the wind as I run. It was the perfect size for me.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Other jackets have claimed to 'disappear into your bag' but this one actually does.  Cutting wind can change your temperature in a big way, so I keep this in my backpack, on my climbing harness, and everywhere in between.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This jacket is great for just about everything! definitely not a jacket for a downpour, but can hold up great for a light rainfall, and great for wind protection.

I bought this for my husband and he loves it. He takes it biking and it stuffs into the back pockets of his jersey. It is not a great rain jacket as i is water resistant but cannot handle a sustained deluge very long. He is 5'10" weighs 150lbs and it fits him perfectly.
I got the orange color.  I'm 6' 0" and 182lbs.  The medium fits perfect.  They were on the high end of my budget but very happy with the purchase
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The only issues I have had with them is the sizing. I was right in between a medium and large. Medium was perfect length but too tight in the thighs and waist. The larges were big and too long but doable. I went with more room and movement with the larges and glad I did. I just cinched up the velcro adjustments a tad and the waist was good. I'll have to watch to not step on the heels of the pant so I fold them up. Also the bottom is a tad tight around my Vans boa snowboard boot. Other than that I really do like them! I'm usually a large in most other pants.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: What more can I say, for a sub $500 gore shell pant these things rock. Great face fabric that is soft and doesn't seem to wear down paired with gore tex that keeps you dry. Large side zips for ventilation and all the other necessary features make this my go to resort and touring pant.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I'm 5'8", 160 lbs. My regular pant size is a 31x30. These pants fit perfectly and comfortably around the waste, with a little adjustment from the internal waist bands. However, they're super long. 

In my experience with this pant, the smalls have the right length but too tight of a waist. And the mediums have the right waist, but are too long. Even with ski boots on they're too long and just bunch awkwardly. 

Call it sacrilege, but I got these pants shortened at an alterations shop. Ya its probably not great for the goretex, waterproofing, etc.  but I'm not losing any sleep over it. Otherwise, its worth noting these pants have a great fit in the sense that they're not all up in your business, but they're not super baggy either. They hang loose and relaxed for a great and comfortable range of motion.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Liked these pants so much I decided to buy another pair. Sweet deal at the end of season price. Feel is great and love that they are made from Goretex so they can take a beating. They are a bit on the baggy end but still have a great fit. Very happy with the purchase.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Fit:  The articulated fit is not very clean looking when you walk around. There is extra material. The pants look athletic though and have some really cool details. When I skied in them they just felt great. There is no resistance from the material because they are cut as if you are bending your knees skiing or snowboarding. Every ski pant has some articulation but these are really articulated. So as a pant designed for an athletic activity they are great. Make that fantastic. 

Warmth: The lining on the inside makes a big difference. They're not insulated but very warm for a shell and because of that lining you can wear them comfortably without a base layer in the spring. 

Breathability: They are warm. And goretex is not air permeable so I got too warm in them skiing bumps. But there are big side vents for dumping heat which I used a lot. I was also skiing in spring like conditions so that may also be why they felt so warm. 

Durability: Don't know yet. Only a couple of days in them so they're still perfect. I don't know how these things could rip without some major incident. They sure feel solid. 

Construction: These things are top notch. Everything from the material to the zippers feels like quality. Better than any other ski pant I looked at. 

I really like these pants and highly recommend them. They're kinda baggy in a cool athletic way, the material feels soft for goretex, every detail is high quality, they have lots of pockets and they're just built to rip down the mountain.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: These are my favorite ski pants Patagonia makes, and my pant of choice for resort days and chillier backcountry tours.  The fabric is great, a little softer and warmer than a traditional shell pant and has held up well over 3 seasons.  Happy with the outer thigh vents, and the cargo pockets are nice and roomy for lunch of an extra set of gloves.  Definitely two thumbs up.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I got these pants as a christmas gift and was really excited about them. They seems to be well made at first, but ripped after only 4 times on the hill.  I have been skiing for 25 years and never had a pair of pants break down like this.  I contacted Patagonia and they said I could send them in for repair but it would take 4 weeks to get back and all they could do is patch the rip.  It is pretty disappoints when you get a pair of pants that cost over $400 and they rip within a month. Then to top it off the companies response is all we can do is patch it for you.  I would defiantly not purchase these again and would never recommend them to anyone.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Lightweight Synchilla Snap-T Hooded Fleece Jacket - Men's
column5: Have you ever camped or climbed for days out in the wilderness? Remember that feeling you get when you finally have those creature comforts again. This jacket is like wrapping yourself up in a huge blanket and then drinking cocoa all morning. Pilling will happen but all fleeces have that problem. I will say the length is a bit long but the elastic around the bottom allows for the jacket to be folded under around the waist. Arms are a bit tight, however a large would be way too big.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Lightweight Synchilla Snap-T Hooded Fleece Jacket - Men's
column5: Quality fleece that doesn't pill. A classic that reminds me of the fleece I had when I was a kid.  A great layering option.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Lightweight Synchilla Snap-T Hooded Fleece Jacket - Men's
column5: I bought this as a birthday gift for my boyfriend. He said that he really likes that it's lighter weight then his other Synchilla but still soft, warm and breathable.  He said he is much more likely to wear this one hiking then the heavier weight one. He got the nickel because Synchilla does tend to collect doggy hair, and since the dog is white the Nickel will hide the hair better.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Lightweight Synchilla Snap-T Hooded Fleece Jacket - Men's
column5: Honestly, I think I can donate every single jacket in my closet because of just how awesome this jacket is. I've been wanting this jacket for years, and finally decided to reward myself after I got a promotion. Perfect jacket! Pre-wash, the small fit kind of baggy. Like the body seemed to fit fine, but the arms were baggy and really wide. Post-wash, I think it fits way better. The arms shrank down and the body tightened a bit more... so I think the jacket got even better. I wear this for any occasion - to work, grocery shop, for walks, basically anything! I love that it's not overly thick but still keeps me warm. It doesn't keep the wind out completely, but I kind of prefer that because I get overheated easily. I own the raspen red and nickel colors.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Lightweight Synchilla Snap-T Hooded Fleece Jacket - Men's
column5: I was so excited to give this to my boyfriend for Christmas. He absolutely LOVED it and was thrilled! However we encountered a few issues within the first two weeks and need to unfortunately return it. The first issue was with pilling- the soft fleece started rubbing off on the seat belt in the car and onto his dress shirts for work. The second issue was a broken zipper on the pocket. Disappointed because the color combo was beautiful and the weight/warmth were perfect additions to his Patagonia coat "collection" (really- obsession!).

column2: Lightweight Synchilla Snap-T Hooded Fleece Jacket - Men's
column5:
This is my go to for almost any occasion. Looks good and fits great. Whether I'm ski touring, lounging around the house or heading to the office on a cool morning it does the job. 
Like most Patagonia though, it does run slightly large. I wear a medium, and can comfortably wear a flannel underneath.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Lightweight Synchilla Snap-T Hooded Fleece Jacket - Men's
column5: I'm a medium in most other Patagonia items, this had a weird fit under my arms, too baggy.  Will return and possibly try a small.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: These are adequate for the job, but I had to write in and say that I personally wouldn't purchase these again. I've owned jeans from Marmot, Levis, Patagonia, and even (back in the day) American Eagle, but these are the only ones that have lost their color in such a concentrated place on the front pockets -- they look like they have light-colored patches. I keep the standard in my pockets: car key, smartphone, and chapstick. Besides the discoloration, these are nice jeans. Bummer.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
You can't go wrong with these jeans. I wear them just about every day! The material is very durable. Plus when you purchase Patagonia you know you are getting a quality product. 
I typically wear a 
The only reason I am giving them a 4 star is because to me there are a little bit baggier on my lower part of my legs. I have pretty skinny legs so this might just me a problem.

I typically wear a size 32 and these fit perfectly minus being slightly baggy on my lower legs! 

I would recommend these to anyone!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I returned these and choose the Performance model (which is the same pant with a little stretch to it) over this model. The stretch of the performance fit allowed more freedom in the legs compared to this model. You will need to size up 1 size as well with both models.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I found these to be true to size waist wise. I am a 33 waist, there is a little extra room in there. Inseam was hard as I am a 31 inseam.  I went 32 and will have them altered. The inseam 30 was too short.
my boyfriend wears these everyday! very comfortable and true to size
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
Great pair of jeans. Solid construction and great denim.  The look good and will last a long time. 

Only reason I took a star is the sizing... I am always a 32x32 but had to send them back.  The 34x32 fit perfectly.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I got the 32 waist in short and regular, as I couldn't tell the actual length. For my size, the regular was 32 length and the short was length 30.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
The waist and length fit was spot on... but... they hugged my thighs and calves pretty significantly.  Possibly due to my extensive running habit... but its relaxed fit for me i guess if im going to look at patagonia again. 

Fabric was soft and looked good, i was pleased with it other than what i mentioned.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: This belt is lightweight, looks great and works well with ski pants.   Love the teeth on the buckle, non slip.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Fits my 36" waist with a few inches to spare.  Best of these web belts I have ever tried - stays put.    Works well with Jeans.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: It's a good belt. It'll probably survive the apocalypse. I'd be ok with a slightly smaller buckle, though.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Buckle measures 2.5 inches long and is 2.25 high. The webbing is durable and high strength . I cut roughly 3 inches off the end of mine and stiffened the cut with a lighter, I wear a 29 waist so I had some excess belt. I have not had any issue with fraying or the belt becoming loose. I've been wearing this belt everyday for 3 weeks now, I love it. Get yourself one, you won't regret it.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I work construction as my main job, I am framing currently and i keep a hammer, a large pouch for nails, tape measure and a speed square. So there is a bunch of stuff hanging off my belt and it remains tight and secure all day. The only drawbackfor me if the size of the buckle itself, since it works so well it is not really an issue but it would be nice if the buckle was smaller.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Does your belt fit, and does it keep up whatever you're trying to keep up? Basically the only boxes a belt needs to check, and the Tech Web Belt does it simply and comfortably.

The webbing is robust and I have a feeling it will not need replacing for a long time, maybe never.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I love this belt, its super light weight and stays put all day long! I've taken this out into the mountains and to the beach and have yet to run into any problems.  The webbing is super strong and the buckle doesn't protrude out as much as my other belts do.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This belt is pretty much the only belt I'll ever need. Although it's a bit wider than I originally thought, it works perfectly. It has yet to come loose, yet it's still super easy to adjust.
I was having to buy new belts every 3-4 months , my boyfriend told me about this belt. I ordered it and I love it!
I was a little nervous purchasing this belt as I have an older version that will not stay tensioned.  They use a heavier web and this belt stays where you want it!
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Fitz Roy Bison Layback Trucker Hat - Women's
column5: Love this hat!

column2: Fitz Roy Bison Layback Trucker Hat - Women's
column5:
The Layback Trucker Hat is a really comfortable and cute hat made specifically for women. It isn't as structured as the men's trucker hats and the front panel is made of softer organic cotton. The bill is also shorter. I needed a new hat for hiking and casual wear and this one has been perfect for me. It is my new favorite!

If you have questions about this hat, I'd love to help you out.
amcclary@backcountry.com or 801-204-4562
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Fitz Roy Bison Layback Trucker Hat - Women's
column5:
This is my favorite hat! I had originally bought it and wore it out on the boat at the lake and was mortified when it blew off! The first thing I did when I got home was order another! 

Fits well, looks awesome.

column2: Fitz Roy Bison Layback Trucker Hat - Women's
column5:
Having a 4 year old is hard, especially one as strong-willed as mine is (just like her mother).  Little did I know when I brought home matching camo Patagonia hats tonight that it will be the daddy-daughter equivalent of a best friendâs necklace.  She loved them so much she insisted on sleeping with both of our new hats by her bed.  I appreciate any opportunity to win as a dad. column2: Fitz Roy Bison Layback Trucker Hat - Women's
column5: Perfect fit, love the buffalo print, and the color. The gray goes with everything! Highly recommend!

column2: Fitz Roy Bison Layback Trucker Hat - Women's
column5: Can't beat a Patagonia hat comfy stylish and awesome colors

column2: Fitz Roy Bison Layback Trucker Hat - Women's
column5: This is a classic style trucker hat that goes well with any casual outfit.  I typically have a hard time finding hats that fit my smaller sized head but this one worked just fine.  I had to put it on the smallest snap and it was still a tad bit loose in the head but still worked.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Fitz Roy Bison Layback Trucker Hat - Women's
column5:
My girlfriend bought one of these hats and here's what she says:
Hats in general have never been my thing. They would either fall off my head or down my forehead or just generally make my head look weird. Trucker hats were always the worst until I realized this Patagonia Layback Trucker Hat had a “low crown” which means it is overall smaller and the bill falls higher on the forehead.  Basically, this trucker hat is the only hat I've found that fits. And...it looks great.

column2: Fitz Roy Bison Layback Trucker Hat - Women's
column5: My wife got this hat and loves it! The low profile design is perfect for women.

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Pullover Sweatshirt - Women's
column5: I REALLY wanted to like this sweatshirt.  It was rather disappointing.  I did like the color and did like the softness.  It was narrow in the shoulders and there was no give.  I felt restricted in the chest/shoulder area.  I am not muscular, but do wear a 32DD bra size, maybe that was the problem, girls too big??  I'm 110 lbs and 5.2" so I'm not really bulky for it to be so tight in the shoulder area.  The stomach area was nice and loose and the arms fit great.  I'm usually a XS.  I know the S would probably fit my shoulders, but than my arms will be too long and the stomach area will be huge.  Maybe it's just not for my body type:(
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Pullover Sweatshirt - Women's
column5: The quilt snap sweatshirt is a great lightweight shirt. Cozy and soft and fits nicely
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Pullover Sweatshirt - Women's
column5: I love the brand Patagonia. Their products are top of the line quality for sure. I own a fuzzy fleece and wanted the quilted look. Perfect pullover to cuddle up to by the fire during the Holiday season. Whenever I wear it all my friends wish they had one...men included. It is not only a casual pullover but I wear it hiking in the fall in Utah and it does the job well by keeping me warm while offering me great mobility. My only wish is for it to have pockets but other than that  I love it! Love the fit and color options! Super soft and cozy for sure!
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Pullover Sweatshirt - Women's
column5:

column5: ....and it will be be my go-to layer come winter!

column2: Performance Better Sweater Fleece Jacket - Women's
column5:
I'm a sucker for jackets. Patagonia is one of my all time favorite makers-of-jackets, and I have spent a lot of hours in my Houdini this summer and the R2 has always been a cooler weather favorite. With temperatures in Utah finally dropping, this fleece has quickly made it to a top choice in my jacket rotation. 

The first thing I noticed is that when I slip it on it fells like a warm fuzzy hug. The inside is super cozy fleece that feels AWESOME--it's honestly the jacket I reach for every morning when I go out back to grab eggs (and the pockets are nice and big!)  I'm pretty slim, and most Patagonia jackets tend to fit a bit more on the boxy side--not this one. It's slim fit, and the stretch panels on the side not only allow for movement when hiking or climbing, but give it a flattering silhouette also (I like the fit so much more than the R2 fleece from a couple years ago).
It's thick enough that it really keeps the chill off when I'm up in the cool mountain air, but not so thick that it limits physical activity or range of motion. I think this is going to be a new favorite for winter running, a great mid-layer when it really gets cold, and I think it will be perfect for winter climbing trips in the desert. 

One last thing I want to talk about that is never mentioned enough, it the no-stink-factor with so many of Patagonia's layers. I've worn this up a few peaks in the last month, and then throw it on to run errands around town, because it still smells great :) 

The Performance Better Sweater Fleece is a definite must have for your jacket collection.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I gave this as a gift to a friend that will be hiking Kilimanjaro and she said it was the perfect compliment to her trip: large and water resistant, she could pack anything and everything she needed into it - and when it got a bit full she could use the straps as a backpack and it was a perfect way to walk through the airport or when moving from camp to camp. She loves that she can bundle it up into a very small package when it's not full and collapse it wherever she goes. She thinks the 90L is perfect for long trips--anything longer than a few days--but would recommend the smaller 60L if you only plan on packing for a small out-and-back hike or shorter trip.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: For starters, I’m a pretty small person, 5’ tall and to be able to pack this puppy to the brim and still be able to carry it is a huge bonus for me.  The 90L bag is perfect for flying because Of the 50lb weight limit. From multiple packing of this bag when stuffed with clothes, some books, and tools it only ends up a few lbs over and I can just take the heavier stuff in my carry on. The back pack straps have set me free from airport and transit anxiety because I can be completely autonomous to carry it myself. I travel A LOT and sail on boats professionally. The duffle is water resistant enough to throw into a dingy with some water in the bilge and nothing on the inside gets wet even when taking waves over the side.  Salt water has no effect on the zippers (sometimes zippers seize up and need to be waxed in order to run again) and doesn’t start to crack the nylon webbing. It’s flexible enough (and the 90L is size reasonable)  I can continue to use it as storage in my bunk and it doesn’t compete with me for space.

I also need to mention it was raining and none of my stuff got wet. I highly recommend this bag.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Pretty jazzed up on this one. It's comforting to know how durable this thing really is as you put it through the wringer in the airport, trunk of your car, ski mountain etc. Really, you can toss this thing around and not worry about ever damaging it. And the backpack straps are a cool little add-on that I use a ton.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I have been wanting a black hole duffel for years! I ended up going with the 90L and love the size. It is plenty of room to pack clothes and gear! This bag is too big to be a carry on, but has worked gear as a checked bag. 
The shoulder straps that act as backpack wear is a great feature when you have to tote this bag around. 
I am so happy with this bag, I actually bought a second one for my boyfriend!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: All the reviews on this bag are all that you need, I'm just here to tell you that if you have any big trips coming up-this bag is a must have. Durable, lightweight...HUGE. What more could you ask for.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: My closet is full of flannels and this is by far one of the softest in my collection. It is a heavierweight flannel so it will keep you nice and toasty. A must have in every flannel lovers closet. It fits great and isn't too boxy or too slim.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I picked this up in large part after reading "Let my people go surfing" and understood how important it is to make an informed purchase, knowing the carbon footprint that product has.
I got the fjord flannel in a medium, my normal size, and it fits perfectly. The shirt is so soft and made from organic cotton. It also has the ironclad guarantee.
Very warm and could easy be used as a jacket for cool fall days.
This flannel will slowly dominate as other brands fade out and cannot be worn any longer
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is, hands down, an awesome flannel. It is silky soft and quite thick so it will definitely keep you warm. It is probably a bit too warm for most shoulder seasons. I loved it but returned it because the fit was a bit tight for me. I think I am just a bit fat and broad shouldered for it. The sleeves were awesome. Rarely do you get enough length with any shirt and this was fantastic. The torso is tight for the arm length though in my opinion. I returned it and found a better fit with the Mountain Khaki Pedan Flannel.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I have yet to own a warmer flannel. Perfect for a vest because it keeps you warm all over.  Would definitely recommend.

Very soft and warm flannel.  A must have for the cold weather.  I'm 5'11" with broad shoulders and the medium fits perfectly and allows for movement.  Recently wore it fly fishing on a cold morning.    Solid construction.  I now own two of these great shirts.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: My absolute favorite flannel! I ALWAYS keep my eyes peeled for sales on the fjord. Can be worn in a multitude of ways and is helpful to have a little extra room in the shirt. Fall through spring, this thing works, and hey...they look pretty damn good.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Gave my boyfriend a Fjord flannel as a gift - he LOVES it. I can't get him to take it  off - it's actually rather absurd and I may buy him a different color just so I can wash the current one! It's a thick, heavy duty flannel, but still  soft and comfy. This will long outlast all of your other flannels. The fit is very loose and relaxed
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Great Quality, comfort, and warmth, however I am 5' 10" 165, athletic build and the medium is pretty big on me

I will say upfront it's quite expensive for a flannel, but once you have it in hand the cost becomes quite apparent. The materiel is heavy duty, soft, and warm, and it looks to outlast many of my other flannels! Like other reviews have stated, it runs a bit large and loose.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: As the season changes from shorts to jeans and the weather shifts it’s always good to pick up a new flannel. The fjord did not disappoint, it’s warm and girlfriend approved. The sizing is perfect, a lot of Patagonia items sizing can be all over the place, the medium was spot on for me. Mountain town business casual never felt so good.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Patagonia hit it out of the park with these flannels. They fit great and layer well. Patagonia is hit or miss for me with the length of their products, and this flannel is perfect.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is the most comfortable flannel that I have ever worn in my life! Loose fitting which I like and just all around great material. Probably helps that I am a big Patagonia fan but still an amazing piece of gear.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I bought this shirt last year as a gift for my dad for Christmas and he lives in Iât. I figured another year down and another Christmas around the corner he deserves another one! He claims itâs the most comfortable shirt he owns! Morale of the story - if you want to make your Dad happy, buy him the Patagonia Fjord Flannel!

I personally picked up two of these flannels this year, and have been wearing them non-stop! I absolutely love the fit, and the feel, it is heavier than  most flannels, but not up to the Carhart level of burliness, but still will insulate and keep you nice and warm. 
It's kinda like chilling next to a nice fire place, but really just putting on a shirt and getting the same affect. 
Let me know if you got any questions!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Its soft, warm, and seems to be good quality. I haven't washed it yet to see if it shrinks. My only complaint is the cut of the shirt. It has a straight cut with no taper so it looks huge around your waist if you don't have a beer gut
.....if your looking for a warm, stylish, "comfy" flannel. And it's from a company who stands up for our outdoor pursuits.

It's a little extra wide for a medium, but the sleeves run a little short. Overall, it still works, but the fit is why I gave it 4 stars instead of five.

column5: Going to work on a cold wet Tuesday morning sucks, but you are a smart person and you realize that you have to make choices in order to be happy.  If you chose to wear this  hug from the comfort fairy, you know how to deal with that kind of Tuesday.  Get two.  It's cold out there.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
One of my go to shirts, something that is casual enough for the city and warm/cozy enough to wear around the camp fire. I had purchased a medium and it fit me well (6'2 / 175lbs), it shrunk in the wash but still fits ( a bit short in the sleeves though). I had purchased a different style in Large and it was way to big, even after being shrunk in the wash to try and size it down. I would recommend going a size down unless you're looking for something to wear layers underneath. 
Cons: Not ideal for backpacking/hiking if you are tight on space, it is pretty bulky and doesn't pack down well.
Pros: Warm and comfortable.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This is my man's favorite flannel- it is SUPER soft and cozy, but not too heavy to wear in more mild temperatures. The prints are great too. It's very easy to wash- so far no fading or pilling. 
In regards to sizing, I would say that it fits a bit big. He has one in a size Large, which is great for layering underneath. The new one is a size Medium, which fits more like a standard t-shirt. For reference, he's 5'10 and about 165lb with broader shoulders.  If you're in between sizes, I would recommend sizing down if you want a more trim fit.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Bought this as our camping travel bag. We keep different weight jackets in it as a darn I forgot elimination pack. This is the sixth Black Hole bag / backpack between us. We each have the 45L & 60L Black Hole bags for traveling, but wanted a duffel strictly to grab & go when camping. Space is limited in our Viking Hardside trailer for storing clothing. This bag is never unpacked, just added to so as needed.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I gave this as a gift to a friend that will be hiking Kilimanjaro and she said it was the perfect compliment to her trip: large and water resistant, she could pack anything and everything she needed into it - and when it got a bit full she could use the straps as a backpack and it was a perfect way to walk through the airport or when moving from camp to camp. She loves that she can bundle it up into a very small package when it's not full and collapse it wherever she goes. She thinks the 90L is perfect for long trips--anything longer than a few days--but would recommend the smaller 60L if you only plan on packing for a small out-and-back hike or shorter trip.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: For starters, I’m a pretty small person, 5’ tall and to be able to pack this puppy to the brim and still be able to carry it is a huge bonus for me.  The 90L bag is perfect for flying because Of the 50lb weight limit. From multiple packing of this bag when stuffed with clothes, some books, and tools it only ends up a few lbs over and I can just take the heavier stuff in my carry on. The back pack straps have set me free from airport and transit anxiety because I can be completely autonomous to carry it myself. I travel A LOT and sail on boats professionally. The duffle is water resistant enough to throw into a dingy with some water in the bilge and nothing on the inside gets wet even when taking waves over the side.  Salt water has no effect on the zippers (sometimes zippers seize up and need to be waxed in order to run again) and doesn’t start to crack the nylon webbing. It’s flexible enough (and the 90L is size reasonable)  I can continue to use it as storage in my bunk and it doesn’t compete with me for space.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I purchased this bag for a three week Euro Trip in March, including a road trip around Iceland that exposed us to all of the weather elements.  This bag was perfect - big enough to hold all of my bulky, winter clothing (for three weeks!); durable enough to withstand a two week road trip in the elements; and versatile enough to be worn as a backup when travelling between spots.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Excellent bag for gear and equipment when traveling or out in the countryside.   Durable and roomy.

column5: sturdy and pretty

It is one of my favorite purchases for sure. I got it in a small which fits nicely, if you want it to fit tightly I recomend sizing down.

column5: Awesome style and real warm.  I bought this as a gift and it is well loved.  Its quite warm, and doesn't look super-techy.  Very nice classic look to it.

column5: Love this vest! The fabric is super durable canvas which withstands to water, scrapes, food spillage, and cold temps. Love the dual toned color options, and the pockets have ample space for keeping your hands toasty.

column5: I love this vest. Seriously. It's probably one of my key fall pieces this year. Any chance i can wear this vest I do. I'm sure people around the office think I live in this thing. Not only is this vest good looking it also functions. Took it down to the desert for a late fall climbing trip and it kept me warm while I was resting between burns. It does like to collect dirt, chalk and dog hair but can be easily dry cleaned off. You can risk a washer but it is down so it needs a bit of extra special care. If you want to wear a thicker layer under I would suggest the recommended size however if you want more of a fitted look go a size down. I wear a small according to the size chart but got an XS instead and I'm so happy I did.

column5: I'm a vest slut.  I love vests.  This one rocks.  It's warm, it's comfortable, it's durable.  AND it looks amazing (I got the ruby, but it was a tough choice)!  Patagonia did it.  I'm not sure what else you could want in a vest.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
Who needs a full jacket when you can layer under this amazing Bivy Hooded Down Vest?! I bought one of these in last years color way, and am more in love with it than ever. Super toasty, I layer this over a Patagonia Snap-T most days in the fall and spring. 

Pros: 
-great colorways
-super toasty
-large hand pockets
-zippered stash pocket 
-great for layering in Fall and Spring

Cons:
-collects lint
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: My step daughters home burned down July 2nd, and she lost most of her gear and clothing. I purchased this for her (along with much more) to help her get geared back up for a month long trip to Europe. She loves it as much as this time around!
super warm and i love the retro feel of it.

Love this thing through and through! I have worn it almost every day since I got it! So cute, so warm, and people can't get enough of it! Favorite piece in my closet right now for sure! If you are looking to layer under, size up for sure. I got a XS and can layer sweaters and long sleeves under, but cannot get any  of my insulated layers comfortably under it.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Love this vest! Been eyeing it since last season but I didn't get it last year because of the price, and it sold out extremely fast! I'm glad I picked it up this season because the colors are even better! I got the sulfur yellow/navy combo and it's a great color combo for fall/winter and rainy days, it's so cute!! I love that the down used is recycled and how there's a DWR coating to combat the weather. It keeps me warm and cozy, I wear a XS and I'm 5'4" and around 120-125 lbs. The fit is a regular fit, a tiny bit big for me even for the XS, but it allows for layering. The only con I have is that the the material does attract a lot of lint, not sure if it's because of the color I chose but it's a lint magnet! An easy fix is to use a lint roller before wearing it, but it's just a little annoying when I want to just throw on the vest and go outside.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Warm, in a yurt without central heating, no question.

This is one of the few 5 star items hanging in my closet. I'm a beast when it comes to reviewing jackets (my closet is full of an embarrassing amount) and I have few 5 star coats in my arsenal.  Here is why this one takes the cake. 

1. Recycled Down: WHAT? Yes. Patagonia responsibly sources their down from products like comforters, old jackets, or pillows and gives it a new life rather than sacrificing new birds to keep us warm. I think that is pretty darn neat, and I feel a little bit better about sporting down, knowing this fact. 

2. Fit is Perfect: I don't know what those wizards are doing over at Patagonia but their woman's fit is one word: DIALED. I am 5'3" and 120lbs and the size small is perfectly tailored in every way. 

3. Details, Details, Details: I loved the silky taffetta lining inside the vest. It's a lovely floral pattern. I think it beautifully contrasts with the more masculine and utilitarian feel of the tough/thick DWR outer fabric. This appeals to my inner girly-girl, who I try to keep hidden. The pockets are lined with a nice, cozy fabric that's ideal for chilly hands. 

4. Durability: Besides being water resistant this fabric is really abrasion resistant too. It's thick and ready to rumble. I honestly do not mind paying a little extra for a Patagonia product, because I have perfect confidence it will spend the next 10 years in my closet. 100% worth it 100% of the time, every time. 

5. Classic: I may not be much of a fashionista, but the clean lines on this vest won't go out of style anytime soon. It's cozy, cute, and fetching. Did I also mention it's warm? I tend to run hot, so adding an extra layer to my core is the perfect way to bundle up on chilly mornings or campfire nights. With the down feathers, this one is warmer than most; it's QUITE thick! But not so thick as to transport you into Michelin Man territory.

I'd been lusting after this vest for 18 months. I can't say I'm surprised but it's my most commonly used piece of fall attire. Can't wait to apres all over the canyons in this thing for winter!

Shred on.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I bought this vest for my girlfriend, who loves it.  She sized up from her normal xs, to make sure she could wear layers underneath.  Both fashionable and functional!

This vest is everything I thought it would be. I ordered it in a Medium, because i wanted to be able to layer underneath it and I think the size is perfect! Its long enough to stay covered if I take it out on the slopes this winter, but not too long that it can't also be worn casually - which is how I plan to mostly wear it. The inner pattern is really cute too, it has mushrooms and not that anyone will see it- I thought it was a cute detail. It will keep me super cozy this winter and in Park City, that is a necessity. So glad I bought one of these!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: The vest came extremely fast and it was everything I wanted!!! I will definitely be buying more from this website.
This vest is modern and old school all in one piece of clothing. Fits really well, form fitting and snug through the hips so you don't feel bulky or manly. You will love this vest!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I pair this vest with everything you can think of: t shirt, flannel, sweater, coat, and hoodie. It looks good with every single one of them and keeps me so warm. I never imagined a vest keeping me toasty warm (excluding arms of course) like this. I'm completely satisfied with it.
Bought this as a gift for a friend. It runs true to size, is really warm, and looks great. Highly recommended.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I love this vest! So comfy and warm. I used this vest as my only source of warmth on a weekend getaway to Colorado earlier this winter. I was limited to just a backpack so I didn't have the space for a normal mid-weight coat. I decided to take the chance/risk of just using the vest and i'm happy to say I didn't regret it once! The down insulation kept me nice and toasty when the sun would start to go down and temperatures dropped. It felt like my core had a little heater wrapped around it. The liner is really comfortable and the pockets are money. The lining in them is soft and cozy and are a dream for hands that might be a little chilly. The only downside to this vest is that the nylon canvas outer material is a literal magnet for anything with static cling. If you have an animal that sheds, chances are you'll end up looking like you are wearing a fur vest. I would definitely invest in a lint roller but that is a tiny price to pay for such a great piece! I'm 5'5 and about 120 with a C chest and the small fit me perfectly!
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: This is the perfect piece for backpacking on sunny days. It keeps the sun off of you but breathes well enough to wear all day. After a long trip with lots of sun, I can't imagine spending a day walking without it. It also works well as a light hoody for chilly mornings and packs super light. Contrary to other reviews, I found the button closure very useful, as the hood never came off of my head when the wind picked up. Very impressed.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: Keeps my ginger skin from burning on those full days out in the sun.  Very comfortable to have on all day.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: I cannot say enough good things about this shirt! I used it all summer while fishing, kayaking, hiking, sport climbing.....really anywhere that I would be out in the sun or wind. Keeps you nice and cool, dries quickly...I want one in every color!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5:
If you are like me and hate to mess with sunscreen, this is what you need! Even in early fall down in Indian Creek, UT where the heat is in the mid-80's. You won't over heat and will be cool and protected when you really want it. Even if you are ski touring, they wick away the moisture when you are getting after it and overall just a really nice, versatile piece. I'm 6' - 165lbs and went with a Medium, Fit's perfect. Highly recommended. 
If you have any questions:
email me: wbowen@backcountry.com or give me a call: (801) 204-4571
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: I wore this sun shirt on the water and in the woods more days than I could possibly count over the summer. It is lightweight enough to wear on the hottest days, but still keeps the sun off. I generally cannot wear long sleeves without cooking in the heat, but I was able to row countless miles of river and backpack endlessly without ever once blaming this shirt for making me hotter then normal. My only con would be that the shirt runs a full size large, but just order a size down and you will be stoked on the fit. A must have in any outdoorsmans wardrob to keep the sun off.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: This shirt fits medium on an athletic body. It's very thin, but retains its heat well. Definitely more of an active piece than for looks. I use it for ski touring, backpacking, and just to wear around when I need another layer to stay warm.

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: This thing is great!  I picked this up specifically for climbing in sunny, warm conditions, and it's been AMAZING.  I wore it for three days straight on a trip down to Moab for some climbing and canoeing, and it kept me cool and protected from the sun the entire time.  Soak it in some water and and you'll forget you're in the 102* desert sun and think you've been transported to a winter tundra!  Very comfortable, I'm usually between a M and L for most shirt sizes, and I got this in a Medium and its a pretty good fit, but I feel like I miiight have been able to get away with a Small even.  Being a synthetic material, it does get a little bit stinky after several days of use, but not too bad.  If you spend a lot of time in the sun and hate lathering yourself with copious amount of sunscreen, buy this right away!  If you have any questions, give me a call at 801.204.4691, or email me at rlindsen@backcountry.com!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: Alrighty this hoodie tripped me out because I got it and wore it out on a 95 degree day hiking and felt shirtless, then wore it to bed camping in the Uintahs on a 25 degree night and it was an oven! woah, GREAT versatile hoodie for anything, and my go to as a baselayer or outerwear. I normally wear an XL hoodie, but purchased the Large and it fits perfectly, go down a size. Loved the Roots Red color, and have climbed, fished, and hiked in it-things to normally beat it up, but it still looks brand new.. Bravo Patagonia.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: I wear this thing like a uniform.  I live in Southern California, so desert climbing, hiking, backpacking, etc.  It is life.  I hate putting on tons of sunscreen and missing spots and worrying about it.  This is light, baggy, airy, and protects your skin.  Pull the hood up and no more red ears and red neck.  Match with a hat and sunglasses and the I tell the sun "BOY BYE!!!"  Sure casual day hikers think I look like the unibomber, but they won't laugh at me if they get skin cancer.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5:
Not getting sunburned is one of my favorite things to do outside, and Patagonia's upf hoodies have facilitated my interest in avoiding melanoma for years. 
The Tropic Comfort is Patagonia's 'minimalist' option, and I appreciate that it isn't covered in unnecessary pockets or zippers. The thumb holes at the cuff keep the sleeves down over the backs of my hands, and the button on the collar helps me adjust the height of the neck easily.
Aside from those two features, there isn't a lot to Tropic Comfort. Patagonia's UPF fabric breathes well, is reasonably abrasion resistant, and the colors options are nice!
I think that the Tropic Comfort runs pretty true to size. Mine is a bit baggy, but I think that it is more comfortable to move in that way, and don't think a close fit will prove nearly as breathable as a more relaxed option.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: I've been wearing this shirt for backpacking and climbing in the alpine.  It's incredibly comfortable and is the best shirt I've found for the hot days of summer.  I love the cut and the hood design fits nicely over my climbing helmet.  Additionally, the colors are a nice respite from the normal colors offered in the outdoor clothing world.  If you are always in the sun and looking to save your skin, I highly recommend  giving this shirt a try.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: This shirt is so thin I wear it on the hottest of days. It's a godsend for my tender & pale skin complexion. Definitely runs on the large side.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5:
Ive decided to consider this hoodie a staple of my desert adventure and backpacking kit. Im one of those weird folks who hates the sun but loves canyoneering and rock climbing and backpacking. Sun burn makes me mad, but I don't have to worry about that anymore. The sun could be blaring all day and I would be sitting pretty in this hoodie. 

The best feature of this hoodie though isn't that it shields me from the sun (any old sweater could do that), but that it keeps me cool while doing so. The fabric this thing is made of is so light and thin that should a mere wisp of breeze pass by, the evaporative cooling process begins immediately and you'll get a nice chill on your skin. If you pass by some water, dunk it in and reap the cooling benefits, the wetter this thing gets, the cooler you get.

I highly recommend buying many of these if you find yourself trying to hide from the suns gaze often. It's been a game changer for me. 

Im 5'10", 175lbs with an athletic build and a small fits me perfectly (I like my shirts a little snug around the chest and shoulders).
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: The Patagonia tropic hooded shirt is essential for any high exposure sunny environment, especially on the river.  This thing breathes exceptionally well and the hood is a nice addition allowing you to keep the sun off your ears and sides of your face.  It's extremely lightweight, durable and dries pretty quickly when it gets wet. An essential piece of clothing for river trips.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5:
I love this shirt! I have now purchased a few of them. I wear them during Spring touring trips, mountaineering expeditions, and some fly fishing. The fit is a little bit loose, but it is still true to size. I've worn this on a few Spring corn searches in 65 degree weather and didn't overheat at all. It doesn't make me a better fly fisherman (at all) but I would still strongly recommend this shirt.

Feel free to reach out with any gear questions or needs.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: I picked up two of these (one for my husband, and then one for me because I didn't have time to look for a women's version) before a bike touring trip -- best buy I could of made! My husband wore it biking when he needed cover from the relentless sun, and didn't overheat. I wore it after riding just to not get any more sun than I already had -- it also worked great at the beach. Can't go wrong with this one.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5:
I took this down to San Rafael Swell over Memorial weekend and wore it every day. It was light, cool, and protective. I seriously felt less warm than others in my group who had more skin exposed. 

I was able to avoid lathering sunscreen all over myself and the shirt didn't even smell bad at the end of the weekend!

column2: Tropic Comfort II Hooded Shirt - Men's
column5: This hoody is officially clutch for any warm, sunny adventure. I took it climbing in the desert for my first time last weekend, and it was perfect. We climbed offwidths and chimneys in the sun all weekend long. I wasn't in the shade once, and I never wore any sunscreen, and I didn't get any sunburns at all. The fabric feels incredibly comfortable hiking in 75F temps, and it stayed strong in rockier situations. I'm really in love with the colors and sizing. The body is definitely relaxed, and the sleeves feel slim.

column5: I'm still a bit in awe of just how much junk I was able to pack into this little guy. Perfect for almost any adventure, whether you're hitting the town or the trail. The bag is incredibly durable and though it is not waterproof, it does resist light moisture. Carry it normally as a duffel by the handles or over/across your shoulder, or switch it into backpack mode and throw it on your back. I'll be flying home for the holidays, so I've got the 60L black hole as my carry-on  and a matching 120L in Paintbrush Red of course, so it's easy to spot at baggage claim!

column5: I've taken this duffel with me all over the world. My  husband has one as well and also loves it. The option to wear it as a backpack is awesome and the straps are adjustable which is also a plus.  The side pocket is HUGE and holds a lot of stuff. I do wish the inner two pockets were a smidge bigger, but they are big enough to hold a few travel sized toiletries.  The zipper entrance to the duffel sits against your back when you wear it so you don't need to worry about somebody getting into it while you're wearing it. Overall a great bag whether you are backpacking through SE Asia or going on a weekend trip.

column5:
Patagonia needs to make their jackets American size, not European.  I wear an XL with every other jacket or shirt except Patagonia.  This thing was too tight, and I'm not sure if Patagonia is simply trying to skimp on cost.  But as expensive as their jackets are, this thing should fit perfectly.  

Also, while the jacket is warm for the size, can we update the shell a bit Patagonia?  This thing rips at the drop of a dime.  Don't even think of getting it near a fence or a flame.  Let's update the jacket some, and get a shell that is firmer and one that doesn't melt if you're roasting marshmallows.  

Aside from that the jacket is warm and thin, making it very portable.  It just greatly needs an update to address the issues mentioned.

column5:
This was my first Patagonia apparel purchase (I own their Ascentionist Pack) and it was love at first sight!  The classic/old school style really caught my eye and it is as comfy/cozy as it looks. I own this in a light Rose/Pink color which is not available right now, but it's vibrant enough to stand out from my not-so-colorful wardrobe (lots of blacks, whites, greys, and neutrals) without it being too loud. Not to mention it's softer than I expected it to be!  The recycled polyester is blended really well and isn't super dense, so it doesn't make the fit of the overall sweater stiff and it feels good against my skin -- not scratchy.
It's also way warmer than I anticipated it to be as well. Not super wind resistant, but I wouldn't wear this as an outer layer anyways. It's great as a fall midlayer or lounging around the apartment in fuzzy socks and leggings on a chilly night! 
The only thing that docked a star for me was the sizing -- I usually wear an XS in most garments  but the sleeves and hem of the sweater are a little shorter than I would expect (and I'm a fairly short person). The collar is a little  tall too -- not tall enough to be annoying but if I were to button it up all the way It would be kind of tight under my chin.

Besides that, I feel really good when I wear this sweater. It's cute, super warm, and I feel cozy in it.
column8: I've used it several times

The quilted cotton is my favorite for all Patagonia items, and this one is definitely the coolest looking. Plus it has a hood! Can't get better.

Whether it be mid-layer for warmer ski days, light layer to wear on chillier camp nights or just on a cool night out in town this vest works perfectly and packs down to nothing. The slimmer fit and synthetic insulation keep you from looking like a puff-ball but still pack a good punch when it comes to warmth.
