column5: My nephew is looking sharp, staying warm, and killing it with the ladies! The fit is great and he appears to staying warm as far as I can tell! Highly recommend this product from Patagonia as well as every other baby product they make, awesome!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
In preparation for the recent Engearment mission to Iceland, we picked up a few extra bits to make sure our littlest gearhead, Danjo, stayed warm and dry no matter what sort of shenanigans we got up to.  The foundation of a great layering scheme is a great base layer.  And, wouldn't you know it...one of the all-time greats is available in mini sizes.  So, we had a set of the Patagonia Baby Capilene Midweight base layers delivered just in time.

The set comes with two pieces - a long-sleeve onesie and a pair of pants - and are available in six sizes for everybaby from birth to 24 months.  There's no difference between boys' and girls' sets other than the colors.  The 0-3 month size is still working for the little dude since early December at about 14 pounds, though it's starting to get small.  Patagonia rates it up to 10 lbs, but with baby sizes, everything is a total crapshoot.

We found baby Capilene to be a great foundation for a baby layering system and used the same set almost every day.  After washing, it dried quickly enough - despite a janky Icelandic dryer - that we could wash it at night and put it back on Danjo in the morning.  It also really liked to absorb liquids, so spit-up and drool made for frequent washings.  No damage from washing, so far.

There are a few features we've really appreciated.  Patagonia uses snaps that feel exceptionally solid.  When you snap the onesie together, it's not coming apart until you unsnap it.  Also, hand covers!  The sleeves have magical hand covers that fold over and keep the little ones from scratching themselves or getting cold hands.  Though we haven't tried it ourselves, Capilene must be pretty tasty because the little dude loved shoving his hands in his mouth the second we covered them.  Keep an eye out for our upcoming base-layer taste test.

Does your kid need Patagonia Capilene?  No.  But, if you plan on having the little one outside in some chilly conditions, it's a great (and adorable) way to keep them warm and dry.  Add in a set of Patagonia Baby Synchilla Booties and your nugget will be cozy and well on his or her way to being a little gearhead.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Soft, warm and the color is as seen above. I ordered the Pico Stripe/Peppergrass Green/Feather Grey for this little guy and with his red highlights in those locks it looks great. He is just one and the 12 month is a perfect fit.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Micro D Snap-T Fleece Jacket - Infant Girls'
column5: Not only does my baby girl look adorable in this, but it's also easy to put on and I love the hood.  The pullover version is difficult for young ones so I really appreciate the zipper on this model.  I bought the 6mo size so she could rock it from months 3-8ish and I'll definitely be picking up another one for the rest of winter.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Micro D Snap-T Fleece Jacket - Infant Girls'
column5: After hearing my 1 year old niece was in need of a warm hoody for the winter, I knew it needed to be this - since I love my Snap-T hoody too.  I picked one up in Craft Pink.  It's really cute and looks great matched with Patagonia's Synchilla Booties.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Micro D Snap-T Fleece Jacket - Infant Girls'
column5: Perfect fall gift for a friend's little girl.  She looks as cute as I had hoped and seems warm in the fall air.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Micro D Snap-T Fleece Jacket - Infant Girls'
column5: Jacket is cute. It was nice to not have another option that isn't pink when shopping for a little girl. I think the sizing is confusing. I ordered 12 months thinking I was ordering a 12-18 month jacket and received the 6-12 month jacket, so will have to send it back to get the bigger size.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column2: Micro D Snap-T Fleece Jacket - Infant Girls'
column5: Got this as a gift for my friend's 1 year old daughter and she loves it! It fits well for a 12 month old, the sleeves are a bit long, but she'll definitely grow into it. Plenty warm for light fall days and the color block is just too cute to pass up. Can't go wrong w/ Patagonia fleece at all.

this is my quintessential shirt for anything outdoors and active in the summer. great fit, design, material and quality of construction. planning on picking up another whenever i find a pattern/color that i like as much as my original.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I own 3 Banditos and I'm pretty much done buying shirts.  This does it all!  It is an athletic/slim cut and I appreciate that for my size.  I only buy Patagonia athletic cut and it hasn't let me down.  I've used this under my PFD on multi day raft trips, guided climbers on multi pitch, backpacking (seen in picture), bikepacking and simply around town.  It has a great western look, a dress down look and is semi professional looking for that person in the outdoor industry or just wants to go from the crag to the bar and being able to look and feel good.  Now that I have 3 different colors, I'm set for a long time with shirts.  It's also super light, breathable, dries super fast and eats odor where you don't always get that with other synthetic shirts.  Don't look any farther, this is your EVERYTHING shirt.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Email me directly with all your Patagonia questions - jelam@backcountry.com
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This shirt was tighter than other Patagonia shirt I have purchased. Will likely return for a larger size.

40" chest, 32" waist

I bought this right before a 10-day trip to Italy, and I was super impressed with it. The fit is spot-on, it dries super fast, doesn't smell terrible after a couple wears, looks better than a t, and the vents on the back actually work to let the wind in. This is everything you need for a do-it-all shirt.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I got this shirt for my dad for his birthday. I thought it would be great shirt for him to wear to work and straight to the golf course after and he said that it's great for exactly that! It's super thin and technical but doesn't look it. He can dress it up or dress it down. It's super breathable and awesome for really hot summer days where you don't want to have armpit sweat marks. We have a history of melanoma in our family so the sun protection is always a huge plus for us!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Shirt is lightweight, fast drying vented and super comfortable. Fits is great and true to size.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I am always glad that Patagonia makes shirts and pants that are fit a more athletic build. This shirt is no exception. One day I wore this shirt trad climbing then to a work presentation. Pretty well rounded!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This shirt is insanely light, breathable, and comfortable. I took this shirt on a big multipitch climb and was amazed at how well it fit and kept me cool, all while allowing full range of motion. I also love the snap buttons. Much easier than a regular button up.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is my go to shirt for hot summer days.  The vents in the back provide great ventilation and the fabric is super lightweight and breathable.
Smooth transition from the trail to the office. Performs good and looks good.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: ...on the great divide mountain bike route, absolutely love this shirt. The shoulders allow full range of movement and the shirt is light and helps keep you cool. It's pretty pricey but I can't wait to pick up another for fishing and hiking.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I got one, put it on ,went upstairs and ordered another one. Awesome shirt. Fits folks better with a long torso. It is super comfortable and lightweight and the snap up buttons keep the front from getting snagged on anything.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I do everything in this shirt. The price might turn you off at first, though you will find a way to wear this shirt as much as possible. Once your friends find out that you're wearing it five days a week, you'll admit it because you don't care and it's that amazing. I take this shirt everywhere with me...and even do most of my trail runs in it (have taken it up to 47mi at once). The comfort of this shirt is second to none, and I love how there are small flaps in the back and perforations under the arms  to keep me cool on the hottest days. 

Shoot me an email to know more
Expert Gearhead
Jelam@backcountry.com
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I just got another Patagonia Bandito Shirt (Chambray/Glass Blue, size large) and took it down to Fruita, Colorado for my first desert mountain bike mission of the spring. Like last year's model (which I also have) the fit is true to size, but slightly trim, which gives the shirt a nice look and provides a more technical fit, so there isn't too much material flapping around while Biking/Hiking/Running. The material is soft and wicked very well on my ride. The collar provided great sun protection for my neck and didn't get in the way at all - plus, it's what makes this shirt so versitile as an everyday shirt.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is a super versatile shirt that works great on the trails, and looks great before and after.  I've always mountain bike in tech T's or bike jerseys, but last summer this shirt quickly became my favorite riding shirt.  It's a nice lightweight fabric that breathes and vents well, with a collar that can give you a little extra sun protection.  It is a little on the slim fit side, which works well on the bike, but some people might want to size up.
Bryan from Patagonia shares his thoughts on the Bandito Shirt
The Patagonia Dirt Craft shorts are awesome!  They are true to size and fit great.   The length isn't super long and the shorts themselves aren't to baggy.  Awesome buy!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Really comfortable and so far durable!

I seriously threw all my other cycling shorts and liners away and bought multiple pairs of these. They are amazing. Breathable, comfortable and just all around actually comfortable. 
I need Patagonia to invest more into this line because I will continue buying. I really wish they had a winter lineup for us cold weather riders.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: My dad loves these shorts so much I had to get him another pair. The fit is true, the quality is superb of both the shorts and the chamois, and they look freakin' sweet.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
Just like everyone else, I LOVE these shorts. The chamois is super comfy and the shorts are a great material.

My favorite part is that you can wear them casually and they don't look ridiculous like a lot of bike shorts do. They are a little longer than a casual short but not too wild.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Patagonia, easily my favorite outdoor brand due to the standards and mission of the company, enters the bike space with a killer MTB short.

I got the green with the yellow zippers and belt, and the main color is subtle like a seabreeze, while the contrast pops vividly. Now at least I know I look the part, amiright?

Personally, not a huge fan of baggy, or super long shorts. While these are baggy and I knew it, I do feel they're marketed towards before-during-after ride. I would not wear these to work, nor would I wear them to a bar or dinner. 11.5 inch inseams, even for this 6 foot dude, are a bit too long. They still scream, "I mountain biked today, I ride, I'm gnar!"

I really want somebody to nail the non-spandex, non-baggy approach to breathable cycling gear that I can wear around town before or after without looking like I'm an advertisement for the sport. If anybody knows a style/brand where I can find that, please gimme a shout!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I'm 5'11" and 178lbs. Typically a 32 x 32 in most jeans. I got the medium's in these and they fit great. They're definitely on the more athletic fitting of bike shorts, but they are super comfy and breath well. Really happy wearing them when trail riding and fit decently with the Leatt Airflex Pro kneepads underneath!

Pros:
- I love the fit. They're non baggy baggies and fit right above the knee. Athletic fit is what I'd call it. 
- The material is stretchy and breathes well. I'd also be pretty happy wearing these hiking and for casual use. I haven't had many diggers with these yet, but the material seems relatively durable. That said, if you're planning on doing bike park laps or free ride stuff, I might consider something a bit more hefty.
- The liner is pretty spot on for being a first venture to the bike apparel realm. Comfy and keeps you happy on the saddle.
- Though I don't really need to tighten the shorts up at all, the build in belt is pretty slick.
- Pocket situation is fine, two normal pockets and one zippered.

Cons:
- Only issue I've really had with them is stretching my legs out sideways - it feels just a little tight or something. Not a huge issue, only really noticeable when you're standing up to really hammer and then get back up over the saddle.

If you're in the market for high performance trail short that you can wear off the bike and not look like a bike dork, these are the shorts for you! Photo was taken on the Wasatch Crest overlooking the mouth of Big Cottonwood Canyon. If you have any questions on these for sizing or anything else, don't hesitate giving a shout to either my email cojohnson@backcountry.com or direct line 801.204.4547 and I'd be happy to help!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Love these shorts, light weight and wicks moisture while I'm riding.

The Patagonia Dirt Bike Short is incredible.  Starting with the chamois.  Very soft, very comfortable, very padded.  Even better they vent like a champ as well! 

The outer short is stylish, and really light, but able to withstand a beating.  I've done quite a bit of field research and these shorts have held up throughout.  They're an easy short to wash.  Haven't had any issues with DWR treatment, repels water nicely.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: These shorts are great. The overshort is well tailored for the active cyclist. The leg openings are appropriate to not get caught on the seat or the wind. The waist is more fitted so a medium fit's my 32in waist on point. The pad is just ok, but on par with other shorts in this price range, however, the liner short material is very nice for the money.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I'm a 34 waist that is typically a medium.  These shorts are like a 32 waist at best...  Not even close...  Just say'n  I got to start biking  and you have to start sizing them right! We're obviously both at fault!
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: awesome mtn bike shorts with chamois. compared to a lot of the fox and tld stuff these seem to be of higher build quality and the chamois is super comfortable. only used a handful of times but would highly recommend. wear a 32 and bought a 32 and they fit great.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I love my Patagonia Dirt Craft Bike Shorts. They are incredibly comfortable and the various pockets work great.

The only thing that I'd change is that they're a bit longer than I'd like.

So Patagonia finally got it right.
Take a off 20% discount coupon from realdiscount.tk

The Patagonia Dirt Craft Bike shorts are so awesome. For one, the shorts themselves are so well designed and don’t look like a weird motor cross style. I live in them in the summer time. They are great for hiking, swimming, smoking the magic grass in the park, and of course, killer on the bike. This design has Patagonia’s legendary quality stitching and button along with an adjustable waist. The chamois is something to really write home about. If you have ever used Patagucci’s Capilene underwear, you will already understand what Patagonia is doing with this bike short liner. The waist band is extremely comfortable, the fit is on point and the pad itself is thick and cushy. Five stars for Patagonia getting into the bike space!!!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Patagonia definitely nailed their attempt at making great biking shorts. I wanted a pair that wasn't too long like most biking shorts, so I purchased these. I am 5'11" and they fit just above the knee. The fabric is comfortable and breathable. It fits amazing and works great for mountain biking. The liner that comes with it is also great. It is tight and makes the longer rides more comfortable sitting on your seat. Would definitely recommend these for mountain bikers looking for a good pair of shorts.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: So Patagonia finally got it right. A comfortable, basic looking bike short that performs. They also managed to create one of the best shammy's i have used to date. So far the best shorts for longer days in the saddle. The material is really durable for the amount of brethability which is another difficult part of designing a bike short. Finally sizing. Now Patagonia is a little wild on sizing but i would say they are true. I am 6 foot 185 pounds in a 34 waist . I am a huge biker and love helping people build clothing kits, bikes, or help in any way to keep you rolling. If anyone has questions feel free to give me a call or shoot me an email.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I wore these all last season. It felt different switching from a road bib but once i got used to that it was way easier to move about on the bike and they look pretty good for food/beer after your ride

I've taken a few tumbles and they still come out of the wash looking like new.

There's a big difference between the size of the liner and the  short. Once you have them on you dont notice either any more.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I had all but given up on baggies. Typically what happens is I get a new set of baggies and after one ride throw the liner away because it is total junk. While I am still left with a reasonably nice pair of shorts they are not riding shorts.  I waited a while to write this to make sure I really gave these a good shake. The liner is amazing. As comfortable as my best bibs. I even wore these on  few long trainer sessions to really check them out. I figured the trainer is the best test since I tend to not stand and if there were any trouble spots they would show here. They never did. With the current run of warm weather here in the Wasatch i have also taken them on a number of road (one over 3 hours) and dirt rides. Again no complaints as to the way they ride. Super comfy the whole way.

A few little things. The front pockets are comically shallow. My phone sticks out and there is no way I would carry anything in them while riding, or even just walking around for that matter. The side zipper pocket is really nice though.  Next, and this is more a comment about baggies in general. They are pretty hot. It is early spring here so it is not a problem but I don't think I will be doing much riding with them come summer. I guess if I rode charlifts at resorts they would be fine for that. Most of my riding is of the long XC type so I suppose I am not really the target buyer for these anyway.  That said these are really nicely made and they are super comfortable.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: The only "bad" thing or issue I can say about Patagonia's first foray into MTB shorts is that they made to few and sold out before the season even started! I purchase both colors and they are my go to shorts everyday. I have a lot of expensive riding shorts, brands like Kitsbow, TLD, Gore, Club Ride etc. and none of them are as comfortable as the Pats. The only rub and hopefully next years shorts this will be corrected is that they need to make the two front hand pockets deeper, besides that, my go to pieces for the 2016 summer!

Honestly, I gave this as a joke gift to my cousin... and he wears the thing all the time now haha. Great Patagonia style and fit. Comes in a variety of colors and designs, which means you can snag one for any occasion. They are pretty durable as well, my cousin fishes and kayaks in his.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
Run faster, climb harder, look cooler. If you wanna let it flow but need to keep the sun out of your eyes, try this visor. I'm a big fan of this, I don't really wear it for a casual day in the office, but I love wearing it trail running, under my helmet when I'm climbing, and out on the water when I'm rafting, supping, or lounging. 

Give it a try and see what happens. I feel it will exceed your expectations.

I sadly returned this visor. I wanted it to work for me really badly! It just didn't look great on me, but everyone else that i've seen with it looks awesome! I would still recommend this product to anyone. Especially for warmer activities where you want to put your hair up and not under a stuffy hat. Water activities would also work really well for this product. Sad day for me, but will work for others!
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: This hat is amazing. Not only does it look good on, but it is unlike any other visor. The material allows for it to bend, fold, and even crush into a tiny ball in your hands (I've rang out lots and lots of sweat from this visor), without sacrificing the visor form. I typically wear this running, working out, or hiking. The visor is adjustable and stays on well. I liked it so much I bought it in bandana blue and underwater blue!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Who would have thought that I could get excited about a new visor?!  But this is seriously the best visor ever.  I wear a visor a lot when I run.  This one is SO comfortable.  It's incredibly light and super-soft without a lot of structure, though there's enough that it'll hold its shape. It seems well constructed, so I expect it to last a long time.  Very happy with this.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Okay, so I was a little apprehensive about looking like I popped straight out of a Everybody Loves Raymond episode, but the Duckbill visor is awesome! This summer's heat has been really unbearable, and wearing a hat has been making my melon feel a lot like the Florida Everglades, and because it's super important to protect your melon, I wanted to give this a try. And it's really, really comfortable. This visor is not only lightweight, but super flexible and easy to adjust. I really like the fact that it doesn't mash down my hair in the way a running cap does, which ultimately discourages the wet dog look.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I have a Duckbill Cap and it is good cap for my running. my head is big size (usually L or XL) I can wear the Duckbill cap and get my swat well but want to try more comfortably for my head that this visor. easy to put sun glass on the brim and can put into the pocket same as D/Cap.

Why wear a hat when you could wear a visor and keep your head cool but keep the shade!

I also use this under my climbing helmet, and it's quite low profile. perfect!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Have taken it everywhere, from Wintersin Tahoe to Summers in Europe. Very comfy and stylish.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Versatile backpack for business and outdoor use. It is waterproof and has a laptop pocket.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought this bag for a teenager and wasn't sure they would like it. Fortunately, this bag is one of the most universally loved backpacks that I've ever seen. This navy and paintbrush red color way is awesome, it's more fun than a plain black bag and the navy is dark enough to hide any residue.  It handled a weekend trip to a foggy city like a champ. My daughter carries this with her while she commutes via city bus, Max train and longboard. I'm hopeful that it will hold up to the rains of the PNW this winter, but only time will tell.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: My step daughters home burned down July 2nd, and she lost most of her gear and clothing. I purchased this for her (along with much more) to help her get geared back up for a month long trip to Europe. She loves it as much as this time around!

Use it as an everyday carry, awesome padded pocket for the laptop and notebook. Water resistant when I get caught in the rain on the bike. Great addition to my black hole duffel for traveling. a ton of room for camera gear, extra clothes, whatever else you need for the day.

I got this pack primarily for use as a commuter backpack with the occasional travel use.  So far I have thoroughly enjoyed this, there are tons on pockets inside for your phone, wallet, laptop, even a water bottle (inside), you name it.  It is super comfortable on the shoulders, and the back panel is sturdy and soft.  I love the material that Patagonia uses for their Black Hole series of bags, it is super durable, pretty much waterproof (with the exception of the zippers), and comes in some really cool colors.  You can use this pack for many different uses since it comes with one giant compartment that can be adjusted using the fold top, it also has a hydration reservoir slot.  The front pocket allows for smaller items and a daisy chain down the front lets you clip whatever you'd like to the front.  I love this backpack, and would recommend this one or the slightly smaller one to anyone looking for a commuter bag that is very multi-functional.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I have used this pack for traveling, bike commuting , riding trains, and schooling. The amount it holds is amazing! I primarily got it after my other backpack did not protect my laptop in a few downpours. This has been put to the test in rain and done great. So far, I have stuffed it with a pair of shoes, extra clothes, 15" laptop, 2 books, a notebook, pens, wallet, sandwich, and 40oz hydroflask. Love it! Get one!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Got this for my brother for hid bday and he loves it. Carries his 15" laptop nicely so his hands are free to dual-wield strawberry frappucinos.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Patagonia quality as usual. Double as everyday and extra  travel pack to go along with my black hole duffel.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I really like this pack.  It has lots of pockets, seems quite durable and is plenty water resistant.  Its comfortable even was a decent load in it and makes a great hiking or school pack.

My issues:
Weld the seams!  The pack is water resistant and not water proof.  I have used it in downpours and my stuff has gotten wet.   It still is quite water resistant and the only time my stuff got wet it was a tropical storm :P

Put a small zipper pocket in the top lid.  The fold over lid is a bit odd but is quite practical once you figure out how to use it.  If it had a pocket to prevent things from falling into the main compartment that'd be $$$.

Overall, Love it, 5 stars!
I love this bag! I use it all the time. It's my day to day school bag, travel bag, hiking bag, etc. It's great for any occasion and keeps your belongings dry in the worst of weather
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love this backpack! It has huge pockets so you can always fit one more thing, which is important in a pack. I also like the waterproof material. I also have a matching duffel and messenger bag so I was obviously sold. Patagonia does it again!

This is my go to pack for all of my climbing gear. It is burly, durable, and also looks great. Love the top loading and am always amazed at how much I can fit inside this thing. It is versatile enough to fit climbing shoes, harness , chalk bag, snacks and layers to just fitting a couple extra outfits for a weekend adventure.

This is the second Black Hole 32l pack that I have owned. Overall this is a great pack and is a great upgrade over the first gen pack. You have plenty of space if you bike commute to work or need to throw some clothes in your pack for an overnight stay. Inside there is organizer that can stash pens, keys, and a Passport or wallet. The full zip on the side is a nice feature if you have stuff crammed at the bottom of the pack and don't want to search for it. The only feature that I am 50/50 on is the two buckles to close the lid.  They can be a little annoying when you are in a rush, but help to close and secure the lid. Overall this is one of the better 32l packs on the market.

This backpack has worked great! I've used it for simple day to day use, hiking, and traveling. I love it's versatility. It's super comfortable to wear, even when it is loaded up. The side zipper makes it incredibly easy to access your gear quickly and efficiently when you don't want to have to undue the top. I do wish it had a side zipper on both sides, but that is just nit picking. I got caught in a hail/rain downpour and the material of the bag held up perfectly and all my gear stayed dry! I'll be using this bag for a looooong time. My go to bag for sure.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This simple waterproof backpack is amazing! Being a college student walking around campus in the pissing rain is a struggle. Having this backpack has saved my laptop and my grades. This back also rocks for hikes and day activities. Would recommend.

This thing will hold pretty much anything besides a seven piece mariachi band. It easily held everything from my previous day pack and then some.  I love the overall design of this bag. It's completely modern and stylish. It's at home pretty much anywhere. In the mountains, at school, on the train, on da' plane. If I had to make any changes I would love for it to have a water bottle carrier on the side. Besides that it has pretty much all the other bells and whistles. Great product and Backcountry was as easy to deal with as ever. Goat worthy!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love this backpack because it acts as a small suitcase. When you lay the pack down it zips almost completely open so you are able to lay it out like a suitcase. I can fit so many things in here. Currently using this pack as my day to day backpack from going to work to then going to school. It gives me more than enough room to fit my books and lunch and any miscellaneous items. Cant wait to use it as a travel bag!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The original Black Hole 35L pack was one of my favorites, and this is a killer update.  The old pack was great, but not the best for wet weather commutes even though the fabric was waterproof.  The fold over top of the new pack does a great job to remedy this, and I've had it out in the rain on my bike with my laptop and iPad inside with no problems at all.  It's a few liters smaller than the old pack, but if you need to the fold over flap can be overstuffed, and you can easily get that 3 liters back.  Two thumbs up all around for this guy.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I don't know about cold feet, as I used these in New Zealand in the middle of their summer.  I will admit, my feet got hot enough to need a soak and  cold enough to need a sun dry during the trip, but they worked perfectly.  Helped me fill my wading boots while wet wading.  I wear a size 12 boot and an XL was snug on my foot.  Fit is almost exact to the booty on my Redington waders.  I didn't have time to exchange or reorder to see if an XXL was what I needed, but I was comfortable in the XL the duration of the trip and won't be returning them.  Not knowing how long these things last is what keeps them from a 5 star rating.  I only used them for two weeks of daily New Zealand wet wading.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: These are pretty sweet. They're thick neoprene so they keep you warm even in super cold water and the bottom is textured to prevent your foot from sliding around too much in your boot.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: These Patagonia wet wading socks are great! They are nice and thick, love the lace hook, and keep your feet warm in those cold mountain stream waters. They do run small, so I would recommend going up a size. I normally wear an 12 so I got the XL, but I ended up needing the XXL. Overall though, awesome pair of wet wading socks for those hot summer days that you don't want to be out there sweating in your waders.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
One thing you should keep in mind when looking for wading socks is the thickness of the neoprene. These are 3.5mm thick. Thats why all the other reviews talk about how toasty they are... No big deal. BUT! Most full waders come with a 3.5 thick sock sewed into them. If you buy a cheeper pair they may only be around a 2.5mm thick or less and then your boats that you bought with your waders may feel a little loose..

They are very true to fit. I have a large and wear a 10.5 shoe. They are snug but comfortable to hike around in all day..

Happy fishing!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I use these for those super hot days when I'm wearing shorts and wet wading in the river. The gravel guard is clutch for keeping out those annoying rocks and dirt. If you're looking for something to keep your feet warm and dry in the water look no further.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: These things are awesome!  I got these before running a river in northern CO, and I'm sure glad I did because the water was really really cold in the spring and these kept my toes super warm!  I don't know how I would have been able to do it without them.  The gravel guard is really nice too so you don't end up with rocks being pressed into your foot all day.  I'd recommend these to any river runner, or fly fisher in need of warmer feet on the water!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I used this wet wading up little streams with just shorts on and these socks keep my feet super warm! Even when they fill up with water I dont feel a drop in temperature.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I've got big feet.  size 15.  And these do not fit a size 15 perfectly, but it's the closest I've been able to find.  the product is typical Patagucci quality (ie very good), and they seem to work great.  they have a texture on the bottom of the outside of the sock for inside the boot, and a hook to attach the top of the rolled down sock to your boots.  No softies inside the sock itself, just straightforward neoprene.  Enjoy!
Oh yeah, some people don't like the trout branding, I think it's kinda cool.  Looks nice.  Not huge on the sock...
column8: I've used it several times

column5: My girlfriend wears a size 6 1/2 (womens) shoe and the size small fit her foot well without being too bulky in her boots.  She really liked the socks for wet wading while backpacking in the Uintas.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I was stoked to see these came in an XS.  I have loved my other wet wading socks but they were always a bit too bulky with extra material.  With the XS I get the fit and performance!  These kept my toes warm in all the summer water I was in.  No pressure points and great fit.  Recommended for anyone looks to have a sock that will last and work out on the water during the warm months.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Wet wading the Yampa and Fish Creek in Steamboat was fantastic, but water shoes just dont' cut it.  The combination of these booties and wading boots makes a huge difference.  Bought a few pairs - also good for taking out newbies in old boots and not having to purchase multiple pairs of waders.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I consider vests the most understated and necessary part of my layering system. I'm often cold, yet overheat when wearing heavy fleeces or sweaters, so a vest is a happy medium.

I have a few other Patagonia vests and have been nothing short of impressed with their performance and versatility, so purchasing another Patagonia vest (one that was more technical than say my other options) was a no-brainer. Also, I love the  Nano Air Jacket, so I figured it would be hard not to love the Nano Air Vest - and I wasn't wrong! 

This vest is incredibly lightweight, highly breathable, and provides me with core warmth in all the right ways. The fabric is super stretchy and moves with you, rather than getting clumped up in your movements. Thus far, I've used the vest while trail running, hiking, and every day wear. 

As for the fit, I purchased an XS and it's perfect. Typically, I wear either an XS (in Patagonia) for a true-to-size fit, or a S for a slightly loose / relaxed fit. All in all, this vest is definitely a new go-to!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought this as a gift and it was perfect!  Per the recipient, this is a very light vest but still adds a nice layer of warmth.  This fits true to size and is consistent with Patagonia sizing.  The fabric is very soft but still feels durable enough to wear on any outdoor adventure.

This vest is originally $200 on Patagonia, but BackCountry had it on sale for a GREAT price! I had to have it! I ordered the Violet Blue in a women's small and it is absolutely beautiful! The fit is perfect, the material is light weight and SO soft, yet this vest keeps your core warm! I will be wearing this on a week long hike in the Alaskan Rain Forest during the wet season! This is an absolute must have in any adventure!! I will be back to buy a second one!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I have been pleased with my Nano Air Hooded Jacket so I decided to give this one a try for warmer conditions and to wear under a shell.  I've put it through its paces as streetwear, on hikes and on a multi-day bike trip.  It performed as I hoped every time I used it.  The vest is very lightweight but is a great piece to keep me warm in over air-conditioned offices and stores.  Outside hiking and biking it cuts the chill of the wind and provides warmth without being overwhelming, particularly in the mid-40s to mid-60s damp type conditions so common in the Pacific Northwest.  The vest is so light you don't know you have it on.  I found the vest to be even more versatile than the jacket.  I wore a headband for warmth as needed, and could leave the vest on over a short-sleeved t-shirt even as the day heated up.  I was able to leave the vest on and zip it up if the wind picked up, or open it up to cool off.

I was a little worried about the color (Mayan yellow).  It's the end of the season and choices were limited.  I ended up being happy with the color.  It's somewhere between a lemon yellow and chartreuse, but it doesn't come across at all like a high-vis jacket (although the color is certainly visible).  I'm pale skinned and look best in jewel tones and this color still works for me.  I will continue to wear this into the winter as streetwear as a way to stay warm.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love this thing. It is cute, light, and great to travel with.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Natasha from Patagonia talks through the new Nano Air Vest from Patagonia
Hat breathes nicely

I. Love. This. Hat!

Backpacking in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge presents more than a few challenges, mosquitos being among them. I needed a hat that I could shove in the brain of my pack, not take up too much precious space, but be able to pop right into action when a headnet was required.

I took this hat on an expedition this summer, after testing it out as a running hat throughout the spring. My hair journey has been varied, and this cap has kept my head cool from long long braids to my now close-cropped 'do.

I love this hat for how lightweight it is, easy to adjust, easy to throw in anything and pull out later, looking none the worse for wear.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Lightweight, keeps the sun out of your eyes, sweat out of your eyes and doesnt hardly add any heat to your head. Perfect active hat.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The mesh top is awesome for the summer
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I use this for two purposes.  Trail running and fitting under my climbing helmet.  Looks good, feels good, smash-able in your pack and it breaths well while making you look good and it dries really fast.  So perfect with just the right amount of sun protection!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Finally, a hat that is breathable and looks good! It's super light weight too, I barely notice it on my head. The duck bill is long enough to block out the sun but short enough that even with my head down I can see those tree limbs that are trying to take off my head!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Baseball caps are fine, but to be totally honest they're a little bit uncomfortable. Run or hike or do anything to sweat in them, and they start turning a little salty. They get some nice fades, but they're not any-activity utilitarian. 

I had an adidas climacool cap that I used for running for maybe 10 years. It was getting pretty nasty. I liked how light it was, but it had a larger inflexible cap that proved annoying. If it was windy and I was hiking, I couldn't turn the cap around because it would hit my pack - but then it would blow off. 

This thing. It's got a luxurious sweatband. The cap doesn't get in the way. You can bend it in whatever direction. The color is great. It looks good forwards or backwards, flipped up or not. 

Imagine a hybrid between your favorite cycling cap, a trucker, and a running specific hat - that's this. 

Now I want more.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Having a 4 year old is hard, especially one as strong-willed as mine is (just like her mother).  Little did I know when I brought home matching camo Patagonia hats tonight that it will be the daddy-daughter equivalent of a best friendâs necklace.  She loved them so much she insisted on sleeping with both of our new hats by her bed.  I appreciate any opportunity to win as a dad.  I recommend this hat to all customers, but make sure you buy one for your BFF too!
Hit me up if you need help picking some out!
Great hat! You can hardly notice its on your head. Great ventilation, sun blockage, quality. Fits great and easily adjustable. Trail running go-to hat.

I mostly wear a hat when I'm running to keep the sweat out of my eyes, and maybe light rain. This does the job perfectly, and has way better ventilation than your standard trucker cap. It would've had 5 stars if it were easier to adjust. I throw it in the wash after every run and it tightens, and I have to fight with the clasp to loosen it back to my size again. I wish Patagonia still offered the red and blue style.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: What more do you need in warm sunny weather than a breathable cap that also keeps the sun out of your face? The answer is: nothing. I've used this hat from anything to white water rafting trips to trail runs. Best adventure partner any girl could ever ask for. 10 out of 10 would recommend.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I bought this hat for my girlfriend, who is a redhead and fair complected. She absolutely loves the style and color. She was looking for a light, breathable hat to take hiking in the warmer months. This Duckbill Cap is flexible, breathable, and easy to pack along for camping trips. A definite "Yes!" for any outdoorsman wardrobe.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I wear this hat on almost every run. It keeps the sun off you're face and let's your head breathe as if it wasn't there. Definitely gets style and durability points as well.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I originally wanted the visor version of this hat, but it didn't work for me so I tried this hat and love it! The mesh is awesome and helps keep you cool on super hot days. The fabric of the hat is pretty rad and quick drying so if you do get it wet to help cool you down or are using it for water activities, it wont be a sopping mess for hours like a typical hat would be. very cool!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I had been looking for a good hat that I can take running or on tours, and this Duckbill Cap works like a charm! Perfect size and shape, and doesn't get in the way, but still keeps the sun out! Super light and breathable, and it can pack down pretty small, in case you need to throw it in a pack. Great for casual wear as well.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I bought it for running.
This is a very lightweight and flexible.
And most important it is very cute!
I want also to buy other color, because it is now on sale

In order to keep myself from seeing just how dauntingly long an uphill is when I'm running, I wear big hats.  I have waist-length, thick hair that retains a lot of heat no matter the weather.  I've been running in truckers' hats for years in order to have some ventilation but the mesh of the duckbill is far preferable.  This hat can easily pack anywhere - any bag or waistband.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: It's an interesting hat, so I don't want to be discouraging, keep um coming Patagonia.  Here's the cons though.  The mesh on top is a good idea, but it's surprisingly thick and slightly heavy compared to other running style hats.  It being all white isn't the greatest either, kind of clashes with the front and will be prone to discoloring.  The brim is unshapable, so it either sits right or it doesn't, you can't mold or bend it.  It's fits my wife better than me.  She likes it.  I look like a seven year old in it, and it feels a little heavy on me.

Well, I love the duckbill series so this purchase was kind of a no-brainer. However, I have a ton of hair and often sweat through my duckbill trucker, which makes me feel like I've got the Florida Everglades going on in my hat (and is pretty unpleasant). My husband kept telling me that I would probably like this hat more than the trucker version, so I took his out for a long bout the other day and was thoroughly impressed. I also own the visor and absolutely love it  (because visors and high pony tails are the coolest and totally underrated in terms of comfort) but I think this might be my new favorite go-to. The brim seems slightly larger than the original duckbill cap (which my husband owns), but I'll take more face shade any day of the week! Picked up the piton colorway and it's spunky as all heck. Reminds me of my dad's old running cap, for sure.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This hat is just like my dad used to wear.  Comfortable, well ventilated, stashable, and does a great job keeping sweat/sun out of your eyes.  I use this for long trail running days in the heat.  When it gets dirty I just toss it in the washing machine with my other running clothes and comes out like new every time.  With all of the new colors I am going to pick up a couple more for my collection.

At first Iï¸ thought this bag looked small but Itâs  a great size bag for weekend trips. Has a shoulder strap and a side pocket for smaller items. I use Iï¸t as my carry on bag whenever i fly home and Iï¸t fits way more than youâd think.

This Duffel works  very good as a personal item bag or for weekend getaways. The quality of the Duffel is excellent with padding on the bottom and very nice zippers & pulls. It has a couple small inside storage pockets and a small separate storage on the side for small items.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: My everyday bag and gym bag. been using it for a few weeks now. I just wish it comes with a side pocket on the outside where i can easily access my keys. But so far, it looks good and durable
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
For the past couple months I have needed to get a new gym bag, I am usually hesitant when it comes to duffle bags. Either they are too big or too small, sometimes they just don't always fit and honestly they are just too darn expensive for what you are getting.

Even though this bag was a bit pricey, I know I am paying for great quality! and I am so glad that I purchased the 30L duffle. It is the perfect size for all my gym gear and its also great for weekend get aways and as a carry-on. 

There is a lot of space in the main compartment for easy packing and no wasted space with two open wall pockets and a well sized side zip pocket.

The colors are also a great plus!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Perfect for a weekend trip, easily carried on at the airport and sexy as hell.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I bought this bag because I "needed" a gym bag. I have tons of backpacks but I needed to go old school so I could carry a work bag on my bag and a gym bag on my shoulder. 

Basically, this is super simple... perfect size for workout clothes or a weekend overnight. Side pocket is what I was looking for - separate the small stuff or essentials. 

The colors are the true reason I bought this bag. I could have gone to my nearest sporting goods store and bought a typical Nike duffle, but let's be real... Patagonia products kick a$$. 

My black hole duffle is going strong and I refuse to  buy a new one (the old version is better!) but it's just too big for a gym bag. 

The should strap padding doesn't move, which I like. You can adjust it to the middle so that's good. The grab handles are handy as well (see what I did there?). 

35L is perfect! Colors Rock (that's the real reason I bought it).  I think it will last a long time. Check out the other photos I'll post!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Gave this bag as a gift for use as a gym bag. Researched several options and landed on this one as being the right size to carry gear, but also fit inside a gym locker. The color choices are solid as well. The external pocket can be used to hold shoes, so you can separate them from your clothing.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: gave this bag as a gift.  They loved it.  It is the perfect carry on size.   They color was great and the workmanship is awesome!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: These shirts are a summer must. The material is light, comfy, and washes really well.  The fitting of the shirt is spot on and looks great in all the right places. If this shirt gets wet it drys fairly quick and doesn't hold stink if you are going to wear it on the river. It's stylin' while remaining quite casual.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have been wearring these shirts for 11 years now and they have become the only short sleeve button down shirts I wear and own. I actually still regularly wear the one I bought 11 years ago and it shows very little wear. I will say that these shirts are more boxy than some of the more modern fitting button down shirts out there, but they are very comfortable and look great. The best thing about these shirts is that they are basically wrinkle free. Pull it out of the dryer or off the clothes line and you're good to go!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Patagonia just makes great products that they stand behind and it's a pleasure dealing with Backcountry too.  It's a gift so this Saturday I will no what he thinks about it...

I'm a 44 inch chest and the large version of this shirt fits like I'm a kid trying on his dad's t-shirts.  If you're going for the super baggy look, then ya, it fits 'true to size'...but if you want something to fit normally then definitely go a size down from what you normally where.  Otherwise they seem to be pretty quality shirts.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I bought a round of these shirts for my Dad and then picked up some for myself.  Great to wear around town, into the office or on a river/drift boat.  Outstanding travel shirt as you can simply wash it in a sink, air dry overnight and throw on the next day and it looks like new.  Patagonia shirts are durable and the buttons hold up to abuse.  Pretty simple all purpose shirt that repels stains from those late night taco cart ventures to normal wear and tear.  Love em!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: These shirts wash great and always look good straight out of the dryer. Never need an iron! In hot weather I wear them with no undershirt and they do their job of laying mostly above your skin to help you stay cool while active. These shirts work  good for hiking and bicycling. They also fit right in at just about any restaurant. Perfect for travel. The only problem is I can't seem to stop buying them.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I live full time in Central Florida, Puckerware  for me are the shirts to wear. I have 4
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Versatile shirt that can be worn to the office to impress the boss, to the stream to wet a line, and to the bar for some laughs. Care is easy and the colors and fit are great. Highly recommend.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I look so good in these pants.  I love the fact that they feel like pajama pants, but look like I'm getting ready for business.  They are so comfortable!!!!!  

If you have any questions about this or any other gear shoot me an email at jasjones@backcountry.com or give me a call at 801-523-4053
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: The first thing I will say is that these are more durable than the description lets on.  They're my new go-to over my Venga pants also from Patagonia.  The breathe very well and the cut moves with you in a way that they go unnoticed, unlike my Vengas which keep moisture and stick to my legs in big moves.  I'd say an overall out of the park home run on these, Patagonia.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I used these pants during a climbing expedition in Colorado, and they were marvelous! The quality is top-notch: comfortable, and dependable. These pants withstood  rocks, water, and glissading -- no rips or tears, and kept me dry.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Buy this pantalon in blue (31), which I thought perfect, after buying the black (31) same but the latter is bigger than normal and when it is adjusted wrong.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: On the fifth day climbing jesus was resurrected wearing these pants and was ready to ascend every pitch that these heathens dare claim un-climbable. The comfort this garment provides often leads me into situation where I am no longer wearing underwear and simply going commando. The cinch cuff is great if you wanna show off those ripped calves and look like 80's Kurt Russell in his full glory. I feel like the pants will last quite a long time, which is cool because the material is (as I mentioned before) quite comfy and is still resistant to any tears or scrapes you may encounter on the wall. I also used these pants on the river after I encountered 3rd degree burns from the pain orb after a long day of rowing. They dry pretty well so take that for what it is.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: These pants fit great on me, which is rare because I have pretty big thighs. They're great for climbing and most activities you would do outdoors. They dry quick, and the cinch cuff is super nice so you can pull them up to your calf or even your knees if you need to.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I really wanted to like these pants. They get good reviews and I generally like Patagonia gear. The adjustable waist slips on my pair of pants, so within a couple minutes of walking I'd need to tighten it again.  I'm generally about a 29" waist , but ordered 30" since they don't make a 29". I figured I'd cinch up the excess with the adjustable waist.
These also seemed to fit a little tight in the thighs. Not a major issue, but given the other fit issue I think I'm going to return them and look for something else.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: A problem I've had in my life is having a longer inseam than waist size. These pants only come in set inseam lengths. This makes these floods on me when the waist fits and even though it's not a huge deal it looks funny. Other than that they are a nice material that performs well and the pockets are functional.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: These pants are absolutely incredible for climbing. The adjustable waist and cinch cuffs are perfect for getting just the right fit. The mobility is invaluable for being comfortable through the variety of moves climbing can require of you. I climbed Fine Jade and Honeymoon Chimney in Castle Valley in these pants and they were perfect. From thin face , to offwidth and chimney climbing, these pants were perfectly comfortable for all of it.  These are my go to for any big climb.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Of all of outdoors shorts and pants that I own, these are by far my favorite pair. They feel more durable and of higher quality than any other climbing/outdoor pants I've ever seen. Everything about the pants is high quality and on top of that, the green color is amazing. I am 5'11" and weigh 180 lbs and the size 32 waist fits me perfect. The only semi-negative thing about the pants is that a size 32 for me at a 5'11" are a little long. However, this is completely negated by the elastic ankle straps which are excellent.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: These pants are awesome, I've been wearing them way more than my stretch zions because they're a little lighter weight and the cinch at the cuff is way nicer than having to fold up/snap your pants up. Liked them so much I snagged a second pair. They do run a touch big, so I ordered a single waist size smaller than I normally wear
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
These look nice and fit well. The shockcord cuffs are a great feature for keeping the pant bottoms out of the way, and the angled zipper pocket is easy to use either standing or sitting. The integrated tightening thing is cool and also works well.
The fabric seems quite durable so far. It's survived a few climbs on the very rough rock of Powerlinez, but did get a small hole in the knee when my bike slipped out on a high-speed turn on concrete... However, I think I fared far better than if I'd been wearing shorts. Great pants!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The only other technical/climbing pants that I can compare these pants to is the Prana  Wyatt and these blow them out of the water both in term of functionality and comfort. They do run slightly larger, but then that might be due to the fact that most pants I wear are slim, and these are labeled as regular. I ordered size 34 and they fit more like 35/36. They are very thin, but the material is tried and true and holds up quite well. The  cinch cuffs on these are what sold me, they are great when climbing but nice to have them down for the approach if the temperatures demand it.  I will be ordering another 2 of these! Great pants!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I am 5'11" , weigh 198 and have a 36 waist and these pants fit flawlessly.

If you are looking for a lightweight pair of climbing pants for the fall/spring, these will be your jam. They are super stretchy, baggie in the right places, and the key for me is the adjustable cuffs.  Which is a feature all climbing specific pants should have. 

While they do fit a hair larger than usual, I stuck with my usual size and I have not had any issues due to the adjustable waist. Overall a great piece and I suggest that anyone who is looking for some steezy pants for the cliff/boulders or even casual wear, pick up a pair of these.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Seriously! These pants are awesome.. lightweight so you barely know they are there, and they don't restrict movement at all. Perfect for climbing or hiking! I broke these in on a recent trip to Red Rock Canyon and they performed stellar! A  cord runs through the ankles that you can tighten to get the pant out of the way when going for a climb or when it heats up outside.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
This thing is amazing! Super stylish when you want to look classy out around town, yet also functional and warm out on the water. Very simple which I like. Zipper chest pocket, two non-zippered waist pockets, with two internal dump pockets, simple snap closer. 

Definitely made for the angler. Very relaxed fit but still feels and looks really nice. Definitely size way down on this guy. 

I'm 6' - 165 lbs.  I went with a size: SMALL and I think it fits awesome! 

If you have any questions, 
email me: wbowen@backcountry.com or give me a call: (801) 204-4571 

Don't mind the crutches, I just had surgery :)
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I wear a 46 Regular sports coat and XL fits great. Very soft fabric and light weight. It exceeded my expectations.

Back Country shipped immediately and when I called customer service with a request, they could not have been more accommodating and friendly. I found my new go to store.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I got the Patagonia Tuff Puff Shirt Jacket a couple weeks ago and have been wearing it a ton ever since. It's extremely comfortable - stretchy, breathes well - and even has hand pockets (crucial). I wear it as a shirt over a t-shirt, or as a midlayer - it's been great for travel this fall, as it can be worn the entire trip! 
*This definitely runs one full size big. I typically wear a Large, and in the Tough Puff Shirt medium fits me perfectly.*
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Until the Tough Puff I never would have called myself a 'shacket guy'... I figured you either wear a jacket or you don't... so either did - or didn't. Then the Tough Puff came along and my world was changed. I would definitely call this closer to a shirt than a jacket. I tend to run on the warm side of things and this is great for cool mornings and warm afternoons... inside and/or out.

First off, this thing looks slick... I mean classy. Just as much at home on the hill as it is in the pub. Face fabric is durable enough to wear as an outer layer and not worry about abrasion, technical enough but with none of that techy vibe. 

Works great as a layering piece when it's under a shell. I've worn it out on the river a time or two now under my waders and it has kept me warm and comfortable the whole time on the water. 

Zippered chest pocket gives you a safe and secure place to store your small and important items. Two hand pockets are great to warm hands up real quick, and two big drop pockets on the inside... well... I haven't found a great use for those yet, but I have no doubt that there is one. 

As far as sizing goes... a little wonky there. The Tough Puff runs a full size large.

I received the Patagonia Tough Puff Insulated Shirt today in size medium, color industrial green. I tried on both the Tough Puff Jacket and Shirt prior to ordering - both styles run about 1 size large. I typically wear Large jackets from Patagonia; however, I am stoked I ordered Medium in the Tough Puff. The fit is great, the fabric is nice and soft, with a good amount of stretch. This will be getting a ton of use this fall! I'll report back with more info once I've had a chance to wear it for a bit.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Didn't get too much detail out of Mom, but she loves this jacket. Said it fits true to size. She lives in the Northern Wisconsin, and seems to keep her warm throughout the winter and handles the winds of Lake Superior
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I purchased this for my kiddo's mom's birthday.  Here's what she had to say:
"I normally wear an XS but bought a small so I have extra room for winter
sweaters/layering up & it’s a perfect fit for that. On warmer days, the outer shell alone is great at keeping the wind at bay; it’s a little baggy, but again, I bought a size up so I could layer on colder days. The inner coat is nice and warm on cold days & very flattering. The coat is well made; the zipper to separate the coat is completely covered with a nice seam, the outer zipper flap snaps closed, also completely covering the zipper. There is no way water is getting through! I had an unfortunate incident causing my dog to knock me over & drag me 5 feet into the street & a puddle, and the only part of me that got wet were my knees. The coat kept me dry, didn’t tear or snag, and I was able to simply brush the dirt off when it dried. This is the nicest coat I have ever owned. It’s beautifully form fitting & functional.
-Erika"
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I got this for my sister in law because she takes the bus to work every morning so she needed a really warm jacket to walk to the bus stop and wait in the cold. She absolutely loves it! she says it's really warm and it makes her waiting in the cold less troublesome.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I've worn this jacket since last April. I've gotten many compliments on how stylish this is, and have worn just the shell in the rain, and both pieces together through the fall. This jacket holds up well down to 20-30°F range. Below that temperature I need a warmer coat, but I take public transportation in Chicago, so Winter commutes involve polar vortexes.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This jacket is so warm! I love the double layers and anticipate the outer, waterproof shell will be perfect for rainy springs. I bought this in February in Washington, DC and it's been almost too warm for our average temperatures in the 30s and 40s, but I'm looking forward to using it when I move to Boston next winter! I haven't had a chance to test it in our infamous, wet "wintery mix" yet, but it is impervious to 20 mph winds. The tweed-like outer layer also looks professional enough for the office.

The fit is feminine without being too snug. I originally ordered a small as it was the only size available in gray, and the arms and torso fit so well it looked like it had been tailored to me! However, with the addition of a bulky sweater, I needed to size up for the shoulders (they're pretty broad). Thankfully a medium appeared in stock again, and this one fits like a well-cut winter coat. I have no fears I'd rip seams when shoveling snow, and the arms are long enough to provide protection and warmth for my wrists even when I'm biking. It's a tall girl's dream!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is a very beautifully made jacket made to last for many years.  I purchased it for an upcoming trip to Norway where we will be in cities and also traveling north where it will be still cold in late May.  You can zip out the liner and have a chic raincoat, keep the liner in for cold weather, or even wear the liner like a dress with a fluffy scarf and leggings and boots..  If you like your clothes rather close to the body you will love this.  If you prefer a roomy fit, it may not fit quite right.  I purchased the xsmall, the small was too big in the shoulders and just did not fit correctly.

Love heft, construction, design and features of yr ski hardshell?  Wish it was longer so you could commute in it w/out freezing or soaking yr thighs?  Want a seriously wind & waterproof outer layer with insulation zip-out optl for warm-to-cold/cold-to-warm, wet/dry days?  This is THE coat. Vosque is perfect for people who want to stay warm **without overheating**, dry, & sheltered fr strong winds. Hood, sleeves, & stand-up zip-thru collar are constructed exactly like yr technical hardshell. Shell by itself is awesome on days in the 50s & 60s when winds buffet fr every direction.  Inner layer is ltwt quilted jacket best worn separately when it's warmer & not too windy.  Together they're a just-above-the-knee-length coat that will get most ppl thru days @/above 20F. I have worn this coat or part of it every day since it arrived, thru late winter-early spring w/ highs 18-62F & sleet, ice, freezing rain, pouring rain, wet snow, powder, or plain sun, & high winds. Zip-in design ingenious & indiscernible.  Zippers bigger & easy to use.  Pocket lining light nap warm enough for bare hands.  Hood roomy but covers head securely, collar stands & zips independently up to cheek bones.  Sleeves are long--to thumb-knuckle--& slide into the pockets.  Satiny inner layer slides on & off easily--no more struggling in & out of heavy winter coat.  Length combined w/ slight waist & skirt line creates unusual & lovely hybrid of swingy trench & luxe ski coat.  Different layers under shell are possible as weather warms & wardrobe changes--shell's lines very accommodating for long sweaters & hoodies. 2 cautions: (1) I usually order an M for sltly roomy fit 5'5.5"/117lb frame (squ shldrs, flat front), but ordered an L & got exactly what I wanted--room to breathe but not swimming in it. Coat perh too small  for some people of different blds.  (2) If the staple of yr wardrobe year-round is a cocktail dress over bare legs, nothing about this coat is going to keep you warm in January.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have this in the grey and purple.  Unfortunately these pictures don't do it's beauty justice. The outer shell is soft yet tough.  It can handle a downpour and a snowstorm.  The hood fits great and the lines are so clean.  The inner piece is so cute on it's own with gradient baffling.  I wear these together and separately all the time, a great seasonally transition jacket separately depending on the weather, but a bomber heavy duty jacket in the winter.  A favorite jacket of mine - and I have a lot!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I couldn't resist the upstream texture/dk ruby colorway, had to pick up this vest! I admit, I purchased it for the pattern, expecting it to be a fairly basic fleece vest. But the vest is great too, a heavier quality fleece than expected, and high funnel collar gives it a more sophisticated feel.

column5: This is the best vest I've owned. It's super comfortable and warm. Great for the fall, and winter with layers.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Great vest for days when you need a lighter additional layer.  Really good fit, doesn't look too bulky and looks great!

column5: I gave this vest to my sister as a gift and she could not be happier! She said she likes that it's warm without being too bulky. She also likes that she can wear it casually around the house or while she's out and about. Plus it's recycled fleece! She loves it!

column5: Love this style vest, light and soft but really warm.  I dress them up with work outfits and wear casual on weekends.  A true workhorse piece.

column5: This Patagonia Snap T vest is a universal type of piece that works for almost anyone! I bought this as a gift for my grandmother on the north east. Cold weather cant slow her down and if it does, she still wears the vest around the house. Ive seen her take it on hikes and adventures as well as a complimenting piece for a bridge club outing. Seriously universal and classic style keep this as one of the top Patagonia pieces around!

column5: I bought this as a gift, but it was so adorable I may need to pick one up for myself.  I love the soft Patagonia fleece with a retro feel similar to the synchilla snap pullovers.  I loved how this had pockets to stuff your hands in to on chilly days.  I picked this up in Lupine and loved the contrasting blue zippers.  The color of the fleece is exactly as pictured, and this fits true to size.

I recently bought this vest as a gift for my mom, she loves it! She says that she has been wearing it as a stylish piece, but also for hiking, and even biking on cooler days. She did mention that it is pretty warm, so she suggests wearing a thin layer under it this time of year. She loves the fit, and thinks that it would fit well on any body type and for a variety of activities!

column5: awesome colors, comfy and soft. Classic patagonia styling, fits well

Got this vest for my girl. She has worn it several times on camping trips this summer and says it has kept her warm on those summer nights, and is supper  soft and comfortable. Loving the old school looks as well. We got her an XS and it fits her perfectly.

Nice material and this has the versatility to be worn in the mountains or around town. Let me know if you have any questions on any Patagonia gear.

column5: Bought this for my husband and he loves it! He has the grey with the cool wave/mountain design. You could wear the shirt on a hike or around town really. It looks great and is super functional.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: When you're going light, fast and high in the mountains, this is the go to!

This jacket is pretty warm for it's weight and size.  It's a good spring and fall jacket or as a layer in winter.  Fit was good, true to size but a slimmer fit for the size I got (Large).  

If you need to pack it up it packs down nice and tight.  This thing is super light which is one of the perks.  Durability has been good for me so far I'll report back if there are any issues.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: When the deep chill of the night strokes your bones, and that 30 degree bag just isn't cutting it, reach into your pack and grab your ultralight down. You'll be doing some goose a great injustice if you don't.

Improving on the down sweater hoody, the ultralight down provides the warmth, but with a lighter weight and the ability to pack smaller. This thing is amazingly warm and packs up insanely small, if you don't use the included stuff pouch. One downside is that it doesn't pack into a pocket which would be nice, since the included pouch can often times get lost - usually in a black hole duffle or messenger bag. Otherwise, functionally, this thing is great. Fit is slim, which is nice on the insulation side, so you don't have a bunch of extra space between the jacket and you. Compared to the Mountain Hardwear Ghost Whisperer, I felt this insulated more and blocked out the blustery cold than the uber light Ghost Whisperer. The Patagonia repair service is beyond amazing as well, in case you get a tear and start dumping feathers. Usually a quick turnaround and if I didn't tell you where it had been repaired, you would probably never spot it. Between this and the down sweater, combined with Carhartts and XtraTuffs, you have the Alaska uniform.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This is the one jacket I would not leave home without... Spring, Summer, Fall or Winter. It is warm enough if you need it, but won't overheat you if you simply need some lightweight warmth. I have worn it during 10 degree temps and during 60 degree temps. As noted, weighs less than a t-shirt. It does run large. I am 6'2" -180 and purchased a large. It works but I could fit a medium without question. The extra room is not too bulky, however. Great purchase, the hood is incredible.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This jacket is super light-weight while at the same time; provides great warmth. It isn't too bulky so this item would be great with layering other clothes on. It does run large though.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is the perfect insulating layer for summer alpine trips. Weighing little more than a T-shirt, this jacket provides more warmth than a fleece at half the weight. I recommend spending a little extra to get the hoody, as jackets this light will deliver much more warmth with a hood and you don't need to bring a hat! This jacket packs down to the size of two fists in the included stuff sack. Bring this in your summit pack if you are climbing a long route or expect a weather change.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This is a solid ultralight down jacket. It works well as an insulating layer as well as wearing to and from work in mild weather. It's Patagonia, and it's 800-fill, so you know it's going to be a solid product.
-The baffle design looks nice, but I've found that it isn't as warm as it could be. All of the extra seams reduce warmth in windy conditions.
-It packs up very small for throwing in your pack, except it can be tough getting it in the attached pocket sack. 
-The DWR coating wears off pretty fast, although I haven't had many issues with getting it too wet. 
-The fit is pretty loose in the torso but it works well for layering underneath. It does tend to bulge out in the stomach area.

Overall, solid jacket, but a little expensive. I got the one with the hood, but I've found I don't use it very often. If you plan on layering with it, get it without the hood.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Fit, build quality and functionality - this jacket does it all. It's the perfect lightweight layering item for Fall/Winter hikes and to wear casually. It's great on it's own or under a shell. Would easily recommend to family and friends.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Ordered this in a Medium, had to exchange for a Small. This jacket is the best lightweight pack able insulator. End of story. Fit is great, warm, and perfect for layering or wearing as a fall piece to and from the office.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This jacket is extremely warm,  has a ton of pockets, and is made out of some strong material. The waterproofing is great, and the lining is superb. Keeps cold New England winds out pretty well due to the little bit of extra length! In comparison to other related jackets, the price point is perfect and offers so much for what you pay.

column5:
Great looking jacket!  Got this for my son in college...who is picky...he loved it!! Comfy  lining inside and the hood does zip off which is a great feature. Feels like it will be good wind resistant as well.  Sleeves are less padded but still seems warm. 
I ordered a Large but need XL...and they are great with customer service and helping me swap it out...(thanks Nick!!) can't wait for the right size to get here as the weather is definitely getting chilly!
My son is 5'11 and about 170 pounds- Large fit him,  but he wants to wear it with flannels and sweatshirts under so we are moving up a size.
-B

Gave this as a gift to my cousin for Chirstmas and I knew he'd love as his brother has it and he takes it from him all the time.  Great quality, fits perfect and great for the city when the weather gets bad.
