column5: got this as a gift when I was living in fl, got me through a bunch of torrential downpours !!!

This jacket was perfect for the Boundary Waters in Minnesota. It was raining as we portaged and canoed to our campsite. This jacket did not tear and kept me dry the entire time. I'm usually a Medium but purchased a large as usually when I have a rain jacket on, I like to have a sweatshirt as well.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I purchased this jacket to use as I worked as a river guide on the salmon river. I used it all the time and was impressed by how dry it kept me on rainy days. I love how light and pack able it is, it takes next to no space. The fit is true to size and is both functional and flattering.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is a great buy! I wore it everyday for 2 weeks on a trip to Europe, it kept me dry and I also wore it has an extra layer or windbreaker a few times. It packs small and is very light. Also it seems very durable. I usually order mediums in jackets but I got a small and have plenty of room for layers under it!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This jacket is perfect for summer hikes in the Rockies. I tackled my first 14er a couple of weekends ago in this sucker and it kept me dry and protected from wind up on the summit, though I was wearing only a light tank underneath and would have been freezing otherwise. If I wanted to, I could comfortably fit a fleece underneath. Maybe size up if you really want to layer. The 'pit zips' are a boon for those times when you would be too wet or cold without, but too warm or sweaty with the jacket on. Brilliant design feature! As a longer person, I appreciate the length in both body and sleeves; this jacket does not sit awkwardly and uncomfortably above the hip like some I've tried. It  takes up very little space in my small day pack; I love it! I have not worn it enough to notice any slacking in the impermeability department, though I have heard from friends that this can happen down the line (it sounds like you can reinforce the DWR though). Lastly, for the price, you really can't beat the half-off that I paid, but this jacket really is worth it if you are looking for something dependable and comfy. Highly recommend.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: This shell was great, especially while backpacking in the rain. The only reason it didn't get 5 stars was because even with the pit vents open it still felt like a sauna suit a little bit. If I only had it on when it was pouring it might not have created this feeling but having it while misting was a little on the warm side.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: This jacket is both functional and flattering. The fit is simple and fits better than other jackets I tried. I'm short, and other jackets I tried where too long for my torso. This jacket is super lightweight and takes up next to no space in a backpack. It's one of those items you'll be grateful you have when a rain storm hits mid hike or camp.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: This jacket packs down into the pocket making it super small and light weight so ideal for hiking and mountain biking.  So far it has stood up to really heavy rain with no problems.   The medium is true to size and has enough room under it to fit a hoodie or another layer without becoming tight.   The under-arm zips have been a really useful feature for summer rain showers.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Jacket is great. Purchased for my wife and she loves it, fits very well and as expected. The hood is extremely adjustable with the front and back draw cords. Material feels robust and should last for many years to come.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: My step daughters home burned down July 2nd, and she lost most of her gear and clothing. I purchased this for her (along with much more) to help her get geared back up for a month long trip to Europe. She loves it as much as this time around!

Needed a rain coat and this did the trick! I like the length of the sleeves. I also tried a marmot and didn't like it as much because of velcro along the zipper. Only complaint is that I always seem to be between a medium and large with patagonia. I have a large nano puff, but for this decided to keep the medium as the large felt too big and frumpy and sleeves super long. The medium is better in the arms but fits snug over my hips...which might be the way it should fit I don't know. I have the galah green and love it!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I just got this rain jacket for my girlfriend due to the crazy rainy weather recently.  It's a great lightweight constructions and packs down nice and small, perfect for hikes and around the town.  I love the way it fits her, she wears a small in all other Patagonia, I got her a small and this one definitley fits true to size.  I'd recommend this jacket to anyone looking for a bomber rain jacket without much bulk, and a stylish look.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I purchased this jacket for my wife to use while traveling. With unpredictable weather this lightweight jacket was the perfect traveling partner. You can throw it in any bag and take it with you just in case something comes up.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Great jacket, keeps the water out like it should and is pretty slick looking if I do say so myself. Fit was true to size and mom loves the Red so it checked all the boxes.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is a great rain jacket for its price! It is light and can pack up very small which is great for taking on hikes or  just wearing around town when it rains. Looks great and is extremely functional! No complaints!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Like most of Patagonia's outwear, you just really can't beat the quality for the price. Light, breathable, spacious, stylish and packable, this gem of a jacket can be a casual piece for a night on the town or accompany on your daily commute to the office. You could go a size up to layer underneath, but it really does fit true to size. 

I highly recommend it. No complaints so far!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I got this jacket as a gift for my girlfriend for when spring hiking rolls around.  The fit is perfect and has room to stuff an extra layer underneath for when the weather decides to change.  One thing that makes it a keeper are the underarm vents for when it gets a little too warm.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought these for my son. He's using them as an authorized under layer with his USCG uniform. As a Boatswains mate, he will see lots of weather and there bottoms look ready for the challenge! Well made, light and comfortable.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I used these under some patagonia pants to cut the wind and it worked very well.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Thin but WARMTH. Not form fitting which I like. Chilly Mornings and Cold Night with this are SUPERB. Highly Recommended Product from PATAGONIA.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I used this one in a hike trip for 3 days with temp in low 30s, not too cold, but was confortable enough to just to put some light weightwater proof pants on top of it and hike the entire day. Also,the antimicrobial treatment works!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: It get 4 stars instead of 5 because the synthetic material picks up odor quicker than a natural fiber blend layer (ie merino) but the fit is good and they keep you warm for colder days on the slopes.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I'm 5'11" and 175lbs - I wear a 32 x 32 jean. I bought a medium and they fit great - not too tight, not too loose. Probably could even fit into a small honestly.

Pros:
- These are decently warm and are my go to layer for under my (shell) Arc'teryx Theta SV bibs for both resort and backcountry skiing. They almost run a touch hot for touring, but with the side zips on the bibs they're able to dump heat well enough.
- Wick moisture away! Can't ask for more on that.
- Have a good fit. No weird hugging in places it shouldn't.
- Long term durability seems fine. Have only used them for a season, no QC issues to speak of.

Cons:
- Being synthetic, it will pick up funky odors faster than wool. These aren't too bad, but noticeable after several days of tour (ie hut trips).

Overall, can't go wrong with these. Great pair of bottoms for a base layer and will last a few seasons for you!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I've always worn under armour base layers since they've been in the game so long. When i got my first pair of Capilene bottoms i wore them and couldn't believe how soft and stetchy and comfortable they were. I haven't worn a pair of under armour bottoms since. These things breath great, feel like you're wearing nothing but also keep you warm when you need that extra layer. I highly recommend everyone try these out.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Warm and comfortable. Great next to skin layer. I wear these with non insulated ski pants at the resort and touring.  Good weight for most resort and touring days. Great for lounging around on the couch as well.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Warm enough for most resort days when it is not super cold (I wear shell pants, not insulated) and cool enough for cooler touring days. (might be a bit warm for warmer touring days.)
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I purchased these for a good mid base layer for Alpine riding out west.  This is a very warm good base layer, and has good wicking properties.  I have other base layers from diff. brands and the material is very comfortable and non chafing. I have a size large(I have mediums in burton mid layer pants for comparison.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Super warm and comfy.  I wear these under ski pants in wide a range of temperatures.  This is a great versitile base layer.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: 第3套 C3系列的产品了，好处就不多说了，反正穿上，你就知道它的好处了！大赞！！
I love these! They're slim fit and fit nicely underneath my dickies on cold days. Nice to wear under my waders on semi chilly days too.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Patagonia makes a great product and their capilene is definitely no exception to that rule. Warm and comfortable and the fit seems right on.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I just bought my second pair. First pair lasted me for almost two years, and I still continually use them . These are hands down my favorite base layer,  light, warm, no constriction, and incredibly comfortable.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This is my third pair of the newer Capilene pants. The first pair I tried on was a size men's medium, it fitted me except the waistband was as if it was fitted for a size large and thus too loose. (did they put the wrong waistband on the pant?)The second had a problem with the thigh area, it was way too small and it had already ripped its seams along the inner thigh from someone else.  (was this pair missed labeled as a men's medium?) Then I finally got my third pair, it fitted me good at the store.

 On my first outing, I noticed the waistband was becoming too loose and kept riding down. When I got home afterwords, the waistband had apparently stretched out, the elastic had failed. (this isn't the first time with the newer capilenes, check my thermal weight review) I still tried to wear them for a few more outings using my pant belt cinched tight enough to hold them up, it kind of worked. That is until I noticed the seams were ripping along the seat area and the fabric had runs alone the leg. This is from just from a total of 4 short outings and what I consider  very light use. I have  had them for less than one month.

The older versions of the capilenes were awesome, I still have several pairs and after several outings and very heavy use, they still look new and feel great. 

I cannot recommend these, to anyone that plans on using the new capilene mid weight for actual backpacking, hiking, climbing, let alone search and rescue. Due to their poor quality control, poor durability, and poor design.

Maybe  the new capilene mid weights were meant for casual wear, but I am not sure if they'd hold up for that.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Awesome base layer for skiing and they work good under normal street cloths when it gets cold.  The fit was just right and they are very comfortable.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Worn these a couple times to keep warm when attending outdoor sporting events in late fall.  They certainly helped me to stay warm and were very comfortable and light weight enough that I didn't even notice them when worn under jeans.  Very comfortable and warm but they also breath very well.  Liked them so much I am buying them as Christmas gifts for my dad this year.  I'm a 32 waist and got the medium and the fit is pretty good.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Capilene mid-weight is one of my favorite baselayers. I know the fit on me is perfect, love picking more of these up when on sale!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Love me some Capilene.
This shirt is my go to in both 100 degree heat as well as 0 degree days on the mountain. 'nuff said. 
(It also is great at keeping the BO under control, which other people certainly appreciate)
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Neck is not too tight and not too loose. It doesnt hold the funk of shredding all day either like some layers. I will be buying these from now on for sure.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I picked one of these up for my brother in-law for Christmas. He needed a new baselayer to replace his 10 year old HH LIFA and this hit the spot. It fits well, is comfortable and I'm sure will hold up well over the years.

I bought this for my boyfriend even though he already has about 4 of these, he HAD to have a black one too. I'm not kidding when I say that he wears one of these everyday so it was worth it to add a couple more of these  base layers to the arsenal. However, these guys are so breathable, they can be worn for several days of running, biking, backpacking, etc. without washing and still be fresh enough to cozy up next to (#GirlFriendApproved).  He has worn this in 16* snow in the Tetons and 80* sun in San Diego to keep the sun off. This base layer does it all and doesn't quit.

column5: Super warm and comfy. I wear this under my ski jacket in a wide range of temperatures. This is a great versitile base layer.

column5: This feels very nice against the skin. It doesn't fit extremely tight which is great. It is perfect for biking on a cold day.

if you can't be bothered with maintaining a cumbersome wool base layer, this is the solution.
Garment feels nice against the skin, even when wet, it dries fast, and the over all quality of stitching and details are just excellent. And at this price you can afford to have an extra layer in the pack for the way home/down.

column5: Patagonia capilene is generally accepted as one of the best synthetic baselayers around. I'd have to agree. Knowing its a patagonia piece adds to the excellence because i know the quality is there and it was produced with thought about sustainability.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This is my go to base layer. I wear it right under my shell for touring on 20-30 degree days and with a 1/4 zip Capilene for colder days (10-20). Great wicking so you don't get cold at the top. It's not a fitted layer which is nice for casual use. Patagonia is on point with the Capilene line. I look forward to getting a lightweight for hiking this summer.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: The Capilene midweight and thermal weight base layers are a staple for my winter running.  The high tech fabric wicks moisture exceptionally well and does an excellent job of retaining heat.  Topped off with a windproof shell, you are good to go with temperatures down to the upper teens - and much lower if you add another layer.  The quality of these garments is first rate - currently my first choice in base layer winter running gear.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I ordered this for myself initially, but after trying it on, it was just too big.  I'm 6'0, 170 lbs.  I have some older capilene from Patagonia and the Large fit great.  I ordered a Large with this one and ended up giving this to my brother who is 6'2, 215.  The large was a great fit for him, and he loves it.  Seems to fit more true to size than previous years.  Great base layer for any occasion.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I bought this as a christmas present for my brother, he loves it! It keeps him nice and toasty when he is snowboarding. They breathe really well and don't hold in too much stank. It is a great quality item, what you should expect from patagonia. Get for cold days.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Great weight, really keeps me warm.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This Midweight Capilene piece from Patagonia is my go to for ski days. Lots of versatility here, On warmer days it can be worn all by itself under your jacket, on colder days I layer a lightweight fleece on top. Comfortable against the skin and surprisingly warm for how thin it is due to the interior grid pattern. I especially appreciate the thumb loops, not your traditional wrist gaiter creating bulk under your glove and jacket but still does the job of keeping the sleeve from bunching up.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
First of all, thank you to Patagonia and Backcountry.com for hand selecting me to test and review the Capilene Mid-Weight crew top.

For those cool days (35-50), this top has become a center piece for me. From snowboarding to running, I have found myself wearing this shirt more than any other in my closet over the last few months. The Power Grid fabric from Polar-Tech is very comfortable, lightweight and breathable. Even on high-intensity runs, I find that it regulates my temp better than some of my running-specific long sleeve shirts. Heck, it's so comfortable that I lounge around the house in it most mornings. The thumb loops are great for ensuring no air will get into the wrist area when wearing gloves. 

Though I do really like this top, I don't know that I like the fit for what the top is supposed to be - a base layer. Yes, it fits true to size and the cut is very comfortable. The build is certainly what we've all come to expect from Patagonia - high quality of course. But being a base layer, I expected this to have a close-to-body fit. Patagonia describes the fit of this top as "Slim fit" but it simply is not. It fits just like a normal long sleeve. I have the Patagonia Capilene Thermal-Weight hooded top and that is also billed as a slim fit and it certainly is what I expected a slim fit to be - close-to-body fit but not too snug. Long story short, I think the cut - though it is comfortable - needs to be updated and I think if it did fit how a slim fit should, it would function as a base layer even better than it already does. 

All in all, I really do enjoy this top. Like I said, I love it so much that I tend to just lounge around the house in it because it is so comfortable. It is my go-to layer for chilly days in the outdoors whether its a relaxing hike or a high-intensity trail run. I just wish it fit a bit slimmer - like a base layer should be.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This layer performs beyond just acting as a baselayer. It's even become my go-to winter running shirt

Purchased this item to help keep me warm on cooler days when spending a lot of time outside.  Have used it a couple of times and it does the job, fits true to size and does everything it claims to do.  Only knock is the comfort which I'd say is average as the interior grid pattern isn't the most comfortable feel - at least for me.  I have Patagonia's capilene bottoms (mid weights) and consider them ultra-comfortable.  These tops I'd say are average comfort.  If considering buying another top I'd probably do more comparison shopping with other brands to better judge feel whereas with the capilene bottoms I'd buy more without hesitation.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: This a great update to Patagonia's previous best selling baselayer, Capilene 3.  It's the most versatile baselayer Patagonia offers, and the best for year round comfort.  The new fabric has an interior grid pattern based off of Patagonia R1.  It helps capture warmth when you're cold, and helps move hot air and moisture out when you need it to.  Layers super well with an R1 on top, and handles stink well with Polygeine anti-bacterial treatment.

this top is perfect for those days where every layer you wear needs to be a little thicker than normal.  strip down to this and it is surprisingly cool, yet adds a lot of warmth when layered.  It's nice and long so you can tuck it into your bottom layers so you don't get that dreaded draft when your jacket gets lifted up.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I used this pack while traveling through Vietnam and Nepal for a bit over a month. I was initially hoping that I would be able to fit all my stuff into it, but it turns out I had a ton more work documents (and other random stuff) I had to haul with me, so I needed an additional bag. That said, though, if you are looking for a bag for minimalist travel or for short-term trips, this could be great. 35 L is a pretty decent size, especially for warm weather destinations. If you’re going somewhere cold, it may not offer enough space for bulky items. There’s no designated laptop sleeve, but I was able to get my MacBook Air in the back with soft items around it. The small zip pocket on the back panel will fit a passport and a few other small items. 
 
I took this on most of my flights (international and domestic) as a carry-on, so that was nice (for the flights when I couldn’t, it was because of really strict cabin weight restrictions). Minimal straps = easy to stow. The only bummer was that the waistband couldn’t be removed when I checked the bag, but it held up just fine. This bag got rained on being unloaded from a flight in Vietnam and while on top of a jeep in Nepal, but it did prove to be pretty water resistant. However, I would NOT put it out in a strong downpour, and would think about investing in a waterproof cover for it. 
 
The feature I loved most is that the back opens clamshell-style, facilitating access to stuff in the bottom of the bag. I also liked having the top load option (great for accessing stuff if you are sitting somewhere and the bag is between your legs, for example). Both of those openings have double zips, so I threw a travel lock on each of them. I really never worried about my bag being messed with because of that, which was great. 
 
For fit, this bag lived up to my expectations in terms of comfort. I am 5’3”, between 120-125 lbs., and I felt like the small pack carried well for me. I liked that there were additional straps to adjust the load where the shoulder strap met the pack, as well as where the hip strap met the pack. I found that securing the chest strap really did make a difference to distribute the weight correctly. Obviously, the back isn’t as breathable as a suspended mesh back, but for what it is, I’d say it’s done well. I carried this thing fully loaded up a small mountain and through lots of city streets. When I got back to the U.S. I took it on a day long fishing trip and hiked comfortably with it for 5+ miles. So while I wouldn’t go so far to say that it should be used for trekking, it is totally set to hike with (as it should be, taking into account its original purpose and design!). 
 
I had some Eagle Creek Specter packing cubes that I used with this and they worked great together. I was able to fit two full cubes in to form a base, and then some half and quarter cubes on top of that. If you’re into being matchy-matchy, the blue and gray are essentially the same color as this pack. 
 
Some cons:
I do wish there was a spot for a water bottle. There’s a space for an internal hydration pack, if you’re into that (I’m not always).
I did get a few stains on this pack since it was hauled through some muddy conditions and put down on the dirt. I’m not sure they will come out 100% from the gray. If that’s something that’s going to bother you, go for a darker color if you can. 
There’s one small part in the stitching that came out a few weeks into my trip. I kept my eye on it and it hasn’t gotten bigger. But it was a bummer to see that weak point on what is an otherwise sturdy bag.
If the bag isn’t fully loaded, it can be a bit floppy. There are no side straps to compress the load. 
 
Overall, this is a solid bag. I wouldn’t say it’s the BEST travel bag out there, but it is an interesting option, especially for people who also climb a bunch (double-duty!). 4 stars for what I used it for. If you are using it just for climbing purposes, check out the other reviews too.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This pack carries nicely on long approaches with a full rack, harness, layers, food, 3L bladder (and still with some room to spare).  The gear loops on outside are solid and is where I hang my shoes, helmet, and chalk, which is mostly because I don't want to stank and chalk up the inside of my pack..  I love the rear loading access and use it pretty much exclusively.  It's super easy to lay the pack down and open it up and then you have easy access to everything right there.  I've only climbed a few pitches with it on but I really enjoyed it and found it well balanced and didn't interfere with my harness at all (I'm 5'11" and I have the small, so maybe that makes a difference).  The only con that comes to mind is that it can be a little sweaty on long approaches, but not miserably so.  Regardless, I love this pack and would totally recommend it.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I've been climbing more and more lately and was sick of cramming everything into my hiking daypack, so decided to try a purpose-built crag pack. Good choice! As others have noted, this one is the perfect size for a sport-climbing kit (60m rope, a dozen draws, belay devices, harness, chalk bag, and extra layers), and for bigger trad climbs, you could just carry the same stuff and let your partner haul the rack. It's also really easy to lash a static rope to the top if you need one, or move the climbing rope up there if you need to carry the rack too. (Or maybe get a more helpful partner?) Anyway, the map/guidebook pocket is handy, and the top pocket is plenty roomy for stashing wallet, keys, phone, camera, small first aid kit, and snacks. The hydration sleeve is helpful, but it works best with a small (2-3L) bladder that you can attach to the provided clip, otherwise it will slide out when you open the back. But except for dropping my 4L Dromedary (twice), I love the clamshell back opening. Super easy to load and unload and we were able to belay right out of the bag, which kept things neat and tidy. For external storage, there aren't a ton of daisy chains, but there are enough for a reasonable amount of crap like shoes, helmet, and Nalgene, and there are also little loops on the sides so you could use a cord or bungee to lash a sitting pad or whatever else onto the back if needed. Fit notes: I'm a 5'5" woman and the small/medium fits okay, although I have to cinch most of the straps pretty tight. In my perfect world, the hip belt would be angled for those of us with actual hips, but this one gets the job done. The sternum straps are moveable, although moving them is such a pain you'll want to get it right the first time. And the shoulder straps aren't exactly contoured for those of us with curvy chests. Squishing happens, although now that I've got the sternum straps dialed in, it's not too bad—no worse than any other unisex pack. Overall, it serves its purpose well and seems sturdy enough to last a while. I'm happy.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I bought this pack as a gift on sale for someone. Absolutely worth every penny. Pros: 1. Sale price 2. Space for gear, there is enough space for a rope 12 draws, a gri, ATC, shoes, and chalk bag along with small packable snacks(Anything more would have to be crammed) 3. Gear loops are all over the pack, so if you don't shove it in the bag odds are you can attach it TO the bag. 4. Ability to grab what is at the bottom of the pack instead of pulling everything out. 5. Place for bladder extremely important for longer more strenuous approaches to be precise about how much you can fit in it I have not placed the bladder in it so this would limit the space a bit more, would probably place draws outside of bag instead of in it if I had the bladder in there. 6. Weight distribution/pack support. Overall amazing pack very happy with it so far. No cons yet, doubt I will find any

bought this as a clean streamlined airline carry-on bag. The panel load back panel is awesome. Unbelievable amount of gear and clothing crammed into this bag. No frills, clean design is a quick stash overhead or under the seat. Just the right amount of exterior zippers for passport, wallet, book and snacks. Great design !
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I take this pack with me on sport climbs that are minutes away from the parking lot and treks that are a couple miles out. It has just enough room for a 60m rope, your shoes, harness, climbing rack, a jacket or two, and any other accessories that you'll need. the top and side pockets are great for stowing snacks and guidebooks or anything that you would want easy access to like your keys, phone, or wallet. The zippered back panel is great when you need something in the bottom of your bag and don't want to go digging for it and end up tossing all your gear on the ground. If you can't fit all your gear inside; fear not, there are multiple gear loops that you can attach biners to. My only wish for this pack is that it had a external pocket for two for water bottles. other than that, I love this pack and take it climbing every time I venture out.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
First, I bought it on sale at nearly half off. At that price it is six stars.  At full price, four. IT looks like it will wear well but I've only had it out about four times now. 

I bought this to carry everything for a day for me and my daughter to climb half a day at Smith Rock or for me all day splitting gear with a partner.  It is just enough pack in volume for a 60 meter rope, 2 liters of water, shoes, harness, a rack, some sandwiches, and a layer or two.  Odds and ends in the pockets.  If I'm carrying my kid's stuff too, or more layers, It is easy to put the rope on the top of the pack and bring too much stuff.  I carried a second rope out a few weekends ago and the weight and feel were just fine. It adjusts well and is plush without being bulky or stiff. 

The zipper in the back makes getting in and out in the dirt easy and I never feel it on my back.  The top access lets you use it as a rope bucket in a pinch, or to just cram stuff in a bit easier once the main bulk is in. The side pocket is a little weird because of its low volume.  The top pocket is good. 

I subtracted one star for the weird side pocket and the strange lack of outside daisy chain with some loops instead.  I just like easy to use stuff and this level of minimalism is just not intuitive to me yet and I still look around for places to hang a spare draw or sling. I don't get the loop system or what I'm supposed to hang off of it to make them useful. I'm sure I'll figure it out but...why no daisy chain? 

This really is not an alpine pack.  I would use it for long routes in Tuolumne that are all approach and rock, but not if I was carrying axes/tools, bivy gear, or a lot of weight for a long time.  This is an excellent rock climbing pack for easy to  burly day trips.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This pack is great to carry stuff to the crag with but I was trying to get a mid size bag for alpine climbing. It really didn't distribute weight well to climb with and is difficult to strap things to the outside of.

I just got my bag yesterday and I screamed with delight. It's a good size and I got it in the all gray color so it is appealing to my eye as well. The only thing that I am intrigued with how well it is going to work is the zipper for taking out the rope is in the back rather than the front. I'm not sure how common this is but it seems like the backpack straps will get in the way. Other than that, it's going to be wonderful to help keep me organized and it is SO comfortable. Patagonia always makes legit stuff, in my opinion, so I trust it'll be a reliable and sturdy bag.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
great insulators. pair with the jacket for a wearable sleeping bag. material does rip if snagged, but it patches well with gore-tex repair kit.

i keep these in my pack in case of an emergency on backcountry splitboard missions. also great by the campfire during cooler spring/fall trips.

typically wear a 31 waist, the small fits nicely but snug after a big meal. waistband has comfortable elastic too.

Honestly, I keep my house pretty cold in the winter and I've been lounging around in them as well - so sweet! As a fan of Patagonia, I am not disappointed. Another great piece in my collection.

column5: I got these pants for my dad and he is glad I did. He uses them primarily as a layer under his fishing waders. He fishes pretty often in the winter and cant ever seem to stay warm! He claims these pants have solved all his woes and he stayed toasty warm! The pants fit true to size. he wears a 30 size pant and the size small fit him perfectly.

They are pretty beat but warmer than this new version; easier to put on /take off; softer. And black.  SO disappointed.  Patagonia, please redesign these back towards your original. Ok, these pants are everything you thought they would be. 

I live in Florida and I still bought them. I was able to justify buying them somehow and i'm so glad I did. I travel as often as I can and these will go with me on all future travels. On the plane they feel like your wearing a minimal sleeping bag, especially if you pair it with a Nano Puff hoodie that you can sleep the whole flight away. 
These made my wife extremely jealous, she will probably try to steal them every chance she can. I'm not sure why Patagonia hasn't made a women's version yet, there's certainly enough demand for them. 
Also I would love another color. I would definitely buy a second or third pair in another color if there were some available in the future. 

Size, fit, and finish was good and am very happy with these!

column5: The Patagonia Nano Puff pants are a great insulated pant. They are light, comfortable, pack down small, and have a reenforced seat. Two jean style front pockets, and one zippered back. Great yurt pants, or just for those bitterly cold days.

PATAGONIA, please hurry and get me these in womens.

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5: I’ve had the Patagonia vest front sling a month now and love it. Amazing amount of storage and front pockets keep my go to stuff handy. I really didn’t think this pack would fit everything i had in my vest but it did and then some. I find that I rarely swing the sling around since having all my go to flies and gear in front pocket. The one thing I’d like to see added to the sling would be more loops to the sides and bottom of the front vest pockets for zingers and other accessories. Also, I have the standard wooden/rubber hand net that is pretty heavy and just doesn’t feel right on the sling. The D ring will be on your right shoulder blade instead of center with a traditional vest leading to the net falling to right side when bending over. Also, with the heavy net weighing down right shoulder you can feel it after a day of fishing. I think this is more of a issue since I have a heavy wooden net. I’m working with my Gearhead advisor Laura on a lighter net and better retaining system that will attach to the net end instead of the handle. All in all, get it his pack...you won’t be disappointed.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5: My customer, Erin, got the Patagonia Vest Front Sling. She has been crushing grayling with her father! This proves that you can cast all day with a sling pack and not feel hindered. Patagonia makes quality gear and stands behind their products. If you have any questions, hit me at 801-523-4075 or email me at borloski@backcountry.com.

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5: had to replace all my gear after it was stolen out of the back of my truck in my parking garage. Had this vest once before, and knew I wanted the exact same one. Comfortable, lightweight and secure. Holds all my gear in well placed pockets that are pretty easy to access with one hand, which can be helpful trying to juggle a thousand things at once on the river.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5:
After what seemed to be months of trying to decide on what brand sling to go with I finally decided to purchase the Patagonia vest front sling. I will say the one thing that attracted me to this sling was in fact the pockets up front. Based on the pictures it appeared that I should be able get everything I normally need at my fingertips right up front. Which turned out true! A couple concerns I had prior to receiving was the possibility of the items stowed in the front falling out when you spun the vest around. That turned out not to be an issue however if you failed to close a pocket it most certainly happen. The other issue I had read was the vest not staying in position. I was so concerned with these two items I ended up ordering an Orvis Safe Passage sling at the same time. So here’s my impression of the product.
First off I have not had any issues with the vest moving horizontally or vertically what so ever. Even loaded down it stayed right where I wanted it to. So not sure what the other folks are doing that would cause unwanted movement? Also the pictures show the front pockets high on your shoulder. You are able to adjust this so that the front pockets come across you’re for chest for easy access as well as staying clear from your casting arm. I can only say that I absolutely love this vest and it does everything I needed to do and more!! Very comfortable and easy to access!  I think the only thing I could see that should be changed is installing a couple drain holes in the bottle holster at the bottom of the vest.  Being that is the closet to water it could hold water if one were wading in deep water. I purchased the blue only because I felt it may stay a bit cleaner than the tan. And by the way I did return the Orvis Safe Passage.
Great product, company A++++ in my book!
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5: Lots of features with multiple storage options. Gave this as a christmas present and my friend is pretty stoked on it. Fits pretty well and is super easy to carry around. Probably going to have to get myself one as well pretty soon!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5:
I want to like this sling a lot but it really doesn't work for me.  I like the idea of it, but I'm still searching for the perfect river storage system.  I gave it 4 stars because I think it is a great design and it has a lot of features.  

Pros: 
There are 2 roomy pockets on the front and a fly patch, big enough to hold 2 or 3 tacky boxes, tippet, nippers, forceps etc.  Main part of sling can fit a small layer, lunch, more fly boxes and an extra reel.  There is a waterproof pouch in main compartment for phone or keys.  There are also straps that you can use to strap rod to if hiking. 

Cons: 
Runs big so there are lots of flaps from being tightened all the way.  When I put a water bottle in the water bottle holder it weighs the bag down below my hips causing a lot of strain.  Constantly have to adjust because it is either rubbing or moving around on my shoulder.  May not be the case on a larger framed person.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5: this product is SOOOO great it gave it to my best friends babysitter so she can hold all my love notes and she absolutely ate it up! we've only known each other for half a week and we're already engaged!

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5: Comfortable and easy access while wading make this sling pack the best I've used.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5:
This pack is an amazing hybrid of vest and sling bag.  Spacious? Yep. Features? Tons.  It's still small and lightweight enough to be a minimalist pack, but packed with enough pouches, pockets, slots, holders, and space to carry all of your essential gear and then some. Accessing the bag is as easy is unclipping one of the straps and swinging it to your chest from your back. I recommend watching the product video to get the full scope of this. It even has two pull straps on the side of the bag to which I secure my tenkara rod holder making it the perfect bag for any style of fly fishing.

The only negative I can find on this bag is the occasional need to adjust it on my shoulder as it can feel like it is slipping off.  It obviously won't slip off because of the straps securing it to you, but probably because of the weight distribution it needs an occasional slide back on to the spot I like it to sit. This is a personal issue, and certainly not anything to remove any stars for.

In summation this is a fantastic pack with something for every fisherman.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5: I've been using this sling to fish all summer mostly for trout but also on the North Carolina Coast for Redfish and other saltwater fish. In the heat of North Carolina the bag did not trap heat due to the airmesh back and minimalist design. On trout rivers/streams from Virginia to Arkansas to Colorado this pack kept me will equiped for an afternoon outting or all day float trips. I enjoyed how easy it is to switch from the front organizer to the rear pockets. I also enjoyed the capacity of this pack, and how well it carried. This allowed me to take more water and food than I would normally stuff into my vest, allowing me to stay out longer and presumably catch a few more fish. All in all I don't see myself going back to my vest anytime soon.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5: Picked this up for the boyfriend and it's basically the prime fishing sling pack. It's super easy to fit and adjust, and rests comfortably against the body. The sling has good room to hold your fly boxes and accessories, as well as a solid water bottle pocket and the piece to hold your flies on your shoulder. Easy attachments for your net and such too! As mentioned by others, the only not-so-perfect part of this pack is that it runs over your right shoulder- doesn't make much sense for those who cast right handed. It still does function and work well, just might be another perk if it were designed to fit over the left instead!

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5: I wanted to scale down my vest to something manageable on the water but not too small that I couldn't store all my gear between trips. I needed to hook my net, hold a box of in season flies, and store the wet ones, but didn't need to carry everything with me. I can carry everything and more. Took awhile to get used to the feel of having one strap, where it would sit,  and I kept thinking the strap was coming off my shoulder. Now I am at ease swinging the pack around to get at the pouch. Worth every penny in the use it is getting and will get in the future. Four stars because I think it is a bit big for my awesome female frame. FYI manufacturers, woman are not the same build for waders or in this matter, vests as men.

column2: Vest Front Sling - Fly Fishing - 488cu in
column5:
I absolutely love this pack after only a few outings (5-7). Super comfortable and light weight which makes it easy to use on local rivers and streams but maybe not those big rivers but if you're fishing those you probably know what you're doing. Tons of storage space and extremely customizable with all the lash points and what not. 

Only issue I have--and I concede the bag is designed to be light weigh and sleek--but the rod carrier system comes lose pretty easily. Interesting because Patagonia makes a vest/camel back that has a bungee strap system far better than this unreliable latch. It's a bigger deal of you like to hike and jump around rocks and trees to get to that honey hole as its jostled more. So I use it to hold a rain jacket, if I use it. But as far as complaints go if that's it I don't think this bag should be ruled out. It's just a great all around average day pack

column5: My girlfriend has these and she says: With the amount of snow Utah has gotten this year, I was very grateful to have these Patagonia Powder Bowl Pants and have been impressed by their durability and functionality throughout the season. The outside leg vents are great to keep airflow moving through but I do wish they also inner thigh for cross ventilation.

love these pants! tested them in the harshest weather conditions in Japan  and they never faltered. My only issue is that I only have one pair! They aren't cheap but they keep you warm and dry in the harshest weather conditions and that alone is worth the price when shredding the mountain!

column5: These pants are excellent in both fit and function.  I'm a curvy athletic girl, size 10 and the Large was perfect with plenty of room to layer under if needed.  We haven't had a below 20 degree day yet, and they were plenty warm without an extra layer.  Excellent quality.  Like the addition of a discreet back pocket (new this year over ly design) and ventilation locations on outer thigh.  Super high quality, as you'd expect for this brand and price.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I LOVE these. They are very well made and indestructible. 

Quality: These are made for lots of use. They are the only ski pants I have ever had that I don't end up cutting up the bottoms on my edges. They don't look worn at all after a full season of use, even in the Goldenrod color, which is light and awesome looking. 

Waterproof: I tested these in pretty much the harshest environment for moisture....The Cascades. I've never had these soak through, which is a first. They were solid when I had to teach ski lessons all day in solid downpour rain. 

Warmth: These are super warm without being bulky. I was skeptical of having insulated pants at first, but am super glad to have these. It's great to be able to sit on the snow and not be cold. 

Fit: I am 5'5" and around 130. Small fits great. 

Area for improvement: The only thing I would change on these is the button at the top. I think it would be better with some sort of clasp that can't pop open. Occasionally the button pops open on these. Still not a biggy. ( And pretty standard on most ski pants anyways)

column2: Lightweight Synchilla Snap-T Fleece Pullover- Men's
column5:
Have a Snap T for a few years now and Patagonia still makes the same version without hardly updating the classical design or materials.
The Synchilla fleece is fuzzy to the touch, warm for Cool weather wear and is a good midlayer under a jacket or shell for warmth though it is bulky. The sleeves are somewhat short as it extends barely to my wrists and does pull up when arms are extended. The pullover does pull up as well when you lift your arms.

Some issues you may encountered:
1. It 's true to size but does shrink over time esp. if using low heat in dryer
2. The fleece slowly gets harder over time so try not to wash with harsh detergents to help slow that though dryer on low dry setting does help
3. It does NOT BLOCK OUT THE WIND! It's the SAME thing with many North Face fleece! The wind WILL CUT THROUGH the fleece.
- In cool or warmer temps, it's not much of an issue esp. in warmer areas.
- But when you wear it as an outer layer during COLDER temps and there's a chilly wind, You WILL freeze! You'll find out if you live in New England with chilly arctic air weather conditions.
- Patagonia obviously has Not made its Synchilla fleece dense to block out the wind.
-

column5: I have owned this pullover for about a year and worn it over a dozen times, and it is easily one of the more comfortable jackets that I own. This jacket fits relatively loose on me. I am on the slimmer side and usually wear Mens Medium in shirts and jackets, and if anything this jacket is a little on the large side for me. The material is incredibly soft, but will wear down quickly if washed often or worn in less than ideal conditions. Additionally this jacket does shed a little. This in my opinion should not be used as a performance jacket as it is more of a fashion piece, and because of the lack of durability in the fabric itself, but I love the designs and colors for the jacket. The collar seems to be designed to stand up, but the height of the collar feels a bit high.  Overall, I would strongly recommend this jacket to anyone looking for a comfortable, attractive looking pullover for Spring or Fall weather.

column5:
I love this fleece and own it in 3 colors. It's not a technical garmet but I do take it cragging in spring and autumn and into the mountains in summer. Any time it's going to be below 45 degrees fahrenheit during the daytime, I'll reach for a different insulation piece.

It's super soft and uniform when you first buy it, but over time the fleece gets rougher and more textured. I wish I'd taken a photo of my first one beside a new color I bought 10 months later, the difference is stark! But this seeming degradation of the fabric just makes it your own and I prefer it in its "well-used" state.

It isn't the most durable piece and after a year of regular use I'd worn a thumb-size hole in it near the abdomen. But for what it is and what it costs, that's to be expected.

I wear a medium in most but not all Patagonia garmets and comfortably wear this in small.

column5:
I wear this vest for just about everything. Come winter, I'm cold - all the time, so a vest provides just-enough extra warmth without bogging me down. The Nano Puff is lightweight and I barely notice that I'm wearing it. I have a few other Patagonia vests, but the Nano Puff was actually my first and totally set the standard for subtle warmth and comfort. 

The synthetic insulation keeps me warm—even when wet, so I'm able to wear this vest on its own in inclement weather or layer it underneath a hard shell when the conditions call for it. I do don it casually as well, mostly because the warmth is so subtle and comfortable that it's hard not to rationalize wearing it all the time. The two hand pockets keep small necessities close, and the drawcord hem allows me to seal in warmth should I need to. I purchased the black and after 3 years of solid wear and tear, it still looks brand new. Also, I have dogs, so I'm constantly being bombarded by muddy paws and dog drool, which the vest has withstood ceaselessly. 

As for the fit, I picked up an Small because I wanted to have the option to layer underneath it should I desire. Typically, to achieve a more form fitting look, I wear an XS, but do wear a Small when I want more wiggle room. 

Bottom line: this vest set the stage for my current love affair with vests, and I'm sure it will do the same for you!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I bought my jacket 2 weeks before my backpacking trip in Olympic NP and it packed down to virtually nothing and kept my pack light. When the temps dipped down into the 40s at night, it kept me nice and comfortable without the bulkiness of a winter coat. The fit is perfect. I'm a pretty big person, 5'10", 190 with long arms and this jacket fit me perfectly all the way around and in the arms!

I would buy another one if I didn't already have 5 jackets :)
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This lightweight jacket is perfect for my mom. She wears it as a lightweight jacket during the cold PNW winters around town and as an insulator under her ski jacket on the mountain. Patagonia always creates high quality gear that last for years, my mom will certainly be using this jacket for many years to come.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This jacket fits great, true to size! It is super warm and light, which was one of the selling points for me. I would definitely recommend this jacket to anybody.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Take extra off 20% backcountry coupon from www.realdiscount.tk

Allow me to say that I have a certain expectation as to the quality of gear that I purchase. At first, I loved this jacket. It is lightweight, but also quite warm. It packs very well. It fits in my climbing pack like nobody's business. After about 3 months of wearing this jacket, I notice the stitching starting to unravel in a few places. I noticed the cuff was starting to unravel as well. I can't say that I was particularly abusive towards this jacket. I wore it rock climbing twice. I've also been wearing it back and forth to my office job. I'm really disappointed. I expected rugged outdoor gear.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The Patagonia Nano Puff jacket I received for Christmas has been the perfect layer under my nicer coats, ski jacket and barn coat. It adds the perfect layer of extra warmth, while not being bulky and binding.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Warm and keeps the wind out. It is super lightweight and it easy to stuff into any pack or purse. It keeps me comfortable from 0-55 degrees. I got it in black and find myself wearing it out on the town just as much as I do in the woods.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: I bought this as a gift for my brother and now all of his friends want one too. It is the softest pullover ever he said. Loves the color options and room for movement in the fleece. The quilted look gives it that extra fashion flare that your average fleece polyester can not.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: it fits a little big, especially in the mid section but other than that it looks great! its super soft and comfortable. highly recommend it!
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: I love this coat. Very comfortable and nice material. Love wearing this jacket out on the town.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: Oh Patagonia, how I wish you would clean up your fit. One side of me loves the softness and style of the this fleece. The quality is great and it is super cozy and a joy to wear. However, the fit is too boxy and too square through the torso.  I wish they made a slimmer cut.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: I'm 6-2, 180 pounds and I wear XL in all my sweaters & jackets (including Patagonia). I've had this sweater a year and it's great. It's thinner than I expected but still warm as it needs to be. However, it fits like an XXL (about 4 inches too long in sleeves and body length as well as baggy around the torso). I have multiple other Patagonia jackets and sweaters, all of which are XL's and they fit perfect though.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: Fits pretty true to size and is a great piece to have in your closet.

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: Super comfortable, really nice spring piece by itself, and a great insulating piece on those cold winter days. The fit is a little strange: waist runs small and chest and arms run large? it still looks great though.

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: Good quality, awesome fit (better than the standard fleece), warm and looks great.  I wear it under my nano puff and it is a awesome layering piece. Highly recommend

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: Im in love with this sweater, it is so soft and warm and cozy, I sometimes even just wear it as a shirt. Ive wore it on a 20 degree F. day with a base layer and was comfortable. I also love the color, I got the Tapenade. I like my clothing to not hang below by bottom and the sleeves to not go too far past my wrists and not too baggy, I am about 5'11" and 125lbs and the small fits absolutely perfect, my only complaint would be the elastic on the wrist and the bottom of the sweater are a bit too long but you can always tuck them underneath or even hem them.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: I've being eyeballing this sweater/ jacket for a while now, finally it came on sale but only the carpet color ones.  I do like it, I have a similar one from the older generation super warm. It does fit a size up so if u are looking at the M go for an L.                                                   I'm giving it 2â­ï¸â­ï¸ for the simple reason that either the company or this website only put "on sell" the extremely ugly colors that nobody wants. But they keep the good colors top dolor for the same product........ not a annual sale competitive at all!

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: I gave this as a gift for my brother, here are his thoughts. "I am 5"9" amd 150 lbs and the medium fit perfectly! A little loose allows for layering but it does not appear baggy. It is incredibly stylish and I love the "tapenade" color. I can tell it will last a long time. I wouldn't recommend wearing as a mid layer while skiing as the cotton will take a while to dry out if it gets wet. Best as a lifestyle piece."
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: I haven't taken this off in weeks. People are starting to ask questions. It is just so freaking comfortable. If you do not value comfort and quality, do not buy this! If you look for the best of the best and the most versatile product out there this is for you!

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: I got the tapenade color for my husband and it is so great. The fabric is so soft and the thickness is nice and warm. A little easier to move around in than the fleece jacket that is similar.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: I got this for my brother as a Christmas gift, and this is what he had to say: This thing is easily the softest and best choice if you are looking for a warm and comfortable jacket. It fits well and the Tapenade color is awesome. Definitely worth the extra money over the sinchilla Snap-T for comfort and fit.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5:
This pullover is so comfortable and warm.  It's warmer than most any sweater in my closet, which has come in handy this winter. On cold winter days, I find myself returning to this pullover regularly.

The size does run large and a bit boxy as another review noted. The positive is that it leaves plenty of room to layer beneath but otherwise will wear a bit loose around you.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: I usually stay clear of pull over sweaters and fleeces since sizing can be a little inconsistent. Either too short and too wide or just too large over all. I have been very impressed with the cut and fit that Patagonia provided on this pullover and it is quickly become my favorite item in my wardrobe .
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Cotton Quilt Snap-T Fleece Pullover - Men's
column5: It's super comfy and surprisingly warm for how thin it is.  My only dislike is how long it is cut.  The bottom has a stretchy part that literally goes down past my butt if pulled all the way down.  I have to fold it under by my waist so it looks normal.  I'm 5' 11", 175lbs in a size medium.  The rest of the fit is great...arms are slightly long but I don't mind.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Good looking flannel. Quality, fit and finish seem awesome. Looking forward to many years of comfortable service.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I wish I could get one of these flannels in every color.  They are so comfy and the fit is spot on!  Patagonia really knocked it out of the park with their organic cotton on this shirt, it's so soft to the skin and has a great warmth level to it.  I'd definitely recommend this flannel to everyone.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The shirt fits true to size and is perfect for high 40 degree weather and higher.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: A great mid weight flannel that looks great on a hike or in the office. The materials were soft and appeared durable. I am of that perfect between size in most every Patagonia item, medium is too small and large is just too big. The medium was perfect in every way aside from being two inches too short on my 6'1" frame, Perfect fit through the chest and shoulders though. The large was just way too big. I am not at all upset about this though as I exchanged it for the fjord flannel and the medium was spot on perfect. Some day I will either gain weight to fill out a large or shrink enough to fit the medium.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5:
Email me directly with all your Patagonia flannel questions - jelam@backcountry.com

If you're a fan of the OG Fjord, you won't be disappointed with the Fjord Lightweight. Winter transitioning to spring is when I find myself wearing this flannel on the daily. It's soft, comfortable, cut well with a relaxed fit, and one of my favorite tops for spring and fall days. Only gripe is I feel the sleeves are a tad long. Though, I roll them up once and don't have an issue.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Fit and aesthetic is textbook Patagonia, which is to say quite nice, especially for those of us on the positive end of the ape index. I was a little worried it would be too lightweight, but the material is just right for daily wear in milder conditions.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Fit like a burlap sack and as comfortable.  Feels very cheaply made and poor quality of materials.  Would highly recommend try on before buying.  If you are slender it will hang like a gown off of you.  I expect much higher quality from Patagonia.  Will impact my desire to buy other items without trying on first.
This flannel is slowly becoming one of my favorites.  I feel its getting softer every time I wash it.  The fit is on point to.
Patagonia is tops. The cut is roomy and the shirt looks and feels wonderful. I highly recommend. If you're not happy, backcountry dot com people are friendly and there to help.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: These are great lightweight Flannels.  Very comfortable and soft.  Patagonia does it again.  I can't wait to fill my closet with a few more of these.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Excellent lightweight flannel shirts. These are light and comfortable sizing is spot on for patagonia regular sizing.

Recently received this shirt and it is true to size.  I lift weights so at 5'11 I have a decent amount of muscle.  Sometimes I run between a large and extra large, but this large fits great. 
This shirt is comfortable and isn't too heavy.  Will definitely be ordering another color.
Gets the job done. I have a small head but this fits great. so may run a little small?

I love this beanie! My one issue is it is a little small. I have a large head, but I'm hoping the other reviews are correct in that it will stretch out. I've only had it a day now, but it's very warm and I'm very happy with the quality.

But its just too right around my big noggin, and never feels very comfortable.  If you have a smaller head an not a lot of hair, this will probably work for you; but it just isn't right for me!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Warm. Doesn't disappoint. Got a lot of compliments wearing the beanie and a beard.
Great beanie, looks great, feels great, and if your a brand lover, then that speaks for itself. Bought a few for family and everyone uses this during the winter trips.

column5: Great Hat for casual and to keep nice and warm on a winter run. Unisex, my sister ended up wanting the same hat. Can be worn rolled or unrolled for different looks
Simple, warm, gets the job done.

column5: The hat is perfect for everyday wear or for any adventure.  I've worn it hiking in the fall, while ski touring in the winter, and on days in between when the temperatures drop.  A classic, great beanie.

column5: This is a really warm wool beanie.  Mine ended up in the wash and shrank into a weird shape but I suppose thats what I get for throwing a wool hat in the wash.
Warm nice hat
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Just like the description says, this beanie is comfy! It fits nicely and looks good. I got the green and love it.

column5: This is about as classic as you can get with a beanie. Ready for the wilderness or the deck of a boat. The merino wool/nylon blend provides perfect protection and warmth for whatever the adventure may be. Backcountry got it to me super fast as always!! Great product!!!
This beanie is amazing, super warm and form fitting, plus legit style. Wear it camping, or out for drinks.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Gave this to my husband in Underwater Blue and he loves it. It has a similar fit to his Coal beanies but is warmer. So far its kept its shape and hasn't shown any signs of pilling.  I really like all of the colors this beanie comes in so he may be getting another soon.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This hat looks good on just about anyone, and will keep you very warm on and off the mountain. You can wear it with anything and wear it for just about any occasion or event.

column5:
It's been getting colder in the northeast and this hat does the job and does it well. I like that since it's Merino, it doesn't get too hot, but it also keeps you warm when it's getting colder out. 

The only complaint I have is that it holds moisture. I had to let it dry out for a few hours after a quick 5 mile/ 2 hour hike the other day. -- With that being said, I didn't realize it was wet until I took it off.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Classic styling in an 80% merino blend designed for durability and warmth. Oh and Patagonia made it. What more do you want in your go-to beanie?

Its pretty seriously warm.  I might have actually overbought.  Im warm natured and it doesn't get super cold around here.  Wore it into work this morning on my motorcycle, and didn't get cold at all.  temp was high 40s.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Great for cold days... keeps your head and ears toasty. Quality. Fits well and gives me a great excuse not to comb my hair.  Win win.

column5: The morning rides on the steel steed along the San Fran Bay are no match for this lid laced with comfort and class.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This is my favorite beanie! It is snug enough to stay on my head and it's very warm. I love that it's still cute at the same time!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I loved this hat when I saw it online, but it didn't work for me at all when it arrived. I would not say I have a particularly large head, but this hat was really tight. Too tight to tuck my mane of hair up into. It seemed to be very warm. Has a nice lining inside, but outer material is stiff and scratchy -- I sent this one back.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: My mom has this old-lady type wool hat and the wool is the itchy type. When my mom puts on the hat, it will stretch and has small holes the size of  a penny. So I bought this beanie for her. It fits comfortably and my mom especially likes the inner fleece layer. Best of all, this beanie doesn't make her feel itchy. Now, she's all smile!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I am constantly scared to get beanies to keep me ultra warm because they always fall off my head or won't cover my ears. This covers my ears and is very snug. Super warm and comfortable, can't wait to test this out in the colder months!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Great beanie!  Perfect fit for activities like trail running; just snug enough to not shift and fall off head.   Fleece lining stops the wind from going through.
