column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5:
You don't become a category leader by exhibiting mediocrity. Patagonia practically invented technical clothing and with the Nano Puff Hooded Jacket they pack tons of performance into a stylish package.

60 grams of Primaloft Gold insulation ensure that you stay warm even when the arctic winds come howling. The lightweight polyester shell is finished off with DWR to thwart any light precipitation. With stylish quilting this jacket is just as at home in the city as it is deep in the wilderness.

If you're looking for a jacket that looks great, packs small, and offers sufficient warmth this is a worthy candidate. I gave this to my sister and she couldn't be more pleased. This is the perfect shoulder season jacket but is also ideal as a mid-layer when you're exposed to inclement weather. Pick one up and you'll look great no matter where you venture.

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5:
Patagonia does it again with this nano puff hoody. This is my #1 most used item in my closet. Seriously so versatile, cozy, warm, stylish, durable, RAD, use-for-every-single-activity kind of jacket. Uses are endless. From snow hikes to airplane travel to chugging some apres drinks at the bars, this jacket flawlessly transitions you throughout life's adventures. If you don't have a nano-puff yet, you need one. Enough said. 

Fit" I am 5'11'' about 148lbs and I am usually across the board a medium in Patagonia tops and a small in their bottoms. This jacket is a little boxy but length is perfect so I dig it.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: I have used this jacket a ton over the past two years & it always seems to make my bag or pack. It is perfect on its own for cool summer mornings or great as a layering piece under a shell in the winter or the rain.  Definitely very lightweight & not as breathable as the Nano-Air, but for things like camping & hiking it hits the mark.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: I purchased this jacket after wearing 2 others that friend's had, so I knew what to expect.  It's wonderfully lightweight but fits over pretty bulky clothes if needed.  I love that it has a hood  because I hate carrying umbrellas.  Fits true to size.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: Fits perfect with slightly tailored waist, arms a bit long but that's what  I expect. Very lightweight. Expect to wear it around town in all but CT frigid winter temps, and will take it on my spring Utah camping trip.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5:
There is a reason you see Nano Puffs everwhere. They are awesome. They are pack able, somewhat reasonably priced, warm, and look good. The durability is probably the biggest deficiency with this jacket. After years of use, mine is showing some wear. The elastic in the cuffs has definitely seen better days. 

http://www.snowbeastreviews.com/wnanopuff

for a more in depth review
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5:
I bought this jacket 8 months ago, and it has been great!  Very lightweight and packable, I had it with me as my only jacket while backpacking for two months in New Zealand, it's warm, shields you from the wind, and is somewhat water resistant-  Although I did get caught hiking in a heavy down pour and by the end of a few hours, I was soaked, but it did continue to keep me warm.  

I later used it as my shore layer for chilly nights while kayaking for 3 weeks in Baja, and as my outer layer over a hoodie while skiing on warmer days in Colorado (in the 40's)

It's sleek and good looking in town, and layers well, both over and under other garments.  

I always thought Patagonia brand was too expensive to be practical for me-  But they put so much thought and quality into each of their products to ensure you get your money's worth, I highly recommend them.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: I love this jacket so much that I have 2. I bought my first one about a year ago and I wear it so much that I was afraid I'd wear it out so I bought a backup. I have purchased other Patagonia jackets and this one has the best fit. Very flattering jacket. I wish it was down, but it's pretty warm. My absolutely favorite jacket!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: I have the 2012 version of this jacket.  It has held up well over that time frame.  I love it because it's practical to pack for hiking, backpacking, or travel.  It's very warm in cool to chilly conditions, has a hood one can pull on if the wind speed or temperatures change quickly, has a practical fit (read: not "slim fit" or "figure-enhancing") with enough room to allow for light layers.  Because it has a synthetic fill, it is extremely easy to wash and dry and have ready to wear within a couple of hours of doing so.  It has served me exceptionally well in my work:  with good, lightweight wool layers underneath, I am not bothered by chilly, breezy, or even windy conditions in alpine environments during the summer and fall months.  It's a great hiking companion in warm winter through chilly fall conditions. It works well under a soft shell or rain shell if the weather is especially cold, windy, or wet.  I've used it as a sleeping layer during camping trips on fairly cold nights.  It has been my go-to jacket over the past 5 years, and I've never been disappointed.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: The jacket is so lightweight, yet warm. It fits true to size - I'm 5'1" and 106 lbs and the XS fits well with enough room for layering underneath (I've worn with medium weight ice breaker). Packs easily into inner pocket even when wearing gloves - which usually make me Klutzy! I love that the hood can be easily pulled up and no strings/toggles to tighten for a warm fit when hiking - yes the hood can look a bit dorky if wearing about town, but such a plus when on the move.

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: I bought this concerned of the body length. At 5'7" and patagonia usually making womens tops a tad too short for my taste, i was so happy to find this jacket came down to mid butt and gave me plenty of length in the sleeve. Ive used it as a rain jacket, over a light hoodie for extra warmth, over a t shirt on a chilly spring night. It is a classic piece that i have no doubt will be around for years. It has become a staple in my wardrobe. I like a jacket to have a little room to layer underneath. And with a medium it gave me enough room to do just that without leaving it looking bulky or frumpy on days its just over a tee. I have a thin frame but a little more muscular build.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: I love love love this hoody. It's light and comfortable, as well as figure flattering. It's my go-to piece for hiking and has kept me warm during high altitude longer hikes in the middle of winter. I also have the pullover version. I'm 5'3" usually a size 4-6 and I have the size small.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Nano Puff Hooded Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: I'm really disappointed in this jacket. This is not an inexpensive item that I might've been more forgiving of. I bought it for cross-country skiing and other winter outdoor activities. It has very little insulation or warmth and it has NO water resistance - none at all. When I'm skiing while it's snowing,  the snow melts right into the jacket and after a bit, I'm wet. Do not recommend, especially at this price.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Been using for a season, no complaints. Super warm and dry, and plenty of room to move.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Solid Patagonia construction and fit, maybe a little big but style points for sure. The two layer goretex construction takes a lot to wet out, only one time in the fifty plus days I put on these last season did that happen when it slowed seven inches in an hour (which would wet out nearly anything).  After a break to de ice my beard and eat a snack these were dry as a bone in fifteen minutes, although the outer fabric got wet in this monster dump I stayed dry. Skiing in the trees these pants can take a beating too. I would recommend using nikwax on these every twenty or so days to keep the fabric in good shape. If you take care of your gear it takes care of you. I really wish the vents were on the inner thigh to dump heat quicker and allow less potential snow to blow in but the powder bowl pants are great in temps in the twenties without any kind of base layer.  Great price for a solid shell goretex pant.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Got a medium in this and it has a relaxed fit in the legs, but is a bit long (I have a 31" inseam in regular pants), which can be annoying sometimes.  Otherwise, they are comfy and are the quality you'd expect from Patagonia.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Great quality pants, but the sizing just doesn't work for me.  If you're tall and lean, I think Patagonia's cut is designed for you.  Me?  Not so much.

I had been eyeing these for a while, and finally went and tried them on. 25 year skier, 34-35" Waist, athletic build, size large fit perfectly with room to spare. Adjustable waist straps, functional pockets and zippers, gaiters sealed nicely to my boots, water/windproof to this point. 3 days of 0-15 degrees F, 20-30 MPH winds,  sleet/freezing rain, powder, all terrain that the east coast has to offer (maximum of 12" powder so far.) All I had on under was a light merino base.

 I am not disappointed by my purchase at all, in-fact... I should have got these sooner... I had my last pair of pants for 6-7 years, these blow them out of the frozen/puffy-white water.

If in doubt, try them on... and then buy them, you won't regret getting them.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought these for my bro, here is what he had to say, "These pants are awesome, GORE-TEX helps them breathe and keeps the water out. The vents on the sides are perfect for those warm days on the slopes when you need a breeze. The seams are fully taped to keep the heat in and water out. Would definitely suggest these to anyone who skis at the resorts and those who head to the backcountry!!"
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Liked the pant.  had plenty of pockets and appeared to be constructed of good quality.  Ultimately medium was way oversized, I thought.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I like the fact the vents are on the outsides of the legs. I feel like they do a better job allowing more air to flow.  The sizing is  a touch large but there are tabs on the inside of the pants to take in extra material if they are too big which is a nice touch as well.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
I've had these Patagonia Powder Bowl Pants for two seasons now and they haven't let me down.

The 2ply Goretex is breathable enough for mainly resort skiing, and the side vents provide some relief quickly and easily.

The fleece lined pockets are a great touch, but as with some other pants I'd love for the zipper to close down instead of up. Maybe I'm OCD, but I'm constanly reaching down to make sure that my wallet and cellphone are safe.

I find the bit to be a bit baggy in the quads, but nothing outrageous. The reinforced ankle cuffs are a nice touch.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: gave this as a gift and they like them. they are a tad baggy but not terrible. i wouldn't recommend  sizing down
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Returning these. I'm 5' 11" and 185 lb. Usually wear a 35 / 32 in pants. These were long in the legs and big in the waist for me.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I have this pant in the 2012 model and loved it. So when it was finnaly time to replace them I jumped at the opportunity to get the same pant. Gor Tex keeps me dry while keeping me from gettin boggy when I'm hikeing up and I really like the vents on the hip for dumping heat rather then on the inner thi like most of the other Patagonia snow pants. I'm 6'2" and 165 lbs. I like like the length of the size M and the waist has a stretchy adjustable belt thats integrated into the pant which makes em fit perfectly... in normally a 31" waist.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: These pants are everything you would expect from Patagonia, a simple design with great technical properties. From the waterproof Gore-Tex shell, to the temperature regulating vents, down to the boot gater; the powder bowl pants have it all! I would recommend these pants to all winter sport enthusiasts.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Fit well, keep you dry!
Just like any Patagonia product.. excellent  craftsmanship,  fits well, last forever and a bit pricey.. Anyways, these are bomb proof and probably I will hand these down to my grandchildren one day.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Bought these recently to replace my aging ski pants. I knew I wanted to go Gore-Tex this time around, but the high end 3L stuff all have price tags that are hard to stomach.

Enter the Powder Bowl from Patagonia. The pants were soft and comfortable out of the bag and well featured. The mesh interior is great and the large leg vents get the job done when things get swampy.

Despite the "slim" designation, I find the fit to be plenty relaxed; the pants certainly don't impede any movement. I might have been able to size down to a large, but with the adjustable waist tabs I decided to stick with the XL.

I've yet to wear them in truly rough conditions, but my initial impressions lead me to believe that they will be more than up to the task.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Needed a new pair of ski pants, so I went with the powderbowls. The gore-tex keeps my lower body dry and protected in all this blower Utah pow. Unfortunately the crotch area ripped on the first day of wearing them. I am firm believer in Patagonias quality, so I knew it was just a defective pair. Called Patagonia and the were more than happy  to set me up with a new pair. They are know absolutely bullet proof. For the price these are honestly the best pants for Gore-tex technology for $300
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I'm working on wearing these bad boys out.  The fit is comfortable, they keep you dry, and are good for all day in the back country, or all day at the resort.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I might wind up owning these. The medium is supposed to be 32 but was gigantic on me so I guess I'm a small even though my waist is 32. Nice pants, especially like that they come with a short inseam. I would like them a lot more if they came up higher, especially in the back, and had suspenders.

Truth be told I'd rather own a bib but the Patagonia bibs only come in the relaxed fit variety which ain't for me.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I am shorter and wider than most skiers and snowboarders and I always have trouble with finding pants that fit. I also don't like to wear my pants like I am 16 year old and have them drag on the ground. The XL/short size is perfect size and length. They are warm, but not too warm and have vents on the side for hot spring days.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I love this coat! I can wear it casual or for work. It is very warm on cold days. Best coat I have purchased.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I wanted something that was light weight yet warm, that I could wear with my work out pants and nikes.  I love this.  I ended up wearing with work out attire, under my other patagonia coat for extra warm, with jeans.  It is so versatile.  it well exceed my expectations.  -- Ben's wife
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I was excited to see this new version of Patagonia's better sweater coat with a zipper (not double, though), new for fall 2016.  Unfortunately, I found this item to have something of an odd fit.  Unlike other better sweaters with long sleeve length, this particular coat came up just above my wrist bone.  Also, the fit through the shoulders felt a little narrower than the typical fit for my size. In contrast, the rest of the coat was generously cut, so I am reluctant to try to size up in order to gain additional sleeve length, as I think the rest of the coat will be too voluminous.  The sleeves themselves are not tight.  Not sure whether fit is by design or whether it was mis-cut, but I did read an additional review on another site addressing the same issue with sleeve length.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I purchased this in late spring so I haven't had much use for it yet. But it's very soft and stylish, and the cut is feminine and flattering. I love the length, and that's largely what drew me to this jacket ... I wanted a lighterweight jacket to cover me over some of my longer cardigans. It arrived with an unpleasant chemical odor that, thankfully, washed right out ... and it looked beautiful after washing on cold/gentle and laying to dry. As a petite person the XS was my ideal size (I'm typically XS in t-shirts or size 2 petite in tops), as the S was too large in the shoulders and too long in the arms. I definitely am looking forward to wearing it more frequently come fall and next spring. The classic navy is a pretty, multipurpose shade.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: (From the Wife) This is such a great style of coat! It's super cute and classic looking. Great fit and comfy hang on the mid thigh. Loved the pockets too. But, I just couldn't justify spending the money so I sent it back. I will probably end up buying it again though!
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5:
The style of the jacket is great. Love the high collar, comes to my jawline. It is loose over my small stomach area having the few pleats. I love the length, it covers my behind. Also the black color is slmost like a dark charcoal gray, to me it isnt a true black. Its nice.
What i dont like about the coat: I havemt worn it outside but it is thinner than other fleeces, i am concerned it will keep me warm in cool weather but because the style is exactly what Im looking for i will keep it.

bought this as a gift and it fit ok but was not super impressed with the quality, doesnt look as cool as other patagonia coats i've seen in the past, the person who got the gift hasnt complained so her feedback is that she likes it.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I just got this for my baby niece.  It's super soft, and I know she'll be nice and warm on those cold winter days.  Patagonia quality ensures that her parents will use this for all their kids.  5 stars!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I picked this up for my niece and needless to say it was a great buy. It is easy to put on, even for a novice babysitter. Material is super soft and it is absolutely adorable on her.

Sometimes it can be tough finding the right size for your growing baby. You don't need to worry about that with this Patagonia fleece jumper. Our baby is three months and opting for the 3 to 6 month size, I feel we have plenty of room to grow. In addition, it's a great layer when traveling in the car seat. It saves us from having to use a blanket when we take her out of the car and walk around outside for a bit.

I'm not sure if my niece is as stoked on this as her mom but they both love it. It's comfortable, looks great, and can be worm as is or layered under other layers on cold days. Patagonia nailed it with this piece.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This is our second bunting that we have bought, one last year and another for this coming year. They are so versatile and easy to layer under or over while being warm and cozy. I love that I got this on sale on your site!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Boot-Length Bottom - Men's
column5: I have been wearing these all season so far and am very happy. The boot length is awesome and means I don't have to deal with bunched up pants or extra layers in my boots. The only downside was that they split out at one of the seams after about 3 weeks of heavy use, but Patagonia as always was easy to deal with and they were quickly replaced at no charge.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Boot-Length Bottom - Men's
column5: "I would give these 6 stars if possible. Super comfortable and warm and the boot length cut is great for wearing with ski boots. Can't go skiing without these babies."
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Boot-Length Bottom - Men's
column5: I will never again return to non-truncated base layers. These pick up where my ski socks leave off for minimal redundancy in extremity fabric. They are warm, comfortable, and withstand the somewhat violent spin cycle of my washing machine.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Boot-Length Bottom - Men's
column5: Patagonia has always made some pretty comfortabe & long lasting thermals. Very happy with these!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Boot-Length Bottom - Men's
column5:
The grid fleece fabric on these is awesome! Super plush and comfy, but the thin parts of the grid allow it to still be quite breathable so they do not suffocate you when it warms up. When it's super warm you'll definitely want one of their lighter offerings, but for mild to cold winter weather these are awesome. 

I am a 34 waist, Large fits perfect.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I purchased this because I needed a day bag for traveling.  It fits easily under an airplane seat, is lightweight, and durable.  I had no problems getting it to fold back into its pocket, either.

I walked 10-12 miles each day in Japan using this.  The padding on the shoulder straps is good, and it didn't give me any problem wearing it cross-body, although  I did alternate  which side of the body I wore it on throughout the day.

It fit my rain fly, water bottle, phone, passport, travel journal, pens, and had a TON of leftover space for snacks or small purchases.  

I was in Japan during a typhoon, and I definitely needed an umbrella to protect the bag.  The water resistance helped, but after being in the heavy rain for a bit, everything in my bag was wet.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I like the bag very much, but the price is a little bit expensive
Dope...for daily Bag...!!!!!!
I love the weight & design of this bag - but the pockets are all too small.  won't hold my small wallet, phone, etc.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I use this everyday! I can fit everything I need into it. Padded and adjustable straps are great and comfy. The main compartment is very roomy and spacious, which is my favorite feature. Very comfortable to wear walking, biking hiking, even skiing with! Incredibly light weight and versatile. Also very cute!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love my lightweight courier!  I needed a bag for bike rides, hikes, and urban adventures in hot and humid areas that make carrying a backpack a nightmare.  This bag fit the bill perfectly. I can pack a map, bug spray, sunscreen, camera, jacket, and water bottles comfortably.  It carried my iPad, wallet, phone, other essentials on overnight bus rides.  My courier has been with me all over Central America and SE Asia, and has taken a beating.  Another solid product from Patagonia.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Detailed video of the Specs on the Patagonia Lightweight Travel Bag.
When I'm are out in a downpour, there is no other pant that I would want on. These work so well, and fit and move with me, keeping me from the misery of being cold and wet in the backcountry!

I must have tried 5 pairs & these were the best fit for me.  Some were way too heavy with tight waist & super super long legs.  I’m a small person (5’1, size 4, short legs, 30” inseam). Comfortable, light, & seems like they will be awesome rain pants.  I like the adjustable cinched ankles.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I got these for my mom for her bike trip in Ireland. She said they are very high quality, and the combo zipper/snap on the ankle was useful to keep the rain out on wetter days. She was pleased with their performance on her trip and said she stayed dry. She also liked that they were long enough.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: These pants are great. Lightweight, waterproof, and the fit is comfortable and secure. The zipper pockets are nice and I like the ankle zipper and snap features as well. Typical Patagonia product which allows you to stuff it into the pocket and zip it closed - very convenient and practical. Overall pleased with this purchase!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I used this mostly for canyoneering when there are waterfalls involved but no wading in pools. Great purchase. I am a 27" waist, with 36" hips, size 4 usually and bought this in Small. I was warm in it and once was sweating a little in it even though it was chilly out and my feet were freezing from the water.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Functions as advertised keeps the water out!

I've only used these once but they seem to do their job and keep the rain off. I agree with the other reviews that say they are ultimately not as breathable or as durable as some more expensive rain pants out there. However, I did not really need anything more hardcore then this so they work for me!!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I recently acquired a pair of these shell pants, and have worn them skiing and on snowshoes trips with moderate precipitation and high winds. Even when my rain jacket soaked through, my lower half was completely dry-the pants had no trace of moisture on them (any water or ice brushes right off). I haven't yet worn them in a real rainstorm, so I can't say how they'd perform in that environment, but everything I've put them through on the mountain they've held up to wonderfully. 
Due to the nature of the fabric, it does make that swishing noise when you walk, but it's never bothered me when I'm on the mountain. Really the only (small) issue I have with the construction of the pants is that the draw cord around the waist has to be tied if you want to tighten it, and the cord material is slick enough that a double-knot is required.
I am 5'4 and 115 lb and the small fits comfortably over hiking pants.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
These pants are a great option when you need something fully waterproof and lightweight. I would say that if you're an ounce counter with your gear, they might be a bit heavy for backpacking, but for car camping and light hiking they are great. 

They fit true to size, but I did size up one size from my normal size to be able to accommodate a warm layer underneath. I'm a size 10 jean and I went with the large. They fit a bit big, but I'd rather have the extra room to layer rather than feel like a stuffed sausage.

I love these pants!  I used to use the cheaper, low quality rain pants because I thought they didn't really matter because it can't rain all the time...BUT, I found they are just as essential as a quality rain jacket to my comfort!  These pants fit nicely over my hiking pants without being too tight.  And they are pretty breathable so I don't feel like I'm sweating to death in them!  Even better, I recently wore them on a science expedition to Churchill, Manitoba with the Earthwatch Institute and found that mosquitoes can't bite through them!!!!!!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Mallory from Patagonia shares her thoughts on the newly updated Torrentshell pant
fits great and performs well. also looks solid. all in all a great product
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I used these working as a guide in Alaska for a season.   They were not particularly breathable, which joined with the fact that they don't fit over my boots meant stopping every time the weather changed unlacing removing boots and starting back up.  In Alaska where the weather changes frequently this was a nuisance.  Also, they didn't fit very well.  The cuff on the ankle was small and the waist large, Which meant I was constantly pulling them up despite trying to cinch the waist down(I am 6'2, 200).
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
These work fine to keep rain off for a basic rainpant but aren't anything "special".  They're less breathable than I had anticipated and, naturally, not as nice as some of the more expensive pants I have.  

They do the trick though for preventing rain from absorbing into your under layers and it's nice to have the ability to stuff them into their own pocket.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: This top is a great underlayer for many activities. For a mid weighht it is super light and versatile due to the waffle pattern. That makes it quick drying, packable and just warm enough. Super breathable. Thumb loops are minimalist and make layering easy. The cut is short in the torso.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: My husband wears this everyday now that he has it. It is a base layer, but it is pretty good looking as a black pullover, and it is super warm.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I got this as a gift for my dad who lives in Bend OR and is currently living through the craziest snow winter ever. He wears this thing all the time, on walks and hikes or under a sweater to work and it always keeps him warm! He especially likes how lightweight and breathable the shirt is which makes layering a breeze. I got him an XL and it fits perfectly. He is 6'2" about 210lbs.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I wore this as a mid layer while boarding and it helped keep me warm in 20°F weather.  I'm 5'10" 150lb.  The Med fit great.  I mostly like the thumb hooks inside the sleeve that keep the sleeves fully covering your arms.  This makes layering up a breeze and keeps the sleeves where you want while sliding your arms through additional sleeve layers.
I plan on wearing this as a plain'ol shirt because it looks great.
I recommend this product.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: This piece is excellent. Very comfortable, warm enough for activities in cold weather and cool enough for sunny weather.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is an awesome thermal. Its really lightweight, the material is comfy and feels good on your skin. Can get a little bit smelly so you have to wash it regularly but the material is durable so its no problem.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This has been a super nice piece to have for anything from running to ski touring. It is on the lighter side, but that doesn't make it any less warm. Breathes pretty well, so you won't get sweaty, also. It eve has those helpful thumbhole cuffs so they can help keep your hands warm, and make it easier to layer, without your sleeves bunching up. Worth the money and definitely a go-to piece of mine.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Not really warm enough for a midweight.  I have midweight from other companies to compare.  This is more a lightweight.  I'll keep it for running.  The sleeves are too short to use the thumbloops, I'd like another 5" but most people would probably want 3" more.  Don't love it for winter.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Goes under everything! Great quality
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: It's pretty good. I got it in Small but should've gotten it in the Medium size though.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Just delivered in the mail today, tried it on and feels great.  It's a little thinner then my other capilene baselayer (probably 6 years old) but it feels soft and lightweight.  The inside has a waffle pattern to it to wick away moisture.  The fit is perfect!  It's not to form fitting but loose enough to wear a thin base layer underneath, plan on wearing my CW-X performance layer underneath for ski trip later this month.  I did noticed the stitching on the arms is somewhat noticeable when not wearing anything underneath, but not enough to warrant anything less then 5 stars. Ordered the Lemongrass color and it has a great look to it, not too bright either!  The length of the sleeves is perfect for me, down to the base of my wrists.  The thumb loopholes are a nice feature to keep the sleeves down in cold weather.  Overall very happy with my purchase!  Rock on Patagonia!!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I have been wearing Capilene 3 pieces forever.   This is my first new piece.  The Midweight is the new 3,  but it is all new.. I like the grid inside..  Can't say if it is warmer, but more comfortable then ever.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This has been my go to piece for splitboarding and ice climbing this season. I hated Capilene for years because it smelled horrible after about 30minutes of wearing it. However for this season patagonia updated the entire line and capilene material, and it is fantastic.

 I just came out of a four day hut trip in British Columbia where it was around freezing and snowing everyday, everything was soaked by the end of the day. Even after four hard days of sweating my ass off breaking trail, dropping pillows, and chopping firewood this shirt was fantastic. It dried super quick, kept me warm, and the smell was tolerable after days of use. If you are thinking about giving capilene another try, or looking to get your first piece; do it. I have the peppergrass color and it looks pretty good with my ginger beard. The color is insanely bright. SAR won't have any issues finding you if shit hits the fan. 

The thumb loops rule, super minimal and help keep the shirt tucked into gloves and under other layers. 

the mid-weight features a great waffle print fabric that is the perfect weight for most mild winter conditions. If it is super cold go with the thermal weight. fit is more relaxed than previous years and is reasonable to wear into the store to pick up a few beers and cans of dinty moore beef stew after a long day of touring.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love this layer. I wear this over a tech-t 90% of the time for skiing. Fits great, soft feel to it, and very comfortable. Runs true to size, and hasn't shrunk or anything after washing.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have several of these and absolutely love them. The first one I bought is several years old and looks just as good as the one my wife just bought me. Great base-layer but yet looks good enough to wear to work. I like wearing the crew neck version underneath for further layering. I'm 5'9", weigh 155 and a small fits great. A little form fitting to accomplish the goal of being a base layer but not so tight that it looks like I'm seeking attention. Haha!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: A good piece to use as layering or wear on its own.  Will function everywhere from the slopes to the woods to the bar.  Very comfortable if you layer properly.  5f10in 165lbs and medium is perfect
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Just received this with my new Patagonia coat.  Love the feel.  Sizing might be a little tight for some people but right for me.  5'10, 164 lbs, 40 inch chest and 30 inch waist.  The Medium fit me perfect.  I would buy this top again.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Beautiful piece. Lightweight, warm, and soft. The design is smart as there is no down under the pits to keep it as a warm midlayer. Highly recommended. However, I advise you order a full size up.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: If you have questions about this jacket, please feel free to reach out to me directly. My personal phone is 801-204-4679 and you can always shoot me an email at sarruabarrena@backcountry.com.

Weighing in at 9.5 oz, this is truly an ultralight jacket, not to mention a warm one. The 800-fill goose down traps body heat very well, and I found myself comfortable in temperatures down to the low teens. It also packs down small so it fits nice and compact in your pack.

While it does have a DWR coating that works reasonably well, you'll definitely want a shell over it if the heavens do open up...it is still down after all, and wasn't really designed with heavy duty waterproofness in mind. As an insulating mid layer or outer layer on clear cold days, however, you can't go wrong.

The fit is near perfect, at least for me. The cut is such that you can wear a thin baselayer underneath and still wear your shell over it. I also like that the logo isn't large or in-your-face...kind of a pet peeve of mine. (Don't get me wrong, I don't mind logos on gear, I just prefer them to be subdued and not screaming at you.)

I'll admit, I was a little hesitant to spend the money on something that says Patagonia on it, but I'm glad I did. The Ultralight Down Jacket has become one of my favorite cold-weather pieces for my outdoor adventures, and should last a good long time. I highly recommend it!

PROS: Warm, lightweight, packs down small, looks good, logo is not in-your-face

CONS: a little pricey, DWR only average

column5: Wow!  Just got my jacket.  I am truly impressed at how light it is yet so warm.  I love it.  Can't wait to take it out on the trail.

Pros - Lightweight, compact
Cons - Loud/Shiny

column5: Lightweight and warm for the weight.  Usually throw this on at the summit over my softshell then remove for the descent when skiing.  Not my go to for around town.  I usually wear my hi loft down sweater or fitz roy hooded down jacket when it gets really cold.  Purchased a medium and can fit a knifeblade softshell with a light merino wool top underneath it.

column5:
This is an amazing down jacket. I don't know about some other people who have reviewed it, but the fit is very nice and wears well under a ski jacket as a mid-layer. I can't say I have any issues flexing my lats in this jacket ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Otherwise the updated compressing pocket is much better (and smaller) than the last version that I owned. This jacket keeps you warm when it's cold outside, but it doesn't overheat you when it isn't very cold during use.

Amazing jacket.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Superlight weight.  Unfortunately, the fit is not "regular" despite the description.  Pinches the armpits when you flex lats or hug someone.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: At first I have to be honest. I thought this jacket was only the large price tag because of the Patagonia label. But I have to say this is by far the best down jacket I have ever had. It's 800 fill keeps you perfectly warm. It was snowed 15 inches so far in SLC and I used this jacket to shovel and it was perfect. It weighs pretty much nothing and the way it compacts is super handy. This is an all around great jacket, perfect for any use. I would strongly recommend you buy this jacket, and the $300 is totally worth it

If you need lightweight warmth in a tiny package this is the jacket for you. A few updates such as changing the face fabric from 10D to 15D make this more durable, and helps reduce the chance of feathers poking through the jacket material. 

My favorite update to this jacket is you can stuff into the chest pocket or side pocket. No more stuff sack. Also the two stuffing options allow you to make travel pillow for camp or long flights. Two thumbs up!

stuff jacket into the side pocket to make a travel pillow

Its alright. Its stretchy, fairly warm, blocks wind, and really durable.I use it for rock climbing and I've dragged it through chimneys and climbed cracks with it and it isn't looking beat up at all. The only thing i dont like is the cuffs on the sleeves. its a small detail that almost ruins the jacket. They arent very elastic so they always drop over my hands and make it hard to climb and they cant really be pushed up you're forearms because they just slide down. I wish i had gotten the hooded version which has Velcro to hold the sleeves in place

column5: The quality of the jacket was great. I just didn't like how it fit on my near the neck area. I ended up returning this item and bought the hybrid hooded one.

column5: Great soft-shell with nice flex and windstopper action. I have a 40" chest and 31" waist and went with a Medium.  One of the things I like the best is the shell's resistance to abrasion.  It has a more durable feel than a nylon soft shell so you do not have to worry as much about the material tearing  if it gets snagged on a tree branch for example.  Patagonia's gear is always worth consideration. NF Apex Bionic would probably fall into this category as well but I preferred the Adze Hybrid.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Great jacket. Perfect for skitouring and climbing. The high pockets are great for keeping out of the way of your harness. it is a superb outer layer for moving hard in cold weather. I routinely layer this with a R1 and baselayer for temps down to single digits and am fine once I start moving. The slim cut keeps things close and enables you throw over a belay jacket or other puffy piece to stay warm at the transition or snack breaks. Superb product. Highly recommend it.

column5: Take anywhere go anywhere light jacket. Very comfortable and warm.

column5: I bought the green and it looks sharp on me. The stretchy fabric is one of the best features as it moves with you; it's not constricting. It's summer so I can't attest to the wind blocking or warmth yet. I'm also very happy with how quickly Backcountry.com exchanged a large for the medium when I ordered the wrong size. (You need to be about 6'3'' and 200 pounds for a large I think)
Jimmy from Patagonia talks through the newly updated Adze Hybrid jacket, based off the best selling Adze Jacket.

Wanted a down vest and found this version on sale so bought the Ramble Red which complements my Patogonia French Red Down Sweater Jacket. The Ramble Red is a bit darker than the French Red which is slighter brighter.
It's not yet cold yet but autumn's cool weather has appeared with winter's cold temperatures coming.
The vest fits over a t-shirt and a lightweight fleece with enough room for a heavier base or mid layer. It's not thick as a regular down vest but appears to be warm enough, at least indoors.
The fabric is lightweight so it probably won't hold up well if you use it harshly.
There's no inner liner in the hand pockets so you'll need to keep some gloves in those pockets.
Buy it when it's on sale ~50% off :)

column5: Great vest very warm everything as expected.

column5: Little late getting this review out. I got this vest for my husband, and he loves it. He wears it about every day. It looks great. It's all he needs on more mild winter days. He got a medium and the fit was perfect. Also love that the down is gotten humanely.
Best vest i have ever had! keeps you warm all day and looks really good! I would totally recommend this to anyone!

column5:
It gets cold in South Dakota, and I'm an outdoor photographer who isn't afraid of the coldest nights.  This vest is great when riding in the truck and jumping in & out, but it doesn't stop there.  It's so thin it's an easy way to boost warmth under my main winter parka when the temperature hits zero F and is still in a free fall.  It's hard to believe that something this thin and light could be so warm!  I've worn it almost everyday since receiving it last month (in temperatures hovering near zero F) and would buy another one of these if something happened to this one.  I wear under either an Outdoor Research Floodlight (lightweight jacket) or under a Mountain Hardwear Absolute Zero parka when the mercury is hiding in the thermometer's bulb.

Kent in SD

This vest is nice. It's surprisingly warm and seems durable. I also have a Mountain Hardwear Nitrous jacket, and this is definitely thicker than that. That isn't really a benefit or a drawback, but note that it is pretty thick and pretty warm. The price is really high though. I got mine on sale and it isn't hard to find this or similar down vests from other manufacturers for the $90-120 range.

As for sizing, I'm 5'11'' and 175lbs and the medium fits comfortably with a lightweight fleece underneath. I have a little room but not too much extra.

Well, an XL is long enough.  But it's also big enough to fit an additional person.  If I had an extra 50 lbs of beer belly it'd probably fit just great (hey, gotta have goals, right?!).

column5:
For some reason I used to be a vest hater.  I'm not really quite sure why, but once I realized the incredible versatility of a puffy vest, I was hooked.  I actually own both this vest (in black, picture below) and the Patagonia Nano Puff Vest.  The down vest is certainly more lofted and warmer relative to the Nano Puff, so I choose which vest to wear based on the temps and expected level of moisture (Nano Puff is synthetic and performs better when damp).  

Photo: Enjoying a Rainier Beer on the Tokasitna Glacier at Mount Huntington Base Camp, Alaska Range.

I bought the L after having tried on an XL Down Sweater Jacket.  The jacket in XL was way to roomy for me. The vest in Large ends up being a snug but usable fit in all but the length. Its simply to short. Seems there is a gap in between the XL and L. I have had similar problems with North Face sizing.

column2: Nano Puff Pullover Insulated Jacket - Women's
column5: I got this jacket to be my go to midlayer for skiing and it has not disappointed.  Super lightweight but packs a punch when it comes to warmth.  When touring or snowshoeing I throw this on over my baselayer and I'm good to go, an added bonus is it is a synthetic insulation so it drys a bit faster than down when you're out and about and it starts snowing.  It fits very true to size, perhaps even a tad smaller and it's cut to fit very close to the body so you don't have any bulk when using it to layer.  The nice thing about the fit is you get a lot of warmth without any of the bulk but its still flexible and moves well when you're skiing.  When downhill skiing, it fits under my jacket perfectly without feeling too snug .  Overall a great jacket/layer that I would recommend to anyone looking for something lightweight but very warm.

column5:
I wanted to love this jacket because it's lightweight and warm. Great for layering or packing in a backpack in case the summit of a hike is a little chilly. But within the first month of owning it the seems started to unravel around the wrists. Just from normal wear. Not doing anything too rugged in the jacket.  The threading of the wrists also started to unwind. I contacted Patagonia about this seeing as the jacket was only 2 weeks old when I first noted the problem and they were not willing to exchange the jacket for a new one. I thought that was disappointing considering how expensive the jacket is.

I also find this jacket hard to get off. The zipper in the front does not go deep enough down the front of the jacket to allow it to be easily pulled off. For anyone with broad shoulders this could be hard to get off.

column5:
I bought this as a gift for my husband and this is what he said.

"I've been running and bike commuting in the Windchaser shirt for most of the spring and have loved it so my significant other gently persuaded me to invest in another hot weather layer to rotate into the cycle because I'm a smelly human.

I jumped on this layer because the purple sleeves make you look like a toaster strudel in the best possible way. This layer is the perfect weight for even the hottest desert runs and has dried remarkably quickly. Not much else to say about it other than it works perfectly, looks great and is fun to wear.

Make sure to wash it frequently to keep its wicking abilities at their best and to keep the stink at it's lowest. I generally just hand wash it while I'm in the shower and let it dry for the morning."

Note: this is a really, really lightweight shirt. Think like silkweight!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I have been focusing on my base layers this year with aspirations of controlling how sweaty I get. I sweat, I do not perspire! Therefore, I needed good first layers to move moisture away from my body both when I am hiking and when I am running. I purchased two short-sleeved lightweight and two long-sleeved shirts, one light weight and one midweight. I have been mostly running but I have gotten out a couple times snowshoeing with these.

For all activities that I have used them for they have been excellent. They do soak up sweat but they also get rid of it very quickly, even with additional layers over top. As the only layer when I am running they are saturated in some places but much less so than other shirts I typically run in (I live in the PNW and it is still very humit as of writing this review). In fact, they are so good that I have been running in the capilene shirts almost exclusively since I purchased them (about 5-6 weeks)

The first thing you'll notice is that this shirt, even the midweight, is extremely thin. Typically I only wear a shirt or shorts once and then wash it. However, after a couple of washings of these shirts, I noticed that they had signs of wear. There were little snags and distortions in the fabric. I began to worry that these would not last long enough to make them worth the cost. I thought about buying several more to lighten the burden but then decided to do a little testing first. Since these shirts are treated with polygene they should not stink as much as a typical polyester. So I wore one shirt for two weeks running 4 times per week and hang drying it after rather than washing. I ran once in a standard poly shirt and let it hang dry for the two weeks as a control. The standard poly, as you can imagine, stunk after a couple of days. The capilene got a little funky but not unbearable. Even better, when I start to sweat in a standard poly that already has the funk, it stinks even worse when it gets wet; not the polygene capilene. Though they were a little funky, they never got worse even resoaked in my sweat the following day. I then decided that I would repeat the test but rinse the shirts after each run in my post-run shower. This time there was a slight funk but barely noticeable (and no complaints from the wife which is the real test).

In the end, I decided not to purchase any more shirts but instead wash the shirts much less than my typical running stuff. Because the shirts are so thin, I rinse them in my post-run shower and they are dry and ready by morning for the next run. This cuts down on the number of washes and will, in theory, increase the longevity of the shirts.

Amazing shirt and, in a way, cuts down on washing and waste as a result. When I need another one I will be purchasing another one of these shirts without thinking twice.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:

So when my Uncle asked for a versatile work-out shirt this was my first thought. So far he is very happy with his gift! He has worn this shirt to work out in the gym and to use as a base layer for winter hikes. He says it is super versatile and comfortable!

column5: These shirts weigh nothing and feel great. A pair of these went on a 10 day sea kayaking trip and didn't seem to pick up much odor at all even after constant use. The downside is that the stitching (specifically the hems) seems to be mediocre at best. After one summer of use, 2 of my 4 shirts have unraveling stitching in various places, which is not what I was expecting from Patagonia. I would not bank on these lasting a long time.

column5: Very light and airy shirt, great fit! I purchased this partly because  the description claimed it to be anti microbial , Baloney Sandwich.  Capilene has always stunk and I believe it always will. Sticking with merino.

This is a great t-shirt for daily wear in hot sunny weather. It feels cooler than going shirtless, and you get to avoid the whole lobster red look and, you know, skin cancer. 

Lightweight is an understatement, the fabric is so light and thin you feel like the tag, which is thankfully not placed behind the neck, is as heavy as the rest of the shirt. 

This piece works great as a standalone piece in hot weather and as a base layer in cooler weather. I am between sizes so I opted for the larger size to use as a daily wear t-shirt, if I was looking for a lightweight base layer for cooler weather I'd go with the medium in the long sleeve version. On a side note I have the long sleeve version of this exact shirt that I use while in the sun all day installing solar panels to protect me from the sun and love it even in 100 degree weather. 

Durability is impressive for this lightweight of a piece. It stands up to washes and daily use without showing wear but doesn't like to be snagged by thorns or scrapped against asphalt roof shingles repeatedly. 

I'd recommend this wholeheartedly for warm weather or those among us like myself that are exceptionally sweaty and need something that really wicks moisture away, but if you'd like a similar option check out the Ether shirt from Arc'teryx.

column5: Bought this jacket on a whim and it was a GREAT decision. This is a perfect vest for putting over anything. Even sweaters! I bought the black so it matches everything and it's really comfy. Recommend!

I bought this vest as part of my cold weather ski get up. This is an essential piece in properly layering for frigid ski days.

I start with a merino base layer (Mons Royale long sleeve turtleneck), then the Patagonia Better Sweater 1/4 zip in an XS. Then this down vest on top in a S. Last, the North Face shredromper bib pants and the North Face Anorak shell on top. You're guaranteed to stay warm that way.

The reason I opted for a down vest over a down jacket is for breathability and temperature control. Down can get wet and cold if you get too hot and sweat, so it's important to use it wisely in insulating and a vest is the perfect balance between staying warm but not getting over-heated.

I love the fit of this vest. It pairs so nicely with so many other pieces and adds incredible warmth to the right areas. This vest packs the highest amount of warmth with the least weight and bulk, making it perfect for my ski layering process.

It's like a more waterproof, bomber version of the Patagonia Mini Mass bag, except it doesn't have a side water bottle holder nor a rear outside, magazine-sized back sleeve. Also,  the laptop sleeve comfortably fits a 13" laptop and the tablet sleeve only fits iPad Air and not older iPads. A 15" laptop is a tight squeeze.

I decided to get the mini version of this and could not be happier with the decision; the amount of space being ideal for going to school or work. It has a padded sleeve for a tablet, as well as a bigger one for a laptop and folders, than there are a number of side pockets that zip, a side place that a waterbottle fit into, and the various straps to clip things on. The strap on this bag is extremely comfortable, easy to adjust, and allows the bag to sit perfectly on your lower-to-mid back. The materials this bag is made of are quite durable, and the outer DWR coating provides a good layer of protection from the rain. Over-all one of the best bags I have bought, and the best messenger bag so far.

column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I had the last version of this pack (the 25L) and used that until it finally kicked the bucket. That pack was great. This pack is excellent! Almost perfect.

I use it primarily for climbing adventures when there's a long hike in and/or a walk off that doesn't return to the base. Carries well, climbs well, holds tons, and  is easy to load. 
I've been able to fit a double rack, personal climbing gear, water and snacks, and a layer or two without much trouble (may need to lash helmet to the outside). Pretty impressive for such a small pack. 

Highlights:
-climbs really well
-holds a ton of gear for a 30L
-reinforced at high wear spots
-sort of stands up on its own
-easy to load
-compresses down if using as a summit pack on a longer trip

I do wish this had a sleeve for a water bladder. It has a 'sleeve,' but it's more for the plastic back support thing. Also, the zipper pocket on the inside it tiny; it barely fits a headlamp. 

I'd definitely recommend this pack to any friends and none of my enemies!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This pack is my go-to for any and all alpine adventures. The lightweight design and the added full length daisy chain allow for so much versatility. I will be heading down to Aconagua soon using this as a summit pack. I've also gotten some Winter overnighters in with just this pack and not having to worry about taking a separate summit pack as this pack is light enough to be that pack as well. I've also gotten many days in touring with it and the ski carry makes it perfect for a quick rappel if needed. You can macgyver a snowboard onto it, but if you use a split, you can simply use the ski carry option too.  I haven't had any issue with the suspension system, even when fully packed out. I would definitely recommend this pack as it is not a one use pack, and can serve as a multitool pack for any and all alpine adventures.

Feel free to reach directly out with any and all questions!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Kelly Cordes shares his thoughts on the redesigned Ascensionist pack.
good pack for day trips
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: The vertical daisy chains allow for plenty to be added
With skis
Red straps were added for ski carry. Snowboard carry is also creatively possible as seen

I own several ascensionist packs, well pretty much every size, and these new ones are hands down, an improvement in some ways and lack in other ways. The 30L is an ideal size for pretty much everything, from a technical day ski tour, to an overnight summer trip. It is lightweight and the new material seems to be more durable than on the previous generation. I do miss the spindrift collar for when you are trying to get as much in it as you can, as it did keep the weather out. Also, compression straps would be nice, not necessarily for compressing the pack, but for holding skis for those needing some sort of ski carry system. I added some to mine that you can see in one of the pictures. Easy enough to do, but would be nice if if came with some sort of strap. Overall, it has been a great pack so far. I have used it extensively for the last 7 months, for those that have had durability concerns from the last generation. This includes multi day ski tours, overnight alpine trips, and technical ski mountaineering where the skis are on the pack a good share of the time. I can easily fit a probe, shovel, saw, full snow study kit, down jacket, first aid kit w/emergency tarp, an emergency sled, helmet, 30m rope, gloves, water, food, and other various items needed, all inside the pack for a general idea of what it is capable of.
