A few notes: this isn't intended to be a ski-weight winter jacket. It's an ultralight layer for those needing both weight savings and warmth in a three-season layer. I wore this as part of a layering system, with a mid-weight wool base and a rain/wind jacket to keep drafts out. I stayed comfortable most of the time and only moderately chilly (not dangerously cold) when temps dipped into the 20s. I had a down quilt I could have wrapped up in if it got any colder than that. Speaking of the quilt, this jacket was also part of my sleep system on cold nights, providing the hood that a quilt is missing. 

The word "system" is key for ultralight hikers. Everything needs to work together.  No single component needs to (or should!) work entirely on its own.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: The jacket is light and easy to pack when I go backpacking.  It also does a great job at keeping me warm.  The small is a little snug, so I would suggest on possibly going up a size if you plan on layering.

Love this jacket. Its light-weight but ridiculously warm and breathes well. This is my go to jacket to throw on anytime I head out the door for the evening, going hiking or up into the mountains. My only beef is the medium is a bit more snug then I would like but the large is way to broad in the shoulders so I opted for the tighter fitting medium.

This jacket is so warm and so light. It has become my new favorite jacket. It folds up into nothing and is perfect for camping and rock climbing. It's nice that you can fit multiple layers underneath too. Definitely one of the best purchases I've made.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: My wife uses this constantly in cooler weather - everything from walking to work, after running, wearing at work, etc. More compressable than other jackets, she can pack it and take it anywhere. She loved it better than the others, including the regular Patagonia down jacket. It's no belay jacket for ice climbing, but it has met all of her winter needs.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have a couple of primaloft jackets and love them.  I've been wanting to try down cause everyone says its warmer.  It was hard to resist the sale price and the vibrant purple color.  I've used it a few times.  So far, the plumage hasn't found its way out of the fabric, nor does it show through.  The fit is perfect ...enough for a heavy base layer with a vest underneath.  The hood is effective against cold winds.  The only caveat is the upper arms could use a tad more room or stretch.  I definitely feel it, but only at near full flex of my biceps.  I am by no means a powerlifter, but my arms are on the muscular side.  Aside from that, kept me warm in the 40's with a light base layer.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: It's hard to believe this is 800 fill.  Doesn't seem that warm.  Loved the color and fit true to size.  Noisy fabric, like a plastic bag over you.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: i love puffies! this makes a great layering piece under a shell, but also great on its own.  It's a bit noisier of a jacket but it breaks in.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I think this jacket converted me to a Patagonia fan for life. It has become the ultimate staple in my wardrobe. As a layering piece or on its own, I take it with me just about everywhere. 

It is super light, low profile, and stuffs into just about any bag. And I like that the design is a bit different and more modern than your typical down jacket. I have this in black, and it has a nice little sheen to it that I think makes it more fun. Added bonus, I've received more compliments on this jacket than anything else I own!

This number has been with me three years now and it looks just as good today as it did the day bought it - and it has traveled with me errywhere. Seriously awesome. I'm still not sure how it's so durable, it seems like it would rip easily but doesn't. Compare this to a LuLu down jacket I've had for about the same amount of time that will tear if it catches anything.  

There is one tiny, tiny hole that I need to patch. Even with the tiniest of a tear, it does leak feathers, so when you buy the jacket I'd recommend snagging repair tape to keep on hand with you just in case, especially if you plan to wear it a lot on its own (instead of as a layering piece). 

If you plan to wear this more as a layer, I'd recommend going with the sans hood version. As with most jackets, I do wish it was just a tad bit longer.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This little number and I have been through a lot. It kept me warm on a glacier, on chilly fall nights backpacking, and in a scary rescue scenario. I have repaired this jacket with dental floss, suture thread, and tenacious tape. And now I am on my second jacket! It's too delicate for a belay jacket unless you are very careful, but it is perfect for backpacking. The down does not leak from the jacket through the seams. I can layer under this jacket easily without having to size up. The DWR finish does wear out over time and I have not figured out a good way to replenish the finish. I am afraid that a spray on product might damage the loft of the down feathers.
All in all, this jacket is perfect for backpacking and perhaps climbing if you are careful. It packs well and is of top quality. Don't lose the stuff sack!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I own 1 Nano puff Hooded Insulated Jacket and 2 Nano Puff Pullovers in my usual size small (I'm 5'3 and fluctuate between 120-125 in weight). Worn them all to death. 
 
Love this jacket. It's warmer than the Nanos, and roomier in the sides and arms.  With the Nanos the most I can get away with underneath is a Patagonia Cap 3 or 4, or a typical button down shirt if I'm kicking around town. I could fit anything from a wool sweater to a hoodie underneath this guy. Rad.  That said, hoping this holds up as well as the Nanos.

I have always been a huge fan of Patagonia products, and so it's no surprise that this jacket definitely did not disappoint. Not only is it one of the lightest jackets that I own (mere 8.9), but this down also kept me extremely well insulated. I've worn it for winter hiking, climbing days at the crag, and camping and backpacking trips. In extremely cold temps, I throw a hardshell over the top and it provides the perfect layering balance. It's so comfy that I even wear it around town just for the hell of it. The jacket is compact as well. On backpacking trips I'm able to stuff it in the included self-fabric stuffsack and throw it in with the rest of my gear. I am 5'3, 130 pounds with a shorter torso and the medium fit well and gave me plenty of room to layer. Overall, simply the best. I would highly recommend!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: The coral color of this jacket is gorgeous, BUT the black feathers inside the jacket show through to the outside and look like black grease spots all over the jacket!  Even for $240, this is unacceptable.  Not BackCountry's fault, but Patagonia should get their act together.  Come on!  Don't they look at the jacket before mass producing it?  The jacket is still functional, just looks pretty bad.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5:
Hard to take this off it feels so nice!
Fits true for Patagonia.
I am 5.7 118 lbs with a 34 A bust and long arms. XS is a perfect fit everywhere but the sleeves for me so I usually size up to a Small in Patagonia jackets, little more room everywhere else with a good length in the sleeves, leaving room to layer underneath if needed.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I wanted to love this item. I did. But I feel like I always ended up putting it on and then switching to something else. For me it's an awkward in between a base layer and a mid layer so I never reallly know what to do with it. The zipper is also really long. The sweater is good quality, I just don't think I have a lot of use for it.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This jacket is perfect for fall and spring weather. I have used it for climbing, hiking, and is cute for just casual wear. Also great for layering in the winter months.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I have always ordered Smalls in Patagonia pull overs and can wear base layer under.  This one fits odd.  "plenty of room except the shoulders" are tight.  The cut is not like the others.   There is simply not enough room over the cap of the shoulder, makes it uncomfortable.    I am 5'3  111 lbs and not a broad shouldered girl and really needed to replace my worn out previous version.  Very disappointed.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Great color and well made, but it didn't fit (too big).  I would try an XS, but the sleeve length was perfect on the small, so I'm thinking they might be too short on an XS.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: This is the warmest/most versatile  base layer I've found. It is perfect for colder days skiing, but  also doubles as a great hiking and camping fleece. I purchased a small which fits comfortably yet tight enough to keep me cozy.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Great shirt- 5'6" and 130- got a medium and it's perfect!

I needed a technical fleece to run outside in Maine in the winter. This fleece is amazing! I didn't think it would keep me warm, but it absolutely does. I wear a long sleeve underneath and have been able to withstand temperatures of 15 degrees. I purchased the lupine color and it's a gorgeous color. I purchased the medium and it fit my 5'5" frame 124 lbs.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Bought this for my momma because I absolutely love mine. It's super durable, stretchy, and moisture managing. I sweat my ass off in it whether I'm backcountry skiing or alpine climbing. The exterior is very durable, and the grid fleece interior wicks moisture fast so I can stay warm and comfy in sweaty situations.
My Mom's been wanting an R1 for a while now and finally got this for Christmas. Needless to say, she loves it. It has a great fit and is very comfortable.

This is the perfect all around go to sweater. It is incredible soft and comfortable. It has great movement so I love wearing it during my outdoor activities. It's that perfect layering piece that everyone needs in their closet. I wear this sweater all the time. whether it be to go out hiking or to just hang out in my living room. Would definitely recommend. I normally wear a small and this fit true to size.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: The R1 is my go to layering piece for outdoor activities when temps drop below 50.  I'll wear it over a synthetic t-shirt for hiking in late fall or under other layers as it gets near or below freezing.  It's great for hiking, x-c skiing, or pretty much anything you'll do outdoors, and also looks nice enough to wear out to a casual dinner at the end of the day.  I've had two of them in black for several years now and just got the Lupine and the Epic Blue, which are both great colors.  The older ones I have seemed to run a bit small and I used to have to order a size up, but I've found the two new ones run truer to size.  I normally wear a large and the large R1 fits perfectly.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This layer is perfect for chilly Indian Creek days/ desert nights around the campground.

Bought this for my wife who had the following feedback:
Once again, I am so happy with a Patagonia product.  They never disappoint.  This shirt is not only light and comfortable, but it's much warmer than I expected.  I have worn this shirt skiing, snowshoeing, alone, under a shell, over a tank top, camping and around town.  Perfect for any outing.  The only complaint I have is that this is not a feminine fit, it's a pretty straight fit.  I purchased the green shirt and love the color.  Will continue to purchase more Patagonia product.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Bought this pullover for my daughter who was going to climb Mt Shasta. I have one and it is the perfect weight for an active lifestyle.  It is definitely an "athletic" fit and we both ordered one size up to allow an extra layer up under it.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love the R1 - I have four pullovers, a pullover hoody, and a jacket. The fit of the R1 for 2014/2015, however, is strange. The small is way too big in every aspect. The extra small is unusually long in the back, and the sleeves are too long. I'm 5'4, 110 and normally wear the small because I like to layer. The current colors are great - arctic mint and Tyrian purple - but the way the R1 fits lately is a little disappointing.

I'm a big fan of these, they are durable enough to wear hiking through thick brush, but comfortable and stylish enough to wear around town. I've worn these in combination with gaiters grouse hunting and they far outperformed my old setup with generic hiking pants. I've also work these under waders, and while most pants bunch up or have pinch points along seams, these were comfortable. 

I did find them a bit long but i have shorter legs.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
These pants are comfortable and stretchy. The picture makes them look thick and canvassy but are not. If you are familiar to Kuhls Renegade long pants they are similar in thickness. They have two front hand pockets, one zippered rear pocket on the right butt cheek (wished it was on the left side instead) and one zippered pocket on the right leg (ahh there's a pattern here). There are two closure buttons and a zippered fly. I've worn them backpacking, hiking with my dog, rock climbing (tons of room in the crotch) and just hanging out at my favorite Cidery with my bro.
I would have given five stars but I just don't use the right pocket for anything.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Awesome pants for hiking, fly fishing and bird hunting.  The double fronts do a good job taking abuse but the pockets suck.  One pocket on the back and one cargo pocket.  The back pocket is on of those interior zipper pockets.  It would be better off with two jeans-style pockets on the back, no zippers.  

Close but not quite perfect
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Who designs "field" pants and only puts back and cargo pockets on the right side? I'm not sure if it was a hipster intent on looking cool or an attempt to cut costs, but when I work in the field I like access to a full set of back and cargo pockets because I put stuff in them. The pants are well-sewn and the fit is decent but those missing pockets are a fatal flaw in my view.

I bought these for my father-in-law who is an avid bird hunter. He has reported they are the best pants he has ever worn. Perfect for long days in the field as they are lightweight and moveable. Two thumbs-up.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This is my first pair of Patagonia pants and they are perfect for days on the trail. I can wear my compression pants underneath with no problem. They are comfortable and durable. I really like the fit and feel. I'll probably buy a second pair in another color too.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: These pants are perfect for weekend adventures and hikes. I was looking for a pair of pants that could hold up to bush wacking and multi-day hiking. They fit the bill great! Giving a 4/5 due to the fit being a little baggier than I had hoped, but not terrible.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Another great product from Patagonia. Provides protection from thick brush, burs and anything out find yourself in. Fit is loose and comfortable, has stretch on the waste and belt loops. Great breathability and movement.

May look a bit more orange to some in the photo, but it definitely appears red in person. I'm 5'8" and roughly 165 lbs and the large was a snug, but comfortable fit. Great layering piece for a day on the hill or a day at the office. Has held up well after a handful of days inbounds and out, as well as a dozen or more washes. Can't go wrong with this Patagonia pick up.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Im never disappointed with Patagonia. This R1 is a great jacket, and Its perfect for the breezy Autumn air.  Its a comfortable fit. I have absolutely zero complaints about the product.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Awesome mid-layer if bulky things under your shell bother you. Super thin (for a midlayer) and very ergonomic to your torso. Super cozy too.

The R1 holds true, warmth without weight. I'm a huge fan of layering, while mixing and matching I figured out the R1 out performed most of my thicker under layers (close second to the Better Sweater) quite incredible how warm and movable it is, I wear it as a ski layer, casual layer....hint: I wear it everyday..........worth the price to feel this nice!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is my go to piece for intense aerobic activity in colder weather. I usually wear it under a light soft shell jacket or rain jacket. Always warm and breathable even when running up a mountain face. Bought 6 years back and it has withstood the test of time.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Bought originally as a warmer layer for my year guiding surf trips in the tropics, and when I returned to climbing it served as a great layer for windy or cooler pitches. It fits snug against the body allowing you to forget its there. Well built it has held up against cracks,  off-widths, limestone, everything without ripping or tearing. It may just be that im a dirtbag, but it also doubles as my nice but casual city layer. Great piece, lots of memories.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I started replacing worn or lost essential gear this year and an R1 layer was an easy to replace piece I have missed.  I went for the full zip instead of the pullover.  I like the easy on/off of the full zip but I kinda miss the low front profile/ bulk of the pullover.  I'm almost 6'1" and about 190.  The fit is stretchy, and snug but not tight. It's longer  overall than my old pullover and comes a few inches past my pants and the arms stay put even when climbing.  This  is nice when standing but the full zipper makes weird waves when sitting if you are worried about your photo pose while driving or overall bulk of layers.  
 The layer is perfect for cool weather. I use it for everything from an under-shell layer for morning spring skiing to a quick layer in the shade climbing or cool-ish evenings.  It sheds moisture super fast and washes easily.   I wear it to work over business casual in a medical office.  R1 is bomb proof.  I found my last one on the side of a mountain after a spring melt and it had been there a while. I wore it for nearly everything including off widths for about 5 years until somehow I lost it.  I expect this one will last just as long.  It is similar to a merino wool sweater except tougher and only a little bulkier to pack. It also makes a great travel piece.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Bought a black, size medium R1 on sale.  I was going to pay full price so the savings made it even better. I'm thin at 6' tall and 150 lbs and the R1 is pretty snug around my torso. It does take getting used to. The pockets are higher up on the body and it does feel like your elbows are flared. The quality is tough to beat though. 
The zippers are silky smooth all around and the stiching looks like it will last a long time. This is my second R1 and I have owned many other brands - north face, marmot, Eddie Bauer. 
None of them come close to the fit and finish of Patagonia
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I purchased this jacket not too long ago and took it out for a spin on a day that was fairly brisk (start of the hike was in the 40*s F) I had this, a merino 1 silkweight base layer, and a nano puff vest, and I felt perfectly comfortable the entire time. Beyond the function, this jacket also looks pretty cool and could definitely be worn causally.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I'm an avid climber and cyclist.  The R1 is perfect for scaling mountains, but also for anything else you might end up doing--including hitting the town after cragging or your last century.  For a fleece, it does a great job at breaking the wind as well, if your using it as a jacket, but is thin and light enough as to not be restricting as a midlayer.  The thumb holes are awesome for chilly belays, waiting for your third, but also don't get in the way when you don't want to throw on some gloves on a ride to the grocery store.  I have a North Face fleece that is twice as heavy and thick and this fleece is assuredly warmer.  My wife likes to point out that the bright blue, while super ugly, is good for being seen while on the bike.  Probably the only feature I haven't hit is the awesome wicking power.  Sweating up a storm on that sunny face figuring out that crux move?  No problem--the R1 will wick all that away, leaving you dry and comfy for that next shady belay.  Also, it is pretty comfy with the sleeves pushed up (and they stay up).  I'd buy it again and again.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: it was 1 pound 4 ounces, not 12 ounces.
I bought this hat to wear while running during sunny days. I love the breath-ability and how quickly it dries.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Been looking for a hat which wouldn't turn my hair/head into a sweaty mess. This one is great. Breath-ability is top notch, and it also doesn't lose it's shape when it is stuffed in a bag, which is an issue I had with the other hats from Patagonia.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Super versatile and stylish hat, I have taken it everywhere and worn it for tons of different activities. The mesh breathes great, the coolmax liner wicks very well, and it never loses it's shape.
function as towel, build no stain, foldable to keep in pocket. so this is perfect for runners.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Is great for running, i used for trail running and hiking, to go to the beach, washed all the time and still like new.

Having a 4 year old is hard, especially one as strong-willed as mine is (just like her mother).  Little did I know when I brought home matching camo Patagonia hats tonight that it will be the daddy-daughter equivalent of a best friendâs necklace.  She loved them so much she insisted on sleeping with both of our new hats by her bed.  I appreciate any opportunity to win as a dad.  I recommend this hat to all customers, but make sure you buy one for your BFF too!
Hit me up if you need help picking some out!

This is a vast improvement over the traditional trucker hat. Firm but soft bill make it a highly packable hat. Classic trucker shape. Good breathability. The part that is still lacking for me is the actual part of the hat, the sweat band, that sits against the skin. All hats irritate my skin especially when sweating. This hat is an improvement but not nearly as good as the visor equivalent. So the search for the perfect hat continues...

-update-
Found the perfect trucker hat. Doesn't have the soft brim for easy pacakbility but has a vastly improved sweat band that doesn't irritate my skin and can accommodate my large noggin. Headsweats classic trucker hat. Give it a try.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This hat is a throwback for sure! The breathability and coolmax headband make this hat great for running or hiking on hot summer days.  You can't go wrong with a retro-inspired hat that's actually technical!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I like wearing hats while doing anything outside for sun protection/hair management. This is the best trucker hat option for any activity that might induce sweat as it is absorptive, lightweight, soft, and comfortable. It is also great for getting wet as it dries quicker than cotton truckers. Most common uses are trail running, hiking, and kayaking.  The white mesh tends to get dirty easily but the hat is washable and cleans up well.  It's got the patagonia logo so the quality is great and the style is both classic and timeless.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: My to go running hat.  Flexible/soft bill, light, breathes and absorbs sweat off my bald head when I run.  Also can be tossed in the laundry and washes up well.  Fits the bill for me.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Pros: lightweight, looks nice

Cons: bill won't hold curvature so not very comfortable, white mesh discolors with sweat easily, tall crown
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Got this in the howling turquoise color.  It's bright, and durable, and the bill never gets bent out of shape, no matter how many times it gets buried at the bottom of my bag.  I've worn it hiking, camping,  at the beach, and just because I'm having a bad hair day.  I get compliments on it all the time.  It throws off a nice shade (the underside of the brim is black), so if you're sitting in the bright sun you can still see without needing sunglasses.  Great hat.

Duckbill trucker hats are the best.  It's a little bit expensive for a hat, but definitely worth it.  They're made out of different material compared to patagonia's other cotton trucker hats and the bill is flexible so you can shove it in your bag and the bill will pop back into place (though haven't kept it smashed for very long).  Also the material makes this hat dry super quick.  

I own two different colors and I literally wear them everyday during my morning runs.  To me this is honestly the perfect running/trail running hat.  I've ran numerous marathons and half-marathons in them, they're just so lightweight and breathable.

Pro-tip: After every run I rinse my hat off in the bathroom sink and let it soak in the sink for a little bit with some baking soda, and just hang it to dry to keep the stink out.  I washed my first hat in the washing machine and it caused the front panel to separate from the back a little bit.  Still perfectly useable and you can't notice it unless you take the hat off, but I was sad when that happened.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Fits great, very lightweight and breathable. Very comfortable with a classic style.

These hats are the best. I wear them running and hiking on the trail because they are lightweight, suck up the sweat, dry quickly, and are machine washable.

I wear them everywhere else (work, out with friends, anywhere) because they are comfortable and look sharp like a classic Patagonia Trucker. 

Highly recommended.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I live in hats and this is my new go to. I have only had it for about a week, but I don't think I've taken it off yet. So far it has proved to be a great looking hat with great performance on the trail while running and out cruising on my bike around the city. I personally have one of the lighter colored versions and thought for sure that it would get scuzzy right away as I tend to obsessively adjust my hats on my head and my hands are usually dirty when I'm out on the trail, but I have been pleasantly surprised. I would recommend this hat to any person who is looking for a functional trucker hat that performs just as well in the bar as it does on the trail.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This thing is great. The bill has a moldable feel to it so I like to tilt it to whatever side I need if side hilling on a trail for a while. Additionally it dries out really fast when soaked through with sweat, and water.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Great style with the print on this one! I have 2 others so comfy it's the trucker hat for this decade!

I have a tiny pea head and often find that trucker hats make my melon look way weird. That is until I discovered the Patagonia Duckbill Trucker. I bought this hat specifically for running and hiking and after a year's worth of use, it's been nothing short of awesome and everything I needed in a hat. The Supplex panel dries quick and the sweatband wicks away moisture while the adjustable rear buckle is super easy to adjust and doesn't cause any unsavory pressure points. The bill itself is generous and keeps the sun out of my face while I run. Seriously awesome hat! Oh, and I've thrown in the washing machine after it got pretty gnarly last summer and it was totally fine. Air dried it and made sure the bill didn't get warped.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I bought this hat based on its slick look, and airy mesh sides. Little did I know it would become glued to my head after wearing it for ONE DAY. I haven't taken it off since, and probably won't even try to peel it off until it becomes a manky pos.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I use this backpack for pretty much everything - including hiking, work and traveling. Iï¸t folds up extremely small so you can pack Iï¸t as an extra bag to use later while traveling. Thereâs also a laptop pocket in the back and are a second set of straps incase you want to carry Iï¸t as a shoulder bag rather than a backpack which i like.

Love the colors, love the size, I can fit my laptop in it perfectly but love that it's not a dedicated laptop bag. I love that it zippers closed at the top rather then toggle or straps and I love that it has handles to carry it like a tote.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This bag is magical like many Patagonia bags. It packs super small, but serves a great function. I took it as a day bag to Italy for 2 weeks and it was a tank. It ate giant pieces of salami and San Pelegrino, held layers and all of my personal effects (in a blackhole cube of course!) and still had room for more. The padding works great and the straps are very comfortable. I liked being able to stow the traps and waist belt away and use this as a tote, and it doesn't even drag on the ground! 

Best part of this is it's ability to hide messes and clean up well: We took a long train ride with a bag full of groceries and I discovered a day later that all of the berries we had bought got squished and mixed with salami and salad greens and fermented, yet there wasn't a drop on the outside. A quick rinse in the sink and some inverted air time and it didn't even smell. This would be a great diaper bag OR farmers market bag, but not both!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I think this is a very versatile bag. But mine arrived packed in its stowable pocket, and when I unfurled it, it was terribly wrinkly. Any sense of whether these wrinkles will fall out? So far they haven't.

I bought this for a trip to Central America, and I couldn't be happier.  It's super lightweight so it's great for carrying anything you'd need for a day at the beach. Arguably the best feature on the pack is the back foam pad, which doubles as a seat cushion if there's nowhere convenient to sit. When you need to store the bag in a carry-on or suitcase, you've also got the ability to zip it into it's small external organizer.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I bought this as a birthday gift for my runner son.  He is somewhat of a minimalist so he insisted he doesn't need this and that I return it.  I was very tempted to keep this for myself as it is so light and looks very comfortable for trail runs.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I initially bought this for hiking, but I use it for MTBing now as well. It comes with a 2L reservoir, which is perfect, though I do find the hose is a bit too long (personal preference I suppose). My FAVORITE thing about this pack is that if you have nothing in it, its incredibly low profile... but it can also hold a surprising amount of stuff. For perspective, I hiked Timp here recently (half day) and fit a light jacket, water bottle, chacos and snacks in without issue... in addition to the full 2L reservoir. My iPhone 6 fits securely into the chest pockets. I don't trail run, so can't speak to that portion. But for what I do, I'll never need another pack. I love you, Patagonia.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Pretty close to ideal in terms of balance of features and simplicity. Fits close to the body and feels weightless on the trail. After using it for a year, I just noticed it has a whistle on a lanyard in the right mesh pocket (bonus!).
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I bought this vest/pack for those quick trail runs when you need a couple of the essentials but don't want to have a larger pack bouncing all around.

Size SM/M was a perfect fit for me (5'2" and 120 lbs) and actually carries a lot more than I expected. Only complaint is that the front mesh pockets aren't quite big enough to hold a cell phone but hey, forces you to not have such easy access and to enjoy the atmosphere around you!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I had written this pack off as just a running piece at first, and didn't think a pack with no waist straps would do well mountain biking until a buddy of mine started riding with one and raving about it.  

This is my new favorite riding pack, and one of the most comfortable I've used.  The chest straps have two ways to tighten down, and the packs sits really well even over bumpy terrain.  Not having a waist strap is actually a great thing, and makes the pack super comfortable.  

I've always liked packs with front pockets on the waist straps, but the pockets on the main straps here are even sweeter.  Plenty of room for gels, chewies and bars, and super easy access whether you're on or off the bike.  

It is still designed as a running pack so the interior has just a hydration bladder pouch and the rest of the pack is open.  A little tough for a biker to get used to since there's no dedicated tools, a pump, or co2, but I got used to it pretty quick.  Finally the exterior stretchy pocket is great for food or an extra layer and actually holds everything pretty well despite not having a secure closure at the top.
I tried to use mine for the first time and found out the water bladder had a hole in it.  I didn't even get to use it.

nice snug fit to the body with very little bounce. Living in New Hampshire with our wet spring/fall weather  im a little concerned with the top loading drawstring closure.My cell phone fit nicely in the zippered storage pocket on the front.Stretchy pockets each held a 10oz water bottle.First time out with this vest i put in 14 miles of trail/dirt road.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
Overall the pack has nice adjustment.  It sits close to the body and doesn't bounce, barely know it is there once it is on.  The bladder is easy to fill and clean.  I would say this pack is good for medium to long runs or for lightweight hiking where time isn't an issue.  

The lower pockets on the front are good for holding bars or gels but not much else.  I did have my phone in there with the elastic tight so it wouldn't come out.  Not much can fit in the zippered pocket.  Also the key pocket in the back has a clip for a key, but the key will not fit in the pocket (maybe it isn't suppose to).
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Patagonia designer Evan takes us through the new Fore Runner Vest/Pack

Perfect on-route pack for multipitch rock climbing; frustratingly small on approach. Expensive and never goes on sale.
I really wanted to love this pack. I researched and tried on several packs shopping for a multipitch day pack and this one disappeared on my back- super comfy, I felt I would reach for it enthusiastically. I love the handle, the rope strap and buckle, and the simple drawstring closure. Tough, no fuss. And it is perfect on-route. It carries what you need and you pretty much forget it's there.
But it is just so small on approach, particularly for trad. I either have to wear my harness with gear clanging around, frankenstrap stuff to the outside of the pack, or both. You just can't carry a day's worth of personal stuff (layers, snacks, approach shoes, water) and a day's worth of climbing gear without turning into a junk show. 18-20L would be enough.
I could give it 4 stars but I am probably going to return it so I don't think more than 3 is appropriate. Bummer. It's so close to a killer pack.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: My gym bag in the winter and my multi pitch bag during the season. Very simple, durable, light design. It has everything you need and nothing more. Fits tight and snug to your back so you're never battling a pack trying to throw you around.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
This pack really hugs your back while climbing.  I found that I could totally move freely with it, to the point that I could forget I was even wearing a pack.  It's night and day vs. other packs that feel like they "slosh" around, pulling you off balance.

I also really like the rope strap and the overstuffable top.   It feels like you can add a few liters for the approach and then vanish them once gear is racked on your harness.  However, weight is carried on your shoulders, with an insubstantial waistbelt and sternum strap serving only to hug the bag to your body, so don't pack it too heavy.

The outer pocket on the back fits most guidebooks as well, making a quick reference easy.  The internal sleeve just fits a 3L bladder snugly.

My only wishes are (1) that the outer pocket on the back had some sub-pockets so I could organize small things for easier access; and (2) that the hole for passing the bladder drinking valve out of the pack were larger.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: here is a helpful video!

I just received this in the mail and can tell it is worth every penny. I am upgrading from the rei flash 18 which disintegrated quickly after regular multipitch climbing. 

Also, let it be known that I usually stay away from patagonia just because it's patagonia. But this bag is extremely good. The material seems very scratch resistant and durable, it has sturdy loops for hanging on anchor, and a rope strap. Perfect.

07172016 update: used on many long routes now. And I'm buying another one. So good! Let it scrape against rock in the chimney on the casual route on the diamond, not a scratch on it. Did I mention the rope strap?
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This pack was awesome! I had the pleasure of multi-pitching in Red Rock with it -- this is a pic of the pack hanging out at the anchors of pitch 2 on Big Bad Wolf :D

I spent a long time researching and trying to find the best summit/multipitch bag to use. I found the linked and decided to try it out on my week long trip to Red Rock. I couldn't be happier with this bag!!! It is perfect and is everything I was looking for. 16L is just big enough for water, Snacks and a warm layer. It has a built in area for a platypus style water system. It also have two great zipper compartments. The shape of the bag sits high off my harness and also is low profile so it doesn't interfere when I carry a rack. There are two haul style handles that work great to hook it to the anchor and since the top is draw string it's easy to access when I'm belaying. My favorite feature however is the ability to carry a rope over the top. I dislike carrying a rope as a backpack especially if you already are wearing a backpack and this bag makes it super easy. I love this bag and am super excited to use it more!!!!!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: '...and Patagonia added gear loops to attach the cams and draws you don't need for the next pitch.'  In the climbing vernacular 'gear loops' are located on the waist-belt of a harness or climbing pack. They are designed for 'easy reach'  racking of 'draws and hardware. The Linked Pack's waistbelt does not have gear loops. What the pack does have are twelve, small webbing loops to which one can attach accessory or bungee cord for lashing things to the exterior. (You wouldn't want to try and coax gear off those tiny loops mid-pitch!)  Patagonia doesn't refer to these as 'gear loops' as that would be misleading. Anyway...great little pack. Simple, functional, durable and light.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I think this is a wonderful pack for multipitch climbing with a simple yet elegant design. Burly construction with tough fabric, and I'm digging the new roll-up closure system at the top of the pack that all Patagonia packs seem to utilize these days. 

What I dislike about the pack is the fact that the tiny gear loops on the side of the pack are minuscule that they would only be able to accommodate CAMP Nano 22 sized carabiners. Furthermore, I'm unable to fit the spout and hose of a Platypus hydration bladder through the bladder outlet on the back of the pack. Hence the reason I give it 4/5 stars. 

In case people are curious, you can easily fit a 15" macbook book pro sized laptop into this pack along with a ton of other odds and ends.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Didn't think I would use this before next ski season, but it's proven to be a great addition. While designed for climbers, I've used it extensively for cycling this spring. Size is perfect for a shell, nalgene, tools, and an extra layer. Outside zip pocket is huge - runs the full length of the pack. Inside zip pocket for small stuff. Another pocket to hold a bladder, and a hook for your keys too. The external "lash," points are practical too ! Waist belt is easily removed if not needed. Originally I ordered the grey, but returned it! The webbing handles and trim are WHITE - I mean bright white! Exchanged it for the red color and am quite happy! A bit more practical! Looking forward to ski/snowboard season - should be ideal for lift served areas!
column8: I've used it several times

Guidewater pants are legit, light like you are wearing nothing but tough enough for when you kneel down to cast on some tricky flat water trout. Quick wicking keeps you dry all day. Recommend for all summer wet wading days. They’re stylish enough to rock off the river too!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Light and well constructed.  I decided to return them as they just didn't fit me as I wanted with my 34" waist.  The medium would have been great travel pants but were a bit tight in the thigh for activity.  The large was comfortable just a bit loose.  A belt would have fixed that and would have been fine for hiking, fishing but felt a little messy for running around town in.
I have used it a couple of times for hiking and a couple of other times for a stroll around the city during fall. It's a keeper!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I wear them all the time whether it's around town, hiking, on the boat or under waders, they don't bunch or ride up. Great light-weight pant for all reasons in the spring, summer and fall!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have been looking for a lightweight, cool (temp) pant primarily for fly fishing, but versatile enough to wear around. This pant fits the bill.  I love the Patagonia Guidewater pant for all of these reasons. I have used in the drift boat as well as for wet wading and they look good enough to wear around town for post-fishing activities. The DWR is fantastic and the pants are light enough to avoid overheating in the summer sun. The fit is nice with relaxed cuffs. I typically wear a 33 or 34 in waist with a 32 in inseam and the Medium fits perfectly

column5: Light, comfortable, and extremely effective at retaining heat. Love this vest. It's great for everything from cold-weather camping/trekking to breezy spring nights. I highly recommend.

column5: Materials, features, and details are spot on. Ended up returning it anyway. I'm a medium in pretty much everything Patagonia, and found the medium to be smaller than expected. Tried the large, but it was true to size. Seems like a fantastic product, as long as the sizing works for you.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I never ski tour without the nano vest.  The synthetic insulation keep you warm even if you've sweated through it, but still packs up easily into the backpack.  The outer material is tough enough to shuck willows without tearing but still incredibly light and even repels water a bit with the DWR treatment.   The fit is athletic without being form fitting.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Been wanting a vest in my gear Arsenal and finally pulled the trigger on this bad boy. Super stylish and keeps your trunk warm and comfy! Have had nothing but positive compliments since I've worn it. Nano-Air products are some of Patagonia's best offerings and getting it @ the end of the season sale for a super low price was too good to pass up! Backcountry got it to me super fast! Goatworthy!!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I own a number of different Patagonia vests.  This one is my favorite.  I love the warmth in such a light weight.  And yet it's still very breathable.  I've worn it on the slopes and in the office with no complaints.

column5: I found the fit to be very strange.  I am usually between a L and M.  I bought the L and it was fine around the shoulders, but way too big through the torso.  I tried on a M and it was too tight.  I then tried out the Nano Puff vest and the L fit like normal Patagonia gear.  Be sure you try it on!

column5: This vest is the most comfortable article of clothing I have.  It keep you warm but is very breathable.  Ask my girlfriend I have a hard time not wearing it every day.  Great for skiing, hiking and even formal enough to wear to the office.  Hands down best vest out there.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Corey from Patagonia shares his thoughts on the new Nano Air Vest

After literally months of searching for a warm but stylish winter jacket, I can finally stop!  I've returned several others, done hours of research, tried on tons in stores ... This is IT.  Super warm (tried it on in the house yesterday and literally started sweating; wore it outside with one light layer in 20s this morning).  Flattering feminine fit (but not too big in the chest, often a prob for me).  I have other Patagonia jackets and tops and they tend to be boxy/shapeless on me - not this one! Long sleeves and hits at hips with a little more "tail" coverage in back.  Puffy/cozy but not bulky.  Collar is warm (no need for a scarf) and flattering.  Took me a minute to find the rest of the hood (zipped away neatly) but when I did, was surprised to find a full warm puffy hood (had expected a thin shell hood); was able to tuck it back away easily.  Got the Mogul Blue color which is more of a nice dark aqua.  I am a medium and got medium - there's still room for a sweater underneath but as noted, the shape is flattering.  And it's on a great sale!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I love this jacket!!  Its super warm and cozy but also looks super cute.  The collar is awesome.  The fabric has a really nice buttery feel... super quality.  I'm stoked!!

column5: Got this jacket for my lady. She is 5"3 103 and the xs fits her perfectly. This is her new go to jacket for winter time. The stash a way hood future is great to. And she really likes the slim fit o the jacket. Overall great jacket if you want to keep warm while looking good!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I bought this jacket for my fiancee but would like to share her impressions along with some of my own opinions.  She already has a Patagonia Down Sweater (size XS) and is a big fan.  It is one of her most used pieces in the fall, winter, and spring (we live in NY/CT, so there is a long season for puffy jackets).  I suggested that she get a warmer puffy with a hood to use as an alternative to her winter parka.  She first tried the Patagonia Ultralight Down Hoody (size S) but found the cut unflattering, slightly too big, and probably not as warm as desired.

Fast forward a few weeks, and we decided to do a side by side comparison of the Downtown Loft Down Jacket and the Hi-Loft Hooded Down Sweater.  Here is my analysis of the key differences:

Downtown vs Hi-loft:
Runs small vs normal  (S vs XS were about the same size)
Form fitting vs more boxy
More subtle branding vs standard Patagonia logo
Heavier vs lighter (due to beefier outer shell material, it seems)

That analysis is not meant to say that one jacket is better than the other but merely that they probably have different target users.  The Downtown Jacket, as the name would suggest, is a better fit for folks who want a more stylish jacket for staying warm around town that will also work really well for staying warm on outdoor activities.  I could very much see this jacket used as a ski jacket on dry days (or under a shell with wet snow).  The Hi-Loft also seems like a great jacket but is more in line with Patagonia's traditional offering (and boxier cut).  

The hood stows away into the shawl collar.  After a first impression, this seems to be one of the best designed features of the jacket: the hood is large enough and seems to be quite warm, but when stowed away it helps turn the collar into a sturdy and warm shawl collar, which looks like it will really help keep in warmth and beat away wind without having to have the hood fully deployed.

Stay tuned for further impressions on this jacket.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: i am easily a medium on patagonia, often a small. This jacket was so tight I could not breath- but nice coat

We moved back to New England not too long ago from living in the south for awhile. I knew the first winter back would be brutal, so I researched extensively for a jacket. The Downtown Loft Jacket was the perfect match! 
I am tall, 5'10'' and it fits perfectly. There is plenty of length in the arms.  The bottom of the jacket hits the upper thigh. It is very slimming and most of all is so warm!! I honestly can not remember a time that I wasn't warm in it. 
I have washed it in cold water multiple times and put it in the dryer on low heat with a tennis ball to make it all fluffy again. It looks new each time.  
The only down side is that it does not do well in wet snow/sleet. I would expect that for a down jacket though.
I highly recommend the Downtown Loft Jacket and am so glad I made the right choice!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
When I was looking for a coat, I thoroughly researched reviews, articles, brands, quality, etc.  I was looking for a quality investment and something that would meet the following needs: 
- Warmth
     - Unpredictable Midwest weather (Iowa)
- Durability
     - Outdoor playtime with my dogs and hikes
- Style
     - I work in an office/professional environment

Based on my research, I kept getting pointed back to this particular coat, so I decided to take the plunge and make the purchase.  I ordered an XS (I'm 5'2", 115 lbs) and it fits like a glove!  The coat has a feminine cut, which was different from my old coat, so it felt a little snug on the first wear, but it was really just a matter of me getting used to the cut.  

Now, keep in mind I've only owned this coat for a little over a week, but so far this has been a win across the board!  I purchased this in black (goes with everything) and am able to wear mid-weight layers with ease -- dress shirts, blazers (albeit these make the coat a little more snug), thermals.  I've received several compliments at the office and feel that it looks even better in person and is professional looking (in case I bump into some executives -- doesn't look disheveled and bulky like my old down coat was getting).  When out playing with my dogs, the hide away hood and neck/face cover is amazing for windy mornings!  The coat blocks wind well and gets warmer the longer you wear it, which also covered my warmth requirement.

Looking forward to seeing how well this coat does this winter!
column8: I've used it several times

Great jacket. The fabric feels very smooth and the collar is super stylish! I got the purple colour and it's a very nice tone — almost pearly finish.

It's pretty warm, I wore it today in -3 celsius with a long sleeved tshirt under and I was warm.

column5: It seems like such a simple idea to attach a fishing vest to a backpack like this, but this is honestly the first time I've seen this. I picked it up and was instantly impressed by how well made everything was and how truly waterproof the pack is.

I was super hype for this Patagonia backpack and fishing vest. I had originally planned to use the bag all the time, even for just my casual outings. I was wrong once I recieved the item. The bag is made with excellent material and is very high quality and durable, but it's just super small for casual backpacking. With that being said, it's made for fly fishing... And it plays the part well. I highly reccomend the backpack if you are fly fishing. If you are not, stay away. I accidentaly dropped the bag in a puddle, conpletely submerged. Guess what.... It disn't collext any water inside. It might as well be called waterproof. I use my tenkara rod holder in the water bottle pockets, and it's a little small. But with a regular fly eod tube, it would fit perfect. I love this thing and woukd recommend it to every fly fisherman.
Both my wife and I have this sweet vest/pack combo! It is absolutely amazing! More than worth the money!

I bought this pack to replace my chest pack which replaced my hip pack which replaced my vest... 
As you can see I have had a hard time with carrying my flies and gear. I never liked vests and so I began my search, the problem with the hip pack and the chest pack was there weren't as many pockets as a standard vest and no real ability to carry other gear. Nor were they as comfortable as a vest. I recently began going back to the vest because its the most versatile of the selections out there (for me). 
Out comes the Sweet Pack! Its a vest, its a back pack, its a vest pack!!! 
Really it is everything I need for a day hike in. I can put rain gear in it, I can put food in it, I can put wadders in it, I can put BEER in it. to top it off, I can convert it to just a vest and fish with it being very light. 
I think this is my longest review ever and its for a fly fishing pack. THATS HOW GREAT IT IS!

column8: I returned this product before using it

column5:
Reader's Digest Version: If you love the Fjord, you'll probably love the Heywood. Buuut, if you love soft and light flannel on the whole, you'll probably love the Heywood, too.

Non-Reader's Digest Version: Flannels are great, they're one of those things that you can't go wrong with. And the Heywood? You especially can't go wrong with. I love the Fjord, but have found that its thick and plush fabric isn't as comfy during cool summer evenings as I'd like it to be. Enter: The Heywood. 

The fabric is soft and thin, yet not paper thin. It's the perfect summer-weight flannel material - great for chilly mornings or evenings, or brisk, a/c laden offices. I love the pockets, they further differentiate the Heywood from the Fjord which is cool. 

As for the fit, the Heywood is a little more slim in the shoulders than the Fjord. However, the fit in the torso / waist is comparable to the Fjord. The cuffs (on the sleeves) are a little more slim-fitting, too, which is a nice touch as the giant cuffs on the Fjord was a pet peeve of mine. I can wear a 0 or 2 in Patagonia's button-up shirts, but often prefer the fit of the 2, so I went with the 2 per usual. I wear an XS in the rest of Patagonia's line, or Small if I want a little extra room. 

Bottom Line: this flannel is perfect for summer, fall, spring, and winter. It's not as paper thin as I was expecting, which I much prefer. It's a really nice alternative to the Fjord, so if you run hot or you prefer thinner flannels, the Heywood is your gal.

This is a great flannel! The 4 fits me well. I can definitely wear a 0 or 2 in my tops, but my shoulders require a 4 out of Patagonia's flannel and I prefer my shirts to be a looser fit. The pinion strip pattern is super cute! This is light weight and comfy for wearing around the house or as business casual (as someone else noted, flannel passes for business casual in ski towns :). The sleeves can easily be rolled up. Don't size down if you want to roll up your sleeves! I do prefer thicker, hardier flannels, but the trend these days for ladies flannel is to run lightweight, unfortunately. If you want a thicker weave, go for Patagonia's fjord flannel. LOVE that one.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Flannel seems to pass as ski-town business-caszh, which I took full advantage of this winter in Park City. The Heywood Flannel from Patagonia was a perfect addition to my winter wardrobe, usually consisting of various tech layers. It's warm and light, and fits me splendidly.

I took this flannel in a 6, versus a size 8 in the Fjord Flannel, which is a good deal thicker than the Heywood. The Heywood's cut allows it to look great both buttoned up or unbuttoned, over a dress or t-shirt. The Pinyon Stripe/Black was super versatile, too.

After 4 months of pretty consistent wear, the Heywood still looks as good as the day I bought it. I'll be looking to add a couple more to the collection next winter.
column8: I've put it through the wringer
