The length is perfect for us tall girls, 5'11".  I wish the pockets had zippers so you could actually zip your phone into the pocket, but it's ok. This will be a great jacket to layer for snow adventures. I bought the medium, my usual size for Patagonia, but the shoulders were too narrow. I exchanged for the large and it works, although the body of it is a little big for me...
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I am 5'2" tall 112 pounds and XS fits me perfectly. 
 It is so lightweight, it's like wearing air. Or feathers. Or nothing at all.  It'll pack up compactly- but I would just want to wear it.   I'm sure I'll get plenty of people feeling it. If that interests you at all-just buy this. From Backcountry.com - duh. They have fast shipping and fantastic customer service.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Lightweight and perfect for spring as a jacket- great for layering with a vest or heavier jacket for the colder months. Easy to pack. Got it in medium, ox blood red. Love the fit and color.

So I got this for my mother in the oxblood red and my mother doesn't stop about how beautiful the color is.  Says it keeps her warm and is her go to spring jacket.  Overall my mother is pleased its a good color and you have options, you can use it winter, fall or spring and still be comfortable.  Patagonia is a brand you can always count on to get the most out of what you want.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This is the perfect jacket for backpacking during spring months.  Light weight, warm and packs small.   Works well alone and also layers well underneath a shell.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is a thin jacket.  (aka shirt jacket)  I was surprised by this but  I love how warm this jacket is without any bulk.  I can easily stuff it in a bag while hiking or trecking around campus.  It is thin enough that bigger coats can layer over top for extremely cold outdoor adventures.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I got this jacket for my sister and she's loved it so far.  It's super lightweight and sleek, so it doesn't have that puffy look that some down jackets do.  She even took it on a ski trip to sun valley and the down survived the snow!Didn't even use a shell good DWR coating.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I was hesitant at first because this jacket is so thin, but it has suited me so well. Not only is it fashionable and super comfy, but it is pretty warm. I wouldn't wear this jacket skiing or anything, but to throw it on over a sweatshirt to go grab a beer or just walk around outside this jacket is perfect. I am 5'6 and 130 and got a size M and it fits perfectly over my sweatshirts. Would recommend this to everyone! Gonna buy my boyfriend the mens one soon!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Lightweight and very warm. High quality. Love it.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is the perfect lightweight jacket for chilly nights. I get cold easily and this jacket definitely kept me warm on some 30-degree nights in the mountains. It packs down easily which is great for camping and backpacking and it is not too puffy when on which I like as well. Very flattering fit. I typically wear a Medium and it fits true to size - I can add some extra layers underneath if needed.  I had been looking for a down jacket for a while and I am very happy with my purchase!! You can't really go wrong with Patagonia!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Words of wisdom from my mother:  

"My daughter gave this to me as a gift.  I usually wear a medium and it fits true to size.  I love the fact it has lots of warmth and  isn't puffy.  It will fold up into a small bag and you can put it in your purse if you get too hot.  Where I live it doesn't get extremely cold, but this coat keeps me nice and warm in all types of weather.  The fit gives a slimming look because it isn't so bulky."
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: As much as it sucks to have to wear these when it's rainy and miserable outside, my husband is SO thankful he has these pants. I have the women's version and love them. My husband loves the fit, and they keep him dry when he needs it too.
100% waterproof whilst being lightweight and comfortable. Got me through a 700km run no problem!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I don't love rainpants, but when you're outside in multi-day rain you really can't stay or get back to dry without them.  

These seem quite burly, although I've only used them hiking/light running.  Assuming the fabric matches the quality of Patagonia's Torrenshell top, this should last a good long time.  

Pictured Tom, during our run across Iceland.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Held up to 2 weeks of rain and more rain in the southern alps of New Zealand as well as other soggy backpacking and hiking trips. Basic rain pants with Patagonia quality. Great fit and solid zips.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I ordered these for a recent backcountry trip and have to say I love them. The fit is great and the weight is good too. I was considering the Helium pants from OR but saved a little $ and have a better zipper for putting on with boots. 

Would buy again.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I bought these for my husband, for a trip he's going on in October to the Upper Cascade Mountains with his buddies. When he got them, he put them on and ran outside and grabbed the garden hose and started spraying himself. 

I ran out and said," What are you doing?". He gently replied, "I'm making sure these don't leak and get me wet as it rain's a lot in the PNW during fall season so I need to make sure I stay dry.?

I thought to myself, hmmm... that's a good idea. What other way besides waiting to see if they work then field testing them before you go.

He also likes the bottom long side zipper from foot to high calf area so you can slip them on without taking off your boots or footwear. And their super light-weight.
Love these, use them for any activity that I'm doing in the rain.

These rain pants are what you would expect from patagonia- quality, functional, and durable. They do run a slightly long in the leg, but they have a snap button at the cuff with two adjustments that can cinch down around a leg or boot to prevent them from dragging the ground. Beyond that, nice double zipper adjustable side vents, side mesh pockets, and elastic/drawstring waistband. 

Bottom line- definitely recommend these for anyone wanting a good pair of rain pants.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I've worn these while doing aerobic activities through admittedly not-so-fierce southern California downpours while and they haven't wetted through yet. Unlike every other pair of rain pants I've purchased, these were comfortable enough to actually keep wearing throughout the day. I'm not sure what else I'd want in a rain pant!
They are a little long in the leg.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: i carry these everywhere i go as soon as i take my bike places. they are light, nice packing size, great deal! get on it and buy them!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Fits true to size, easy and light to pack for any weather. I always have them close by outside
Kosuke from Patagonia shares his thoughts on the newly updated Torrentshell pant.
fits great and performs well. also looks solid. all in all a great product
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I grabbed the torrent shell pants and matching jacket.  Not the smallest pack, but packable none the less.  Waterproof for now, wore them for 3 days in Shenandoah. Fits great, light weight, and has the pit vents which is important for me.  Certainly a good suit.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Got nothing to complaint about , good quality and fair price
Have not used in heavy rain yet but have been great in light rain. I always pack these along with me on all my trips.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Just finished using these pants for a week of hiking in wet, cold and rainy arctic Sweden. I wore them for 2 days straight in mild rain and they never wetted through, whereas a fellow hiker's Marmot Membrain pants did under the same conditions.

Very comfortable, the fit was perfect, and they conveniently stuff into one of the pockets for compact storage. Breathability is average.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Totally waterproof and comfortable, even hiking in warmer weather, they breath well.  I was hiking a 6 hr down pour and they kept me dry.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Over the years I have had several different type of day packs for camping, going international and just day to day use. I was looking for a bag I could take to school and just as easily on a plane to my next overseas destination. This bag accomplishes that. It's simple design just makes it a joy to carry and you can cram so much into it. I believe it is a must have for a daily traveler.

I love that I don't have to worry about my things getting wet. Plus this is a good size that can hold a lot of things but isn't overwhelming. There's lots of small pouches inside for different things but I mostly use the zippered pouch on the top part. I also like that the water bottle holders are tight so things don't fall out but stretch to fit larger Nalgenes. I also like that the laptop section is padded because that makes me feel even safer carrying stuff in this bag. It fits well on the shoulders too. I/ve had it for a couple years now and it still looks brand new.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I really dig this bag, and I bring it everywhere with me. In the PNW, it's important to have weather-proof gear. This bag keeps my stuff dry (the material is completely waterproof - the zippers aren't sealed, though, so I am wary about true downpours) on bike rides and my daily commutes. I stuff everything from laptops (great padded pouch) and books in here, to all my climbing gear, my snow stuff... The daisy-chain is tough, the pockets are HUGE, the brain section is awesome, and I really dig the colors! This bag has become my every-day-every-thing partner in crime.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: So I got this backpack for school purposes and was overly surprised when I actually had it in my hand. The color and description are accurate, the think looks like it could withstand a hurricane, and there are plenty of spaces inside to organize my stuff.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I use this pack for work, it has a nice sleeve for my laptop and large main pocket to huck everything else in. Hard to beat if you want something for work/school/travel.
Gave it as a gift, and got rave reviews and a pile of photos of it in action. Just about perfect for travel and daily use.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Good build quality and all the features I need in a rugged backpack for work and travel.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I already have two Black Hole duffels that I love so I figured I might give the pack a try too. I'm not used to top zippers like it, but I think I'll get used to it. I love the laminated shell and the pockets seem well thought out. It should server as a great pack for traveling and day hikes.
Love the thought out use of storage in this bag and is a great size for me. Ive taken it on day hikes and also used it as an overnight bag. Lots of convenient pockets for all of your stuff! cool.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Excellent pack, I'd give it a 9/10. I've used this bag five days a a week for about 1 year now and it's shown no signs of wear. 
Anything from being thrown around in my car to hold my running gear to working up steep approaches in the rain, to stuffing a bunch of crap in it when I moved. 

Pros: Easily accessible- very intuitive flap and zipper setup, Black Hole material is very high quality and very sturdy, zipper are smooth and easy to operate when under stress, massive cargo space for a light pack, brain pouch is very useful, water bottle pockets

Cons: While the material is fully waterproof - the zippers are not taped and the back will also soak through in a sustained downpour (it's meant for a situation such as that, just buy a pack cover if that's an issue), water bottle pockets are too snug - they hold a full nalgene but you really gotta cram it in,  sternum strap is kinda wimpy - no full strap capacity 

GREAT PACK
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This is not a hiking backpack and besides what the description states there is no waist belt to secure this pack without the extra load on your shoulders and back. The bag itself is nice looking and great lightweight pack but not functional for true hiking/trekking as I needed it for... It's so hard to find fashion/stylish hiking bags while functional at the same time.

Great for carrying your daily essentials and keeping them safe from unpredictable weather in Utah.  Awesome pack I use it on the daily from morning commutes to the shoreline hikes with the dog. The pack is pretty universal for almost anything that requires packing up and taking with you. The feature I enjoy the best is the rigid back it’s not super stiff but it does have some flexibility to it and the pattern it has molded allows great airflow. I’m constantly receiving completes on the outer finish of this pack as well, looks slick and durable are the main ones. The organizational pockets are perfect they thought of everything for everything so you’ll have easy access to it all. The laptop sleeve is nice fits the mac superb and is brilliant how it doubles as a hydration sleeve and allows a tube right out the top. If you have a budget for only one pack this is the pack.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Absolutely essential for college, day hikes, climbing especially 

There's an excellent handle on the daisy chain that lets you carry it like a duffel and the waterproofing is solid. 

Not going to be using this in a downpour unless you have a pack cover, though it's perfect for light rain.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Love it! Lots of space and the pockets can hold a Nalgene bottle. Very well made as well.

This is my favorite pack for every day use that Patagonia makes, I use it all the time for work and travel.  Updated this year to include external stretch pockets for water bottles or extra gear, with still the same old standby features of padded laptop sleeve and internal pen/gadget organization.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I gave as a gift and received the following feedback:

“I like the stylish sleek look. I’ve had a number of compliments on the pack within the first few days of using it. The laptop sleeve won’t fit a laptop with an extended battery, but the normal battery fits just fine.”
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Durable and great for travel or as a laptop bag.  The laptop sleeve will only fit a 15" laptop, but I just throw my 17" with an extended battery in the main compartment.  No hip belt so I wouldn't plan on carrying a heavy load or using it outside all that much.  Maybe for a short hike or alpine scramble.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Bought this as a gift for my boyfriend. He says the jacket keeps rain out but there is no mesh lining, so heat vapor from your body does not quickly release from the jacket, despite pit zips. Other than that he likes the jacket and fit. Good jacket for price.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This jacket is great. It's lightweight, stylish, and packable which is a really nice feature when on the go. The material is slightly noisy but was kind of expecting that with this level of protection.  The pit zips are a great feature to release some excess heat. Overall it's a fantastic jacket. It fits well, looks really good, and unbeatable price for the quality you get.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Patagonia Torrentshell jacket is the best rain jacket on the market - durable, flattering, and does the job. Great vents under the arms if you are hiking and it gets warm, upgraded from a Sherpa Rain Jacket to this Patagonia one and was a great decision!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I ended up having to return the Patagonia Torrentshell jacket. The inside liner gave way after a couple of years of light use and it was losing its ability to shed water. It more absorbed water than anything else. Patagonia stood by their product though and replaced it.

Another great piece from Patagonia. The jacket is really well made and the vents help keep me cool on muggy, humid days in the summer. The waterproofing is great and the hood is shaped perfectly to keep the rain out of your face.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: My boyfriend bought this as an upgrade from his old North Face rain jacket. He likes this one way more and uses it as a light jacket as well. It fits him nicely, and the only concern is that the zipper gets caught because of the fabric. He was also hesitant to buy it because it is a very 'loud' jacket if that makes sense, kinda crackling when you move.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This is hands down the best rain coat i have ever purchased.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I bought these as gifts for my dad and brother-in-law's fly fishing trip. We used these last weekend in Glenwood Springs where it rained the entire day. They said without these jackets, they would have been soaked through and cold and miserable. But instead, they were dry and warm and had a great fishing experience on the Colorado River. Totally waterproof!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
Keeps you dry but wear a synthetic shirt underneath to prevent pitting out.
Take a 20% OFF coupons from coupon-code.info

Our first day on the water canoeing in the backcountry at Algonquin Provincial Park was very heavy rain and stormy all day. I was glad to have this Jacket. It kept the water out for the most part and the hood fit nice with my baseball cap. I would highly recommend this product!
Bought this as a gift for my dad and he loves it. He is 5'8" and 185lbs and the Large fits perfect.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I went with a large on this one. The medium fit as well but was a touch tighter than I wanted the jacket to fit in the back and shoulders. The jacket isn't too wide either which is nice when sizing up so you don't get that boxy look as you can in other coats.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
Super comfortable
Take a 20% OFF coupons from coupon-code.info
Price is low when discounting, lightweight . Very unbreathable, waterproof is okay.&

Did a lot or research before buying this coat. Everyone agrees this is as good as it gets, not I do too. I've only worn it a couple times for some summer showers, definitely keeps the rain off well. It does get steamy inside on the hotter humid days, luckily I wasn't outside too long. The hood is great too, plenty of adjustability to dial in the fit front to back and overall height. Jacket is very light weight and compact as well. So glad I picked this up.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
First thing first- the zipper sucks. 9 times out of 10 I can't get it zipped up. It's a struggle to get the zipper engaged. So right away the jacket gets some stars knocked out. 

Yea, straight out of the box it repels water great. Water does not soak through and it beads up. The first rainstorm you face will leave you impressed. But a week later you'll notice the water starts to soak and seep through the fabric; probably because the DWR finish isn't tough enough or maybe just literally dissolves in the rain. I've literally never even taken the jacket camping or hiking, so it's gotta be pretty terrible to stop functioning  correctly with even light use.

Once the water starts to seep through you're gonna hate wearing this jacket, since it's pretty much like wearing a wet, oily sack that sticks to your skin, stifles your respiration, and lets water drip through the zipper. 

It's a garbage jacket, that couldn't stand up to more than one or two storms. I really wanted to like it, but it's literally worse than not wearing anything. 

Hope this helps.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Keeps you dry but wear a synthetic shirt underneath to prevent pitting out.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
This jacket does it all three seasons out of the year. Where it on the golf course if it's about to rain, or pack it down into your backpack for a day getaway that you expect to see a cloud in the sky which might rain on you later. Under armpit vendors come in very helpful.  

I'm 5 foot10 155 pounds and his jacket fits perfectly. To give you a better reference I'm a 40R suit jacket and everything medium from J Crew
take another off 20% coupons code from outdoorback.tk

This jacket is so versatile, it's a lightweight rain protection option that can stuff into a pack really easily.  I love that this jacket has a 2.5 layer membrane to keep the rain out.
I'd recommend this jacket to anyone who is looking for a great fit, bomber waterproofing, and a great warranty.  My friend has one just like this from a few years ago.  The membrane began to deteriorate, he took it into a Patagonia location and they replaced it on the spot for him!  This jacket's a winner.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The description states these are water resistant which is really different than waterproof. I should have known better when I chose to use these pants on a multi-week bike tour through Europe. They packed small and light which seemed to make them perfect for bike touring. They did a great job dealing with the wind. However, they were useless in the rain. For future trips I will bring pants that work for both wind and rain.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I bought and wore these for a 2 night hike up Mount Whitney and they were awesome for early morning (2am) and evening when shorts weren't quite warm enough or there were mosquitoes. They are now a part of my ultralight clothing system for trips where I don't expect temperatures below freezing or precipitation more than a light rain.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Great for packpacking. Shed water good for what they are. I did put a hole in the seat of them already. To the pants credit I was wearing them in a very rocky area.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I wouldn't trust them in any rainy situation, this is not a rain pant. It's too thin. I use them in the summer as a wind breaker/ night camp pant to block mosquitos.  They are good to throw on when it's just chilly enough to be uncomfortable but if you didn't have the pants it wouldn't be the end of the world. I love the fact it's pants you keep in your shorts. I have also found shorts I can keep in my pants.  One issue is the cuffs don't cover shoes well, so it's not very flattering.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
The perfect emergency wind pant. A great option to throw into your bag for backpacking in the mountains. For those cold windy summit days, to lounging around in the cool evening, these pants are a no brainier add to any backpackers bag. They do shed light moisture for those quick afternoon storms, but I would be wary of trusting them in a full down pour for more than a half hour. 

That being said, I would have loved a drawstring. I constantly have to pull my pants up a little bit or tuck in a layer to help them from sliding down. There already is an elastic band, so I don't imagine it would add too much of a weight penalty to have a solid cord that can be adjusted.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Super thin material and no drawstring made these pants not durable or practical enough for me. The pants fit slim and do pack incredibly small, which is the main appeal.  Cuff doesn't open enough to put on over running shoes.  I like the concept but just not enough "value" to justify the price.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I use this pants as part of my gear in the Camino de Santiango  as second layer over my tights and it works great and also as a second pair of pants when washing or lounging around. Durable, wind resistance, but did not use during hiking in the rain.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Why should you choose to pony up your hard earned cash for the Patagonia Houdini Pants? One word: Packability. These pants pack down into the rear pocket, and then can be compressed even further using a small ziplock bag. They are ultralight. These should be in your pack on every trip, no matter what the weather forecast says. Snap closure cuffs allow you to pull them on right away. Once you hear that crack of thunder and it begins to pour, there is no time to fumble around with tight cuffs that require you to take your shoes off. Whip out your Houdini pants from the side pocket of your pack, and throw them on. Boom. Now on to more important things.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
While touring the US on a motorcycle last year, I saw the Houdini jacket on an outdoor store and thought it would be great to venture the rain on the road. And I was right. It was flawless. I wanted to buy the pants, but couldn't find it anywhere.

I know it's not the intended use, but it sure beats using heavy rain plastic gear that will not only constrict your movements, but will not breathe at all. It's common to get home more wet on the inside from the sweat than the rain itself.  Plus, they normally take a lot of space on your backpack/panniers. 

The Houdini pants + jacket are unbelievably compact and do the job wonderfully. Plus, they can be worn over my regular motorcycle jacket/pants. Highly recommended!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I read a review where the person said the zipper would hang up on the fabric when unzipping the jacket, and I thought they just got a bad one.  Well the one I ordered did the exact same thing.  It's like the little wind flap is made of material that is too thin, and it gets caught in the zipper.  I zipped and unzipped it multiple times to see if it would self correct, but it didn't.  It would hang up about 3 times every time I unzipped it.  I think they need to change the wind flap to a stiffer material and/or make it wider.  Very poor design.  Needless to say, I returned it.

This jacket has a LOT going for it.  I returned it due to sleeve length.  My arms are not ordinarily short, I'm quite average, a little on the tall side actually.  But the sleeve length came to my knuckles.  I couldn't stand that.  Great color (oxblood red) and very comfortable, I'm sure it would be really warm and it's a great looking jacket too.  Just don't let the sleeve length surprise you.  Patagonia really should have velcro or something to cinch the cuffs for those of us with shorter to average arms.  I do own a Patagonia Nano Puff in the same size I ordered in this and have no issues with the sleeve lengthen the Nano Puff fwiw.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: This is the perfect weight jacket for transitional weather - warm enough for early spring with a light sweater and through the fall. It's comfortable and runs true to size. It's durable and has been great for especially windy days.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Great spring/fall jacket.   Warm enough, not bulky, keeps the wind out, and did an impressive job the first time I wore it in the rain. Love the big, zippered pockets and oxblood red color. Highly recommend.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: durable, stretchy and warm. good looking jacket too
Natasha from Patagonia talks through the newly redesigned Adze Hybrid Jacket

Having a 4 year old is hard, especially one as strong-willed as mine is (just like her mother).  Little did I know when I brought home matching camo Patagonia hats tonight that it will be the daddy-daughter equivalent of a best friendâs necklace.  She loved them so much she insisted on sleeping with both of our new hats by her bed.  I appreciate any opportunity to win as a dad.  I recommend this hat to all customers, but make sure you buy one for your BFF too!
Hit me up if you need help picking some out!

Based off reviews of this hat, I thought the fit would be deep enough for my big head, but it was not. The Pelican color I purchased is really great looking. I was able to "re-gift" it to my girlfriend who loves it.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I love the classic look of this cap!  I got the pelican color for summer, it goes well with everything and keeps the sun outta your eyes.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I did get Farther Gray Color
First -  this hat is so big ad deep like the one for basketball players
Second - after a few days of use in the mountains, it has sweat stains.  What's crazy >>> Impossible to remove Money wasted

Love this hat! I love that it has solid material all the way around  and doesn't have the mesh on the back like most hats have now.   I've gotten it wet in salt water and rinsed it afterwards and it didn't leave salt marks on it which surprised me.  Good fit and doesn't sit too high on your head.  Great hat!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Keeps sun out of my eyes and that is what I needed it for!
Such a good looking cap that fits so nice I forget its there! I'm a real stickler about how a hat fits and this is by far my favorite!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
The Patagonia '73 Logo Roger That Snapback Hat and other hats with the same material by patagonia is a love/hate relationship. This hat fits and feels like a dream. The only DOWN side is the material and cost. If you sweat, beware this hate will not look the same after you wear it. It will have sweat  stains for the rest of its life. Maybe Its just me and I sweat a lot, but I would think for $30 this should be the best hat EVER!!! 

Recap: If you like your hat to look like its suppose to, Don't wear it if your going to sweat. Which means this not an outdoorsy kind of hat.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: the black color goes with everything. and also the full fabric back keeps your head warm in fall/winter.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Great quality pants, very comfortable. However, they run big and baggy. Had to really cinch the waist and there's lots of room in the butt and thigh area... with baselayer underneath. Otherwise, they perform great on the slopes.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I got these as a gift for my fiance, and she likes them so far. They do fit a bit big so size down if you're petite. Also the material is a little less durable than other shell pants because they're more backcountry oriented. She put a hole in them on day 1 (it's only about 1cm long), but other than that they're great. Hip ventilation is a big win, and they fit over any ski/snowboard boot!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I love patagonia. Great products, never let me down. I am an ex-collegiate skier and avid all-mountain skier in my retirement. I have skier thighs and a small waist. I wear a 10/12 jean in order to fit my quads, and according to the size charts that puts me about a Medium in their snow pants....not the case. The large is too tight to even ski let alone tour with a pair of spandex underneath so I had to size up to the XL (a size 16 jean according to Patagonia) so I could have mobility in my legs. The XL is falling off my waist, but the pants are amazing. Note, the XL is sold out in all versions of Patagonia snow pants. Pretty pumped I grabbed the last pair. Perhaps they should get real with the shape of women's bodies or make more XL's and less Smalls to get with their consumer base. Otherwise, amazing pants. Strong, warm, light and waterproof.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
Pros: Gore-Tex pro is incredibly waterproof and breathable and doesn't sound like you're stomping on a bag of cheetos when you wear it, nice feminine cut with room for curves and muscular legs, great construction.

Cons: Gets suuuuper baggy as you size up-- I'd say they run a bit large. I'm a bit tall and gangly, so I was swimming in the medium although the length was good. The small was a good fit, but a bit short. I know it's cosmetic, but the chunky zippers in offset colors look sooo damn goofy to me. Just not quite as silky smooth and fit for my build as the Arc'teryx Sentinel!
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: Just like any Patagonia product.. excellent craftsmanship, fits well, last forever and a bit pricey.. Anyways, these are bomb proof and probably I will hand these down to my grandchildren one day.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I'm 5'1" so finding ski pants has always been really difficult for me. It seems I return everything I've ever ordered online...but not these! I ordered the XS. They were a tad long but with my ski boots they looked perfect and shortened in length. I have a bit of a booty and large quads for a girl of my size (112 lbs) but these pants fit perfectly and I can easily pull them over yoga pants AND can pull my knee to my chest. The material feels soft for Gore-Tex, unlike some other brands where the fabric is so stiff that it feels like wearing plastic over my legs. I love these! Haven't gotten to wear them in the snow yet. FYI - This pant model is from the 2014/2015 season

I'm 5'1" so finding ski pants has always been really difficult for me. It seems I return everything I've ever ordered online...but not these! I ordered the XS. They were a tad long but with my ski boots they looked perfect and shortened in length. I have a bit of a booty and large quads for a girl of my size (112 lbs) but these pants fit perfectly and I can easily pull them over yoga pants. The material feels soft for gore-tex, unlike some other brands where the fabric is so stiff that it feels like wearing plastic over my legs. I love these! Haven't gotten to wear them in the snow yet. FYI - these were last year’s model but very few changes have been made in the 2015-16 model so my comments should still be relevant.

I bought these pants at the end of the season so I haven't tried them out in real cold weather, but they are amazing in spring slush, vents and taped seams kept me cool and dry, the fabric is super high quality.  the fit is great, they were just the right length with my ski boots on, and the waist is a little higher so I know no snow will be getting down my pants.  I imagine in the single and negative digits I'll just need to throw on a good baselayer and be good to go, I bought the medium which fits roomy enough for layers, without looking huge.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I generally don't like to wear insulated ski pants, I prefer to wear shell pants, then layer with a light or expedition weight base layer underneath depending on how warm or cool it is. I purchased these pants in Tempest Purple size medium; for reference I am 5'4" and 136 lbs with an athletic build. I absolutely love these ski pants. The fit is great, not too tight or too loose, plenty of articulation in the knee area, and the quality is superb. The length is perfect with ski boots on. The waist is a little higher, which is great on powder days or when I bend down to buckle my ski boots. My only complaint is that there is only 1 zippered cargo pocket on the front right leg, I prefer zippered cargo pockets on both legs. I have skied in these several times and they are comfortable and breathable. Buy them, you won't be disappointed. I also purchased the Untracked jacket to match, and it also fits like a dream.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Pretty sure it is scientifically proven that having fly pants makes you shred 10x harder. At least that's what I've found with these babies - the number of lift-line catcalls I've received has sure increased since I upgraded from my blah gray softshell pants.

The fit is (surprisingly) awesome, considering my hit-or-miss experiences with Patagucci. Ample room in the thighs and legs without looking too steezy. Fairly high rise, but that's for the best when you somersault into a couloir in front of all of your friends. Your pride might be bruised, but your tush and lower back stay dry. 

I typically wear a light merino base layer underneath - have skied them in -10F to 65F.  While I haven't had a problem with them being too cold, sometimes on those long hikes they get a little bit warm: unzip the thigh vents and perfection!

I wish their jackets fit me this well.

XS is a true XS - I'm 5'3", athletic build, they fit great.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Patagonia and Backcountry stand up to my expectations.  The service is outstanding and the color, fit and quality of these ski pants are super.  Just spent a week in Telluride in all conditions from very cold to 30's to blizzard and sunny conditions.  I wore patagonia capillene 3 long underwear and a fleece pant underneath, never had any temperature issues. Thanks to Patagonia for a super product and to Back Country for super shipping and service.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have used these pants twice in resort and once touring. I am  5'2" 115lbs with athletic legs and a smaller waist, I got the smalls and with a base layer they are a little long but otherwise fit perfectly. Comfortable to ski and hike in.  My dream pant has two cargo pockets for storing snacks/hat/gloves/beacon, but the one cargo pocket works great. It is slightly off to the side, but works. I don't tend to overheat much so the vents with very fine mesh lining work great. I like the graphite/navy look. It is nice to have not have a black pant or one that is super bright. I have been picky and looking for new snow pants for the past 3 years and excited to finally find a pair that fit well and are functional.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: The pants fit as expected in the waste and length, but they are small around the legs. Taking normal size steps I had to fight against the pants to move my legs. The material seems great but the fit is just poor for an active pant.

These pants are amazing keeps you warm when cold cool when hot. I were these bad boys for everything from sending slabs in the Appalachians too climbing the larger peaks of the Pacific North West. They are my go to do all pant.  Would recommend to anybody.

These are some super comfortable  pants for almost anything. I have taken them on several long treks and mountaineering  routes. They breathe well and are very flexible. I tore the leg open a bit with some crampons so they are not the most durable thing out there and they are water resistant but certainly not waterproof. Just know what you are getting here, a very nice lightweight soft shell, not a hardcore alpine pant.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I recently wore these pants on a trip to the Adirondacks. They were super comfortable to snowboard and hike in all day. They kept me dry through light snowfall and while sliding on our butts down the trails.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I picked these up on GT and am generally excited about them. The cut is great for any number of snow/ice activities....until you try to put on a ski boot. I wear a Dynafit Mercury boot and there is no way in hell to get the pant cuff over the boot. I'm a little bummed because they're touted as ski touring pants in the description, but a ski pant that won't fit over your boot is useless in my opinion. 
That said I am certain that I will love hiking/climbing in these babies. I just thought that I had finally found the glass slipper for ski mountaineering. The search continues....
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I summited Mt. Shasta with these bad boys. Kept me warm with a simple base layer on my snowshoeing trips through Lassen Nat'l Park. Great for snowboarding days as well. The fit makes them look awesome too! They're also very breathable when you do not have a baselayer on. Great for backpacking around the Sierras in the summer. 

Pros:
Warm but breathable
Water Resistant 
Perfect fit
Secure zipper pockets 

Cons:
The belt fastener loosens easily
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: My go to ski touring and mountaineering pant. Perfect for fast and light in the mountains when you want to have pockets and not look like your wearing full on SKIMO tights. Love that you can snug up the pant leg around your ski boots when booting up a wallow of coulior.  Also love that they almost look like a normal casual pant when grabbing a well earned burrito after some mountain adventures. Perfect ski touring pant for Wasatch type conditions, generally dry and not very cold! Great color options are a bonus!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Was looking for a pair of soft shell pants to bridge the seasonal gap - light/breathable enough for fall hiking,  and warm and weather resistant enough for ice climbing. These were on sale so I figured I'd give them a try and they are perfect. Couldn't have asked for anything different. Except one thing. 

When deciding to purchase these I read a review that said the thigh pocket zipper jingled at which point I thought to myself "lol what a picky consumer" and bought the pants. Then I put them on and started walking out of my house and heard the jingle. I don't know how such a small zipper can make as much noise as it does. I just laughed to myself and put a piece of tape over the zipper and it's all good now.

Love these pants and would recommend anytime!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: When I say built-in bear bell I'm exaggerating. But the thigh zipper has a metal tab that jingles enough to bother someone who tries to stay away from noisy gear in the quiet backcountry or wind-less alpine. That was enough for me to pass on this pant.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: These are my go to ice climbing pants. Great mobility, breathability, and durability, everything a good pair of ice climbing pants should be. Basically lived in them for 4 days while climbing in Ouray, Co, used them at least 2-3 times a week for early morning ice climbs up Scruffy and GWI this season and i've yet to see any signs of wear. Pockets work well with a harness, and the waist adjustment provides just enough wiggle room to really narrow the size to just how you like it. Great overall pants!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: These are great pants. I've only used them in the summer and spring months but I've used them quite a bit in that time frame. I've used them mostly for cool to warm weather mountaineering trips in the sierras and have stood up to most everything I've thrown at them within reason (crampon spikes obviously don't count). They also work for climbing as they stretch a lot and offer great mobility. They breath well for they're weight and I am able to manage my body temperature pretty well. They do get warm when the temperatures are higish(like >75) but that's expected. The opposet belt works great to as I dropped a size or two but they still cinch down to fit pretty good across about 3 sizes. They're also great for off the mountain as they are reasonably fashionable and not too techy. Overall these are awesome and I am probably going to buy at least 1 hopefully 2 more pairs.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: These pants met all of my expectations and more. I was climbing some gritty gneiss this past weekend and the pants didn't pull or tear in the least which I cannot say for anyother pant I have ever worn. The length is a bit longer than I was hoping for (I'm 6'1'' 165 lbs). I was in the same camp with everyone else about the OppoSet belt thing being nothing more than a gimick but I actually use it ever time I put the pants on and it has been great. Worn the pants 24 days (not in a row) and haven't had to wash them yet. Only complaint is when the main pockets aren't zippered up they tend to scrunch, especially with a harness on. Not a big deal but a draw back that I noticed. Over all great pant, psyched on these!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Pants - This is my boyfriend's second pair. They are amazing. You can wear them to work on casual Friday, out to the bar that night, and then all weekend getting them dirty camping.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Very tight in the lower legs and does not fit like previous Patagonia pants. The same size.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Wearing them as we speak! Quality pair of pants here. I have to admit that I have been told time and time again that I have chicken legs so the fit of these pants works for me. If you're a slimmer dude these will be a staple in your wardrobe for years.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Very comfortable fit and light breathable texture.  Forge grey is staining badly, disgusting pinkish color makes them unwearable in public.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: They have a good fit and they are pretty warm too. The fit isn't too slim which I like.

Nicely made pants, the fabric was thinner than I was hoping but seems durable enough and of good quality.  Im a thin 6-2, i have no butt to speak of, but fairly athletic calves and thighs. I generally have trouble finding pants that aren't way too baggy, I found the fit on these to be too slim though-not conducive to hiking or climbing or working.   probably very good for manicuring mountain man beards in manhattan high rises, sipping beverages, and looking at web videos about working.  
     probably im getting old, and they most likely nailed the fit on these, they do call them slim fit....nice pants though

column5:
These pants fit well in the waist and lower legs but fit me like leggings in the thighs and butt. If you do squats they probably won't fit you too well. Too bad because I liked the material and color. 

Patagonia needs to make a style in between the regular fit (too baggy in the calf area) and this one.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: These pants fit on the slim side so take that into consideration. The material seems to be very durable and has the feel of carhartt bibs but not as thick. Great pant for beating through the woods after grouse or hanging by the fire with whiskey in hand
Good fitting, especially for tall/athletic build. Quality, durable material. Great pants!
Bought for my husband. They look great on him. He likes the fit (slim but not skinny jean slim) and that they have a durable, high quality feel.

I've always wanted to wear patagonia pants (and shirts for that matter) but they've always swallowed me whole until these. These bridge the gap between a carhartt-esque work pant and a pair of khakis you could tuck a shirt into if need be. They're slim and flattering but they're not restrictive and don't taper all the way to the cuff like "skinny jean" style pants so they still look presentable around bosses whose blood pressure goes up every time they hear the word "millennials" . 
My only nitpick is that they wrinkle pretty easily.
I'm typically a 31x33 and the 32 regular fits well.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Solid fitting cotton pant. Can be classy or professional when needed or just a great pair to lounge around a camp fire in your back yard.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: im 6'4, 200#s... i normally wear a 35 or 36 inch inseam but decided to give the Long version a try. These actually measure out at 34.5 in length.  While i do still prefer a bit longer, these work for me. Theyre not snug, just a tad loose on my legs and im a habitual long distance runner so my legs tend to be larger than most (point of reference, patagonias jeans are tight around my thigh and calves). I really like the material of these... its got a sort of a canvas look to me and feels like its pretty tough, but i wear it as work Kackis with a polo or a nice shirt and I think they work pretty well.

column5: I've been wearing the Patagonia Straight Fit Duck pant for a couple weeks now and I really like the updated fit. While the regular fit duck pants are still available, I went with Patagonia's new straight fit, as I have been wearing the Patagonia Denim in the straight fit and liked the more tailored cut. Patagonia's straight fit is by no means

column5: I love the original fit Duck Pants and wear a 32/Reg.  I though I would try this slimmer fit as the regulars have a little bagginess on my frame.  I could not even pull on these 32/Reg slim/straight Duck Pants.  The sizing is so different, I don't even know how to describe it.  The usual Patagonia quality was in the construction, just bad sizing.  Anyway, I'll gladly stick with 5-star original Duck Pants for my body (5'9", 165lbs, medium build).  I will also echo another reviewer's comment that these seem almost like skinny-jeans.  So if that is not your style, perhaps beware.
Great pants for travel and hiking. The fit is great and they look good too!

column5: Nice taper on the legs like all the kids are wearing these days. Great fit.

column5: I have several Patagonia pants.  The waist in these are fine, but the pant legs fit almost like skinny jeans.

column5: A bit slimmer than most patagonia pants (although I still think they could be a bit more fitted).
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
So, I am 5'8 and 210lbs or so.  Usually wear 36x30 in Levis 514 and have the Carhartt 5 pocket 12oz Duck pants in 36x30 too  but those relaxed fit Carhartts are still kinda big.   These Patagonia are soft and broken in Duck Canvas but at just 8oz or so feel like you are wearing sweat pants.  They do fit me good for 1 hour but loosen up a bit as I break them in.  They come out of the dryer fitting perfect but after the day is over they do stretch. Exactly the same as high end Seven or Buffalo jeans where you notice the stretch.  This is good for me of course.

Must purchase these.  They are great for working and putting up a fence to taking the wife out for dinner since they look like slacks.

column5: Patagonia makes a great product and this bag is great to use as a carry on.  Protects the laptop and sturdy construction.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is a great backpack for travel, work and everything in between.  The straps are very comfortable, and the storage capacity is just right for a work or carry-on travel bag.  The laptop sleeve is appropriately sized and fits a 15" laptop well with plenty of protection.  The pockets are intuitive and the layout is very user friendly.  Great quality as you'd expect with Patagonia!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I bought this backpack this past spring when they produced it in Turkish Red with Blue detailing. I have since used this bag almost every day for school, camping, hiking, and travel. It easily fits all my essentials, with plenty of pockets to help organize everything, and yet it still easily stows under the seat in front of me even on the smallest planes. 
As the description states it has a laptop pocket which holds my  laptop and a couple of small sketchbooks. The Waterproof pocket is awesome, and prevents all my gear from getting wet (I usually stow my laptop in there on rainy days). 
The only bad thing I've noticed with this pack is how much stuff gets lost at the bottom of the waterproof pocket due to weird lining attachment. Otherwise, I really love this backpack and plan to take it on more adventures soon!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I ordered this pack about a year ago. This pack has held up through MANY trips to the backcountry! Was a rock climbing guide through the past summer and was on the crag all day most days of the week. The 1" webbing waist straps were kind of useless so I just cut them off. I got the feather grey bag so the white has gotten a little stained but I'm sure a run through the washer and it'll be as good as new. The laptop pocket was a little small but held my 15" laptop fine. The waterproof "dry bag" pocket is pretty revolutionary, however, it can be a little difficult to put large items in because its so baggy inside. The padding is pretty good but could be improved on. The only things I would want to change would be making the overall pack a lot larger, maybe 35L. Also I would make the bag totally water proof.. Overall a good purchase! Love Patagonia!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I bought this backpack because it said it would fit a 17" computer. However, upon receipt I discovered it does not. It is a great backpack, but I just wish I had known it didn't fit my computer. Will be returning
Not only does it look amazing, but the waterproof pocket is awesome. To clarify, the entire pack isn't waterproof, there's just a waterproof pouch inside one of the pockets.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I love the LOOK of this pack, but when I received it, the waterproof compartment is very cumbersome.  The lining is not secured in the large compartment so it's hard to even see to the bottom of the back. It's kind of like putting a giant black trash bag in your backpack and packing your things in the squished up trash bag.  LOVE the look, LOVE the colors, so sad to be returning it, but I think the large compartment would have driven me crazy.  :(
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I got the butt of the Backcountry stock and realized that something melted the black fabric in the back; unfortunately, it is too late to return because I threw away the shipping box. Check the condition of the purchase before you throw away the box! The backpack itself is roomy and light. The various compartments make organization easy. The straps are a lot thinner but more breathable than the NorthFace backpack that I used to carry. Really- the only downside was that the backpack came in a sub par condition.

Bought this as gift for my dad, here are his thoughts: Patagonia Insulated Fjord Flannel Jacket - This jacket is awesome in a wide variety of uses, from taking the morning chill off at the beginning of a fall float, to shoveling snow on a frigid day.  The quilted insulation works great by itself or it can be worn over a base layer and even topped with a waterproof shell.  The fit is spot on, with great sleeve lengths and ideal fit through the torso.  The side pockets are a handy addition too.  I highly recommend this jacket for any outdoor activity.
Perfect weight insulated flannel for cold days.  Been wearing it everyday since I bought it and could not be more happy with it.  My new essential winter flannel.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This product met my expectation in terms of style and comfort, and exceeded my expectations in terms of softness. I was afraid that the lining would make the flannel look overly bulky and awkward; that was not the case. I would recommend this product for anyone who is looking to combine lifestyle apparel with the technical warmth of a lined jacket. This quality is high, as with any Patagonia product. Overall I am satisfied. Lastly, the fit is compatible with that of other Patagonia products.

The insulated fjord flannel fits just like the non-insulated ones (besides added thickness from the insulation). It's very warm and looks great. For its jacket-like warmth and thickness though, it'd be cool if it came with snaps instead of buttons. I ended up replacing the buttons with snaps on mine and it made it much more versatile as a cold, dry weather jacket for working on stuff outside.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Received this as a Christmas Gift. Kept me warm through the winter. But here in Socal it don't get too cold. Received a bunch of compliments. Having side pockets is a plus. Note: not mentioned above and I didn't discover them until a few days of use. Should read 2 chest & 2 side.  Fit is awesome. Would recommend this to everyone. This is my favorite flannel.
