column5: Wore it gently 3 times and the buttons are already coming off. Too bad because it is very comfortable. Very poor quality for a Patagonia product. I bought a few months ago and now cannot return because  Backcountry will not take it back after 30 days.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Haven't had this very long but it has already become my favorite lightweight jacket. The fit is perfect (I'm 6'4", 210 wearing a Large) and the cut is long enough keep wind from coming up. Love the duel front pockets and the Thermogreen is great keeping me warm during the chilly Denver fall nights. Also is light enough to wear under a super warm winter jacket and great over a t-shirt when the sun comes out. 

All in all, another home run by Patagonia!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Got these for my wife, she likes that these are not too tight and comfortable. she looks amazing in them. highly recommended
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought this for a friend and she love them! She uses them for hikes, climbing, and just as a casual pant. The one thing she did say is that the thighs are a little tight, but she isn't too concerned as she thinks they will stretch out a bit.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Lightweight and soft/comfy.  I have not tested them in outdoor trip yet but so far so good. Although they don't have a tie strap at the bottom for rolling them up I do it anyway and they stay put and give an extra option. They are lower cut and have just enough stretch. The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is that I wish they came in earthier tones.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I want to love these pants more than I actually do. I'm normally a size 4 in Patagonia pants but ended up sizing up to a 6. They fit fairly well except for the butt - tight and kinda squashes my behind. The stretch isn't nearly as good as my PrAna Zion pants. They are a little bit low rise and sometimes cause discomfort when wedged underneath my climbing harness. They also didn't breathe very well - when I hiked up a short but steep 20 minute approach in about 77 degree F, puddles of sweat dotted the pants - it did not look pretty! Once I started climbing, I mostly forgot about them and ended up enjoying the thicker material during some slab climbing for avoiding scratches and scrapes. These will likely be my colder weather climbing pants - and definitely not for hiking.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I haven't tested these outside yet, but they performed well in the gym. I love the belt strap that allows you to tighten the waist.

These pants rock! I recently purchased these pants for hiking and camping and I love them. They are so comfortable and a super cute fit. I have been wearing them rolled, but the length is good unrolled too. The waist-cinch is great to get the best fit, but they also have belt loops to wear with a belt. These will definitely be my go-to camping and hiking pant for the summer!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Reader's Digest Version: This pant is super comfortable. I'd venture to say that the Venga is most ideal for gym or mild-weather climbing at, say, the Gunks or Boulder Canyon. I do occasionally wear the Venga to work as the color I own is less prone to showcasing The Accumulated Gnar and the stretchy material is definitely nice for all-day wearability.

Non-Reader's Digest Version: I really like the fact that the Venga is not made with a swishy, static-y material. The material is just super comfortable. That being said, the cotton component does lend itself to stretching out (a lot) and isn't great for climbing in damp, humid, or super hot conditions (simply because it won't dry quickly). However, the hint of spandex is awesome because it provides ample mobility and the gusseted crotch bolsters my range of motion (which, all pants should have a gusseted crotch IMHO - just saying). I love, love, love the OppoSet adjustment - I get a personalized fit in the waist without having to wear a belt (which is an awesome detail when you're wearing a harness). There are belt loops, but meh, I never use them. The length is also pretty primo, I don't have to up-cuff the pant to prevent them from dragging on the ground. As for the fit, I wear a XS (or SM for a relaxed fit) / 24 (in Gap, J.Crew, Patagonia) in bottoms and the 0 initially fits great, but it does stretch out a bit in the waist hence my love for the OppoSet adjustable doo-hickey.

My only qualms are as such: I do wish that the rise on this pant was a little higher, simply for the sake of coverage. Also, it would be awesome if these pants had an internal drawcord at the hems - though, I have remedied my displeasure with this lack-of-feature by tight-rolling my pants at the cuff. If you've never tight-rolled your cuffs, look it up - it will come in handy  more often than you think it will!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Patagonia strikes back with another beyond-bizarre sizing... Woohoo.

For starters, I'm 5'9", 135-140lbs (pizza-dependent), with bigger skier quads, slightly wider hips, medium butt. Generally, I have a 28in waist and 35in hips, and wear a 4/6 in most climbing/hiking pants.

The 6 was loose in the waist, fitted in the rear and hips, semi-fitted in the thighs... But after an afternoon of climbing around, they stretched out to the point of nearly falling off my bum. Upon trying on the size 4, they were snug in the waist and TIGHT in the rear/hips/thighs, but stretched out to a reaaaally comfortable fit after a bit of climbing. They're a teeny bit short, but not too bad. If you're generally between sizes in pants, definitely go with the smaller size in these.

I snagged the bright blue color, and hoooooly guacamole it's vibrant. Perhaps a lil' loud for me, but awesome. It does show dirt and sweat (ew), and the fabric could be a bit more durable for climbing. My main pet peeve (besides the weird stretching/cut) is that the leg openings DON'T HAVE ANY CINCHING. Woof. It's beyond annoying to not be able to see your feet and have to shake the cuff around to ensure you're really toeing into small features. I usually roll them up due to this, but if these pants had little cinches at the bottom like the Prana Avril pants, I'd be aaaaalll over them.

Bottom line:

These are the pants you want for a long session bouldering or ARCing in the gym, or sport climbing in BCC. 

These are NOT the pants you want to wear while scumming on sandstone and writhing through offwidths in the desert. They will end up with some new "ventilation holes" and interesting red-dirt type stains.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The "Howling Turquoise" color is a bit darker than I expected. The material is a bit stretchy. Super comfortable for climbing.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I got these pants a couple of weeks ago. I have worn them twice for indoor climbing. They are very comfortable, feel durable, are soft and just flexible enough to be able to climb comfortably in them all day. I got the mogul blue color, which is very attractive and the color is exactly as pictured. The pants do seem to run a little big. I am 5'3, 120ish lbs and  am normally a size 4-6. I got the size 4 and they are just a bit big in the waist, though they fit nicely in the bum/thigh area. I think a size 2 would have been too small for my hips/bum/waist. They are also a little long (I wish Patagonia made more of their pants in multiple lengths/inseams), but that's to be expected, I guess, for a smaller person. I haven't used them outside yet, but I'm excited to see how they hold up.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I wore these "howling" pants one time hiking and got mud on the legs at the bottom. I have tried 7 different tricks and detergents to get it out (have NOT used the dryer) and still have stains. You would think outdoor pants could actually be USED in the outdoors! :(
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Tried these on a few years ago in navy blue and waited to get them until they were on sale.  Although I didn't get the navy, I ended up with the violet blue, and was surprised to like the bright color so much.  I got them specifically for hiking even though they're climbing pants, because it's not uncommon for me to do some scrambling during a hike.  The waistband is not perfect, but depending on your build you may not have a problem.  I have hips; I was okay, it just wasn't perfection.  However, I will grab these second to my new Kuhl's I'm about to review, the next time I hit the trails.  Great pants for my usage, lightweight, stayed snag-free, great color, and super comfortable.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I originally thought the color was a little bright, but after seeing it in pictures.. I have to say.. they look nice!  The fabric stretches a bit, so good to buy a size smaller and it'll eventually stretch. I had to put mine in the dryer :)

Super durable fabric though. I took it on a roadtrip - trad and sport climbing.. no tears yet! Yay!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Three days, ~24 pitches and these pants are destroyed! The pants have rips through the back pockets and on the legs, and I wasn't rolling down rocks. 

I've owned Patagonia pants of much thinner material and have been climbing in them for years with no issues. These pants are not worth the money if you actually want to use them for non-cragging wear.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I bought two pairs at the beginning of this summer, and used them on climbing trips periodically this season. Not an absurd amount, but they received use - maybe 20 wears each since the beginning of summer. 

The durability of these pants is the worst I've ever experienced in a climbing-specific pant - jeans are better.
1. Both have holes and tear at the slightest abrasion of rock. I've had climbing pants (even yoga pants) withstand greater force. 
2. Climbing is a dirty sport - between the dusty crag and rope scum, clothing gets dirty. I have no idea why, but this fabric hold onto dirt and grime even after being washed. Especially the purple ones. To quote one of my climbing friends: 'you look like a coal miner' - and this was after washing them! I can only wear these in a dirt-bag friendly environment (i.e. the crag) and not out in public, because I look too damn dirty and greasy. 
3. They are NOT breathable - in warm weather I sweat when I climb. And the color/material combination creates the most embarrassing butt sweat line - ever.

All around, these pants have the worst utility of any athletic pant I've purchased. I've purchased many patagonia clothing items in the past and have never been this dissatisfied with an item.  I'm trying to return them - but have to go outside of Backcountry and file a complaint through Patagonia. It's unfortunate that return policies are at 30 days now - if a pant craps out at 2 months, that's unacceptable in my perspective. Especially for $80 pants that should last YEARS!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Bought these as a gift for a friend and here is what she had to say.

" These pants are wonderful. I like the mogul blue color a lot. They are very comfortable and perfect for an active day. Something that I think would benefit these pants would be to add a tie around the waist because the waist size doesn’t match well with the leg size. So this way you can get the right size in the legs but still have the waist fit without having to wear a belt. "
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: After reading the reviews, I decided to go with a size 2 instead of my usual size 4, and I'm so happy with the pants. They fit well, and have so much stretch! The adjustable waist is a great feature, but I don't even need it because they fit my hips perfectly. I love having a stylish pair of pants that I can wear to work, climbing after, and hiking on the weekends. They are also fairly windproof, as I learned today while hiking a gusty ridgeline in Rocky Mtn NP. Also, the thigh pocket is perfect for stashing my phone so that I can get it out quickly for photo ops! Overall, very satisfied and looking forward to getting lots of use out of these pants.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Comfy pants. Moves easily, no binding.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I ordered size 2. I'm a slight muscular build, and these pants are stretched tight around my thighs, even tighter around my butt, and gapingly too big around my waist! Though the fabric is nice and stretchy, it is not something I would be comfortable walking/hiking/climbing in. Because they're mostly cotton, I would anticipate a sweaty and sticky time going anywhere in these pants.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: i got this pant one month ago, as i am based in China, it took a long time for shipment, when i got it i find the zip was broken, so i contacted bc, but they say it's outside the return time, ask me talk to Patagonia directly, i am so disappointed, u should not pass all responsibilities to customer.
Having first starting with the baggies shorts I figured the pants would be fairly similar. I thought the pockets were fairly shallow compared to the shorts but overall I'm happy with my purchase.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Lightweight material, good in hot weather, dries fast

Fit is not great. Just awkwardly shaped. As another review stated, definitely induces plumber's crack.

Worst thing: pockets. These are those types of pants where your wallet, phone, especially coins or small items are going to fall out of your pocket every time you sit down. Very, very bad pocket design. I was unable to return these since I was out of the country with them for a month and beyond return period, but essentially these will go on the shelf and not be worn again unless everything else is in the laundry.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: These pants are extremely comfortable. When you bend over however, the rear seems a bit low.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: My husband claims that after years of cooking his flesh he is done with the sun.  In addition to a pretty dorky hat he does his lake swimming and river running in a pair of these.  They seem to dry off pretty quick and the ankle gaskets make long pant swimming possible.  Take that skin cancer!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I also ordered the baggie shorts and absolutely fell in love with them.  These pants, while as described and completely did the trick, just felt like they were lacking.  I wore them over a couple days of long hiking through grass full of ticks and snakes.  The weather was hot and although forced to wear long pants I did not feel overheated in these.  

Would like more pocket space.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
Really, my husband has never been nude since owning his first pair of camo baggies, I'll spare you the details. I was not sure when I brought these bad boys home, but for him,  it was love at first site and I become chop liver.  The baggies pants are  made of durable nylon with a DWR, which makes them a really great lightweight shell pant for spring/winter hiking or to pull on post skiing or mountain biking. The camo print makes these his party pants, so he really has no reason to where anything else.

Photo: Post ride in Quincy, Ca. Also pictured is Patagonia's Nano Air jacket and a random panda shirt.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This pant really represents the best of both worlds. They are comfy, lightweight, and stylish. They're great for lounging around or just going out and about. Perfect for summer wear if you're a flip flop or Chaco person with the elastic cuffs.  The pant is a thin material and is really breathable but can be worn in slightly colder environments as well. The  only downsize which is minor would be the shallow pockets on the hips.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Theses are another outstanding Patagonia product with a comfortable fit, light-weight and button up rear pocket. I am 5ft 11 and about 160lbs and mediums fit well minus the rear of the pants.
Only negative as mentioned in previous reviews, is not enough material on the rear exposing your plumbers crack each time you bend over. I am surprised that Patagonia missed such a glaring defect, but I guess thats why they are on sale.....
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: These are great! Light! You will wear these all the time.  I do!

I got these in pants for me and my boyfriend (don't worry we don't wear them on the same days) and we both love them!  They are super comfy to lounge around the house in, stylish enough to wear around town and durable/technical enough to wear fishing or hiking. 

Fit/sizing:
They do run small as I am 5'1, 120 lbs and I got the men's size small and they fit pretty well, a tiny bit long but since they're a jogger style the elastic at the bottom keeps them from dragging.  My boyfriend is 5'11 , 150 lbs with skinny legs and the medium fits perfectly.  

Pros: 
Stylish 
Quick dry 
Durable
Keeps you cool 

Cons:
Loud (think George Costanza swooshy suit) 
They don't make them in more sweet colors like the camo/hickory print 
Things fall out of the front pockets super easy 

If you're looking for a slimmer pant for lounging, traveling, hiking, or fishing that isn't your traditional baggy convertible pant, I would highly recommend the Patagonia baggies pant.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
These pants are supper comfy and breathable I won't wear anything else while fishing/guiding from a drift boat.
They are not to baggy and the elastic cuff at the bottom are great for when your walking around in flip flops and in and out of the water. They have proven to be durable enough for one guide season.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Great looking, comfy, only complaint is that if you have athletic butt when, you bend over you expose your plumbers crack.

These pants are super lightweight and I've found them to fit really well. I'm 5'10, 175lbs and I typically wear a 33, and the large fits perfect. They're exceptionally comfortable, and you definitely can't go wrong with camo these days either!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I purchased the mediums and I was told they measure: 32 x 32. 

I'm 6'2" and I had to return these pants because they didn't fit well on me. First of all, the pants are super light weight and are of thin material. The pants seemed shorter than a 32in length, but that might be because of the elastic. Also, they are a slim fit.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: These pants have made the long drive from Seattle to Nelson to Jackson and back to Utah. They offer great comfort and breathability for long drives in the car and airplane rides. They are also great lounge pants but do have one flaw. The vertical fit in the waist section is too short which causes the pants to show some plumbers crack should you bend over. A slight update to the vertical fit length in the waist would give these pants a five star rating.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
These pants are great - part sweat pant, part wind pant, part throwback style - all awesome.  They're super comfortable and and make for a great casual pant. I've also ridden my bike and nordic skied in them a bit this winter with a lightweight baselayer underneath.   
Can't go wrong with the camo, and then you've got navy or ash tan for more formal occasions.

These are great pants for lazy days. I am a diehard Patagonia fan, but unfortunately didn't find the fit to be great. 5'11 with short legs and the medium was the right length. Find them to be slightly boxy and tight when I try to stretch my legs or bend over. Great for casual campfires and lounging around.
Great shirt. Will shrink to fit, so if you're between sizes go larger.
My boyfriend was needing new shirts and he loved this shirt. (:
This shirt is super comfortable. just make sure to hang dry if you don't want any shrinkage on it.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: High quality like expected. Soft yet durable. Have yet to wash. $39 for a t shirt is a lot so it better last.

Shirt is great quality and the color, I got the blue one, is awesome. It will shrink like crazy. I usually wear a medium but decided to order a large and it shrunk down quite a bit. At first I was swimming in it, but after a wash and dry it had shrunk down to a good size.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: nice heavy weight t-shirt. it is a little tight in the shoulders otherwise a great shirt. i am hang drying because i do not want any shrinkage.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Super cool, soft, comfortable, and was able to get a great deal on it! Would buy another shirt like this in a heartbeat.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought one of these years ago. It's in great shape and I still wear it. I was in the market for some new polos and decided to try a couple more (in Spiced Coral and Gem Green). They fit great, there's a variety of styles to choose from, and the fabric is comfortable.
really want to love this shirt, great material. Coral color is on point, but the sleeves cut seems to always get twisted up on me.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: its a gift for my father , he love the color and material is very comfortable
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is a decent polo shirt but I prefer the Patagonia daily tri blend polo shirt.
Perfect collared shirts for casual anytime occasions.  Also, they can pair nicely with khaki's for the office.

So before I bought this shirt I read the reviews and I know Patagonia runs large usually, so I wanted to do my research.  While reading the reviews everything was right these shirts do run large and as i got further down, a lot of the people my weight were ordering smalls.  That had me worried, last time I got a shirt that was a small I was probably in middle school.  So with some hesitation I ordered a small.  When I put the small polo on, it fit like a glove.  Really glad I went with a small because if a small fit perfectly then the medium would of been too big.  Material feels great, very soft feel and it has a great look to it.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Great for Golfing , Relaxing or anything where you want to be comfortable and presentable.

This shirt has been great for those occasions when comfort is a must, but you need to look a little better than dressing in just a tee. The fabric has a nice soft feel and I always get compliments whenever I wear this shirt. I have this shirt in several colors and  it also travels well.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I love Patagonia even though they are on the pricey side, largely because everything they make fits well, is durable, and can be used in different situations. 

The squeaky clean polo is super soft, a great length in the arms (not too long, and not too baggy like a golf shirt), and a great length. 

That said, I read previous reviews and was glad I picked up a size smaller than my normal Patagonia sizing as I'd read these run large. I got a small when I usually wear medium, and it fits perfectly. 

This is a great polo for around the house, at the office, traveling, and everyday lounging. Can't recommend it highly enough!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I want to keep this shirt but it's too big.  I may try a Small.
I am 5'11" 155 and the Medium is boxy and long, aka too big. 
I am a slim fit by J.Crew standards but don't have much else to compare this polo to.  I have had issues with Patagonia Jackets before seeming to be "barrel cut" but just couldn't resist the sale price along with all of the positive reviews for trying out the squeaky clean.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I really like this shirt.  Its got a little stretch to it.  Fits well, and I have big shoulders.  Love the materials used and as usual, top quality construction from Patagonia.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
What is it with manufacturers lately?  Most larges aren't very large.  

This shirt gives me plenty of room and is sized correctly for what a large is supposed to be.  

The last few casual dress shirts my wife has bought me have fit like complete shit.  I don't see how I can be 5' 7" tall and have the majority of large shirts out there almost feel tight or be too small through the shoulders and chest.  And lets not forget the lengths either.  They fit me just right or are even short on me.  If I was 6' tall or taller I would be showing my mid drift.  Showing off my belly button lint makes a real statement.  

Is the new style looking like the weird douches that try and squeeze into skinny jeans?  It is like the scrawny malnourished look of 90's supermodels has hit mens fashion.   

There are Big and Tall stores..  Maybe I missed the Short and stout ones?   

Patagonia seems to do pretty well with their sizing.   The length is the only real issue for me.  I am not usually a tucker when it comes to shirts.   

It almost seems weird finally getting back into a shirt that fits the way normal sizing should be.
This is an excellent shirt. It fits true to size and is very comfortable. It looks sharp too, so you can't go wrong! It's held up great after several months of machine washing.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: As others have stated, this shirt fits true to size as a regular fit.   It's a really comfortable material and the colors are excellent.  I really like this shirt.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I agree with everyone else who says this is true to size, but these days it is important to note that this is true to size on the scale of more traditional regular fit shirts. If you are used to buying more of the slim fit/modern styles you may want to size down. I'm always between a Large and XL and am definitely a Large for this shirt. 

And it's a great shirt! A nice simple quality polo with lots of color options.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Julie from Patagonia shares her thoughts on the Patagonia Squeaky Clean Polo Shirt.
Great fabric, looks good and feel soft!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Fits great, not too loose, not too tight. Size is correct.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is a great pack for climbing trips - simple, minimalist, light, yet comfortable to carry as well.  I got this to use on Mt Rainier and it was perfect.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
This pack is my go-to for any and all alpine adventures. The lightweight design and the added full length daisy chain allow for so much versatility. I will be heading down to Aconagua soon using this as a summit pack. I've also gotten some Winter overnighters in with just this pack and not having to worry about taking a separate summit pack as this pack is light enough to be that pack as well. I've also gotten many days in touring with it and the ski carry makes it perfect for a quick rappel if needed. You can macgyver a snowboard onto it, but if you use a split, you can simply use the ski carry option too.  I haven't had any issue with the suspension system, even when fully packed out. I would definitely recommend this pack as it is not a one use pack, and can serve as a multitool pack for any and all alpine adventures.

Feel free to reach directly out with any and all questions!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I have the 35L and use it as a summit pack for Rainier,  I wanted a slightly larger pack for Europe and climbing Mont Blanc, this thing was the perfect size for so many hikes and climbs I did for the 6 weeks I was in Europe. 

The straps and belt are very comfortable and I had zero issues with the pack being stuffed to its max. 

I had guys from the UK checking it out while we were in the Midi tunnel coming back from acclimatizing,  They were really impressed with the features and the ease of how I was able to cinch it all back together after stowing all my gear back in it.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Patagonia climbing Ambassador Kelly Cordes shares his thoughts on the redesigned Ascensionist packs

So far I've only used the bag for getting to sport crags and backcountry skiing. It's super light and offers nice back distribution adjustments. The gear loops on the outside have come in handy when I need the extra room. It holds my skis well and there is plenty of room for rope, helmet, and gear. I wish the brain had more to offer; there is very little volume. It's really just a flap to tie down the pack. Overall, nice design and tough fabric. Definitely not the best option if you're only rock climbing, but I look forward to using it more in Ouray.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I used this pack for a 1 month trip to CO including some ice, mixed, and rock climbing, as well as some day hikes up some non-technical peaks. It's a perfect size to fit layers and climbing gear for an day trip in the alpine. It is also a good size for a crag bag for my rock climbing gear.  The fabric seems nice and durable, no signs of wear or abrasion after a pretty busy month. I found the gear loops and straps to be convenient and well thought out. (I particularly like the small elastic/metal pieces to lock down ice-axe & ice tools).

The pack is probably a little bit small for multi-day trips (though you can manage if you strap enough camping gear on the outside for the approach). Also, the lack of external water bottle pockets and very simple design are perfect for climbing, but probably not the most convenient for general hiking and backpacking (though I used this bag on plenty of day hikes, and it worked quite well).

Picture: getting into some ice on the dreamweaver couloir on Mt Meeker in Rocky Mountain National Park
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Carry

I own several ascensionist packs, well pretty much every size, and these new ones are hands down, an improvement in some ways and lack in other ways. The 40L is an ideal size for the technical ski tours or longer alpine objectives, hut tours, or as a guides pack. You can easily get a full rack rope and helmet inside, as well as snow safety equipment if you are using it for technical ski mountaineering. It is lightweight and the new material seems to be more durable than on the previous generation. I do miss the spindrift collar for when you are trying to get as much in it as you can, as it did keep the weather out. Overall, it has been a great pack so far. I have used it extensively for the last several months, for those that have had durability concerns from the last generation. This includes multi day ski tours, overnight alpine trips, and technical ski mountaineering where the skis are on the pack a good share of the time. I can easily fit a probe, shovel, saw, full snow study kit, down jacket, first aid kit w/emergency tarp, an emergency sled, helmet, 30m rope, gloves, water, food, and other various items needed, all inside the pack with room for more, for a general idea of what it is capable of.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This is a simple, well thought out pack that has all the features you need and none that you don't. At about half the weight of many competing products, the Ascensionist is an alpinist's best friend, providing dual ice axe loops, well padded straps that don't absorb water, a removable back panel, and a simple closure system with a couple zip pockets to keep track of the random nick nacks. 

Fully packed, the carry system was very comfortable, evenly distributing the weight and keeping things close to the body. I found that the waist belt would loosen a bit while touring, probably due to having a smaller waist and being pretty maxed out on the adjustment. I have a good friend who also uses this bag that hasn't experienced the same issue, so it may just come down to body type.

I missed the extra capacity of the previous model as well as the spindrift collar, which allowed for some over-stuffing on bigger trips out. That said, with the dual daisy chains running the length of the pack there are tons of options for strapping down gear and tailoring it to your needs.

All in all, a solid choice for a go-to alpine pack. The 40L capacity is dead on for a short multi-day tour or a bigger alpine objective. The pack never feels bulky and held up well to crampon points and ski edges. If you're trying to keep things fast and light you'd be hard-pressed to find a better bag for the job.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: We quickly learned that while winter hiking we needed to keep our daughter warm. That means we dress her just like we dress ourselves. The capilene base is perfect to start with. It keeps her warm and wicks any moisture. The new designs on these are super cute. If you plan to have your toddler outside this winter Id DEFINITELY recommend this. I've noticed all of Patagonia's clothing to run slightly large. This is the same, but you can easily roll up sleeves and pants. I like to buy winter clothes slightly large so she has time to grow into them. Pair it with a fleece vest and a nano puff bunting and you'll be set.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This is a great set for under snow clothes or just to stay warm and comfortable. They have a great look and the pink knee patch is a fun detail. The fabric has some stretch. Have not put to the test yet but happy with product.

A very active pair of friends recently had a little arrival and I wanted something outdoorsy to give to the kid.  She looks amazingly cute in this little outfit!  It works great as a baselayer for when they need to bundle her up underneath more insulation and on it's own around the house on a winter day.  The snap bottom on the shirt facilitates diaper changing nicely.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I've tried a lot of base layers for babies, but keep coming back to this one every time. Material keeps them warm, but is breathable and very durable for active babies. Maybe a bit on the big side, but most of the babies have been on the slim rather than chubby side. We've used it for hiking and skiing, layering it with a Patagonia down bunting during the winter.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: What makes a good baselayer for an infant/toddler?  Fit, comfort and warmth.  The Patagonia Capilene Midweight Set does all three pretty well as it helped keep my girl warm during a colder X-Mas day in Salt Lake and the material is very comfy as her skin is a bit problematic with other materials, but not this one.  The fit was a bit on the larger side but still fit pretty well with my girl being a bit of a tall string bean for her age.  Definitely recommended.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: First of all, this outfit is adorable! It has reinforced knees, which are great since my daughter is crawling everywhere. We use this outfit when we take her hiking in the baby carrier pack. We typically use it as a base layer, under a Patagonia bunting. It helps her stay dry if sweaty, and stay warm overall. The great thing is that she can easily wear it out and about after. It fits true to size.

I love the classic look and feel to this shirt, and the silky material is a bonus. Drapes nicely, blocks UV rays. A little large, but that's typical with most Patagonia items I find. The white was very sheer, so I exchanged for the gray.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Super comfortable, moisture-wicking fabric perfect nearly all year. Great for layering under a vest. Sleeves are  a little long for me, so I just roll them. Like the longer length--keeps me covered even when bending over.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: As a petite outdoors woman, I've struggled to find clothing that fits both me and my adventures! Patagonia is the only brand that I've found works for my size, and truly fits. I've worn this particular shirt on all-day whitewater rafting, boating, swimming and paddleboarding excursions. It is perfect for sun protection in the heat (I tolerated about 80 degrees & then would wet it). It's fast drying, light weight and comfortable: I would highly recommend it!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Patagonia makes shirts for women who are built like boys (no hips), so I had to order a large. It's a bit big, but I love it. I bought it for biking the bridge in Charleston, SC. I like to bike in the middle of the day when it's 90 degrees and 80% humidity - steamy. While wearing the Tropic isn't quite like wearing a tank top, I never get overheated and the breeze goes right through the shirt. Best of all, my arms don't get fried in the sun. Even standing still on the asphalt, without a breeze, is tolerable. It wicks sweat away fast. I'm really impressed.  At the end of two hours of biking in the blazing sun my sleeves are still cool to the touch.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought this shirt primarily for sun protection, since it is advertised as such.  It is a very nice looking shirt - definitely one of my better looking long sleeve poly LS shirts.  Now I may be too critical since I live in Texas where the temps can easily be 90's -- I don't know how much of an "airy cool refuge" it will be here, as it is polyester and a bit heavier than I imagined it would be.  Also, the sleeves are not loose, so it does have that "cling-to" polyester feel.However, it should live up to its UPF 50 and its anti-microbial claim, so it will be a keeper.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I had no idea that this shirt had a large fish on the back of it, but it's included in the picture (my bad) I was expecting a loose fit shirt, but it's more of a fitted style. The material is ultra soft and comfy! I've been running in the shirt and it's a great light weight layer that is thin enough to fit into my fanny pack when it gets hot out!

column5:
Favorite mountain bike shirt. Fits a bit more generously than other Patagonia tech T's, which allows for good air flow and more coverage on the back. You can also a achieve a more downhill look, if that is what you are after. The raglan sleeves help too. The back zipper pocket comes in handy for snacks, keys, end emergency TP.  Tropic comfort also slays on a paddle board and in hiking boots. 

Photo: Beach break while  mountain biking in Jamaica with the hubby. Tropic comfort  lived up to it's name!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Bought this as a gift. She loves it. The back pocket is awesome for her chap stick and other small items. She loves how super comfy and how it fits.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This shirt is so comfortable, lightweight, moisture-wicking. My only complaint is that the sleeves are a tad long. I roll them a couple inches, and I don't think my arms are particularly short.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I. Love. This. Thing.  Probably my favorite piece of gear I’ve ever bought for under $50.  It is lightweight and thin enough to fit under a pretty tight helmet and is so breathable!  Read: it will not turn into a block of ice next to your mouth and skin due to frozen breath condensation.  In windy and colder conditions, it will require another layer depending on how hot or cold you run.  Personally, I tend to run pretty warm, so as long as I’m moving around, I’ve found very few instances that this thing wasn’t enough for my face and neck in winter conditions.

I just went winter camping up in the mountains at Uninta Wasatch Cache National Forrest. I wore this at night when sleeping and it kept me very warm! Its warm but lightweight, compressible, and comfortable to wear.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I have been snowboarding forever and always wore the thermal, wool neck warmers but could never figure out how to keep my mouth and nose warm without looking like a bank robber.  This balaclava is lighter weight but still keeps my neck, head, mouth and nose well protected which is a complete game changer on snowy days. Without pulling apart my hood/jacket, I can easily grab it with my gloves on and slide it on/off my face. Although I would definitely recommend this balaclava, I wish it came in a smaller size so it could be tighter and more wind resistant on my face - it is a bit thin too.
Much thinner material than I expected for a "thermal weight" material. Any wind cuts right through the material.

My go to for when it's so cold out your face tingles and numbs up.  Very lightweight and protects you from most wind and cold situations no problem. Throw a beanie over this and you are pretty much ready for a full on blizzard. 


"You must understand that there is more than one path to the top of the mountain"
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Zip-Neck Hooded Top - Women's
column5:
I purchased this top for active use in cooler temps. 

I love the Elwa blue color, hood, thumb holes in the sleeves, and 1/4 zipper. My only complaint, which is a large reason I haven't worn it too much, is that the fit is a bit odd on me. For my long torso I feel like there's barely enough length, yet kind of an odd, baggy fit around the midsection. Not a super flattering fit for my lean build.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Zip-Neck Hooded Top - Women's
column5: This piece is so cool. You can wear it next to your skin, on top of a thin tee shirt, or even as an in-between layer underneath a puffy jacket and be super warm. I have only used this on one trip so far but it is quickly becoming a regular in the rotation! It kept me very warm in sub 20 degree temps overnight but was also really comfortable during the day when worn alone in the sixties.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Zip-Neck Hooded Top - Women's
column5:
I gave this layer to my sister for Christmas and she literally wears it so much we have to harass her to take it off and wash it  every once in a while. We'll call this one a winner.

Side note: The ponytail hole is kind of weird but amusing (tbd how useful it proves).
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Zip-Neck Hooded Top - Women's
column5: This is the best base layer I've encountered. Fits true to size and is so cozy and comfortable and breathable. Keeps me warm and dry during cold (sub 20 degrees), yet sweaty mountain bike rides. I was SO happy to discover a little slit in the hood that I could slide my ponytail through to keep my hair off my neck when having the hood up. Patagonia thought of everything! Has a bit of a funky smell at first but goes away after the first wash. Wish they had more colors!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Zip-Neck Hooded Top - Women's
column5:
I think if I were to be stranded on an island that happened to have fabulous climbing and alpine touring and was only allowed one base/midlayer, this would be it. No question. 

Fuzzy little waffles snuggle up against your skin, swaddling you in softness and warmth... Then when your core temperature nears that of the center of the earth, the nearly translucent channels between insulation squares dump off excess heat so you don't get clammy while hiking. Also, with the generous zipper, you don't need to take off your helmet to layer or delayer!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Zip-Neck Hooded Top - Women's
column5:
The Patagonia Capilene thermal weight zip neck hoody is my go to backcountry (and resort) ski layer.  I'll literally pull it our of the dirty laundry and wear it anyways... even when I shouldn't. "Why?", you may ask. This base layer is the perfect amount of warm and breathable. I find it is generally warm enough to wear on its own when the tour gets steep or sunny, but not so much that it makes you sweat profusely or want to take it off. Also, I'm a no-hat kind of ski-tourer, so I love that you can effortlessly pop the hood up mid-tour if it gets shady or windy and your find your ears to be frozen. 

But wait, how does it fit? 
This baselayer is listed as slim-fitting (as I tend to want my baselayers). It has a nice form-hugging feel so you can add a plethora of extra layers, but it is not uncomfortably tight. The thumb loops are great to slip on when you want to add your puffy and don't want your baselayer sleeves to roll up with it. I don't wear the thumb loops while touring, usually because I pull the sleeves up around my forearms for air anyways, but they are cozy enough that you could. 

I am a little over 5'9'' and about 140 lbs. I am fairly athletically built with broad shoulders and muscular arms. I usually wear a Patagonia medium or size 6, and the medium fits me perfectly. I have a fairly long torso and the hem hits me right about at the hips. It is long enough to tuck in, but not long enough to be bulky. The sleeves are the perfect length for my wingspan, and the hood fits over my head perfectly. 

I think my favorite feature of this top is the zipper/hoody combo. The zipper is great because when it is really warm, you can unzip and get good airflow. However, when its really cold, you can zip it up to your chin and pop a hat or helmet. Suddenly, the icy wind or cold snow isn't blowing down your neck anymore. Keeping your head and neck cool or warm (respectively), is one of the best ways to thermoregulate and prevent excessive heat gain/loss. 

The only downside of this piece is that I find it has what I call.... the "perma-pew." Since I do use this layer for sweat inducing ski tours or ice climbs, it usually gets really stinky. After just one use post-wash, it is back to smelling like I've been living in the woods without a bath for months. It definitely doesn't have any sort of odor guard, but hey, you're going to be outside anyways right? 

Hope this review was helpful. I very much recommend this top over other capilene or base layers by other companies for cold weather activities such as ski touring or ice climbing.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Zip-Neck Hooded Top - Women's
column5: Review to come. Truly my most worn layer.

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Zip-Neck Hooded Top - Women's
column5:
Sending an enormous thank you to Patagonia and Backcountry.com for selecting me to review this piece. I'm really happy to be a part of the awesome community that is Backcountry.com! Thanks for making me feel 'at home'!

My current measurements:
Height: 5' 4.75"
Weight: 105 lbs./47.6 kg
Pant size: 0/25 - Waist: 26 in.
Bra size: 34AA
Neck: 12.5 in.
Biceps: average 8.5 in.

DISCLAIMER: I have yet to test this piece as a true baselayer/layering piece, so my review is incomplete! However, I do have some things to say about the fit, so that if you do choose to get it, you'll at least know what size to go with.

FIT--BODY: The fit is listed as Patagonia's slim fit. Indeed, this size is true to their slim fit--which for my measurements, still has a little bit of wiggle room. Though Patagonia does make this in an XXS, which probably would fit me from just under my band measurement and down, I have slightly broad shoulders and 1+ in. ape index, so I needed all the length out of the arms I could get. The loops for the thumbs are slightly constricting for me at first because of this, but because of sensory adaptation, I don't feel them after a couple minutes, and go about my business just fine. I can see that when I go skiing these will really come in... handy (yeah, pun intended). The length of this piece is just right--hits about an inch below where my belt is on low-ish-rise jeans. It will be great for tucking into pants while skiing--it'll stay put since it doesn't run short, and I have a pretty long torso compared to my legs. Finally, the chest isn't restricting at all for me since I have a small chest. And because I have room there, I reckon--all other measurements being accurate--an XS may be good for even a smaller B-cup, perhaps. But of course, try it on if you can.

FIT--HOOD: The hood fits really nicely over my head, without constricting any part of my neck--it moves well even if you turn your head downward and side to side. Of course, you may look like a little alien (I have it in that awesome green) but I like it and it's super functional--YOU CAN PUT YOUR PONY TAIL THROUGH THE BACK!!!!

FIT--NECK: I'm really finicky about zippers near my windpipe--so whenever a zipper even slightly touches me there, I really notice it, but maybe it's just me. In fact, I think the placement of the zipper and its ability to NOT constrict the neck are some of the nice features about this baselayer; the neck is not--I repeat--not tight, and somehow the patterning of this piece manages to fit over the chin perfectly without being tight or awkward (which for me, will be nice while running in cold weather). It kind of comes up toward the center when fully zipped, leading to coverage even toward your lower lip. It's going to be great for cold temps in various settings. 

PERFORMANCE: Like I said, I haven't tried this out as a baselayer. It hasn't been cold enough to give it a try as such, but I've worn it as my top layer in about 55ÂºF + weather, and it seems really breathable even at those temps, and hasn't gotten stinky in between wears. I'm a moderate sweater.

BOTTOM LINE: Though updates and pics are indeed to come, I can recommend that this piece should perform fantastically in cold temperatures as a baselayer. (Though I've really been loving it even as a go-to "pull over" for the time being!) Be sure to take some measurements and get the right size--you don't want it too loose, as it is a baselayer.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Crew Top - Women's
column5: great!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Crew Top - Women's
column5:
After owning my fair share of low quality base layers, I finally splurged and got myself a capilene thermal and I will never regret that decision. Unlike the other baselayers I have owned, this is remarkably warm and REALLY thin. Like it dries so fast its like magic. Even soaking wet out of the washer, it takes less than 20 mins to hang dry.  That being said, it also remains super dry and warm during high output activities. I've worn this running, XC skiing and to the office on cold days, stays dry and keeps me toasty no matter what. Long sleeve is really low bulk and feels thin but packs the heat. Would 1000000000% recommend this to anyone who runs cold or needs a solid warm baselayer for winter activities. 

I usually wear a medium I most brand for tops and the medium fits well in this shirt. Only complaint is that the arms are just a lil short. I have long arms though  so it should fit a normal person fine. Fit is a regular fit, not skin tight but not baggy.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Crew Top - Women's
column5: I bought this for my sister who is eternally cold and she literally wears it everyday under sweaters to work, on hikes or just lounging around the house. She is about 5' 7" and a medium fits well without being too loose or too tight. The fit is more "relaxed" but still a thin enough layer that packs a lot of heat should she have to layer up more with a sweater or jacket.  The fabric is very soft, breathable and not bulky. She loves it!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Crew Top - Women's
column5: My husband got me hooked on the Patagonia Capilene a few years ago and I love them. The thermal keeps me warm while wicking away sweat. I have a few of the zip neck shirts but have found the crew neck is easier to later for those extra cold days.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight Crew Top - Women's
column5: I gave these to my Fiancé for Christmas and she loves them.  She says they are warm and fit true to size.  Also they don't restrict movement.  I never have to worry about her getting cold with these as a base layer.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I'm in love with my R1 and glad I opted for the hood! This is definitely more of a technical piece than a casual piece, however I think it can be worn both ways...the zipper reaches almost halfway down the front of the fleece, which is great for venting when your body temp spikes. The hood, when fully zipped, acts as a balaclava -perfect for snuggling into my sleeping bag on chilly nights as it replaces the need for a beanie for extra warmth. Thumbholes are always a nice addition to activewear, and a generous zippered chest pocket lets me stash small necessities.    

Awesome layering piece. Thanks to the Polartec Power Grid, this fleece is lightweight and the definition of breathable. It's powerless against wind, so be prepared and have something to throw on over top when the gusts pick up. Slim fit it is!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I am extremely disappointed with Patagonia's customer service and choices about their updates to the R-line. The previous R-line had a unique fleece fiber that I haven't encountered in any other brand or line. Unfortunately, Patagonia chose to update their R-line so that it mirrored less competitive rival brands and their materials. 
I sent my R2 jacket in to be repaired and wrote specific notes about how I would pay for any repairs that they could not fix for free. I expected the detailed notes to be an obvious sign that I would like to keep my jacket. However, I had inadvertently neglected a box that noted if they could throw my item out after they had determined if it could be repaired or not. This was particularly upsetting because they DO NOT MAKE THIS JACKET anymore and it had strong sentimental value! When I sent my pack to REI recently, they called to let me know they received it and emailed pictures of the damaged areas to make sure they knew what I intended to be repaired. However, Patagaonia sent 2 emails and then "chopped up" (in their words!) my irreplaceable jacket. As I previously said, extremely disappointing.

I got this as a gift for my fiancee to round out her backcountry ski and climbing layering setup.  She had been looking at an R1 for a while, so I finally pulled the trigger and snagged her one.  Her only feedback was that the fit is a little on the smaller side.  With this, I sized up to the Medium (she is 5'8''/Athletic) and it worked out perfect!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Instant favorite, only gripe is the hood leaves a tiny gap for your eyes. It's fine for skiing but kind of eliminates the possibility for wearing casually too. But it's still awesome, love the deep zipper. Normally wear xs in Patagonia, the small on this piece fits better.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Everyone is envious of this fleece. Excellent for touring. Keeps me warm yet dry when working up a sweat. The hood stays tight and keeps my ears warm when the wind starts ripping. When i am sweating to death the chest zip is unbelievably low and allows air to cool you down. Love the color and fit. A little higher neck to duck my chin into when im too nippy. Favorite new layer!
I really love the idea and the feel of the R1 but even sizing up to a medium, my climber shoulders felt constricted and armpits pinched when I moved my arms about.

The medium was so tight there is no extra room for layering and the large was really big. I think the design would fit someone w an hour glass shape. I have athletic build body with thick waist (31 in). This is my 3rd attempt for Patagonia brand outfits and I had to return all. I guess Patagonia is just not for me.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: This was given as a a gift but I was provided feedback. Patagonia is always a win. The zipper length is a bit awkward but it makes it quite easy to take off after a long day on the slopes.  It's very lightweight but provides great warmth as a base layer or light jacket during fall/spring. The recipient has average to long arm lengths and find no issues with the arms being too short as others have reviewed, in fact there's a little excess.

I returned this product because the sleeves/thumbholes were too short, and a bigger size would have been too boxy. I have long arms. The R1 is great in so many ways - lightweight but warm, breathable, and I LOVE the hood and the face coverage features on it, including the extra-soft zipper covers. They've really thought of everything. Ultimately, I decided I want something that I can have my thumbs through the thumbholes while climbing if necessary, or belaying, or putting on a jacket - and this was just too tight.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: A quick spring crawl up Looking Glass Rock with my best friend. Moab, UT.

The R1 is my go-to layer for highly aerobic outdoor activities in cold temps, whether it's charging up a skin track or climbing a couple of blustery pitches after work. Oh, and really aggressive lounging/snacking activities apres-ski. The soft, waffly material will keep you cozy and comfy warm, but can dump excess heat when you start moving.

The 3/4 zip feature is fabulous if you'll be layering and de-layering while wearing a helmet or hat-- I can easily take it on or off while wearing my POC Receptor Helmet or BD Vector Helmet when climbing or skiing. It serves the additional purpose of allowing you to thoroughly ventilate your torso if you start overheating. Some people have qualms about the extra long zipper, but if you're using it for the purpose of high-output alpine activities, I believe the design reflects user needs and offers great benefits for keeping cool and quick layer transitions.

However, as a fairly tall and gangly armed person (read my reviews and you'll notice this is a common theme), there is one MAJOR CON: the damn arms on this pullover are WAY short in comparison to the length and width of the body. Especially if I'm wearing a this with gloves or spending time at cold belays, thumb holes are a must have for me. If I wear the thumb holes on this for longer than 5 or 10 minutes, the loop starts digging in between my thumb and index finger to the point of being unbearable (yes, I know how melodramatic this sounds, and I don't care). The torso on the size medium is already a bit loose, and if I size up to a large, the sleeves fit better (not perfectly) but I'm swimming in the body. For reference, I am 5'9", have a 5'10"ish wingspan, and weigh between 130-140lbs.

The fit is distinctly baggier than in years past. I don't think my body type is THAT abnormal, but it seems like this piece would only get a five star rating from me if I could sew size large arms on to a size small or medium hoody. 

Overall, I LOVE the material and the design idea of the R1 hoody, but I wish I could get the fit dialed better.

I bought this as a gift for my fiance and she almost never takes it off.  Whether she's wearing it on a hike, with her sweats, or our running errands, it always looks great, performs well, and is super comfortable.  
She's got the Howling Turquoise color and has gotten several comments on how good the color scheme looks.  
I see other people have commented on the high zip, which has been the tradition on all R1s hoodies for a while.  Although the zipper isn't offset as in past years, it doesn't seem to bother her at all.  
The one thing that's interesting is the 3/4 zipper.  It's sort of an impractical design, because I'm not sure of any situation where you would wear something unzipped 3/4 of the way down.  Maybe a half zip or full zip would suit more people.
All in all, it's a really great piece and I'd highly recommend it!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Just to be clear I've been a Patagonia fan for decades. I'm an XL normally and in no way unusual in my sizing. Unfortunately I returned it for several reasons. It's huge, way too long and the zipper was too long, i.e. Do I really need a zipper that goes to my belly button? And the zipper shield on the inside is way overbuilt and thick. Waited a long time to get one and very disappointed. In contrast I also ordered a Houdini pullover in the same size and I could barely get it on. Too small. Patagonia I love your products quality but can we PLEASE see some consistency in your womens sizing?
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: This pullover is super lightweight and warm. The fit and material are nice. Although the full face zip isn't as cozy or comfortable as I wanted it to be.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I love love the women's Patagonia R1 Fleece Hooded Pullover for many reasons (below) and highly recommend it!

First, the obvious reasons of Patagonia quality,  construction and company values. Love them all.

Second, the benefits of having three items in one: a pullover fleece, a neck gaiter and a hat. The 'scuba' looking hood acts as (at least in non-sub 10 temps) as a neck gaiter and a hat saving me from having to bring multiple items on a hike. When it is super chilly, I'll put a fleece beenie on under the hood and also pull up the hood on my outer shell to stay toasty warm.  

Third, easy temperature regulation as temperatures rise/fall throughout the day by just popping the hood down vs. pulling a neck gaiter or hat on/off and having to stash away in your pack. I also have a strange claustrophobia thing about neck-gaiters (it can feel mildly choking or suffocating to have one on) so not having to wear one above 10-20 degree weather is awesome. The low-cut front zipper also really helps to cool you down fast if you need to.

I wear it hiking, wash it after each wear and it's held up great. I don't dry it due to its form-fitting shape (and trying to save energy). While it is form-fitting, I have found if you pull/stretch it a bit, it has give without getting too stretched or floppy so if it hugs in places, you can loosen it as needed.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Okay so I have pined after this piece for awhile. And sadly, I don't fit into the men's XS. So when these came out last year I was ELATED. I bought one as soon as I could. 
The R1 has all of the great technologies of the R1 jacket and pullover but with the extra awesomeness of the hood and thumb holes. 
I usually buy an XS in the R1 series but opted for the Small as I found that they run a little more snug than the other R1 options do. 
So - it wicks well, dries well, washes well keeps me warm well and gets stinky just the way I like it. I suggest the R1 to anyone who will listen to me. 
It's pretty much the perfect base and mid layer for me! The hood definitely is fitted. Fits well under virtually anything. And makes you look a little like a scuba diver.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I talked to a friend of mine who bought the same top. She had the same thought. The size I got fit. BUT one size up would have been a bit better. Still love it and use it as a baselayer for the most part. Totally recommend.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
This is definitely my favorite patagonia baselayer. It's incredibly warm without the bulk. The offset zipper is a great feature and when it's really cold I'll pull the hood up under my helmet - it's bit snug, but I sized my helmet to fit without a hat or hood - and zip up the collar all the way up and pair it with the Patagonia Nano-Puff under my Gore-Tex Shell for some serious warmth. 
Like everything else patagonia, the construction is stellar and this is definitely an investment that will last you SEVERAL seasons. 
Fit is slim and long, so if you plan on layering underneath this you'll want to size up. If you wear it over just a t-shirt or tank, stick with your normal size.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This is a very warm fleece for how lightweight it is.  The fit slim and it is pretty long. The hood is a nice option and will stay on your head if you are on a windy peak.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Thin, but warm. The R1 is great on its own in the spring and fall and is a perfect layer in the winter. I've used it hiking, running, and climbing. It has a slim fit--a long sleeve tee fits perfect underneath, but a sweater would not. The fabric is sleek, but the fabric on the palm is starting to show a little wear. I also have to be careful when climbing on southern sandstone because it has a sandpaper quality that will shred any fabric. The balaclava is designed really well--the angled zipper keeps it from pressing on the bridge of the nose. The only thing I wished it had is two side hand pockets. It's also pricy, but for its intended purpose, it's great.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Small Fitz Roy Trout LoPro Trucker Hat
column5:
Having a 4 year old is hard, especially one as strong-willed as mine is (just like her mother).  Little did I know when I brought home matching camo Patagonia hats tonight that it will be the daddy-daughter equivalent of a best friendâs necklace.  She loved them so much she insisted on sleeping with both of our new hats by her bed.  I appreciate any opportunity to win as a dad.  I recommend this hat to all customers, but make sure you buy one for your BFF too!
Hit me up if you need help picking some out!

column2: Small Fitz Roy Trout LoPro Trucker Hat
column5: I was under the impression that the height of the hat would be at 'normal' hat height instead of super 'high off your head' trucker hat height.  That was supposed be the only difference.  For some reason the bill is also much smaller than a normal hat.  And it is crooked as other reviews mentioned.  It looks like a child's hat.  I gave it to my wife who is tiny.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Small Fitz Roy Trout LoPro Trucker Hat
column5: First, this is an awesome hat. It fits great, the colors look good, and it sits like a baseball cap with trucker styling.  I got it in black and gray which I don't see here now so it must be sold out.  The only problem, which is a big one, is that the brim of the hat is crooked compared to the rest of the body.  I've had cheaper hats with this problem before, but expected more out of the Patagonia.  I have another Patagonia lopro that's perfect so maybe I just got unlucky with this one.  It's not annoying enough to go through the trouble of sending back, plus it looks like I couldn't get a replacement now anyways.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Small Fitz Roy Trout LoPro Trucker Hat
column5:
....and now I'm embarrassed.  After reading all the reviews from people with small heads I got this hat and it wasn't small enough....apparently I have the head of a baby seal.  The look of the hat is great.  its a bit cardboardish feeling though, but I bet a couple of runs through the  wash would soften her up.  I hope you have better luck than me!
Yours Truly, 
Super Tiny Head Guy
column8: I returned this product before using it

column2: Small Fitz Roy Trout LoPro Trucker Hat
column5: Great hat, looks good, and the fit is perfect. I have a smaller dome and most trucker hats are too big and look goofy. The LoPro gives you a more streamlined fit, plus the small Fitzroy trout looks awesome.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This baby fits better than the one from last season in L/XL which was way too big.  The improvement goes nicely in tandem with the colorway.  

P.S., this baby makes a great Frisbee.  Think Kung Lao on Mortal Kombat II throwing his hat and you will have fun.
A product you need to try on in a brick and mortar store before purchasing, unless you like paying $6.95 return shipping. Patagonia needs to get their act together. S/M fits like an XL. Steer clear.

My hat size is 7 1/4 (22 3/4 inch), I ordered the small/medium thinking it would fit okay and certainly not be too loose. I was wrong, the hat is too large for me and it sits loosely on my head looking a little ridiculous. The hat seems well made and my wife (who has a large head of hair, unlike me) is happy to keep it. A very nice hat but don't go by the sizing guide on this or the Patagonia site, if your hat size is similar to mine then look elsewhere for a hat that fits.

What can you say about a bucket hat that hasn't already been said? LOTS! There are few inventions that have stood the test of time..... the wheel, computers, the bucket hat. Anyone that is anyone rocks one these days. Do you? Get in the know. Get in the bucket hat! From the moment it was placed upon my dome it was as if I was channeling Hunter S Thomspon and Run DMC at the same time.  So much style and grace rolled into one little tiny bucket hat. An experience that should be shared and enjoyed.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have used  this hat  during my hikes in the scorching Florida sun. I have had great protection. It is breathable, good quality , comfortable and also have had great compliments. Got the emerald color.  I highly recommend it.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: First day I took this hat out I decided to hit the river. The weather was being erratic as it often is in Utah, a little bit of sun and then a ton of rain. Either way rain or shine this hat came through with flying colors provides shade right where you need it and detours water  perfectly  off the sides and it was some heavy rain for a good 20 minutes and never once felt any of it penetrate the inside.  On top of being a perfect shade and water blocker the look, feel and material is top notch. I often have a hard time choosing hats mainly cause of the size of my big noggin and with dreads it adds to the circumference but the L/XL in this hat was perfect and the interior has a nice little stretch nylon rim that snugs onto your head if a gust of wind happens to catch you by surprise.  Overall first day with this hat was amazing on the river  pulling in not the biggest guys but quite a few plumb dudes. Definitely going to be ordering the other colors.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
MY first Wavefarer was directly from Patagonia.  
I liked it so much, that I wanted another. Patagonia must be out of them ( or they are discontinued?)? 
Finally found them here at a fair price.
They are lightweight, seem durable, comfortable and keep the sun out of my eyes. And just goofy enough to get compliments  from my friends.

Patagonia makes great bags and this one is a perfect size for longer runs and is nicely lightweight - but definitely not designed with women in mind!! You can't adjust the chest straps up/down and as they are, they cut straight across my bust and are extremely uncomfortable. Sadly had to return!
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I really wanted to love this pack for longer trail running. I loved pulling out of the bag, loved the zipper, and loved putting it on. Until...I strapped and cinched it on. I don't know how other women do it, but this pack cuts straight across my "bust." How is that supposed to be comfortable for a woman? I am going to have sadly return.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5:
This pack hits the sweet spot of volume and comfort for mixed adventures that involve running (or commuting). It is large enough to fit a pair of climbing shoes, a chalkbag, tape and brush, a thin Houdini-style jacket, a .5L water bottle, snacks, sunscreen, sunglasses case, extra socks, and other misc. accessories. Even with all that inside, it's pretty comfortable for running (even shirtless). I bought the pack in order to do medium-length runs (up to 10mi)  to/from climbing spots (gym, crag, boulders). Perfect for this! I could see it working just fine for longer days focused solely on running/hiking as well.

On a general dorky scale the pack is pretty high, but compared to other running packs it's pretty low. The colors are relatively subdued and there is no ugly writing or design features. I'm 6'1", 155lbs and wear S/M with room to grow in case I get super ripped (or wear layers).
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I primarily use this pack for mountain biking, but have also used it for a few day hikes. It works incredibly well for both. It's enough to fit water, snacks, and a few bike supplies and not feel too big, and even have some room left.  I was worried that without a waist strap that it would bobble around, but that is definitely not the case. It stays secure and feels good while wearing it. 
The one thing that I did notice was that it is not the best for ventilation on your back. When it's hot outside, my back would get really warm and a bit sweaty. (But what pack doesn't?). I would definitely recommend this for mountain bikers who want a small and light trail pack or for hikers going on a day hike. 
I am 5'11" and weigh 150 pounds and the S/M fit me the best
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
My mother in law wanted a new backpack that was in between the size of her other two, and this was just that! 
Plenty of room for the bladder and to carry an extra layer and snacks. Great fit and look!
Fits snug and doesn't bounce. And a 2L Platypus bladder fits right into the inside pocket but leaves room for extra clothes or snacks.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Perfect ultra lite pack for quick lite get away hikes.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Well, I started running a little while ago.  I had about 6 camelbak/other brand bladders from other packs and was looking for something of the vest type because I hate the idea of holding my water and waist packs.  I also wanted somewhere for my phone and food to go when I ran more than a hour and wanted some extra snacks to keep going.

I love Patagonia so I looked at this initially, but after looking at many alternatives I chose this due to the price.  I don;t regret it at all!  It fits great and is super light.  I love the pockets in front, it fits my 70oz hydration bladder pretty well (not perfect but it works totally fine) and it has extra room in case I leave home when it's cold with a jacket and want to ditch it later on. 

I couldn't be happier.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I am newish to running.  I have run before, but I would have considered a 10k LONG. Now I am running 3-4 times a week, and typically 6 mi would be an average/short run.  I really needed something to carry water in as I was starting to really feel out  of it without weather for an hour long run. 

I could fit my 2 and 3 liter camelbak in the pack. I just flipped it upside down and squeezed out the air and all was fine, although a 1.5 liter would probably fit perfectly. The pocket on the shoulder is a little small for my iPhone 6s, but if I let the headphone poke out the hole where the zipper would close its fine. Although the it could also just be put in the top pocket.  

The sternum straps don't adjust, which I have seen with more expensive vests, but the pack weights nearly nothing, fit great, doesn't move around hardly at all, and I much prefer it over carrying bottles or having water bottles right on my chest like many vests have.  

All in all,  I think it's prefect, and for $80, it's really a good deal too.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I like this pack a lot, the size is great and can store more than you think, however, the only negative that I've found is that my shirt rode up while running with this pack. I may be able to fix this by wearing a longer shirt and packing less in it, but I was trying to test it out with a little bit of weight. Overall looks great and makes a fun hiking pack so you don't bring to much with you, but carry the essentials.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Fast schmast.  This pack does that for sure; the load is part of you, and I put about as much in this pack for its first eleven-mile dry run as one might want to.  So yep, run.  Go fast as you can.  But it's not, for me, about making the 200-miler possible; it's about making the ten to fifteen more fun.  When you aren't tempted to add more stuff you don't; the front shoulder strap pockets keep the energy snacks available for the big uphill pulls and the smartphone ready for the glory shots; and I got rainshell insulation gloves warm hat mondo headlamp food (how's a steak and wine lunch sounding to you?) water puro and forty-eight ounces of nicely frozen water in there for a delightful day under a blazing sun.  This one was well thought out and a pleasure to drive.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Bryhn from Patagonia shares his thoughts on the new lightweight running and cycling pack.
great quality shirt. true to size
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
Patagonia sure got the name right when deciding to call this henley a "Daily". Products like this are exactly what I want when stocking my dresser for those everyday needs. Simple, sensible, and comfortable - this shirt has it all.

Colors are excellent and the fit is casual ensuring you feel as good as you look. Can't wait to add more to of these to my wardrobe.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Great casual henley from Patagonia. It fits good and looks even better! I prefer a less tight fit so went with a medium, but I could have squeezed in a small for a more fitted look. I am 5'8'' 150 lbs and I really liked how the medium fit. Birch white color is the way to go.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I love this shirt so much I came back for a second color. The fit is slim but not restrictive.  The organic cotton feels great and the colors are awesome.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought this for my Fiance and this is what he said, "I have owned quite a few Henley’s but this is my new go to! The first time I tried this Henley on it fit perfectly, the sleeves fit nice and fit around the arms while the torso area of the shirt is a bit loose, which I like. This shirt runs true to size and will come in handy as a nice base layer for the cold months in Utah. Can’t say enough about these shirts, I have already want more."
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: just as expected. fits great, good quality, durable. will keep this shirt for a long time.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I got exactly what I expected - A good fit, soft cotton henley that wears well as an every day shirt.  The "Slim fit" is consistent with other slim items from Patagonia.  order your normal size and you'll be fine.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Decent shirt. The sleeves aren't very stretchy and I can't lift my arms up without the entire shirt moving with them.  Decent casual shirt.
