Ordered this for my boyfriend as a gift. He's a rock climber with a narrow waist but wide shoulders so finding shirts can be hard. This fit great though and he said it was really comfortable. He has a long torso too and this was plenty long.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Flying Fish Cotton/Poly Scoop T-Shirt - Women's
column5: The Flying Fish shirt is a very comfortable and stylish shirt with a classic flying fish graphic on the front. It has a slim cut in the chest and rib area, but has extra room in the waist. I've washed it several times and it has held up well and has not shrunk or lost it's shape.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Flying Fish Cotton/Poly Scoop T-Shirt - Women's
column5: wife loves it, color and print is great, its a tshirt looks good, buy it.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Flying Fish Cotton/Poly Scoop T-Shirt - Women's
column5: This shirt is true to color and to size. The fabric quality is soft, sturdy, and feels like it can take the abuse of many spins in the washing machine. The cut of the shirt is not clingy but is rather flattering to different body types. The scoop neck is there to stay, no concern of stretch or sagging over time. Fabulous shirt!

column2: Flying Fish Cotton/Poly Scoop T-Shirt - Women's
column5: The color of this shirt is exact to photo. The material is a thick sturdy comfortable feel. There is no concern that the scoop neck will stretch and become saggy. The size fits true. I am a medium but ordered a large in the event the shirt was clingy to the skin. The shirt hangs loose and does not hug the wrong places giving a nice silhouette.  I thought about exchanging for the medium but like the bigger feel.

column2: Flying Fish Cotton/Poly Scoop T-Shirt - Women's
column5: Small fit me excellent except bust as my chest is like not really very much there (LOL).  So, it hung on the top part really too big for me.  Very soft material, I think the color is as pictured (I got the Cerise and love it).  I really like the shaped hemline - I don't so much go for straight across.  This can be worn for casual and active and all that.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I have two of these shirts and use them for everything. They're fantastic for fishing, not too hot, but enough coverage to keep from getting burned. I also use them as a baselayer year round for hiking, camping, and snowboarding. The length at the waist and wrist is very long which I like. I would buy one in every color if I could.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Back to update my last review. I sized down from a large to a medium and they fit perfectly. I wear a large in their T-shirts normally so that is what i went for first. I wear mine whenever i know I'm going to be in the sun all day. I hesitated jumping on the long sleeve train because i thought i would get too hot. I have been out fishing in the keys and the temperatures hit mid 90's for four days straight and I was doing just fine.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Love this shirt. Keeps the sun off and is stylish too.

Trying on this shirt you would think that it were a custom fit made for folks with extremely long arms. I like to think that my arms are propotionate to my height but this shirt makes me feel like Ive been living a lie for the past 23 years. I wear a large in Patagonia usually and these sleeves went past my fingers. Fabric is on point so ill be buying a medium to see if that does the trick. I'll be back with feedback on how the medium fits.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I bought the brook/tailored grey. Silky smooth to the touch, sun protecting properties, one sleeve was slightly (1 cm) longer than the other and one wrist hole also slightly larger than other. This can be expected with fair trade items. Wore this with a cotton tee shirt underneath on a 95 degree day. Was hot but a bit cooler than a regular long sleeve. Would recommend.
Light, airy, did notice that the shirt is a little long on the torso section. It covers my pockets.

column2: Nano-Air Light Hybrid Insulated Vest - Men's
column5: Picked this up along with the Nano Air Vest.  Fantastic vest for all seasons. Excellent stretch and warmth without hardly any weight. Love this piece. This provides more breathability than the regular Nano Air because of the waffle knit sides and back. This means you won't heat up as quickly, especially when you're on the move. That said, it doesn't keep you as warm as the Nano Air Vest when it gets cold and you're standing around. You can check out this vest compared to the Nano Air Hybrid  here youtu.be/3D2YbGw0dYA
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Nano-Air Light Hybrid Insulated Vest - Men's
column5: Like many others, I suffer from horrific back sweat. I simply do not need any insulation whatsoever on my back. I do however, appreciate the windbreak and warmth on my core. This thing is perfect. From cycle commuting to snowshoeing, this is my go to active layering piece. Since I intended to use it under a shell, I went with the Large. I am 6'5 and 200lbs
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Nano-Air Light Hybrid Insulated Vest - Men's
column5: I am really pleased with this piece. I love the hybrid aspect to it, and  will make it something that I envision myself using often! It is surprisingly light, and still packs down fairly small. It breathes super well too!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Nano-Air Light Hybrid Insulated Vest - Men's
column5:
Perfect Active vest from Patagonia! I tend to overheat at times with my Micro-D. This is vest is perfect for activity! I wear this for long hikes and short bike rides.. I love it!
*My gear head is Zack.. Any questions give him a call.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Nano-Air Light Hybrid Insulated Vest - Men's
column5: This vest is a great addition to the Nano-air family, and the hybrid nature of this vest makes it a very versatile piece of clothing. It can be used as a base layer, with the ability to regulate temperature due to the waffle knit pattern apparent, as the excess heat is forced out the entire back and side of the vest. Than this can also be used as a stand alone jacket during the spring or fall, or during the cooler parts of the day; with the low bulk insulation providing great heat. The feel of this vest is one of my favorite things about; with the fabric soft, supply, and stretchy; allowing it to move with your body instead of remaining static while you move. Over-all another great product by Patagonia that will quickly become a staple piece in my gear closet.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: It takes a lot to get my brother looking spiffy, but this shirt did the trick for him. This shirt isn't too boxy, seems to be a near perfect and true to size fit. No complaints!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Got this shirt for my brother in law for his birthday and he loves it! It’s a great shirt, fabric is soft and the fit is great.
The second I saw this design, I knew I had to have one. The fabric is soft and it fits great. I opted for Big Sur Blue. Don't miss the sweatshirt that also has the bear!
soft shirt fits true to size, great graphic and coloring, I love the bear it looks so rad!
The hand-drawn style of the logo looks even cooler in person. It fits nice . All around a good purchase.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Shirt has a great design that has gotten lots of compliments. Soft, and fits well so very comfortable.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Awesome design and super soft organic cotton feel.  The shirt has a great fit, but I cant seem to keep my girlfriend from wearing it as a shirt to sleep in at night.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This tee is lightweight and will probably be a go to for my guy.  It has a slim fit and is true to size.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: The jacket looks great and feels as light as a feather. My hubs was stoked to get this jacket for his birthday this year and even more stoked to get to wear it for the first time. Living in Portland, OR, we get a lot of rain and with that rain comes a need for ultra rainproof gear. This jacket was possibly a rare exception, possibly a defective item that made it out of the Patagonia factory, because it wet down within the very first hour of wearing it in the rain.  After walking around in fairly, mild rain with the hood up, my husband asked me if the back of his neck was wet or just cold. Imagine my stunned disbelief when I found that the panel at the base of the hood was completely wet down and his shirt beneath it had begun to absorb rainwater.  Fortunately, as proper Portlanders, we always keep spare jackets in the car, but we were really disappointed in this piece's performance.  Judging by the other reviews on here, I'm confident that the jacket I bought was merely a defect and that Patagonia continues to be one of the best brands on the market.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Bought the jacket to replace a size large Torrentshell that was lost on a trip.  Previous reviews were helpful as the jacket does run big.  I'm 6' 170 lbs. and it seems to fit well in the shoulders and torso, but the sleeves are a couple inches too long.  I'm tempted to try a small, but I think this will be manageable with the Velcro wrist closures.  Enough room to layer, but not noticeably baggy.  Backcountry service was great; free two-day shipping arrived overnight in time for my weekend backpacking trip with rain in the forecast.  Using the jacket as a stowable utility rain jacket for everyday use, but also for taking on backcountry hikes in the National Park prone to high humidity and pop-up daily showers.  Didn't want to spend too much money on the higher performance rain gear, but wanted something that would be good enough for outlasting the short T-storms.  Looking forward to seeing how it performs.

As the other reviews say, this jacket does run large, had a customer purchase a small, who is roughly 5'11" and about 165 lbs and usually wears a medium, however the small fits perfectly, with room for a light layer underneath. 
Quality product from a quality brand.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Definitely a great rain jacket, my go to on those rainy days. It does run a bit big, but I like my stuff a little bigger and longer so it was perfect. I usually wear a hoodie or a layer underneath it, so it works out perfectly! Wear this on really rainy days on campus as well as hiking and camping with inclement weather on the forecast. Packs very nicely into the chest pocket for backpacking, and is super lightweight
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Patagonia does it again with another sweet rain jacket. This sucker has Patagonia's patented H2No membrane and it works great in even the wettest conditions. It also packs away really small and is super lightweight. My only gripe about it is that the sizing did run a little larger than I expected, especially in the sleeves. But with the velcro cuffs on the sleeve it's really not a big deal. The Noveau Green is a beautiful color. Get that one.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Purchased this for spring ski tours, breathable and has pit zips. Can dump heat when you need to and keeps you warm with some layers underneath.  The stretchy fabric moves with you, doesn't feel or sound like a garbage bag like some other jackets.

Great jacket, perfect for backcountry touring, but Patagonia is off with their sizing for their regular fit. I'm 6'0, 165lbs and usually wear a medium but was swimming in this jacket. Sleeves were too long as was the overall length of the jacket. This medium was made for someone 6'2, 185lbs it's seems. Have run into this issue with their regular cuts like this. The slim fit seem to be appropriately sized however.

Very nice light weight rain jacket, but unfortunately I returned mine because the sizing was really big. I bought this as an everyday jacket for spring, summer and fall. If your going to use it for outdoor activities like climbing, you may be ok with the extra room for mobility. It would be a great jacket to stuff in a day bag for hiking, etc. The material is pretty thin, so if you abuse your jackets I would question the durability over time.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: So excited to have an insulated jacket that moves quite freely. Still room for a layer inside, but on most days you won't need it.  It is warm and comfortable. Love it.
Take free backcountry 20% OFF Coupon,Take It: outdoorback.tk

I gave this jacket to my girlfriend and she can't say enough positive things about it. The stretch material ensures you can move without restriction. The insulation is warm but packs small making this a great layering or traveling piece. Oh, and the H2No does an excellent job repelling any moisture you might encounter while you're venturing into the wilderness.

This jacket looks great. You can wear it on the slopes with confidence that you're protected from even the worst elements. It's stylish enough to wear right into the bar or pub for an apres session, and afterwards you can wear this to dinner with your mates.

I purchased a medium. She is 5'6" and 120lbs and the medium fit well. If you want a snug fit the small would fit someone her size.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I'm really digging the Stretch Nano Storm, a true wolf in sheep's clothing. I know that is not exactly how the saying goes, but it's true! She is sleek enough to wear as an everyday winter jacket, but packs a big technical punch to kill it on the ski hill. I took this jacket out for a spin at Squaw Valley this weekend and she kept me warm and dry with minimal bulk. Then I thought, let's keep this party going and wore her to one of Reno's signature holiday pub crawls. Can your winter jacket do that? A++.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This was given as a gift but I have positive feedback to share. This jacket is so comfortable and moveable. The stretch in this jacket is one of the best features. It is warm and breathable, perfect for battling the elements.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: The PW is a really nice insulated resort jacket that will hold it's own in tight trees.  The exterior shell fabric is much more durable than other options out there.  You won't feel like you have to go out of your way to  find a clean line through the glades.    There are tons of great pockets on this and like how there's media port through the front chest pocket.  The only thing that I don't like about this jacket is that the hood seems hard to get the adjustment dialed in.  I think since the hood is removable it detracts from the ease of adjustment.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Bought the Patagonia Insulated Powder Bowl Jacket for my Dad, he skies Timberline near PDX and needed an insulated jacket that would stand up to wet days on the hill. This jacket fit the bill perfectly. He was over the moon about fit and warmth. Big recommend here!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Take the teeth out of that biting cold. This jacket will keep you warm all day on the slopes.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This jacket was warm enough for a good day on the slopes but not overly warm. It was great for high output activities.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Definitely a great jacket. I use it for snowboarding in both warmer + cold locations (layer up) and it has held up substantially. Because of the armpit vents it makes it easy to wear this in much warmer weather. I was really surprised that in cold weather (sub 30 with only long sleeve under) I found myself sweating more than once. It’s fairly lightweight and doesn’t feel heavy on my shoulders. The only thing I will caution about is that these do run large. So size accordingly—especially if you want to layer up or if you like a more tightly fitted jacket.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have worn Patagonia jackets for over two decades because I have always liked their quality, design, and practicality.  I like this coat and it performs well in a multitude of conditions (wind, snow, rain).  I have not tried it in a very cold situation and I suspect, I will need a layer under it when it is really cold.  It stops the wind and rain very well and in the twenty degree temperatures has been great.  My only complaints are the zippers, which seem cheap (but I will trust Patagonia that they are not) and the collar is very large and gets in the way of my face.  Minor issues.  I was recently skiing in Colorado with it and it was great.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I ski in this jacket almost every day and i absolutely love it!  This jacket does run a little big but its nice on those colder days to have enough room to throw another layer on comfortably.   There is nothing about this jacket that i don't love quite honestly
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I wear this one all the time riding the lifts of CO ski areas.  Very warm & protective.  Does fit big, but I like the look.  Kind of heavy too.  Glad I got it.  FYI, I do test some products for Gore, but only the ones I choose.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love this jacket, but not the fit.  I'm 6'1 and 210lbs with a 44" chest.  Depending on the manufacturer, I either wear an L or XL in a ski jacket.  I found that this jacket in a Large was too big and baggy for my taste.  I actually bought it in a Medium and it fits perfect, especially if you like more of a tailored fit.  The jacket is really well insulated so I don't need to layer under it with more than a long sleeve compression shirt and a tee.  If I do, its too cold for me anyway and I'm staying in.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I bought this jacket to fill my soft goods mountain quiver.  I have a number of top brand coats, mainly shells  so I was looking for a  jacket that is great on the mountain for those cold days.  THIS JACKET IS ROOMY.  I am 5'9" and weigh 190 lbs with an athletic build.  I find that it does fit big and is heavier than I am used to however it is very warm and airy sitting on the chairlift in January and February.  Skiing in the warm alpine (6-10 degrees C) is very comfortable wearing a light breathable single layer.
The 2 layer Gore-Tex is definitely softer than my 3 layer Gore-Tex shells so this jacket appears to be less technical and would not be my first choice if backcountry or slackcountry is your targeted venue.   Overall I am pleased with this product
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Love the coat, but I was expecting a more fitted style. I buy medium in everything but this medium fit really baggy. I'll be returning for a small. Like the dark charcoal color, makes it a little different than black but still neutral.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: This jacket is really nice. Keeps you warm in cold conditions. A bit higher end than the patagonia snowshot. True to size

From the beasts of the easts to the giants of the west I have been skiing them all for the past 20+ years and have never came across a jacket as satisfying as the Patagonia Insulated Powder Bowl Jacket! Weather it be -25 without winchill or spring skiing out west I have put my powder bowl jacket to the test and time after time after time it prevails! Warm, comfortable, great fitting, reliable are all adjectives used to describe this jacket! I will use this jacket until it literally disintegrates, worth every penny you pay for it.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5:
The Sol Patrol II makes for an awesome sun shirt! The material is nice and lightweight (and the vents definitely help too) which make it easy to wear in hot weather. It wicks moisture, and also does dry rather quickly. Perfect shirt for outside sunny adventures when you don't feel like using a whole bottle of sunscreen for your top!
We did find it to fit a little large- originally ordered the L which is what he generally takes in tops, especially in "adventure shirts", but had to swap it out for the M which fit muuuuuuch better. If you're in between sizes, you would probably want to size down.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5: Soo light it feels like you have nothing on. Great comfortable mesh fabric at center back with side vents and arms facilitates ventilation to keep you cool and the overall cut of the shirt makes you look even cooler.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5: I got this for a friend who's big into fishing at the beach. He said it kept the sun off him without overheating and that the ventilation was pretty great and it didn't get stinky enough that his wife complained after two days. Sounds like a winner shirt.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5:
I normally like to own my gear for a while before I review it. I only bought this shirt a week ago, but we're gonna do this thang RIGHT NOW!
I went fishing and golfing in Northern Minnesota last weekend and I didn't take this bad boy off. I have a lot of tattoos, so I like to keep them out of the sun as much as possible. 
I buy A LOT of Patagonia and I am a true Medium in their line. However, knowing that this shirt runs a little big and given that it is a sun shirt, which I wont be wearing any other shirts under, I sized down to a Small. Fits like a glove.
The pockets are well placed, the material is light, the craftsmanship is on point, every stich is perfect, and the collar!!! This thing has a double rolled, meaning it double unrolls to cover your entire neck. So you don't need a buff in the sun.
I highly recommend sizing down and buying this shirt!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5: Very attractive, well-crafted shirt. I ordered a Medium, which is usually pretty reliable. It was too small in the chest (I take a 41/42). Probably should have ordered a large. No problem with the shirt itself, just sizing.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5: Bought this for my stepdad who cannot be in the sun. He brought it to Mexico and wore it a ton. He stayed cool while having the SPF protection he needs. Looks like he'll use this on the boat this summer as well.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5: This shirt is my go to fly fishing shirt. In reference to some of the other reviews it is a bit baggy under the arms but i didn't have an issue with it. I love the UV protection in the shirt. Has really well spaced pockets. The colors on this shirt are all bomber. This is an awesome shirt for ripping lips.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5:
I really wanted this shirt to fit.  The design is tremendous, well thought out, loved the material, loved the pocket placement and the snapped collar.  It is a quality made shirt from Patagonia.  However the sizing is really strange.  The torso of the shirt fit ok in my normal shirt size (medium) and better in a smaller size (small).  But as another reviewer mentioned, the sleeves were really baggy.  The sleeves looked and felt like a women's blouse.  On top of that, the arm holes where the sleeve meets the torso of the shirt seemed small and high up.  The result was a shirt which felt slightly tight across the chest/shoulder, way too baggy in the arms, and almost right in the body.  Cut and sizing is really important to me, so I returned both sizes I tried on (small and medium).

Totally agree with the Puffy Pirate shirt comment ...
column8: I returned this product before using it

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5: I recently tried this shirt on and I really wanted it to work out.  The fabric is awesome; super light and airy, as well as UPF 30 protected.  I really liked all the colors, and the pockets are really functional, but the fit just didn't work out for me.  I am normally right on the boarder between medium and large, and tried on the Medium, which fit perfectly in the body, but the arms, specifically in the arm pit and bicep region, were insanely baggy.  I understand that this is a shirt designed for fly fishing, and a little extra fabric is warranted so that your cast isn't inhibited, but this was a ridiculous amount of extra fabric.  I felt like I was wearing the puffy shirt from Seinfeld.  Needless to say this shirt did not work out for me, I really wanted it to, but the fit was just too odd for me.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5:
I bought the shirt in Lite Distilled Green.  I'm an avid paddler, lift with heavy weight on a regular basis, and run a few times a week, so I'm broad-shouldered with an athletic build.  I wear large in most brands but medium in this shirt fits me great.  (If you're use to Columbia PFG button-down shirts, the fit is similiar)

I've worn it fishing from my kayak, hanging out at the beach, and out on the docks in the evening.  It is very comfortable and the vents worked great in the high 90s heat we've had here in the Hampton Roads area.  The sleeves are great for avoiding getting sunburnt out on the water and the buttoned keeper keeps the sleeves rolled up high when you don't need the added sun protection.  

Its been through a few washes and isn't showing any wear.  So far its has stayed wrinkle free when I pull it out of the dryer warm.

I love the looks of the shirt and have had enough compliments about it that I ordered the same shirt in Tubular Blue.  I hope the Sol Patrol II style stays around for a while so that I can buy more colors in the future.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5:
This is actually my husband's shirt but he does not write reviews.  I ordered it for him after he admired my own Patagonia sun shirt.  It is everything he wanted---lightweight, good-looking, very comfortable, and protective from the sun.  It is everything we expect from our favorite brand (Patagonia).  And as usual the service from backcountry.com was fast and efficient.  
My husband usually wears size large because of his shoulders ( former swimmer), but went with the Medium for a trimmer fit and it is perfect.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Sol Patrol II Long-Sleeve Shirt - Men's
column5: I just wrapped up a tripped to Brazil and took this shirt with me.  I tested the shirt on the airplane.  It looks really nice and has lots of pockets and if you get a little warm the roll-up sleeves with button keeper is a nice touch.   The next thing i used it for was at the beach as a sun shirt.  Once again it works great for that as it was designed for that.  The next test was hiking a 3400 foot peak in round trip 7.6 miles in fairly humid 75 degree weather.  I was using it more for the bugs than the sun at this point and it did a great job of keeping me bug bite free.  Its definetely got a bit damp from all the sweat but it doesn't SOAK it up like a cotton shirt would and it dried real quick on top of the peak.  All and all I really recommend this shirt.  It fits great, has great ventilation and plenty of pocket space .
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I have a closet full of soft shells. This one is probably on my top 3 list due to the fit and functionality. It runs a bit light on features, but that's why it excels. Only thing missing is an internal cell phone pocket. 

Packs light and great for travel, a great outer shell for those mild winter days, and you can still use it in the spring as a standalone jacket.

The fit is really where this jacket is amazing. Not too baggy, but you can fit a hoodie underneath. I traveled through Tokyo/Hokkaido this winter in both frigid rain and snow, and this was my go-to shell when I wasn't on the slopes. Back in California, this thing was a decent shell on those 40'F snow days, but I wouldn't recommend using this on a cold powder day.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Love this jacket, wear it on rainy days at school as well as on hikes and camping when the weather might be variable conditions. Bought the L, and it fits great, definitely an athletic fit, my other Patagonia jackets in L have more room for a layer underneath, whereas this piece doesn't, good for the warmer spring/fall days with variable conditions rather than a winter jacket
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I wasn't sure about this jacket but based on reviews I pulled the trigger and ordered it. I'm extremely pleased about every aspect of it. The way it looks, fits, feels (the best part), and for a warm weather snowboard jacket the way it performs. For $89 it's probably the best purchase I have made. The sizing is definitely athletic cut so the XL fits me like a large. Again this jacket is amazing and my friends and going to be jealous. I will be buying more Patagonia things in the future.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Understand that this thing has NO lining.  It is simply a windproof shell.  As most people are also saying, it runs a little on the small side.  That means you will not be able to layer much insulation under it.  Pockets are great, nice for keeping the breeze off, but does not take a whole lot before you are reaching for something a little warmer.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
The Levitation Hoody was gifted to me at Christmas by my girlfriendââand what a good gift it was. She knows of my Patagonia fixation, the brand I really trust when going outside, and thus fueled it further.

Full disclosure: I also own a Patagonia Dimensions Jacketââmy go to softshell for skiing and climbing when the weather is really inclement. 

The Levitation Hoody, by contrast, is a water and wind resistant hoody that won't protect you quite as well as a heavier softshell, but is supremely breathable, comfortable, and, most importantlyââLIGHT. 

Pros: 

Extremely lightweightââyou forget you are wearing it, or carrying it in your pack. I really look forward to using this in a Colorado summer while hiking and backpacking 14ers.

 Articulated athletic fitââtrue to size in every way. Sleeves are just the right length, and the taper is perfect for slender, well muscled climbers and skiers. You can be confident ordering the right size for you.

Very comfortable for skiing on days where temps are 20+ degrees.

Repels rainââI had to take a flight to the midwest (yuck) a month ago and didn't have a dedicated rain jacketââthis hoody held up admirably and dried out quickly! 

Cons: 

Not really anything. The jacket could conceivably be more versatile in terms of handling cold and intense wind, but then it would sacrifice some of the qualities that it excels in. 

Conclusion: 

Great, inexpensive, good looking, good feeling shell to have in your quiver. Here's a picture of me backcountry skiing near Vail wearing the Hoody.

I'm 6'1 167lbs, the medium is too small for me, specially if I have a layer underneath this jacket. There's no room at all for a helmet in the hood.
Nice jacket tho - material and design-wise, would be a perfect spring  jacket.  I will exchange for a large.
If you're similar size as me (tall and slim), definitely go for a large!
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: Amazing product. Ordered it for a ski trip, layered it with Patagonia better sweater and Nano Puff under neath. Perfectly warm in 10 degree weather. Love the feel for skiing, wearing around town or driving. Great product fits true to size. Will certainly be receiving much more use from me on wet and cold ski trips or on winter camping. Absolutely recommend and is perfect for layering.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Love this jacket, definitely a tough material, keeps wind out and light rain off nicely. Love that Patagonia started making things not so wide... skinny guys have a hard time with that.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Corey from Patagonia shares his thoughts on the new Levitation Hoody

column2: Fitz Roy Trout Long Sleeve T-Shirt - Men's
column5: So comfy, great fit., you can't go wrong with anything Patagonia. Do your self a favor an pick up this shirt.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Fitz Roy Trout Long Sleeve T-Shirt - Men's
column5: I really enjoy everything Patagonia makes, but i've especially started to get hooked on their shirts. They fit so great, and are made out of a nice thick and comfy cotton. The subtle colors they come in are also great, really can't go wrong with any of the Patagonia shirts.
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Fitz Roy Trout Long Sleeve T-Shirt - Men's
column5: Just love this shirt. Cotton is nice and definitely does not feel like a cheap T.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Fitz Roy Trout Long Sleeve T-Shirt - Men's
column5: love this shirt for any day hanging out on the river or in the city.  Very cool,simple design, comfortable and durable
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Fitz Roy Trout Long Sleeve T-Shirt - Men's
column5: Bought this shirt for the fall season. Shirt size is normal fit (doesn't run large or small), sleeve length is right at wrists, and the waist stops right at the butt so its not too long but also doesn't look like a belly shirt when you raise your arms. The cotton material feels very comfortable and is sourced from the U.S. and feels like nice quality. The ink on the front lettering and the back design is not too thick, but also looks like it won't crack over time. I gave this product a five star review because of the quality make and the nice design on the back. This shirt is quickly becoming one of my new favorite shirts.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: True to size and very comfy. I love wearing this shirt with jeans to the bar so I still look stylish, but stay completely warm after taking my jacket off.  It is also great for hiking, it breathes well and keeps its shape.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: is so much more comfortable in this Henley. Cute, casual and comfortable, this top can take you from couch to street in minutes. The tunic length is great, it can easily be paired with leggings and boots for fall or layered under a vest during the winter.  Blending cotton, tencel and spandex, makes this top easy to move around in while still feeling like you're wrapped up in a cozy blanket.  I'd recommend sizing down, as it does run big.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Super comfortable henley! I wear this shirt all the time.  I love how soft the fabric is! The only downside is it runs a little big so I would definitely size down! But other than that this is a great shirt to keep you warm in the winter
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I really wanted to love this shirt, especially for the price!  I was in between sizes S and M and kept the M in case of any shrinkage (after first wash and dry there hasn't been any noticeable shrinkage).  It is pretty much tunic length, which is annoying when I want to wear it with jeans because I can't access my pockets and it is too long/thick to tuck in to get it out of the way.  Fabric is soft but not as thick as I'd hoped (and the white is a bit see-through) and definitely does pucker/stretch out at the elbows and weirdly around the waist for me... and my cat was able to snag it on my first wear.  Depending on how it holds up I might grab another one if on sale at the end of the season, but maybe not.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Fabric is a little heavier which I liked. nice and warm. I pair this with my Nano puff vest or the retro vest. solid combo
column8: I've used it several times

column5: As the title says, this is my favorite Patagonia shirt to date. As with most Patagonia, it ran a little large and I ended up exchanging the size small for a size x-small. It's so soft and cozy. Perfect fall addition.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: When I placed my order, I wasn't sure what size I would need. I ended up buying one color in a small and one color in a medium :) and am keeping them both. I would agree that this top runs a little big, but I like having the option of it being oversized to pair with leggings. Its easy, comfortable and I highly recommend snagging up each color.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This top is made very well, fabric is nice quality -- super cozy all around.  The buttons add a little detail too.  I sized down and I'm really glad I did.  I'm  5' 5", 125, 32B, and the XS still is pretty roomy.  It hits at the top of my thigh (almost like a tunic) and is overall a little big and a tiny bit boxy.   Still a keeper just because I was really impressed with the quality and felt like it would be a really practical shirt to have around.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I really like the style of this shirt but it does run very large. I am 5'3 125 I usually wear a medium or small in Patagonia tops. I ordered a small and had to return it for an xs, it's extremely baggy and loose around the waist. I would definitely recommend sizing down from your normal Patagonia size when ordering this top.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Solid boots, that fit well, were comfortable to hike in and had decent grip. My only complaint is they hold a lot of water. Not an issue for most situations but for backpacking or covering a lot of miles in a day of fishing something you notice. Overall a good boot and I have no complaints for 80% of the fishing I do.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: It can be difficult to find ladies fly fishing boots without spending a ton of money. I generally wear a women's size 7; I ordered the men's size 5 in these and they're perfect.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I've owned a few different boots and these ones are by far my favorite. The fit, the quality and the comfort of the Patagonia ultralight wading boot are superior. Great for boat trips, hiking around or just planting yourself in one place on the river. My only regret was not throwing screws in the bottom on my first day of my float trip down the lower Deschutes, whoops. The rock bed is volcanic rock and slippery as hell.  Love these though and recommend them to anyone looking for a versatile boot.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This is a review of last years model of this boot. As a petite woman that also loves fishing, I know too well the struggle of trying to find gear that works and that isn't 2x the price of mens gear or in some nauseating shade of pink. These are pricey now as the newest model -  I paid $80 for last years version. But, I still think these are well worth a look by all the flyfishing women out there.

I've been looking for an upgrade from my disastrous old felts, but women's specific boots are insanely expensive. On the verge of breaking down and dropping close to $200 on the Simms wading boots, I discovered these and thought that maybe a size 5 would fit me - being between a 6-7 in a womens street shoe. These fit perfectly with a good pair of socks and my waders on! They're so light, give excellent ankle support, and will take studs. Some of the reviews say that they're not very sticky - to that, I say, anything on the planet is stickier than the ridiculous high heeled felts I started out with, and for $80, I can't wait to take them out on the river. 

For reference for women's sizing, I am 5"1 and 110lbs. I wear a 6-7 depending on shoe type and/or brand, and a 36-37 European size. I ordered these in the size 5 and they're perfect! They're synthetic and really comfy inside, so I suspect that they will stretch as I break them in.

I bought these to compliment my Patagonia waders I got on a steal.  I contacted Patagonia to ensure I would get the correct size. They fit great, feel good, and drain fairly well. Hopefully they'll last me a while, Patagonia has a pretty good reputation.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
These were a gift to a friend who definitely represents the fly fishing world. Here is what he had to say...

"These boots are a godsend not only are they light weight but I'm going from a felt bottom to these rubber and I'm getting a lot better grip. These are great easy laces to tighten, comfy and have great support for rocky terrain. Very happy with the Patagonia Ultralights."
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Comfortable, lightweight boots, upgraded durability from the previous model. They offer reasonable traction, but I threw some studs on just to be safe. The only real issue I’ve had are the laces are a tad short to tie them snugly and there’s not exactly stellar drainage. Even still, I highly recommend these.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Bought this jacket for AK, didn't disappoint.  Great lightweight shell that's also durable!

This is an awesome jacket! It's super lightweight, packs down small, and has kept me dry so far! I have no complaints about it. Fit is just like all other Patagonia products. I am usually a Large in jackets, but a Medium in Patagonia works perfectly.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I wanted to get a lightweight technical shell that I could layer up with with no added bulk.  This jacket has not disappointed yet.  I wore it on one of my last ski days in an incredibly windy/cold day in VT.  Great protection from the elements, hood works incredibly well, as well as, it has great range of motion.  I also like that is a regular fit jacket and not a slim fit.  The regular is very similar to other Patagonia products, slightly baggy (which I personally like), but not nearly as baggy as the snowshot or powderbowl, .  I wore it with a Patagonia Thermal base plus Nano-Air jacket one day and I did not feel restricted in movement on the hill.  I went in the woods with it and came out the same way I went in.  I was worried because of how thin the jacket was that it would come out worn.  This thing can get hit, scraped, brushed against with no fear of ripping, cutting, tearing.  

In the warmer temperature on the following day it worked super well with an R1 underneath.  Vents and pockets work incredibly well.  

Would recommend this for anyone looking for a lightweight jacket you can take anywhere and not worry about it with the added bonus of layering options
 Nouveau Green is awesome color as well.  
.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I have both this shell and the Piolet.  I use this shell for the outdoor sports and exterme weather.  It is a lighter but stiffer material than the Piolet but for sub-zero days when you have to be in the elements this is the only shell I will wear.  I wear a nano-air hoodie under this shell and they make a great pairing.  I am a Large in all my Patagonia Layers.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I bought this as an early Christmas present for my boyfriend who just started backcountry touring. Here's what he had to say...

This jacket is great! I needed to upgrade my backcountry ski gear and I researched many jackets. This is the one I decided on. This jacket is super light weight and keeps me dry with the Gore-Tex material. It fits great and leaves plenty of room for layering. I look forward to using this jacket for backcountry ski adventures, days at the resort, backpacking in Alaska and many more harsh weather environments/adventures!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
The Refugitive is a great, lightweight alpine coat. It's light enough and extremely pack-able- adding to it's versatility. It makes a bomb proof rain coat year-round, and is just as handy a tool in the snow. 

The Gore-Tex C-knit fabric feels much better against bare skin compared to the Gore-Tex Pro material, so this jacket can be worn with minimal baselayers in warm-but-windy situations. 

The breathability is exactly what you would expect from a Gore-Tex product! 

The fit runs a bit large; I typically wear a large, but sized down to a medium. The sleeves are still a little long, but everything else is great. 

The coat does have a small strap to attach it to Patagonia snow pants and bibs, however, it does lack a powder skirt for those deepest days! 

I expect that I'll buy another one of these when I finally do wear this coat out!



Season update: 

I have found the medium fit to run a little tight when wearing a beacon in addition to a puffy vest. 

The hood design is actually pretty poor- The single draw string pulls the hood back. You can see, but the sides of your face are exposed to wind and moisture. 

The coat exterior proves to be durable. Lots of tours and sidecountry on this one- no rubbing wear from pack shoulder straps or waist buckles. 

However, the c-knit material inside the coat seems to be less durable. There is obvious wear where the pack is pressed against my back by the backpack. It seems like the Goretex Pro material is more durable. 

The water resistance membrane seems to have held up. Shoulders and arms still bead water. The ares where the pack sits soak with water, but  it hasn't seeped through yet.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
This is a nice shell. Definitely size down one size. I am 6'4 and 200 lbs an the XL  is too big. The body is baggy and the arms have to be 38 inches long. That's ok because you can use the Velcro to tighten around your wrist to keep the sleeves up. If I just let them hang down, they completely cover my hands!  Looks like a little kid wearing his fathers coat. Really! 
The fabric is great- not crinkly like my other Gore Pro with the Grid Backer. Feels more like my Neo Shell from Polartec. Stretchy around the shoulders. The Underwater Blue color is more "Aqua" green, but ok. The DWR seems quite good as well 
Buy it on sale and you'll be happy.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I purchased this shell for its lightweight versatility - and have used it on bluebird days at Mt Bachelor skiing this season.  The plan is to pair it with an R1 for spring resort skiing & backcountry touring and stash it in my pack for three season hiking and backpacking. It does not have a powder skirt, but that saves weight and is part of the reason I was drawn to the Refugitive. I'm 6'2 190lbs and wear a Large. The fit is relaxed and the arms are long for all alpine adventures.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Just received the jacket in the mail and actually ordered the small and medium based on several comments about the jacket being too big.  I'm 5'10', 164 lbs, 40in chest, 30in waist and the Medium jacket fit me perfect. I was still able to put a R1 hoody or a nano air under the jacket and it didn't feel too tight.   Sent the small back to Backcountry and they refunded my money right away.  Sleeves are a tad long but I prefer that over too short.  The jacket is very light so I will be interested how it performs skiing in Sapporo this winter.

Great experience and why I continue to use Backcountry for all my outdoor needs
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
I think this is my new favorite jacket. The new Gore-Tex C-knit is much less crunchy than Gore-Tex Pro and I feel like I have a better range of motion. It feels somewhat more breathable.

It's definitely designed for an active skier/climber/hiker. It's lightweight so you need a good base and midlayer. I think it would work well skiing on any sunny day out west in February or March. It would work well on a warmish snowy day as well where you are sweating.

The one design flaw is the lack of a powder skirt, which is unfortunate. I hope next year they fix this, or add in more jackets with the C-knit construction.

The color scheme is nice too.

Size-wise: I like that it's not overly baggy. I tend to wear a Large in the Regulator Fleeces but usually have to downsize to a Medium in Patagonia shells. The same trend continues with this (Medium). I do like that it's not quite as baggy as the PowSlayer or Powderbowl. But by the same token it's not quite as slim fit as some of the more Euro styled GoreTex shells. So it hits a nice in between.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: i bought black  / SIZE  L/ Surf Brim Hat. I believe the brand , patagonia.
This is great and hasn't come off after many a white water thrashings.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I got this hat for my dad for Kite Surfing (he is pretty much bald haha) but this worked great for him. Being out on the water in full sun and getting reflection off of the water is not safe, but this hat was perfect for him. full coverage for his head, face, and neck but also the chin strap helps keep it on in case he does a face plant. Overall he is super satisfied!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: Quality construction and material dries fast.  Being bald means extra protection is mandatory.  The hat provides good protection and wears well on the water.  It was used primary for body surfing / body boarding.  The straps tuck away nicely when not necessary and a sinch around the brim tightens when you just want to go out and jump waves ... etc.  The strap held well when buckled for riding and ducking under waves.  The fact that I still have it in my possession speaks to it's effectiveness.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
used it every day for seven days in a row while windsurfing in Greece.
fits well, dries fast, material and design are perfect .

These pants are Classic Corduroy in style and fit. They remind me of the "OP" corduroy pants of the 80's. Not baggy, super soft, comfortable and bitchen colors! These also run alittle long. I think Patagonia wanted them that way because they show a Paagonia tag when cuffed.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: It's tough times for us meatier gents.  These days finding casual pants that accommodate muscled thighs and calves with a normal-sized waist is a challenge.  These do that.  And they are cords; so that's awesome.  I have a 29" inseam and they run a tad long but they maintain a cuff okay for you rollers out there.  Otherwise, you may want to consider hemming. Also, as others have mentioned, slight narrowing in the calves let you know the pants are there.  But I found they don't do any hugging.  I'll buy these again.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: These pants are the epitome of understated chill. I love putting them on after an adventure, or a full day of work knowing that I'll be comfortable. The straight fit are the way to go, because they don't have the frumpy, baggy look of most cords. A must-buy for anyone who likes to be comfy. Just don't wear them on a hot day!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have two pairs of these cords. I love the slim fit. I do wish the lower leg was just a tad bit wider. I definitely recommend them.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: So I ordered these in a size 32, but received a 33. I actually got two pairs, the gray and the ash tan. The gray came in the right size, the ash tan did not. It had the label for the 32 but clearly was a full size longer. Regardless, even the 32's were too long for me even though that's my typical size. I am 5 9 and 160-165 lbs. I took them in to be altered and now love them, they are my favorite pants.

I would have loved these pants if they weren't so baggy up top and thin around the lower legs. I ended uo getting a shorter pair and they felt a little better. I usually wear a 32, but went with a 30 with these.

Picked these up recently in the Bear Brown color.  I'm fairly thin, as well as tall, and appreciate that Patagonia now makes pants with a 34" inseam.  At 6'3" and 195 lbs, the 34/34 fit me perfectly and the straight fight, as my wife would say, "shows off my booty."  The straight fit is a thinner fit and is the look I prefer.

Quality and materials are top notch with these pants.  First of all, if anything goes wrong with the stitching or material, I can get them fixed.  Next, they are made with organic cotton so I don't have to worry about harmful chemicals coming into contact with my skin while I wear these.

From the minute I took these out of the box and put them on, I've worn them every day for about 12 consecutive days and they are now my favorite pants.  Also like the little details such as the Patagonia tag on the inside of the pant leg when I roll up the cuffs.

I've owned may cords over my lifetime, and these are by far the best and my favorite.  I look forward to getting the Patagonia jeans soon as well.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: With winter around the corner, I picked these up last month. Since it was the beginning of fall it was still too warm to start wearing them. temps now are in the 50-high 60's daily and they everything i expected from Patagonia. Great quality, comfortable and affordable!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought these as a gift for my niece.  She's 16 months old and wearing 12-18 month in most items, the fit was perfect. These will surely protect her in the NYC winters.

The size is good, I got 6 months but she they are a little bigger than a normal 6 month size so she will be able to wear them for a while and with clothing underneath.  I love the pattern, too.  I just don't know how warm they will be in the severe cold.  They look good though!

I got these for ski touring (very mellow touring) with my daughter in the baby bjorn and so far she likes wearing them although we haven't been out on a super cold day.  They seem to be pretty windproof and the synthetic insulation is a strong positive given that it will maintain warmth when wet and there's always a good chance of these getting wet either from forces of nature of forces of my little girl.

Like what the other reviewer said, this is very lightweight, not bulky and keeps warm. It fits well too as elastic at waist is pretty stretchy. Although this feature is not important to me, I thought it was cool that this pant was reversible. However, I decided to return it as my daughter was happy enough with her fleece pants and didn't seem too bothered by the cold, so she ended up not wearing it at all.

This is my second pair of the infant puffball pants - have the jacket and pants and LOVE them both.  They are warm yet soft and lightweight and for living in the foothills of Colorado, my son wears them about 9 months out of the year.  Great for layering over his normal indoor wear to go play outside - without overheating him with long underwear on the warmer winter days.  Also really nice for blocking the wind.

This is a go to piece for your summer pack. It's light weight, packable, and provides an updated style aesthetic that you don't get from the full-zip option. If you are into the pullover snap-t silhouette and are looking for a summer windbreaker; this is your find!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
True life confessions: I've never owned a windbreaker. 

Perhaps that's why I find myself freezing my buns off every time I head off on a mountain jaunt in the summer. I don't think to add a jacket to my pack because 1). They are bulky & heavy and 2). I can't imagine needing any sort of protection when its 98 degrees in Salt Lake City. 

This is a situation that has left me uncomfortable on MANY, nay countless, excursions. To have been gifted this Houdini pullover may be totally life changing. 

IT FITS IN MY FANNY PACK.
IT WEIGHS LESS THAN A GRANOLA BAR. 
IT'S WATER RESISTANT. 
THE COLORS ARE BEAUTIFUL. 

I didn't know that wind breakers break wind. 
I mean...I had a super sweet neon one in the 80s, it was turquoise and white with purple accents. But it was lined with thick cotton and it most definitely didn't break any wind.
This thing is perfect for sporting ridgeline hikes or summiting granite peaks. It's game for anything. And it won't weigh you down. Not even a little bit. 
This will be coming with me on all spring, summer, fall, outings henceforth. 

GREAT!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I've put this jacket through the wringer. It has gone on every single hiking, backpacking, and kayaking outing since I purchased it. I even brought this jacket on a trip to Yosemite in February and it was the perfect accessory. I have absolutely no complaints about it! I love that it packs down small enough that I can easily switch it between bags or just keep it in my glove box in my car.

I'm 5'4, 150 lbs, athletic build, normally wear a medium in Patagonia and bought a large so that I was able to layer underneath. I could comfortably fit a Patagonia R1 pullover underneath.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I bought one Houdini for me and one Houdini for my fiance because they're so awesome.  They're light, packable, functional, and stylish.  She's got the Violet Blue color and it's a really great color combo.  
It's the perfect piece to have with you , whether you're hiking, biking, running, fishing, chilling, you name it.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: The only thing better than a Houdini jacket is a Houdini pullover. It's simplistic design allows it disappear even more than it's predecessor, if that is at all possible. This piece is stellar on the trail, whether it's on foot, wheels, or even skins;  always on the move between bags.  The snaps go deep enough for easy on and off, you can even keep your helmet on! The lightweight, but durable polyester shell does a fantastic job of  blocking the wind while going unnoticed. The Kangaroo pocket doubling as a stuff sack is a great addition and shows the thoughtfulness of this design. Who knew something so small could do so much? Magic I guess.  Now if we could only make Houdini gloves...
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This was a straight-up disaster. I had purchased it specifically for an upcoming backpacking trip as it promised lightweight, waterproof breathability. Fortunately I tested it before the trip on a practice hike, because as it turned out it was nowhere close to being H2NO - quite the opposite. I was soaked very quickly during some rain showers and remained wet and clammy for the next several hours. The jacket took a full day to dry completely. It was a complete failure. Unfortunately I lost the jacket on the flight home, otherwise I would have returned it.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
The ultralight Stetch Rainshadow is one of the lightest fully-featured rain shells I have ever used. Weighing a scant 9.2 oz, the very packable Stretch Rainshadow has pit zippers, dual hand pockets, a drawcord hem, adjustable Velcro wrist stays,  and a chest pocket that it packs into and can clip into a carabiner. All of its zippers are coated with a waterproof DWR coating. 

The stretchy fabric it is made of feels amazingly soft and it is super breathable. It does not have a hard shell feel to it at all and is very comfortable for casual wear or high output activity. If you are familiar with Patagonia products, imagine a little bit heavier, but way more wind and waterproof Houdini.  I would say it is similar to the Outdoor Research Helium II and Marmot Essence, but better.

Hoods are normally a big concern of mine in rain shells, but this helmet- compatible hood cinches down tight easily and stays in place.

The fit is a regular fit, with appropriate room for layers. Some say it runs big, but I think it is true to size and built to accommodate layering. If you want a more snug and flattering fit, size down.

It pairs wonderfully with the Patagonia R1 or any of stretchy synthetic insulated  jackets ( Nano Air, Nano Air Hybrid, Arc'teryx Atom LT, The North Face Ventrix). It would be great for anything from spring backcountry skiing to hiking or climbing your favorite fourteener.

I wore it all day long in the rain and snow in Yellowstone last weekend and stayed bone dry and comfortable. My only complaint is that it can get kind of soggy after heavy rain or being out in rain for long periods of time. Wearing it with another layer made it perfectly fine, but if you are only wearing a t-shirt under it, it might feel clammy on your skin. You will stay completely dry due to Patagonia's proprietary H2NO membrane, but it can get clammy. As long as you don't have expectations for this to be a 3L Gore-Tex Pro shell, you will love it.

Bottom line: This is one of my favorite rain shells I've ever worn. I'm going to wear it every chance I get.
If you have any questions about this jacket, shoot me an email at amcclary@backcountry.com or call me at 801-204-4562.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I really wanted to like this jacket. It is a great stretchy material, which is super comfy, but not waterproof at all. I stood in a light rain shower and it started seeping through after 5 minutes. The DWR coating wets very quickly and though the breathable layer tries to absorb the rain, you just feel like you have saran wrap stuck to your skin. I love Patagonia, but this is not a rain jacket.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Took this jacket on its first trip and absolutely put it through the wringer climbing up in the Bugaboos. I tore holes in my climbing pants and my backpack, but this jacket stayed 100% intact as I worked my way up cracks and chimneys for 4 straight days. The stretch was great for climbing, and also, it's super breathable while still blocking wind and rain, which kept me from getting soaked from both sweat and the afternoon thunderstorms. Seriously, this jacket is perfect. Can't wait for winter to get here, because I'm sure it'll be great for backcountry skiing too.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I wore this on a recent backpacking trip & it was perfect to fend off wind & light rain. It breathed, moved, & stowed well. I think I have every different type of rain coat that Patagonia makes & this was the perfect addition to my quiver for a backpacking trip.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: My girlfriend says: Patagonia outerwear never disappoints and this Stretch Rainshadow Jacket is no exception. The material is softer than previous rain jackets I have owned which makes it all the more comfortable.  I am already picturing wearing it on a sunny backcountry ski tour (with some layers of course) for the waterproofing and breathability. Super versatile and comfy!

I researched this jacket a good deal before finally purchasing it. Initially, I wasn't sure about the price point, but I am so glad that I went for it! I have a few Patagonia Torentshell jackets and while they hold up well, the fit is not perfect and I hate the plastic feel (especially in the summer). I wasn't willing to shell out $300+ for a gore-tex model, so this Stretch Rainshadow caught my eye. The fit is spot-on for me. I am tall and thin (5'10, 125 lbs.) and often have trouble finding jackets that fit well in the body, but have sleeves that are still long enough. The XS in this is a perfect fit! It's fitted enough to wear to work, but still has enough room for an extra layer underneath (I tested it with a down vest and it was cozy and didn't look too bulky). The feel of the fabric in this jacket is wonderful. It is smooth and soft and the outer sheen has a matte look (I bought the black color). It is also stretchy enough to move comfortably with your body without feeling tight or restrained. I haven't tested it in torrential rain for hours, but it worked well for an extended time in light rain and in a quick downpour. Overall, I am very happy with this purchase and would definitely go for this option again!
column8: I've used it several times

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight One-Piece Suit - Women's
column5: I love this suit.  Comfort and warmth are supreme here.  The hood fits nicely under your helmet.  The extra long front zipper is great for releasing extra heat if needed.  I am 5'10 and have a longer torso and the large is a good fit.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight One-Piece Suit - Women's
column5: I tried using this as a base layer in Telluride while snowboarding.   While it was a fun idea lounging around the house, this item is not practical hiking around and exercising on the mountain. It was not very warm and felt restrictive with the front zipper.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight One-Piece Suit - Women's
column5:
I bought this for my girlfriend and have a message to share:

"I love this hybrid ninja Kermit the frog base layer versatile onesie.  I wear it every time I go skiing, and it is clutch.  The zippered butt flap is ideal for those moments when you just gotta go.  I originally bought a large thinking a medium would be too short but it was HUGE.  Returned it for medium, washed and dried it, and now it is perfect."
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight One-Piece Suit - Women's
column5:
PROS:
+ butt zipper
+ incredibly warm for how thin the material is
+ hood that makes you feel like a ninja
+ general bad ass points for being a onsie
makes you feel like a ninja

CONS
- must take off your body to wash

I am officially obsessed with this suit. Great for lounging around the house on lazy days and as a base layer for all of your winter pursuits. I would honestly wear this in public as an outfit. Just think of how cute it would look with a pair of fancy winter boots and a scarf.  Athleisure is in right?!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column2: Capilene Thermal Weight One-Piece Suit - Women's
column5: Super lightweight material, really soft, comfortable and warm! Runs big so I had to exchange it for a smaller size but love it!

I absolutely love this jacket.  It's been in the high 20's low 30's with damp air and the insulation around my waist and thighs is so great.  Patagonia does it again.  The jacket is cozy without making me feel like the Pillsbury dough-boy.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Light weight and packable, but still provides some warmth.  Great style and fit. Very happy with my purchase.

I  bought this last winter and found myself living in it.  It has not shed a lot and still looks great despite lots of use.  It's slim fitting and stylish   It's also lightweight and doesn't make me look like the Michelin Man.  I got it on sale for a great price.  Highly recommend!

From day one, this parka has consistently leaked and shed tiny down feathers from the inside and outside.  I purchased the black in a small.  The fit was slim and stylish, true to my tall 5'11" frame.  The parka itself keeps you warm in cool weather for being so thin and compact!  I own a few Patagonia down parkas and I have never had a leaky feather problem.  I am chalking this up to a poor design and manufacturing issue for this batch of Fiona parkas.  Sadly, I had to return because the quality of the parka did not live up to the Patagonia name nor the $299.00 price tag.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I have been looking for a light weight packable jacket, and this one is perfect. It is warm, and true to size.

This coat would be perfect for a liner inside another winter coat.  I thought with a Patagonia label, that it would suffice as a warm winter coat.  I'm returning it.  Nice for cool weather, but not for cold weather.  Otherwise, fit was nice.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: This is my second Fiona. I owned my last one for about 7 years, and it held up great. Just upgraded to this model, and I love it. It's the opposite of bulky, and has some shape to it which is hard to find with a down jacket. Recommend!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Sorta love it--it does fit really small but I'm tiny so it's ok--not optimum with a bulky sweater. I really like wearing it though. I have a shorter version and it doesn't cover enough when it's cold. Customer service was excellent. I had them ship the S so I could see, ended up staying with XS. 
Very happy with the purchase overall. Good price.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: the zipper was just too difficult to deal with. I really wanted this to work as the light weight was what I was looking for.I returned it.

I'm in the Washington DC area, and it doesn't get super cold too often. I have TNF's Arctic Parka, and it's a wonderful coat, but too heavy and bulky to wear regularly, so I only bust it out on extreme winter days. I was looking for an everyday, long, light winter coat. 
I was a bit skeptical of this coat when I first got it due to how light and thin it is. But now I've used it several times, including a trip to NYC, and it's just wonderful. It's incredibly warm for how thin and light it it. I wear it over a thin shirt or a sweater and it is perfect. I was even sweating after walking for a while. 
As far as sizing goes- I usually wear a medium, TNF, Arcteryx, Columbia, always M, even though the fit varies slightly from brand to brand. It might be a tiny bit smaller, but minimal, rally- it does fit a bit snug if i wear it with a hoodie or something heavy underneath, but I never do. I like just wearing it over a long sleeve shirt, or thin sweater, so I thought it was fine. I also bought the large to compare, and the large was definitely too baggy so I stuck with the medium. It's slim and long and fitted and it looks really nice!
Haven't had the feather leaking issue that other reviewers had mentioned.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Everything people said about this coat is true. The fit is weird - too tight across the waist area, arms are way too long, feathers shed. The zipper is hard to pull up. Also, it's hard to admit this but I wanted the Patagonia label on the front, or on the arm - and i rarely want any label showing. Anyway, it's going back. Sigh, I wanted it to work.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: Got this in a blue and gave as a gift. Love the color but had to size up.

My mom was loves the warmth of this jacket and how light weight it is. She uses it up in northern idaho on some 5 degree days this winter and was satisfied with the warmth. She did say she wishes it was a couple inches shorter.. that is her only complaint
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
I think it fits true to size. It is warm and stylish too. I got many compliments wearing it. I bought it on sale in Spring so it is very good value. 

It is not bulky at all and it's good for travel since it's very light.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: My wife loves this jacket. She wears it all the time and it keeps her nice and warm. She also likes the added length.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought this coat for my Mom and she loves it! She says it's a very flattering style and she likes that it is not too puffy. She is 5'4" and 120, athletic build, and I purchased her a size small. I had originally ordered a medium and it was a little baggy, which would be perfect if you wanted to have multiple layers underneath, but I exchanged it for a small since my mom already has a heavier winter coat that she layers underneath. She gives it two thumbs up all around!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
I love this parka.  I bought it a few years ago and wear it so often I thought I better get another just in case Patagonia stops making it. 

This  new model is a little roomier through the chest . I do not need the room in the chest, but some other folks might need it.  Other than across the chest the other measurements match my old Fiona, with the exception of the overall length. This one is about an inch longer. 

I tend to toss a down vest or some other piece under it on super cold days, so I buy mine to fit a wee bit looser. Although I do not feel it is too big when I do not layer.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This is a nice slim looking down coat.  A little more stylish than a big puffy and  perfect for cold fall mornings over yoga pants and running around town; or for those cooler days that you want a little coverage over your hips and thighs.  Nice overall fit and look and should layer well under my boiled wool winter coat
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I was excited when I bought this coat. Unfortunately, after about the second time I wore it everything I touched was COVERED in feathers. I thought this would improve and it did not. My car looks like I own a dog. Not an exaggeration. Entire front cloth seat covered in feathers that I have to pick out by hand because a lint brush won't work. I was past the point of return so now am stuck with it. It is warm but not worth it. sigh.
Loved the coat out of the package - but the fit was terrible.  The medium ran too small (I'm 5'5" 135 lbs) and a large would have been way too big.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: These are soft and seem durable. A little stretchy, but thicker than prana kara jeans. They run pretty long though. I'm 5'4" size 26 and needed to exchange for the short. They are a little tight in the hips, and gap a bit at the waist, but not so much that it is a deal breaker. I have wide hips and a narrow waist, and these would probably fit a little better on someone with smaller hips.

I was nervous about this pair of jeans working for me, I'm short and super curvy and have always had to spend a ton of money on jeans that flatter.  I could not be more stoked on the way these fit me! They're soft, a bit long for someone with a 28" inseam, but I cuff them or wear them with wedges. Definitely, pay attention to the warning about the color transfer and either wash them in cold water before wearing or be ready for the color to transfer onto lighter fabrics.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
There must have been a issue when Patagonia started producing these, because I disagree completely with the below reviewers.

The fit is great! They are not as stretchy as their Prana alternative, but seem way more durable. The color is a great deep indigo, which I haven't seem change dramatically since the first couple of washes. They are a great classic jean you can feel good about wearing due to Patagonia's great environmental practices!

I like the color and stretch in these jeans a lot. First I ordered the 30x32 and then got another pair in the 30x30 because the 32's are quite long. The only negative to these jeans is that they are short in the waist, so they sit low. Not "hiphuggers" but a little lower than I'd like. They slip down and need to be belted or hiked up to be where I like them. I haven't washed them yet, so I don't know how they'll fade.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: As a fan of the Patagonia brand, I had high expectations. They are the most uncomfortable and unflattering $99 jeans I have ever had. The warp and woof is misaligned in on leg, making the grain of the fabric look diagonal instead of straight up and down. This is only noticeable with the pants on. It also makes them a bit pinching with movement. The color has a purple hue that was unexpected. I wanted so badly to love these, very disapointed.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: The Patagonia Houdini is an awesome lightweight packable shell. The breathability seems decent, I haven't had a chance to put it through the ringer on the mountain though so TBD. I have worn it in varied states of downpour and stayed very dry on the inside, I was impressed. The only criticism I have is that there are no pockets outside of the chest zipper.  Which is fine when you're using it in the backcountry, but pockets are always a nice to have. In terms of fit, I went for a Large and feel like it's perfect for me.  I'm 5'9" and 185lbs,

I have been using this jacket as my primary back-country rain shell since mile 1300 on my AT thru-hike in 2015. It is lighter, more pack able, and more waterproof than any other raincoat I saw on the trail. 

Breathability: The breathability is so-so. When you are choosing a raincoat that is this light, you have to have realistic expectations of the performance. If you are hiking on a humid New England day, you absolutely will sweat inside the coat. But with that in mind, the coat does an excellent job of keeping out the elements. 

Durability: After using this for the second half of my AT-thru hike, and on countless day hikes in New England, it accompanied me on a 2800 mile bike packing trip from Canada to mexico. We saw our fair share of rain, and I was never wet under the Houdini. I even crashed while wearing it, and expected a huge tear when I got up, but aside from a mud stain it held up. The helmet compatible hood works for a bike helmet.

Fit: This coat is designed with climbing in mind and has a slim fit, the medium is definitely a close fit on me, and a large would have done just as well.

This raincoat is a must have for ultralight backcountry pursuits.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
The Alpine Houdini is essentially a more waterproof, durable and burly version of the Houdini with some really rad color combinations! Although each piece has their own intended use - I would say both are essential. 

Disclaimer: SIZE UP. I am a large in most Patagonia tops but I would recommend "sizing down" in this jacket if you are on the cusp of sizing like myself. Although I wanted to make the large work, the medium just fit me much better. 

2.5Layer, 30D Nylon and some well placed adjustable areas on the jacket (hood, cuffs and waist) this jacket is meant to live and adventure in the great outdoors. 

Spring skiing, climbing, fishing or taking cover while a surprise rainstorm rolls through your campsite, the Alpine Houdini is yet another clutch piece of gear to add to your wardrobe. 

Please reach out if you have any questions on sizing, intended use or just looking to pick up your first or o1 millionth piece of Patagonia gear. Great brand and great gear... just can't say enough about em'!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Bought this jacket for an upcoming trip for my fiance. Cannot get over how lightweight and compact this jacket is!
column8: I've used it several times
