column8: I've used it several times

column5: This is a light shell, so if you're looking for something more durable in a downpour, this may not be it. For what i need it for, it's perfect. I bought it to wear on cool nights where I dont need anything too thick or bulky but will give me a layer of defense against light winds and rain. Styling with the grey forest camo as well.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I live in California. I was looking for a light  packable jacket to take into town (or SF) in the evenings for when the temp drops or wind picks up. This works perfectly. It looks pretty stylish (for a windbreaker), comfier than a  rain jacket (I was using one previously for this purpose but it felt sweaty and horrible when wearing), is comfy (even when against skin), big pockets, fits in a pocket when scrunched up ( i use vecro straps to make it smaller), and keeps the chill off nicely. It is splashproof but not waterproof but that does not affect me because it does not rain in Cali in the seasons I want to use this anyway (I actually prefer it being breathable to super waterproof). I have used this many evenings in town, had it when the fog rolls in in SF, taken it camping, hiking, and to the beach. Has performed well. I had considered the Houdini, but I didn't like the fit and it did not have handwarmer pockets. Really happy with my choice.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The jacket itself is good but the fabric does not look good in terms of quality. I bought this at 20% off and it did not worth at full price.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Excellent. Roomy pockets..maybe a chest pocket
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I live in San Diego County (Carlsbad), so we don't need heavy jackets here. However, we are the land of microclimates, so what I have learned to do is dress in layers. This jacket is perfect for warmer days because it is super lightweight. However, if you wanted to layer it over a long sleeve base layer you could stay pretty toasty as the jacket is very good with repelling wind and light rain. The only gripe I have is that I wish it had a tiny bit more give in the shoulder area. It can feel a bit restrictive when you cross your arms in front of you. That said my shoulders are pretty broad at 42 inches (31 waist). It's not a bad problem to have it just can be difficult finding clothes that fit well and offer range of movement. Maybe if the jacket had a hidden stretch panel somewhere it would fix that. A large was way too baggy on me and the sleeves were too long. It's also possible the jacket will stretch a bit and conform to my body. I've only had it a week, so time will tell. Again, it's really a minor gripe as it is restrictive in the tiniest of ways but enough for me to notice, and I notice everything. Overall a great jacket.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I've only had this for for the last 36 hours but I've lived in it round the clock. It is my new favorite layer for everyday use. The construction and material are extremely high quality (wouldn't expect anything less though). It's not very warm as another user pointed out; it's about the same warmth as a long-sleeve shirt. But the wind and waterproofing is amazing.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: My son was looking for a basic windbreaker with no lining that would provide just-enough protection -- this was perfect! Good looking, lightweight, does shelter against light sprinkles and wind. He wears it pretty much every day. He's 6 feet 190 and the XL fit just right.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
Practical lightweight shower  proof outer layer.Pairs great with a ultra light compact down jacket.makes a compact practical combo for travel.
The light and variable folds into its own pouch.fits true to size. Shower resistant and wind resistant.quality manufacture. Looks good on. Camo pattern is distinct but subtle. Great for both urban and backcountry use.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought this jacket to provide a water-resistant layer that I could throw in my pack in the event of flying water. Its super light, and packs into its own pocket, which is a huge plus when carrying something you may not use. It is a very thin jacket, so I wouldn't use it for keeping you warm. But if you need a light weight pack-able layer, look no further.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Mediums work great for me (I have larger than average quads, glutes). I will say the socks are a little larger than I'd like for my size 8 wading boots.  Love being able to slide the top down to waist level to help regulate temp when it's hot.  No complaints here.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Bought these for my girlfriend and she loves them.  She is 5' 2" and petite, so we ordered the small petite.  The legs were a little long for her but they were still comfortable.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
Well, a few things:
I'm 5'5 and curvy with a size 8 foot and a size 9 wade boot, so I ordered an XL Petite.  Paid the 1 day shipping and received as promised.  
Waders very long, and neoprene sock had an extra 2" of  material and barely fit in my boot with no room to move.  The clincher for me was the clip for the straps, it's in the BACK of the waders, super awkward and not practical.  The straps going to the front, have no clips and are not the  removable, kind that clip in. There is a plastic piece where you can tighten the straps, and it hit at my armpit which would be annoying for my casting. Additionally, to tighten the top of the waders, there are an elastic pull and toggle, again, hitting this time under my arm and uncomfortable.  I had high hopes, but will go with my old standby Simms wader.
Btw, received a lovely voice mail and email from the Flyfishing expert at BackCountry.  I love the customer service!
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5:
I got these for a friend for Christmas, she hasn't got out in them yet but she said they fit great and are light on the shoulders compared to other waders she's had. 

She is a bit on the shorter side of the scale and the small/petiteworked perfect.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Review to follow, but I'm loving these waders as I'm chasing crazy birds around the wetlands and looking good doing it!

I ordered a Petite in Small.  I am 5 ft short, actual inseam of 28.5 inches.  The petite is stated as fitting a person with an inseam of 30 inches. Having owned another competitor brand in Small with a stated inseam of 29-30 inches, I thought I could get away with the small difference of 1.5 inches.  This is not the case - Patagonia Petite is sized for up to 5 ft 4 inches and caters for the taller end of Petite.  I measured the actual inseam of the wader from bottom of the heel to the crotch - that is 35 inches, vs 33 inches in the competitor wader.  From the crotch to the top of the front bib is 22.5 inches - vs 18 inches in the competitor's wader.   Hope this is of some use to height challenged persons like me.   I also hope that Patagonia can list the minimum height for this wader so that customers can make an informed choice.

Recently picked up these waders for my lady as she needed to replace her Redington Willow River waders that sprung a leak after a year's use.  At 5'2" she picked the medium regular fit waders and is happy with the fit.  She has enough room to move around and climb over rocks without getting a wedgie and can wear layers underneath on colder days.  The booties aren't too massive and fit well in her boots. She commented several times on how nice the materials are compared to her old waders.  Patagonia says the outside pocket is waterproof, but I probably wouldn't recommend putting anything that you want kept completely dry in case of a slip in the river. The sealed pocket inside would be a better option for storing a phone or keys.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I bought these for my wife who is new to fly fishing and who loves fishing and also wants to feel feminine as opposed to wearing MC Hammer pants made from a trash bag. She is very slender and the XS waders were perfect. The silhouette was flattering (as waders can possible be) while providing all the range of motion she craved. The fleece lined handwarmers are a great touch and she was instantly commenting how useful they to take the edge off after taking your hands out of the cold river. The booties fit wonderfully and the merino lining is a nice touch for warmth and comfort. Overall, she loves wearing these waders and feels great in them. More couples fly fishing trips as a result of this purchase.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I think I would like these pants if they weren't so baggy-- it makes them seem like from another decade (before slimmer pants became fashionable). Don't get me wrong, I don't like super slim pants. But I don't want them THIS baggy (especially the ankle parts).

.....the best pants ever made! It has been hard to take these off. They are perfect for everything from bike commutes, hiking, running around town, under waders, just hanging out, or about anything my life demands. The fabric is ultra comfortable, seems to shed water, allows for range of motion, and do not "dirty" up like jeans or other material. Easy to clean up with a little water to keep them looking fresh while out fun hogging. I own a few pairs and love the durability, confident they will last a long time. As a bonus, they are Patagonia so you have the confidence knowing your supporting a company who stands up for our passions in the outdoors.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Got these in the middle of the winter for a fishing trip and I just can't wait for the summer to roll in so I can put them through the trails my favorite pants go through. The fit perfect with the rest of Patagonia product that I order. They feel lightweight and they wick just as you would expect. if they past the first few tests I have in store for them I will be ordering another pair.
column8: I've used it several times

column8: I've used it several times

column5: This belt is great! It will keep your pants from falling down. The tension lock belt buckle is simple yet very effective. I've had a belt with this belt buckle from another brand for over twenty years with no issues. I decided it was time for a new one. My only concern is that the belt is a little wider than I'd like (at 1.5 inches wide), however it will hold up to rugged use. Patagonia really should use more eco friendly materials such as hemp for the webbing on this belt.

column5: Best belt for ski pants and has a great locking buckle feature.   I bought two colors.

column5: The Patagonia Tech Web Belt is the best belt I have found in my 35 years on planet earth. The wide webbing is great for me, I like how it fills-out the belt loops on my pants and keeps them evenly secured to my waist. I've worn this swimming with hybrid shorts and with a suit to a wedding - it is the master of all belts. Get one... or six.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Bought the black, one size fits all! Nice buckle and belt but it doesn't stay tight.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love all types of web belts for their versatility. This one is no exception, heavy duty polyester webbing and an excellent friction based buckle keep this belt locked in where you set it. I've used it everyday for 2 months and haven't had any slipping.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have one of the old ones. It has the thicker webbing and the buckle was installed the "correct" way. (direction) For the life of me I don't understand why Patagonia degraded one of the best belts I've ever owned. And I'm 62 years old so I've worn a few in my long construction career. I'm still wearing the old one and was so happy with it that I ordered 3 new ones about a year ago. I wanted some color variety, you know, break it up a bit..... Well as soon as I got them, I returned all 3 of them. When Patagonia goes back to their original manufacturer, I'll come back and buy 3 more. The new ones are not up to Patagonia standards.

column5: Durable and works with all my pants. Solid belt.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought the Forge Grey color and wear it with my jeans and shorts.  Unlike some other web belts I've had before, the buckle on this one actually keeps the belt in place rather than loosen over time.  I've got a 33" waist and the length was fine - plenty of extra length if I need it, but it stays in place.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: The belt is fine.  The rest of the reviews capture the issues.  It is thinner than previous belts, feels cheaper and the buckle is reversed which is odd.  It holds up my pants and it is not worth the hassle to return, but I would not have purchased it if I had known about the the changes or read the reviews.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Why make the belts cheaper just charge a bit more and keep making the the best belt on the planet. Please notify me when the original belts are back. I'm always in the market for a fine product.
Thx
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
New version has a flimsy webbing material compared to original version. And now they sew the buckle on backwards.

Patagonia used to have an awesome product. The current version is a far cry from the quality expected from Patagonia.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
So... I own 3 of these belts in the older style (which are amazing) and one of the new style. I didn't read any reviews when I bought the new style, assuming it was going to be like the trusty tried and true tech belts from before. One of the first things you notice when you get it out of the box is that the buckle looks to be on backwards. You think it's weird and then you try to figure out how to use it as normal. Then as you go through the day, you continually swear to yourself about how the belt is a lemon and won't stay tight no matter what you try. Then you just never get around to returning it since it isn't a high priority, but it is still annoying. Then one day you are browsing on the line and see TONS of horrible reviews on this what was once a stellar belt and think to yourself, I should totally add my opinion to this, but one of the first ones towards the top is a video and you give it 58 seconds of my time... MIND BLOWN. Due to the thinner material they had to rethink the way it goes through the buckle to keep it from slipping... No big deal. The belt works as it is supposed to now, but I decided on 4 stars because they could have had some sort of public awareness to the change instead of getting everyone riled up. In short, same great belt. Versatile for anything you may or may not need it for and it still comes in some pretty snazzy colors. So don't give it a bad rap, it just needed a little awareness to let people know it's just slightly different.

Green one is the new style, orange is old. Notice how they thread into the buckle opposite of each other. IF you thread it the right way, you'll experience night and day results.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Having enjoyed earlier Patagonia Tech Web Belts, I was looking forward to a couple new ones. What a mistake. I should have checked the reviews on the Patagonia website. The webbing is 50% the quality of the earlier belts (if that). You don't expect a company like Patagonia to downgrade quality over time. Time to find a new brand.

column5:
I normally wear my suspenders but decided to give this belt a try. My world got flipped upside down... but in a good way! Great belt!!  I'm recommending everyone get on the belt train, suspenders are on the way out. This belt has securely fastened itself around the loops of my heart. 
I'm getting my brothers this belt for Christmas. Love it! Great Belt! You won't be displeased.

column5: Having enjoyed earlier Patagonia Tech Web Belts, I was looking forward to a couple new ones. What a mistake. I should have checked the reviews on the Patagonia website. The webbing is 50% the quality of the earlier belts (if that) and the buckle is sewn on backwards (teeth don't grab). Time to find a new brand.

column5:
The pros: It's super-soft, very fitted, and I'm going to ASSUME it wears well based on the brand
The cons: It's overpriced for the quality of the fabric (not at all substantial), and that "fitted" could very easily be "too tight" for a lot of people
This was my first Patagonia purchase, and I wanted to love it... but I'm a little disappointed. It looks nice on, because the fit is feminine and not bulky. But that fleece feels quite thin, and it just doesn't have the feeling of quality I was hoping for in an item at this price point. If you're considering it for a very lightweight layer under something, it may work very well for you. If you want it for a top layer, however, buy a larger size, and don't expect it to be as warm/protective as outerwear. It's more like a spring-weight sweater
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: bought as a gift Nice and soft but to short in length
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Purchased as a gift and is soft but not quite the color or sleeve length required.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5:
I love the fit! But the inseams were stitched together with thread in between NOT cloth. The stitch is a part of the sleeve. Meaning you have fleece, stitch, and fleece for the sleeves. It's irritating, I can feel it rubbing against my arms. Usually, seams are sewn on top of the folded cloth joining the two fabrics together. 

Maybe this won't be a problem for people with a lot of sleeve room. But I like a fitted fit so it does not work for me ! :( So sad.

My wife loves this fleece. It is a great layering piece. It gets washed and dried weekly and holds up great. Patagonia never lets us down. She will probably be buying more colors of this because she wears her grey one so much. My wife is currently pregnant and this light fleece is fitting well even with a growing belly.
Nice fit

column5: Good gloves. Well made. Fit a bit larger, and longer (they almost go up while forearm) than expected.

I ordered these in Medium for my 9 year old son, who is by no means a large kid. However, they were so small we ended up using them for my 4 year old instead. They are a good quality fleece with a substantial cuff, and we're happy with them except for the sizing problem.

column5: These gloves fit my 9-year-old daughter perfectly. She wears them while running, playing soccer, hiking, and sitting around during recess. She has gone from a child who hated gloves to one who loves to wear them.

column5:
I was forced to choose a rating on the product but the product itself is not an issue.  These are nice gloves, but I had to rate my buying experience instead of the actual product.

I ordered a medium for my slightly smaller than average 8 1/2 year old.  The size chart says 6-10 so this seemed like the best option.  Unfortunately, these gloves are far too large.  In fact, they are just a bit too large for my 12 year old son.  The size chart on this product is way off -- a $10 mistake with shipping both ways.  Very disappointing.
"Since 1993 we've eliminated the need for over 20,000 barrels of oil and have kept millions of plastic bottles from the waste stream."

I'm super picky about my bathing suit bottoms. I want enough coverage to feel comfortable wrestling my 2 year old in the sand without flashing the whole beach, but don't want to look like I'm wearing a pair of granny panties. This is the perfect balance between looking amazing and feeling amazing. The bottoms stay perfectly in place in big waves and currents (and tickle fights). And I actually love the way I look in them (and I'm crazy picky). You'll feel free to pedal your bike, get out of the water after cliff jumping, surf with confidence, and eat a hotdog on the beach (man, how is everybody wearing those Brazilian bikini bottoms these days and still feeling like they can move or eat?). Excited to wear these skiing next spring- they are THAT confidence inspiring.

Another great piece of clothing from Patagonia - great bathing suit bottoms - they are thick, flattering, and fit nicely. Great bottoms if you are more active around water as they definitely don't fall off.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I ordered these bottoms in black L and one in cerise L.  I absolutely love these bottoms!!!! They are made of such great quality material that will last for years to come. The fit is the best I've ever had, no soggy bikini bottoms here!! I wish I would have found them years ago, I would highly recommend giving these a try, you will love them.  I like that they come in a variety of colors as well. Back county staff is very knowledgeable and friendly if you have questions about sizing. They make shopping online a fun and easy experience.

column5: The bottoms are great--fit well and stay in place, even during active sports. I'm 5'5'' and 122 pounds and the medium fit perfectly (I could have gone with the small, but they felt a bit too snug on the waistline).

The top comes up easily and the bottoms fill with water between the 2 layers of fabric, bloating the suit out. I would have returned it but I took it on a 7 day rafting trip and wore it for a day . That day I miraculously got my period a whole week early and accidentally bled in it.

Boo Patagonia :(

Super light, breathable, and comfortable. Wore this base layer with a vest for touring, and it was the perfect temperature. Can be worn with any layering system.

column5: I gave this baselayer to my fiance for skiing and she has had only good news to report. She said its worked great at keeping her warm and dry. Furthermore, she liked how it looks like a pretty normal shirt so that after a long day of skiing she can lose the jacket and relax in the lodge without looking like a bum. She'll probably start using it for some spring hiking when the time comes as well.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: LW Cap passes the test both as a baselayer and as a running top. Boom!
Off-set shoulder seams--good for resisting chafe as well as allowing it to look like it fits despite having broader shoulders. Double nice.

SIZE REFERENCE:
Height: 5' 4.75" 
Bust/Waist/Hips: 33", 25/26", 34.5" 
Weight: 105 lb.
Dress/Pant Size: 0/25 
Bra: 32A/34AA/XS/S

I have this in an XXS.

FIT: The fit in this piece is consistent with the rest of Patagonia's slim fit pieces. Because my shoulders are a little broad/bigger compared to the rest of my body (I have more of a V-shape up top) and I also have longer arms, the sleeves are a bit short and the shoulders are a bit tight (yet I still have a bit of room in the lower torso). Despite this I still go true to size, and since I have a body type that's a little hard to fit and the discomfort is minor, no stars docked for fit.

PERFORMANCE: I mainly got this baselayer because I love Patagonia's merino baselayers--a lot. Maybe too much! And though I really adore my Thermal Weight Capilene, I have always preferred my Merino Midweight to almost any baselayer. So for me this was a real test just to see if Capilene could give merino a run for its money. The result: I was very, very pleasantly surprised. I went for a fairly intense hilly run in this and wore it for a total of around 48 hours (with about a single 8-hour air-out/dry-time overnight while I was sleeping and also wore it to bed one night) and was very pleased. The polygiene really did its job. While running and sweating, it did a great job keeping me dry and comfortable, but it was also light and thin enough that I could feel the wonderfully cool air. I started off wearing my Houdini as my shell and then ended with just the Capilene in 45-degree F weather. It was perfect.

BOTTOM LINE: Though I love merino, this sealed the deal for me on Capilene. I want to be able to have synthetic pieces that are versatile and can perform well during any objective, especially when safety (body temp/perspiration) is a real issue. This piece is going to play an important role in my layering system.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Purchased this base layer for hiking (southeast, so 4 seasons of hiking) and for a summer hiking trip to northern and central Alaska.  Researched ahead of time the best base layers on the market in my price range and this one was always on top for quality and dependability. It, along with the thermal grade Capilene, quickly turned into my go-tops.  Warm, light, and an excellent length for a tall/ long torso person. I also purchased one for my sister who is very petite and it fit her wonderfully.  After hiking in it for three days, it did not smell terrible like my other layers either.   Highly recommended. Worth the cost.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
This is my first piece of Capilene. I been told for years that I should use these base layers because they're awesome. Now, I know what the fuss is about. 

I wanted to really put this to the test, so I used this running on a very windy and cold day. The wind was so cold I had to run back for a face mask.  I ran very comfortably in this shirt, with nothing over it. It blocked the wind enough and kept me warm, even though it's so very thin. I'm not sure how they do it, but it really does trap heat. I've since been using this skiing, as it breathes really well.  I've also been wearing it around the house a lot, just because I stay so comfortably warm in it.

I'm not sure about the fit. I'm usually a medium in shirts. I'm 5'8, 135lbs. I can wear small, but they typically aren't long enough in the torso, so medium is usually a good fit. I got the medium in this and it fits, but it's rather loose and quite long. I'm not sure if they meant for it to be loose, or if I should have picked up the small. I will definitely try the small, next time.  I like my base layers to be more fitted.

I highly recommend these capilene base layers.

More questions? Just call or email me, directly.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I am extremely disappointed with Patagonia's customer service and choices about their updates to the R-line. The previous R-line had a unique fleece fiber that I haven't encountered in any other brand or line. Unfortunately, Patagonia chose to update their R-line so that it mirrored less competitive rival brands and their materials. 
I sent my R2 jacket in to be repaired and wrote specific notes about how I would pay for any repairs that they could not fix for free. I expected the detailed notes to be an obvious sign that I would like to keep my jacket. However, I had inadvertently neglected a box that noted if they could throw my item out after they had determined if it could be repaired or not. This was particularly upsetting because they DO NOT MAKE THIS JACKET anymore and it had strong sentimental value! When I sent my pack to REI recently, they called to let me know they received it and emailed pictures of the damaged areas to make sure they knew what I intended to be repaired. However, Patagaonia sent 2 emails and then "chopped up" (in their words!) my irreplaceable jacket. As I previously said, extremely disappointing.

The R3 Hooded Jacket is super lightweight without losing warmth and is super soft. My sister was surprised to find that it is reversible and can be worn with the pocket in front showing or without. Great for casual wear but also is great for a winter trail run or mountain tour.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
A friend of mine had been talking non-stop about how awesome her R3 was, so I figured as a Professional Fleece Aficionado I should weigh in on the whole situation. 

Reader's Digest Version: Hands down the fluffiest, coziest, easy-to-wear and thermally efficient fleece I have in my line up. 

Ages ago I picked up an R3 (orangutan orange mind you) and the high loft fibers shed all over everything I owned, leaving a very barren fleece - so I was a bit apprehensive of giving the R3 another go, but I'm so glad I did. The new and improved R3 touts a shorter fleece that doesn't shed, wicks away moisture, dries quickly, and assures warmth when you need it most. All in all, I love the fact that the R3 promotes cozy warmth while being incredibly lightweight and packable. Sometimes when I'm traveling, I roll the jacket up into the hood and use it as an impromptu pillow.

Perhaps my favorite part about this fleece is the fact that it's totally reversible! One side features a longer, loftier fleece for colder days, and the other has a shorter fleece for warmer days. Whoa, hello, imagine my surprise when I discovered that! One side has a chest pocket and the other has hand pockets. Additionally, my second favorite part about this fleece are the cuffs - super low-profile and slim without cutting off the blood flow to your hands (obviously crucial). 

My only beef is the oversized collar and hood, which I know is for helmet-compatible purposes and warmth and what have you, but it's a little bit much when you're wearing it unzipped. 

As for the fit, I picked up a Small, which is a big long and slightly relaxed, but I love it regardless. I think that if I were to purchase another fleece, I would go with an XS instead. For fit reference, I wear an XS in just about all Patagonia items, but can wear a Small when I'm looking to have a more relaxed fit. Additionally, I wear an XS in Arc'teryx and XS in Prana items.

I was hesitant in ordering this jacket as I wanted something packable for travel but just a bit softer and warmer than my nanopuff and reviews seem iffy. I ordered the  ultramarine thinking it seemed to be a versatile enough combo....
Upon receipt I LOVE the weight, comfort, and versatility of the jacket itself. There is a definite warmth variable depending on which side you wear out which makes it that much more functional. A few things to note, and maybe I just wasn't being that observant, but the hand pockets are only on the side without the chest pocket. They are NOT accessible from both sides!!!! I also ended up returning the ultramarine and ordering the rustic purple (which I haven't received yet) because the ultramarine is highlighter blue. It's kind of pretty with my blue shoes but it literally reflects that blue onto my face as if it were glowing which, due to my tan skin, makes me look reptilian and sick. Reflective highlighter blue is also very difficult to match with a pair of shorts/pants. This also makes it harder for use in a capsule wardrobe. On the other hand, if you are in the back country it would be FANTASTIC for not losing hiking buddies in the wilderness or flagging aircraft if necessary. Something to consider. 
Overall, if you can get over the color options at this price point I would say it is worth the investment.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I borrowed this jacket from a girlfriend to go on a fly fishing trip, and I loved it. It was lightweight, but warm and soft. I think it would be awesome as a baselayer for skiing as well.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: From the R3 description I expected the equivalent of Polartec 300, which I am familiar with. The fabric of this garment was thin, sleazy, and not even warm enough to be a light sweater in the house. So thin it's transparent in places. What a disappointment, especially from a company like Patagonia. I returned it.

column5:
I basically live in this fleece!

The soft, fuzzy material makes it very cozy and the side paneling keeps the jackets shape, making it more fit than baggy. The material doesn't shed and it's super warm.

column5: This is a really pretty sweater.  The dark currant is great, it shines a wine-red color, even in low light, and it's comfortable and attractively fitted.  It's warm, but also light enough to layer well with.  I would say it has a loose to fitted style to it.  As my friend says, "it looks like you skinned a Muppet." column5: If I'm sleeping outside, my R3 is coming along.  This fleece has come on every cold conditions trek and climb I've done in the past three years. column5:
Just got this jacket in the mail today and I haven't taken it off yet. Its SUPER comfy and warm. I'm excited to test it outside. The sizing is def strange as most patagonia sizing is because one person could be 3 different sizes depending on what the item is. Great item!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: But seriously- it's like wearing your favorite blanket in a jacket form. The fleece is SUPER soft, but doesn't shed too easily. It fits true to size- I am 5'2, 113lbs, and I got the size Small. The hood is definitely tailored towards an alpine-style- you could definitely wear it under a helmet if that's what you're looking for. The only thing that I dislike about this jacket is its pockets. The pockets are made out of the super hole-y jersey type material. So if your hands are in your pockets, there's a good chance that they're going to get colder rather than warmer. Other than that, this is my favorite jacket! Feminine cut, looks good, feels good, and made with the Patagonia quality.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love this jacket.  It looks great and feels great.  I like the slim fit also.  It's very warm.  I love the white.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Absolutely warm piece of fabric. And extremly soft too. I've been wearing it without any jacket on top during soft winter days and didn't feel cold. On other way it's so comfotable that you wouldn't want to take it of even in mild summer evenings. Hood is very close fitting which is really good during snowfall. Moreover it has quite femine look to make you feel good looking during harsh weather conditions.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I CANNOT SAY ENOUGH GOOD THINGS ABOUT THIS JACKET. It is literally the perfect in between of puffy and fleece. Now that I have it, I wonder how I hiked without it for so long. I bought this jacket because I was in need of a good midlayer jacket, mostly for hiking and keeping my core warm while  commuting to and from my lifting gym (which is freezing in winter). I have also now added it into my winter running gear and just everyday use. The multiple pockets and hood are lifesavers and it is so versatile, it can work as a midlayer but also as an outer layer & climbing coat. 

It is warm enough that I only needed to pair it with a capilene long sleeve tee on a 10miler in the Catskills in 40 degree weather. Easy to take on and off and lightweight enough that I can roll up and shove into my pack. I used it recently hiking on Shawangunk Ridge Trail which had a lot of scrambling and a fall on my part and the jacket does not snag, tear or pill. The drawstring feature is great too, I used it while doing some outside sled work in windy conditions and I had no problems.  

Patagonia tends to fit small, but this jacket was true to size. I bought the large because I like to layer under it and I was worried about tightness in the shoulders/lat area but it fits great and I easily could have sized down.

Thank you to gearhead Travis Bivins for the recommendation.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
This jacket truly straddles the puffy/fleece line. It breathes well and is super cozy on a cold day.  However, the fabric seems to soak up dirt and never quite get clean. It also has not held up well to use with a hip belot on my pack or my climbing harness. 

http://www.snowbeastreviews.com/w-nano-air

for in depth review.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I was expecting this to be warmer for winter use but I'm pretty pleased with it even though I will be using it for warmer weather outdoor purposes. Great color combination.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I wore a single layer along with this jacket on a -degree day and it was enough to keep me warm throughout the day. The material is very soft and not too bulky. Can be worn along for hiking or running, or used as a mid layer for snow sports.  It's an extremely versatile jacket.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I went through a couple other jackets before getting the nano-air hoody and I am so glad I kept looking for the right one. I took this to Patagonia for a 10 day hiking trip at the beginning of February and it far exceeded my expectations. When we backpacked to the base of the Torres it was very windy and snowed, but this jacket kept me warm and dry. It is so comfortable and the fabric is really cozy so you can wear it over a short-sleeve shirt. I got a medium and it fits great with room for base and mid layers while still fitting under my shell.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Take free backcountry 20% OFF Coupon,Take It: outdoorback.tk

I'm a tall, gangly thing, so I tend to have issues with the more petite-oriented Patagucci fits. The Nano Air is no exception. I ADORE the fabric--it's nearly weightless, instantly warm, and incredibly breathable (think touring, running, xc skiing, backpacking). I love this jacket for more horizontally-focused activities around town and in the mountains, but the fit isn't suitable for anything vertically-focused like ice climbing or alpine. The arms are a great length, but when I reach above my head to swing an ice tool etc, the hem pulls out of my harness, resulting in a cold and annoyed Zoe. The medium is semi-fitted/relaxed, and I'm swimming in the large although the length is better. If only the medium were a bit longer in the torso...
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The Nano Air is perfect for a warm spring day in Alaska!

I bought this jacket but ended up returning it for an Arc'Teryx jacket. I thought this jacket fit way too short, especially for such a warm jacket. I love the look of it just didn't think that the fit was very functional.

The performance of this jacket is unrivaled. Patagonia really outdid themselves with the construction of this piece. Like all the reviews below me, there has rarely been a time in which that I've felt as though I needed to remove my jacket because I'm too warm. It consistently regulates my body temperature and offers a stellar warmth-to-weight ratio when I need it. The fit is pretty on point, and stays true to Patagonia's Alpine Fit, which is to say it has a slimmer fit than say the Patagonia Nano Puff or Down Jacket. Not only that, but this piece layers amazingly. This is pretty much my do-everything jacket (hiking, daily use, skiing, climbing, etc) and to say the least I'm obsessed with it. It does get a little on the stinky side, but it's synthetic and that's to be expected. I'm typically a size XS in Patagonia's products across the board, though sometimes I purchase a Small in the Alpine Fit to accommodate for more layering beneath the item in question.

I will speak to the fabric pilling as I've experienced this myself - I typically just tossed the jacket in the wash and that has absolved the pilling problem, though my husband has one as well and his has endured the pilling far more than mine has. We took a sweater stone to the material and thus far it's held up fine with no holes, though I can see it being problematic and potentially detrimental to the overall integrity of the fabric considering how thin it is.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I had been eyeing this jacket for more than a year. The first thing I was so attracted to was how soft the fabric is. Secondly, as i learned more about it, the performance is what really grabbed my attention. Going ski touring with friends I noticed how the could comfortably keep it on while I was constantly sweating in my down puffy, contemplating whether I should keep in on or take it off. When you're tired and trying to keep up with your buds, its a big deal. Since purchasing this jacket, I have gone on 2 big spring ski tours and a handful other activities. Its light and breathable. I purchased the Chartreuse, which is a loud color but also reflects the sun nicely. I was able to sleep in my sleeping bag comfortably, staying warm but not sweaty, and of course it is super soft and comfy. So glad I made this purchase. Also, shout out to Backcountry's incredible customer service. I chose the wrong shipping option and they fixed it immediately. Then I bought a couple more items and Gearhead Conner Johnson called me to thank me for my purchase and see if I had any further questions. It made me feel so special!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: This hoodie is so comfy. It feels so soft and fits great under a shell or windbreaker. Equally comfortable on warm or cold days. Nano Air is my go-to layering piece. I've got 2 now and I have no problem justifying the price. It's that awesome.

This hoodie is out of this world!! So soft and comfortable. I have other jackets for other reasons and this one fits a particular role. If you need a hoodie that feels like a cloud is hugging you and let's your body heat out, then look no further. The nano air lets you be physically active and still stay warm and cozy. I mainly use this for climbing, hiking, running, and lounging around the house. If you're on the fence, get it.
This jacket is nice and warm yet breathable.  It's nice and light weight for stuffing into your backpack.  I wear it everyday to school and every night for walking my dogs.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I bought the Patagonia Nano Air Hooded Insulated Jacket for my wife as a present to replace some older fleece mid-layers. Everyone should think about replace their old fleeces with one of these as the material is superior (breathable and range of motion) and it feels and wears light than fleece. It is also a great standalone piece in the spring and fall (or winter in CA). My wife is 5'6" and 108 lbs and the XS fits great
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: It feels and looks great. What I love most about it is that it breathes. This is a great jacket if you are doing any kind of outdoor workout because you don't get overheated. It's a slim fit and you should measure yourself and follow the chart. I have an XS but should've ordered the small. (Wishful thinking on my part, so it will hopefully force me to lose that five pounds of excess weight I have.)
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I've worn it a couple of times in weather ranging from the mid 20s to low 40s, with only a mid-weight Patagonia capilene base layer shirt underneath. I was completely comfortable even standing still at the colder end of that spectrum, all zipped up. At the higher end of the temperature spectrum, during or after intense exertion, I had to unzip and my arms felt a bit warm -- but not so warm that I had to take the jacket off. And if a breeze kicked up, the sun hid, or I slowed down, I zipped up at least part way. 

Amazingly light for the amount of warmth it delivers. I have other ultra-light jackets, but this is the warmest. The cut of the hood, with the zipper coming up so high in front, and so much of the head being covered adds a lot of warmth. Its stretchiness makes it extremely comfortable.  There's so little weight or bulk. I love that I don't need anything beyond a base layer underneath. It is a joy to hike in.

I hope the weather stays cold this winter so I have many more opportunities to wear this jacket!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Really does live up to the hype.   My new go-to mid or outer layer for splitboard touring in these early-mid winter (ie. cold) conditions.  Closest thing I've found to live up to the "put it on, leave it on" advertising claim (ie. really is breathable, yet warm).  Only (minor) downsides is the outer material is relatively delicate (watch yourself near camp stoves, etc) and not wind-resistant, but that's not why you're buying this.  I want another.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: The Patagonia Nano-Air keeps you smiling in comfort when the snow starts to fly
An early winter hike in Colorado.

Got this pack to use for school to carry my laptop and books as well as to use out in the backcountry for day trips! Perfect size for what I want to use it for with plenty of storage space. DWR does its job on this pack!

column5: I have had this pack for about 6 months now and it still looks brand new. Iv used it to carry my laptop and books around campus on week days and gear when I'm ski touring on the weekends. My favorite feature is the large goggle pocket. It fits goggles, sunglasses, and snacks for easy access. Sometimes I wish I got the 30L for longer tours so I could have a little more space to work with. Overall great purchase that I will be using forever.

column5: Nothing you don't need. Simple, durable, light, and tight! Plenty of room for safety gear, insulation, gloves, repair kit, food, water, chocolate, gummy bears, Swedish fish, and eyewear. I've also been able to stuff a 60m 6mm cord and harness in but its tight. Multiple ski attachment options but my favorite is the low ski loop which allows the ability to quiver your skis without removing your pack if you add a shoulder strap leash. Perfect efficient movement in the mountains!

column5: I really like this little day pack. i have used it for a number of things. I hate snowboarding with a backpack, but this pack is nice and slim and comfortable on the back. I have found that the probe pocket is a little small. but other then that i love this little pack. everything else fits in great.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Got this for backcountry use- fits beacon, shovel, probe in very nicely.  Has great pockets and places for extra layers, food, etc. you might want to carry.  I personally use it for snowboarding- fits snowboard on great on outside straps and snowshoes. Also use it inside resorts if I want a light pack to carry/want to do longer, in-bounds hike-to terrain.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
Looks like this puppy is out of stock, but I will say that as a very light packer, I found this pack to be excellent for a 3.5/4-day trip out to Colorado for a full day of skiing (and another day for hiking and climbing, and another day for just plain hanging out). It fit a lot more than I thought it would and seems like a generous 20L. I thought it performed really well as opposed to a regular backpack and fit my back really nicely and allowed for more movement in the upper body. I think it makes an excellent daypack for skiing and for ski mountaineering, but for longer adventures, a 30L would be great. Beware of the slight differences, though: the 30L will not have the compartment on the strap for the water bladder hose. I would also have enjoyed an attachment for my helmet, but managed to attach it to the side panel straps for easy carrying. The chest strap was a little low for me, but the hip strap was comfortable and fit me well while both traveling and skiing. I'm also loving the separate microfleece compartment for the goggles--brilliant!

BOTTOM LINE: I've been pleasantly surprised by its capacity and lightweightness, and have yet to test it out further, but love it so far!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: This 20L pack is a great small pack for quick sidecountry missions, or tours where you don't need to take a lot with you.  It's got organization for your probe/shovel/saw, and a nice simple layout for lunch, water, and a few layers.  The insulated hydration sleeve is a nice bonus, and the padded back panel is super comfortable.

I've had the backpack for a few months, and I loved it for hiking and bike commuting. It's insanely comfortable and balances a full load well. The downside: I took it ski touring this weekend, and it's too small. The shovel handle and probe barely fit under the zipper. After adding a water bottle and first aid kit, there's hardly room for skins, and definitely not for extra layers or lots of snacks. This would be a great in-bounds ski or snowboard pack, but I think I'll upgrade to the 30L for touring!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: In hindsight I should have ordered the fishpond but at the time it didn't have the dual main compartment that the Atom did.  The fishpond has much better attachment points for tippet, pliers etc. The plier pocket on shoulder strap is terrible as is and I have lost my pliers a couple of times before using a fishpond swivel retractor in case it falls out again.  I also have some issue with it sliding down shoulder somewhat but found that keeping the bag light will help with that.   With all of the negatives said, the main pocket and front hard pocket with fly patch are excellent.  The dual main compartment allows for a headlamp, rain gear and water filter in back with fly boxes and leader wallet in front half.   I have found using the filter and keeping the water bottle weight out helps it carry better on a long fishing trip.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I toss this bag in my pack anytime I'm heading out on a fly-fishing backpacking adventure.  I love being able to hike deep into the backcountry in search of trout.  I don't love sticking my fly box and other fishing essentials in my pockets.  This pack is small enough to shove in my main backpacking pack on the way in and then pull out once I've set up a base camp.   Keeps all my fishing essentials handy for a day out on the water. Plus the water bottle carry is genius.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Let's start with the fact that I am primarily a kayak fisherman. I am just getting into fly fishing and plan to chase trout this fall when they are stocked locally. For now though, I fish for bass and sunfish. Recently went out in my kayak with only my fly rod , and decided to try putting the Atom Sling Pack over my PFD. Of course, I had to sit a little awkward to make it comfortable, but I could make it work! Now for the important details: I really like the Atom Sling! Why? Versatility. This pack can be used in so many different ways. When using it as designed it spins around to the back  so that when standing in my kayak, I almost forget I'm wearing it. Then when sliding it to the front so I could make tackle changes it was very easy to access all the pockets. Since I am just starting, I am still experimenting with how to set the pack up, and again, it's so versatile there are lots of options. I liked having the tippet holder on the outside so I could have immediate access to pull some line off. Since I don't have that many flies yet (1 large and 1 small pack and neither is close to full) I did not come anywhere close to filling up the inside of the pack. In my research before purchasing I was very concerned about getting just the right size, not too big or small, and I think I nailed it! I look forward to more time on the water so I can refine my setup, especially when I take my first trout trip this fall!
 I also foresee using this pack for short hiking trips. Having good storage, a place to carry water, etc. I think it would make a great hiking pack! At least for the short trips that I would take. It would also work great for a day at an amusement park. It's so light and comfortable. 
 In closing, I will say this was my first purchase from Backcountry. Their service has been great! My Gearhead (they assign you a "personal Gearhead" to follow up and see if you have questions, problems, etc.), Sam Hurst, has reached out several times to follow up and make sure I am satisfied with my purchase, see how I am using it, ask if there is anything he can help with. At first I was skeptical of the whole idea, but now I think it's a great way to stay in contact and give great customer service. When I placed the order I had reached out through the online chat with a question and received the same great service then. I am really impressed!
 In closing, though I was a first time customer, I'm sure I will be a repeat customer. Great customer service before and after the sale, great products! What else could you ask for?!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
After researching and trying on several sling, chest and hip packs for fly fishing, I decided that the Atom Stealth Sling had the best features for what I was looking for. My criteria was: enough room for a few fly boxes, small tackle and tool holders, water bottle holder large enough for a nalgene, clip for a net, enough extra room inside for a packable rainjacket, small camera and snacks and above all COMFORT.
While I tried this sling on without gear, it is extremely comfortable, but fully or even partly loaded this sling is literally a pain in the neck. It is not only uncomfortable, but it constantly slides of my shoulder, even with the cross strap buckled. The only way this sling can be worn correctly is on your right shoulder, which is my casting shoulder. Why most sling packs are made to rest on your right shoulder is puzzling, as most people are right handed casters.
I since switched to a hip pack with a strap that can worn on either left or right shoulders and hope to have better luck with this. The sling pack would normally end up on the bank and I couldn't wait to take it off at the end of the day.
Out of all the sling packs, I think this one has the best features, but I would highly recommend finding a shop where you can try one out, fully loaded, while demoing a rod. Good luck.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Take another off 20% discount coupon from www.realdiscount.tk

Great Sling!  I’m not sure how I spent so long stuffing fly boxes in my waders and pockets.  This sling holds everything I need, plus some extras (beer, er – rain jacket) for a long day.  Super convenient to use and comfortable on your back.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love this pack, been out on the water this year without one but super glad I have something now. It holds everything I need, including jacket or food (plus essentials like beer) without me having to wade back to shore. I do like the convenient sling for easy access as well.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Great for beginners and  experts. Super simple and lightweight.

This pack is great! I use it for Tenkara fishing but would really be good for anything.  It has everything I need! Fits all the fishing gear, but also has room if I want to throw in a jacket or lunch.  The waterproof pocket is great as well!

I had my doubts initially - most of it due to ensuring a proper fit like others who have negative reviews.  Give it some time to make minor adjustments, though, and you'll never head to water without it.  
Main Pocket: The thing looks small, but is a modified day pack - keeping the bulk over your back and out of the way (and water) to provide the freedom to cast, retrieve, fight, and land fish.  I can go all day with it on, meanwhile holding 2-3 fly boxes, Steripen (water purification), a day's worth of snacks, compartment for your shades, sun screen, Ultrathon bug repellent, and a 32 oz Nalgene (seen at the bottom).  The phone pocket is too small for an iPhone 6+ but should be fine for just about any smaller phone.  There's a loop at the top where you can stick a magnetic net release to make for easy landing (pictured is the small, Wetfly Catch & Release net).
Tying Table (outside of the main pocket):  Changing flies out is pretty slick too.  All you need to do is unbuckle the bottom strap and flip the sling around.  Then open the tying table compartment where there's plenty of storage space for tippet, strike indicators, weights, nippers, etc.  Within the tying table is a foam pad to dry out used flies.
Along the Strap: There's a small compartment that'll hold small things such as chapstick, cigar, or gum and has loops on the outside to secure forceps and other fishing tools to keep handy while fishing.
Patagonia thought about it all with this one!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I've never been a fan of vests and traditional backpacks were too much for me. This sling has been a perfect medium. Fits comfortably, while providing enough space for whatever I might need for a day on the river.

I love the hood and how it wraps around your face to provide optimal face sun protection for bright snow covered mountain tops. I wish it fit just a smidge tighter but the small was too small. Overall great product, I'll be wearing it for years to come!

I love the pocket accent too- easy to through something in there without being in the way. I am not personally a fan of the hood so much, though I do understand the purpose for the elastic, so it actually stays in place. Great shirt for hanging in the sun, swimming, hiking, basically all of the funtivities. Definitely would recommend!

column5: Bart from Patagonia shares his thoughts on the Sunshade Hoody.

I purchased this shirt a year ago, and it became my favorite go- to piece for those almost chilly days. It is super comfortable and light, but is still stylish enough to wear anywhere. It goes from lounging to around the town to dinner out. I also use it for running, light hiking, and the occasional extra ski layer. I am a pretty warm person so this light layer is perfect, I stll wear it multiple times a week and am planning on purchasing another.

These are great pants for both traveling and hiking! The only thing is I thought they had the ability to cinch the ankle on the pants and mine came without a cord strung through the holes. Thereâs slits where a cord should be but didnât come with any. Not too big of a deal but it would be nice to have sometimes!

These pants are light and breathable for summer alpine shenanigans. They also happen to be tough, quick drying and stylish.  I wore them for a late summer Mount Adams ascent and epic multi-glissade descent and while my partners' trousers shredded like rice paper on the icy slushcapade, these wafer-thin beauties showed nary a scratch! I also butt-glissaded down Mount Hood on the same trip (in August!), where the squanchy ice/snow is lightly dusted with volcanic pumice, for Pete's sake! No visible signs of damage! I proudly sported them to the brewery aprÃ©s climb. Eight thumbs up!

Start from the good, pants are light, build in belt is neat, DWR finish is great.

However the cut of the pants simply doesn't allow any movement  (hiking uphill is pain in the ass), the double seamlines suck big and confine spaces yet the material is not stretchable at all! If you are only buying these for casual wear, maybe it's fine. Stay away if you plan to hike with these

I'm by no means big but  do have slightly above average thigh,  but with these not a single chance I would hike a single mile.

column5: I wore these on a week long backpacking trip. The pants are light (9 oz.), soft and comfortable.  They block wind and were plenty warm for hiking in the 40's. They show no signs of wear despite some scrambling on rocks.  Two issues: They are closed with a button which was really tight to get through the button hole, and the button fell off about half way through my trip.  Luckily the zipper and belt kept the pants up.  I replaced with a snap.  Also the zip pocket on the right leg is just a little too small to comfortably fit your hand in to get small items.

column5:
I've put it through the wringer

Take another off 20% coupons codefrom  outdoorback.tk

I bought this fleece instead of the standard r1 because I kept seeing reviews that said the r1 isn't that durable and pills excessively, and I wanted a fleece that would be good for rock climbing and could handle a beating.
Overall, I'm not very impressed with this version and I wish I had gone with the standard r1. 
The r1 field's reinforcement panels add quite a bit of bulk and stiffness, making it less packable, and the horizontal pocket is very difficult to open with one hand (however the horizontal pocket can be friggin sweet because it perfectly fits a beer can! So awesome around the campfire!). One if my biggest problems with it is the sleeve cuffs; since I hoped to use this for rock climbing I needed to be able to pull up the sleeves to keep my hands free from obstruction. I see people do this with the r1 all the time, but with the r1 field the reinforcement panels make the sleeves stiffer and not stretchy enough to pull up and keep in place. The stiffness and looser fit also make this jacket less convenient to layer. It just doesn't feel right underneath my nano air or hard shell, and the sleeves bunch up.

This jacket did not meet my needs, but with that being said I do think it is a good jacket. It would be good for manual labor outside in colder weather, or for other outdoor activities but in my opinion it does not make a good layering piece and it's not good for rock climbing. 
Since getting this jacket I've talked to many of my friends with r1s and the pilling and durability never seem to be a problem. If you're thinking about getting this jacket for layering or climbing, go with the r1 hoody or standard r1 despite what some reviewers say about durability. I think Patagonia tried to fix something that wasn't broken with the r1 field. The r1 is the gold standard for a fleece layer for good reason, and Patagonia will always repair and replace damaged gear, so I wouldn't recommend the r1 field.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: As the pullover has more rugged fabric around the shoulders and waist , it's better suited to walked through the woods where other sweaters might snag. The remaining area of the pullover allows for enough airflow that you could be fairly active in cooler weather and without getting overly warm. I've worn this while out walking the dogs on cool days, as a base layer while skiing in single digit (Fahrenheit) weather, and in the office to keep me warm at my desk. In all arenas the pullover has been great. A bit too pricey at $170 in my opinion, but having picked it up on sale I'm quite happy.

column5: This is that windstopper stuff with fleece on top. Sexy and stiff, just like she likes it.
Description

I'm a big fan of Patagonia outwear, and wear my Down Sweater and multiple Synchilla fleeces often.  Those are fantastic and highly functional pieces, and I was expecting the same from the Retro-X jacket, but boy was I wrong!

When I received the jacket I was surprised by how much structure the jacket has for a fleece, or what some other reviewers are referring to as its stiffness.  I'm guessing that the stiffness is due to the windproofing, and it makes the jacket feel more like a wool or leather jacket than a fleece.  It feels comfortable, it just may be different than what you're expecting.

My problem with the jacket is that it does not breathe at all.  Of course a fleece that is windproof won't breathe like a regular fleece, but wearing this jacket is like wearing a sauna suit.  After walking a couple blocks in this jacket I'm sweating like crazy, and I've never experienced this before in anything besides really cheap junky nylon jackets.  The only way to stop sweating is to open the zipper, but then I'm cold, especially my base layers are wet from the sweat. 

So when wearing this jacket, my choice is either drenched in sweat, or freezing my you know what off.  $200 down the drain.
column8: I've used it several times

Great look and fit

Wore it in to work today and got a lot of compliments on it.  It was just below 30 degrees and i was very comfortable outside.  Great product, would recommend to anyone debating.

column5: i got this for my bf-- should've known to size down w/ patagonia.  he is 6' and about 170lbs.  the L was too big, should've gone M.  we ended up returning it, although it's a nice jacket-- fuzzy!

Yes, it's really windproof.
Yes, it's made of recycled materials.
But no, it's not soft. The Patagonia R3 fleece and the Mountain Hardwear Monkey Man look similar to the Retro-X but unlike the Retro-X, they are SOFT AND FUZZY. However, this jacket isn't. The jacket feels like the yellow insulation materials they put in buildings/houses. It's not soft. I'm in college and a couple of  girls literally ran  up to me to feel my jacket, but leave disappointed in it's roughness. Times like that I wished I chose the R3 or the Monkey Man.
But considering that the Retro-X is windproof unlike its counterparts, it's nice. But keep in mind that the jacket feels a bit stiff even after wearing it for a couple of months and I don't think it'll get any less stiff because of its construction with the inner windproof layer design.

But the jacket is very warm and cuddly looking, but beware it's not soft and fuzzy like how I was hoping.
This is a great, warm, heavy fleece. It is very "tight knit" so it keeps the wind out but yet it is breathable.  The lining isn't the same as the outside but is a smooth mesh.  Fits true to size.

I bought one of these jackets around 1993. It was my main jacket for winter for many years. I left it at a new years party and my friend refused to return it conveniently because he love it so much. 

This jacket is one of the greatest jackets ever designed. It has a thicker fleece exterior but it keeps you incredibly warm due to the wind-proof membrane. Pockets are large. 

Patagonia makes quality products that are durable and this is one of the best.

I'm glad to have my new one for this winter.

I am 5'3" and 120 lbs, the size small is perfection. 
The fabric itself is really lightweight, but it also has some heft to it. You won't be facing any sort of Marylin Monroe type situation with this skirt. It's flirty and it loves to twirl. 

I like the silhouette on this little number. But what works best is that it can be both dressed up or dressed down, depending on your evening itinerary. Slap on a pair of cowboy boots, and you've got the perfect line dancing attire. Add flats for a casual yet classy look at work. Add a tank for a hot summer stroll. 

Patagonia is a brand I love to invest in because I know their clothing lasts a good long while, and they aren't prone to going out of style. I also like knowing that this company cares about the environment and takes a huge stand within the industry to redefine responsible manufacturing. Wooo Woooooooo!

column5:
I bought a pair of these a few months ago from backcountry.  At first, I though they were great- they fit well (although Patagonia sizing is all over the place:  I got these in a 34, and they are pretty loose around my hips.  I got two other pairs of the normal , not-stretch shorts in the same size and they would barely pull over my thighs).
I used them most weekends for a range of water-based activities from water-skiing/wakeboarding to kite surfing, or just chilling in the pool.  They looked great ...  then the stitching around the hem started to come undone, before the seat blew out when I was kite surfing.  
I get that gear like this can't be bomb-proof but I am really disappointed that these failed so quickly.  These were big on me, so it's not even as though I was putting the seams under a lot of load. I love the Patagonia branding, functionality and styling, but this is not what the brand- or the pricing- stands for.  

I guess the search goes on for the perfect board short.  This certainly isn't it.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
I used to have  awesome tye-dyed cotton undies made from T-shirt material.  I swear they have lasted 10+ years and are now just starting to look wonky in the elastic trim.  So since I cannot get those undies anymore, I looked at the Patagonia Active Hipster Briefs.   Not cotton, not tye-dyed t-shirt material, but dang if they are not just as comfy if not more so!  I really do not feel like there is any undies fighting my pants, riding up my butt, wandering around in the nether-regions... it's super stealth underwear!!

5'5" and 130lbs and I ordered a couple medium of the stripes.  Wash easy, I hang to dry so they last longer.  Extremely comfy undies, pretty pricey for panties I know, but I hate diggin' out the wedgie!  These have been wedge-free so far, even on a 2 day hike, they didn't stretch out on day 2 and make me cranky.
 
My hubby said the stripes looked great on me, so I bought a few more...  Thanks Patagonia for some awesome undies!  I hope these last a long time!!

column5:
Reader's Digest Version: A barely-there, quick-drying short for long and short runs alike. 

Non-Reader's Digest Version: I'm in love. Like, love-love. I have last year's version of the Strider and WHOA that short is tight and hello-booty-everywhere (that being said, they're great for tempo training or really hot days). However, I'm happy to report that the fit has changed and this year's edition is far less tight and is much more comfortable. I wear an XS in last year's edition (which is a little tight, but not obstructive) and I bought an XS in this year's edition and it's like, perfectly flowy in the thighs but fitted (but not tight) in the waist band. The tie waist is a nice touch. 

The fabric is SUPER quick-drying and soft. Last night I took them on an 8-mile run in 100-degree heat and yeah, I was sweating a lot (i.e. my butt looked like I had sat in a puddle), but the fabric dried within a minute of getting saturated (maybe even less). The fabric didn't chafe and the perforated inserts help bolster breathability. 

Also, the liner is so, so soft and offers a barely-there feel. Like, I wish that liner was in every single pair of my shorts. It didn't ride up, chafe, or obstruct mobility. It was just perfect.

I love the little pocket addition, it's super convenient for gels, house keys, or doggy-doo bags. 

I'm 5'3" or so, and the inseam is short, but not too short that I'm uncomfortable. I prefer the shorter lengths since longer shorts often chafe funny on me.

My only suggestion to Patagonia is to offer the Strider with a split leg. It's a really nice detail that I didn't realize how much I loved until I bought a pair of shorts that had it. 

Bottom line: I'm totally in love and will most likely be buying another pair because they fit so well, are so quick-drying, versatile, and suhh-hhoofffttttt.

I have been running in strider shorts for the last 5 years, and honestly have no reason to buy any other shorts--they are the BEST! Super comfy and wearable for hours. 

To reply to the review that said they are big compared to last year's--last year's sizing was messed up! I have consistently worn an XS  in Patagonia shorts, and last year they were so tight I felt like I put on 5 pounds--I couldn't wear them for more than a couple miles without being annoyed at how awkward they fit. This year the sizing is back to where it was, and the fit is perfect. I love the wide waistband, the leg holes are fitted yet roomy. The back zipper pocket is a nice addition too. Super happy with these shorts :)

Patagonia Capilene Daily Boxers are treating with Polygiene permanent odor control - stops the growth of odor-causing bacteria on fabrics, so you can Wear More and Wash Less®. Products treated with Polygiene do not need to be washed as often, which saves water, energy, time and money as well as improving the lifespan of the products. 

Odor Free. Climate Smart. bluesign® approved. 
Watch the video to learn more!

The Capilene Daily boxers, are my daily drivers, very comfy, stretchy, and really can do it all.  If you are doing high intensity workout and activities, they have the breathability  to withstand, and stretchiness to adapt, and at the same time are totally fine just to wear around the house, and have a relaxed day in. I have been wearing these as my go to's since I first found them in 2012. If you are looking for something better than your cotton undies in the warmer months of the year, this would be the ideal choice! 
Hit me up if you have any questions!

column5:
For probably 8+ years now I've been running exclusively in Pearl Izumi Infinity shorts.  I honestly loved them so much, I bought and hoarded them like Elaine bought and hoarded sponges on Seinfeld.  But, Pearl Izumi has moved on with new styles and frankly that doesn't always mean "better" to me.  So I set out to explore the possibilities.  I have tried several shorts now from Pearl Izumi, Hoka and Patagonia.

Here's what I really like about the Patagonia Strider.  It provides a nice tight but not-so-tight fit.  I like all my goods to stay in the same place.  But I don't want to be choked either.  Patagonia Strider won that battle against the other brands.  I really like the 5 in inseam, but some shorts with 5 in inseams seem to look a hell of a lot short than that.  Patagonia was right where I expected it to be.  Lastly, I have muscular legs and I really want to know that the shorts give me lots of room to move in all directions - especially when trial running.  Again, the Patagonia Strider took the trophy.  

I have not yet tried the pockets.  They are deeper than I expected, but I am cautious about the unclosable opening.  I tend not to like to carry much in the pockets of my running shorts other than possibly a car key (the Strider does have the small zipper pocket on the back like most shorts do).  

Two thumbs up!

column5:
I own 4 pairs of these shorts. I've used them extensively and they are my go-to shorts for long days. They are comfortable, unrestrictive, durable, and the pockets, the pockets!

The Strider Pro shorts have the biggest pockets of any trail running shorts I've found. The latest version has the largest pockets yet. They have 4 gel type stretchy pockets and one zippered pocket. All of the pockets are very large compared to other shorts (TNF Better than Naked, for example). The front gel pockets are a bit bigger and you could easily fit a phone in them. You could also fit 3-4 gels per pocket or other snacks, and even some windshirts and light gloves fit in the pockets. With a handheld bottle and some intermediate water sources, you could do very long all day runs with these shorts with no other storage required. 

In the old version of these shorts you could change the draw string so that it was tied behind or in front of the wasteband. You can't do that now and it's stuck on the outside. I am also happy to see these offered in plain black now.

Let's go over the good, because like all patagonia underwear they are:

column5:
Size reference: 5' 4.75", ~34A, 108-112 lbs. depending on the season.  I carry my weight in my thighs/hips/bum, and I got these in a small despite being a little in-between an XS and a S according to their size chart.

FIT & PERFORMANCE: I am a big fan of the boy short style, and Patagonia definitely hit the nail on the head in terms of coverage. The length is just right, and they cover my bottom entirely, which is nice because a lot of "boy short" styles tend to be more "cheeky”; yet, they are not low-profile, as the edges of these shorts DO show through yoga pants or tight jeans. I have the matching bra which I do wear 1-2 times a week on average, and really like the matching, interesting patterns. The same fabric is used in both of them, which is excellent in terms of its ability to dry quickly, and my bra has lasted through many washes and a lot of activity, so I imagine the same would go for the fabric on the shorts.

However, for me, the crotch rides up after a short time wearing these while doing exercise or other more intense activities like climbing or slacklining, which makes them very uncomfortable. Walking to the store and back, they tend to feel good and stay put, but otherwise, I don't get much mileage out of them.

I think part of the problem is both the varying fabric pattern and the location/type of the seams. The fabric pattern on the majority of the boy short is very stretchy and soft, but the fabric pattern (or gauge, perhaps) on the crotch is tougher and much less stretchy , which makes it feel tighter than the rest of the short. For me, it feels quite restricting. The stretchiness of the rest of the short feels great when moving around a lot, but it seems like this aids in the shorts riding up elsewhere. 

For me, the diamond crotch seam pattern on their Velocity Race Shorts doesn’t ride up and has a more natural feel, and you often see that type of seam in yoga pants, probably because the seem type/placement makes much more sense for us ladies (the seams tend to better follow our anatomy rather than run against it).

If you think these might work better for you than they did for me, I'd suggest buying this previous model that is on sale (or using a coupon to buy the new model) before committing to an expensive pair of underwear you might not like. It looks like the new model doesn't differ in the crotch style but rather in the thickness of the waistband (which wasn't a problem for me as it wasn't constricting).

The attached pic should show the comparison of the seam style in Patagonia's Velocity Race Shorts (in catalan coral) versus the Active Mesh Boy Short (in radiant magenta).

This bra is is so thin and light you really do forget you're wearing it. The modesty cups are a nice shape that lay seamlessly against you, so you can't see the edges of them through the bra or a thin shirt. The split straps in the front offer a pretty little detail, so that you don't have to worry about keeping it totally covered up. I got this in the big sur blue for that reason - many of the other colors seemed to light or pastel-ish to allow to peek out of tanks or tees. Too much like underwear. The brighter color makes it seem fun and intentional - cuz lets face it, with all the strappy yoga tops and whatnot, when do you ever find a bra that actually has the same shape as the straps in a top anymore? 

I'm 5'1" and 110lb. I used to wear a 34 B at VS, but discovered within the last year that a 32 C is a much better fit - it allows me to hook the smallest adjustment which is somewhere between a 30-32. Having said that, I think that anyone smaller around than me would probably want to try the xs instead of the small. I ordered the small, and the chest fits nicely, but it can be a bit skitchy around the middle. Doesn't move enough to bother me, but it's something to keep in mind if you're slightly on either side of those measurements.
