column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
I love me a comfortable pair of running shorts, and throughout the years I've amassed quite a few pairs of Patagonia's running shorts. They've definitely struggled with the fit in the past (too much fabric in the front pelvic area which leads to bunching and chafing, or heavy zippers on pockets that weigh you down), but in the past 2 - 3 years they've made some awesome advancements and the Strider series is evidence as such.

So, admittedly, I was a shade skeptical when I saw the new Strider Pro make its debut on the website: I wasn't super enticed by the shorter inseam or the new pocket configuration. I've been singing the praises of the 2015 edition and pretty much live in them once warmer temps come 'round, so I was a bit bummed about the new updates mostly because I love the old design so much. 

However, if there's anything I should glean from Patagonia's most recent batch of products, it's that change IS a good thing. That being said, these changes, ooh they good, baby! I'm surprisingly impressed despite my original, stodgy impressions.

SLC had a brief bout of spring-ish weather, which I figured would be a smart time to give these the Good Ole College Try. I run a mixture of road and trails, though I much prefer trails and largely rely on road for training / when I'm in a time-crunch. So, I figured I could get a solid "Initial Impressions" feel if I took them on a 5-mile road cruise. I paired them with a lightweight merino wool shirt and a nano air vest and was extremely comfortable. The shorts have a very barely-there feeling and were a treat to run in.

That being said, these are my Initial Impressions Thus Far: 

1. I'm really, really digging the waist band! It has the reinforced elastic on the interior, much like Patagonia's baselayers do, so the short sits higher up on your natural waist rather than being super low-slung. 
2. The fabric is pretty much the same, if anything it might be a shade more lightweight and therefore more quick-drying. We'll see how this performance actually pans out come hotter weather since 54 degrees isn't exactly, well, soggy bottom sweat inducing. 
3. The pocket configuration is aacccuuuttually pretty nifty, albeit I didn't use all the pockets, which I rarely do in my elder Strider Pro shorts either (I dig me a solid hydration / snack holster vest).
4. The inseam isn't all that different than the originals, however it still is a pretty short inseam so that's something to keep in mind when ordering this short.
5. The built-in liner seems to fit differently and more comfortably. I'm not sure what exactly it is, but it's better. Certainly won't complain about an updated built-in liner, that's for dang sure.

Fit Impressions:
I waffle between a Small and XS in Patagonia's fit. However, I'm noticing as of late I'm more of a "true fit" XS, but can wear a Small if I want the product in question to have a more "relaxed" fit. I have a small in the OG Pro Strider and they fit perfectly, so I picked up a Small. The Small is definitely a relaxed fit on me, but a comfortable one for sure. The waist band has an adjustable tie, so I'm able to cinch the shorts down comfortably. I'm not sure I would want the XS simply because I don't like my running shorts to feel super snug in the hips, especially when they're supposed to be light and airy. That being said, excess fabric can do some damage while running, but I'd venture to say that the relaxed fit on this short won't chafe or cause hot spots. I'll update the review once hotter weather comes around, for sure.

All in all, I'm surprised at how stupendous the updates actually were. I'm really, really looking forward to taking these out for a longer rabble-rouse come warmer weather.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I bought this for a fly fishing trip that I was going on. Since then I've worn it out on the boat and on hiking day trips as the weather started to get colder. The fits is great, light weight, and breathable.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I have fallen in love with Patagonia - the fabrics are fabulous, nicely styled, and comfortable.  Whether I am golfing in Cairo,  rafting in Idaho, or out hiking in the Colorado mountains this is the perfect shirt.  Even though the sleeves are a little long, that works for me to provide sun protection for the back of my hands.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I got this for my stepmom who took it on an adventure to Indonesia for 3 weeks, and from the sounds of it, it sounds like it was a life savior! The material is light and airy, great for a sunshirt in the hotter temps. The fit is right on- she typically wears a Medium in tops, and the M fit like a charm. On that note, it does have a little longer sleeves- most sleeves come up too short on her, but these fit well. Overall, great durable sun and adventure shirt- she did say that the colored shirts had some odd bright highlights on the sleeves, so I got her the white and that worked well (it's 100% solid white, no color accents).
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I bought this shirt for our annual deep sea fishing trip in the Florida Keys where it's 100 percent necessary to keep your skin covered (if you don't, you risk sun poisoning and sun rash within days). This shirt was soft and airy and didn't rub my slight sunburnt skin raw. It held up well to suntan lotion, bug spray, fish guts, and salt water. I'm thinking about buying another one just for hiking since the color is so nice.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have long arms and the length was good for me. I have a thin body and it wasn't overly baggy. My shoulders are a bit broader than average and a medium fit me fine.  Just wish it was tailored a bit more to be closer to trim fit.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I tried the Sol Patrol out this summer on three Sierra week-long trips, and it was exactly the right shirt for me. It kept me cool (and protected) above tree line, and I never overheated in it. Notably, it's not a warm shirt -- early mornings I was still in my fleece over the Sol Patrol, just as I would have been wearing a wool tee. After 3 weeks in the woods it shows no scuffs or abrasions to the fabric, and the snap closures are strong and secure. The feel of the fabric is wonderful -- if Patagonia made pants out of the same fabric I would get them. Very soft and comfortable, with just the right stretch in the side panels, and quite breathable. I'm really narrow, 5'7" & 120 # and a small fit perfectly. I was able to rinse it out most nights and it never got stinky.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I'll update this review when I return form Costa Rica in a few weeks, but I was impressed with this shirt when it came. I'm 5'1" and 112lbs, and the small fits perfectly. I'm sun sensitive and will be hot on forest treks, and I know this is going to do nicely. I'll look forward to using the nifty zippered side pocket for my passport and a little money while traveling through airports. I wish Back country had more colors, but the price was right! I just know such a light color will be dirty, but it should be easy to clean. I bought the Ion Blue, which is a very light blue color, though it looks almost white in the photos
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I have been searching for a long sleeve shirt to wear for backpacking that will keep me cool and protect my arms from the sun. First, let me set the record straight: I run HOT - I just turned 50, and my internal temp has skyrocketed! I have other long sleeve shirts but I get so hot wearing them while I hike. I would prefer to hike in short sleeves but I get too much sun hiking 10 hours a day in the backcountry. So enter the Patagonia Sol Patrol shirt. I held off for awhile as I was not sure about the light colors and backpacking, but finally pulled the trigger and I am glad I did! The light color (I got the Ion Blue) really helps keep you cooler than a darker shirt. Yeah, it gets dirty but so does everything when backpacking. The side panels really vent and the best feature of all is the SNAPS!!! Oh snap! No more fooling around with buttons with cold fingers at 5am in the morning in the tent! The snaps seem very durable and work awesome. Okay now for sizing - I feel this shirt runs big. I ordered a medium and it is a little big on me which is ok since I like it that way for backpacking. I am 5'3" and 128 lbs and a 36C-D and the medium has PLENTY of room and is a little long (which I also like). The sleeves are a little long on my arms, but I am a shorty. The Ion Blue is like a light glacier frosty blue (I was worried it would be a  gray shade but it is not). Hope this helps someone! Thanks Backcountry and Patagonia!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Corey from Patagonia shares his thoughts on the brand new Sol Patrol shirt.

This is a great sun shirt and so much more.  I wore it hiking and three people told me it couldn't be a sun shirt because it looked too stylish.  It is tapered at the waste. The fabric is soft.  I hiked all day in hot and humid weather and it was just perfect.

Overall they are well made and the drawstring is a great feature for adjust-ability. I would say in general it seems large for the sizing... I ordered a small and its big around the waist and it seems very long, I had some issues with my mobility being limited when high stepping  while hiking. I think these would be perfect for a leisurely hike and then a quick transition into a town setting.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I love this skort! The side pocket makes it easy to slide your  phone into and the zipper pocket in the back protects my cash/keys when I'm traveling around town. 

Recently I wore it on a 8 mile hike and ended up finding a lake mid hike and jumping in! The skort dried completely in about 30 min of heading back down the trail - I was so thankful to wear it while my friends struggled with their gear.  The under shorts don't ride up on my legs, but I can see why other reviewers might say that. I think it just varies body to body, so give it a try!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I tested this skirt out on a three day backpacking trip and I'm in love.  Fits great and allows for total mobility.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: For the medium size, the front length of the skirt is 15.5" and back is 16.5". The liner inseam is 4 inches on all sizes.
This skirt looks cute on but the shorts ride up after about 5 seconds.  I have found this to be true with other patagonia skorts.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: Freedom to walk on trail without worrying about what I have on to go from church to walking. love it , love it
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
When I pulled on the Happy Hike Skort, all I wanted to do was bust out James Brown's "I Got You (I Feel Good)" and sing it loudly—from the trail head to the summit. This skort has a feel-good design. I'm unbelievably stoked that there's a well-fitting skort out there built for hiking, travel, and beyond.

The fabric is lightweight, stretchy (yet durable), and dries quickly, so I'm able to lunge, high step and even cartwheel should my little heart desire it. There's an internal drawcord, allowing me to really batten down the hatches. The side pocket is great for gels or granola bars, too. 

My most favorite part of this skort is the built-in liner. I was not expecting the built-in shorts to be as well-fitting as they are. That being said, the built-in shorts are NOT booty shorts or a brief liner: they are a true, mid-thigh short on me, which in turn prevents thigh chafing and discomfort. For me, that's been my biggest beef with other skorts: the liners are always riding up, too tight, and way too short to actually serve a purpose. However, the Happy Hike Skort has me coming back for more.

As for the fit: I probably could have gone with an XS, but I went with a Small as I wanted to avoid the whole "pinched hips" sensation that sometimes occurs for me. The Small is definitely relaxed on me, loose in the elastic, but this allows me to comfortably wear the skort on my natural waist rather than awkwardly low-slung.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Bought this as a gift for my wife. Performs well, surprisingly small footprint so it packs well too. Great jacket and she loves it!

Got my sister this jacket for her birthday and she loves it! She uses it to go climbing in CO and said she loves the fit, color, and everything.  She's pretty small, about 5'1 100 lbs and she said the size small fit pretty well.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I already had the "regular" Houdini windbreaker for running and wanted something that would keep me dry. The Alpine Houdini is perfect!  Looks great, light, easily packable. The black looks great (very sharp black color) and easily layers over other fleeces and jackets. I am 5'8", 140#, typically a size 6 and run between a medium and small in Patagonia tops. I went medium for easy layering. Love it.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Extremely light, nice coverage, no pockets
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I absolutely love this jacket!  It is extremely light weight and packs down to nothing.  I originally purchased this as a rain/wind jacket for backpacking, but I find myself using it all the time.  It is so small and light that I always throw it in my bag.  It looks nice enough to wear around town too.  It fits true to size and layers well.  I would highly recommend this jacket!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Patagonia Alpine Houdini is an excellent full waterproof protection piece that works fantastic for the unexpected shower (it packs very well), the expected rain shower and perfect for the minimalist. I love this jacket for running (trail + road), canoeing, hiking and even golfing. It layers nicely over my R1 full-zip fleece jacket as well for cooler temps. I'm able to move freely in it during activities and adventures. If you want to save on weight in your pack and leave your waterproof jacket out, you don't have to worry about this when you own an Alpine Houdini. It is fantastic to bring along as it weighs practically nothing!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Very comfortable bra. My second Patagonia sports bra and probably more comfortable than the first one I bought. This one has wide straps, easy to slip on and stays in place. I'm small chested and it doesn't ride up or pinch me under the armpits or across the back like some do. Wearing it currently and about to go hit the gym. Bought it to take out backpacking. Probably should have bought another while it was on sale!
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: This is not a high impact sports bra by any means( just as it's advertised, it's light support) but it's my go to for backpacking. It's so soft and fits so well without being really tight and restricting. I'm a pretty chesty person but I honestly forget I'm even wearing it because it is really just so soft. I love that it's moisture wicking and after backpacking for multiple days in the middle of June it didn't have any odor to it at all.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I love how comfortable it is and the cute back.  I would definitely recommend it.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I really liked this bra - cute color, great fabric, good coverage. I got the xs which turned out to be way too tight on the girls. Like, serious smash-age. I'm a 32 B and the size chart says an xs is in the range of 32-34 ish. If you're a 32 A I'm sure the xs would be great, but otherwise size up! Ended up giving this to a friend rather than returning it.

This is a fabulously breathable, very well made sports bra. I'm tall and not too busty at a  size 32B, and the Small was snug but comfy on me. For high-impact activity like trail running, it's great, but for climbing, yoga, and lower-impact wear, the neckline is much too high for most of my athletic and casual tops.

I typically wear a 34C/D and bought this in a medium - it fits perfectly fine, and I love the way the material feels on my skin. I hate cups and underwires, and this has neither (though it has a place for you to add cups if you want.)  I wouldn't wear this to run, but I wear it for hiking/backpacking and find it to be comfortable, chafe-less (thank you!!), and quite cute considering I will wear it, as its marketed, as an "on the fly swimsuit." Very happy buyer!
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I just got this bra and already know it will be my favorite. Super comfortable - I wore it on an all day hike and felt supported with no itching or chafing! 
Won't be my go to for running, but perfect for my every day, or hiking, or skiing, or pretty much any other activity bra

I'm 5'4", 135 lbs, wear a 34DD bra. I bought a size M and it fits terrific and I love it. A few notes though - I did NOT buy this bra for high impact (running) activities. It wouldn't provide anywhere near the support I need for an activity like that. I bought it because I wanted something comfy to wear around the house and when I hike with my dog in the woods or go to yoga. For hanging around it is comfy and well made.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: This was a great bra, but I ended up returning it. The issue I had is that it was a little too tight underneath the armpits, I'm not sure A larger size would help because the rest of the bra fit right. For me, I get a lot of chaffing underneath my armpits when I run, so felt like this would cause more problems with that! But it's great quality and fit great everywhere else

I bought this bra as a gift for my girlfriend.

She's very picky when it comes to sports bras and was pleasantly surprised with this one. She especially liked the seamless construction and made comments like 'I forgot I was wearing it', which I've never heard her say.

I wore this bra for 7 days.  Straight. Just that fact speaks volumes.  Now, throw in that I wore it 7 days straight on an Elk hunt in the Colorado mountains says a whole lot more about this bra.  I was a sweaty mess half the day and freezing cold the other half.  It didn't smell, there was no chafing or itching. The straps didn't dig in. Most important,  I didn't think about at all until day 5 when I was like "dang this bra is awesome, I don't feel the need to rip it off at all". Spend the money you won't regret it.  I'm a 34/36 B and bought the medium which is a perfect fit.
I love these bras :) I wear them almost every day, for running, mountain biking, yoga, and to work! They are comfy and look great worn on their own--they double as a running top and a swimsuit top :)
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Ladies, if you want a no-frills quality sports bra this is for you! I am small chested so I don't need all the bells and whistles of these new-fangled bras. I just want a compression tube to keep my boobs in place without padding and with a good fit. It is very hard to find a sports bra that is a perfect fit for us A-cup ladies! Patagonia has nailed it. Plus, it is cute and flattering. I feel comfortable wearing this piece as a bathing suit top, or on its own on a hot day of sandstone desert climbing. Plus, this bra doesn't stretch out over time like most spandex products. Double win! Thank's Patagonia - now come up with some new patterns already.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: The reviews made me hesitant to purchase, but I am so grateful that backcountry has this sports bra available at such a good price. I just ordered my second pair of this sports bra, and probably not my last. It fits SO comfortable. I am a size M t-shirt, but bought a L bra. It's perfect for hikes, hot yoga classes, and casual daytrips but I would never be able to wear it on a run. Different uses for different bras though so I would say it's worth getting and it's very useful.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Size ref: I am 5' 4.75", run between 108-112 lbs. and carry my weight in my bottom half, and have a wider torso in relation to my cup size--I'm about a 34AA-34A (actually between 33 and 34) and take a size 0/XS dress size. I have this bra in a size small. I've had it for probably just under a year and have worn it in the ballpark of 100 times, 1-4 times a week (depending on when I'm in the swing of doing certain activities like climbing).

FIT & PERFORMANCE: the fit is rather unique; I don't have any bras that fit the same way, and I'm not quite sure if this bra in a small could fit women who have a B/C cup and above. I have a pretty small cup size and even I feel occasionally smushed, though the medium was too big of a step up for my cup size (but not for my ~33-34 bust measurement). The good thing about this is that, despite the fact I don't have much, well, *jiggle*, everything stays put and I never have to worry about bouldering on ceilings when people can easily see down your tank top. One odd thing I notice about the bra, though, is that it tends to shift downward on my body as time passes (throughout the day). It doesn't bug me all that much and it tends to feel a little more comfortable if I tug it downward a little when I put it on. I really love the position of the straps, and they don't feel like they cut into my body at all. However, the bust line is very tight on me, to a point where it's quite uncomfortable to put on and take off the bra because it doesn't stretch nearly as much as you think it might if you've ever felt the stretch in Patagonia's Active Mesh Boy Shorts.

CARE: I wash the bra probably every 3-5 times I wear it depending on the activity, though it has actually never once smelled funky, since it does breathe very well. Sometimes it looks stretched out after a use, but every time I put it on, the fit feels like it always has. It does not stretch or shrink whatsoever after a cold cycle wash (or hand wash) and a line-dry, which I think should be a number one factor when looking for a bra--what's the use of a bra that changes sizes after the first time you wash it? The radiant magenta has stayed perfectly radiant, but it has collected a few fuzzies/pills of other garments' materials I wash it with.

BOTTOM LINE: Despite this bra being quite tight, I do love it for climbing, running, bicycling, etc., or when I want something that doesn't show any bodily details through a tight t-shirt or tank top. I wear it with my Patagonia Layering Racerback and the straps show through the keyhole in the back in a very cute way. I'm on the fence about purchasing another one, and am kind of holding out in hopes that I stumble across something that is a little more forgiving for athletic builds, especially for female climbers who have muscles that simply seem to' get in the way' with a lot of bras. If Patagonia adds a little bit more stretch and perhaps a couple sizes more related to cup sizes (i.e., how more 'normal' bra sizing works), I think it'd be quite a hit!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Yes...runs small. But since I didn't return it I still use it anyways. Fortunately I'm not someone that actually needs a whole lot of support in the chest area so I manage wearing it, even though it's perhaps a whole size too small. I would say there's nothing particularly special or exciting about this sports bra. The thin straps make it somewhat uncomfortable but that could also just be a consequence of the small size.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
Let me first say, I have 10+ of these bras (same size: M) and have been wearing them since 2006/2007. 
I noticed a few years back they changed the material they use. The new material is not as durable/substantial as it use to be. 
That did not bother me. What does bother me, is : I ordered a BLACK Medium (same as I have always been: I am 140LB 5'5 and am a 34B) recently and could not even get it over my head. I gave this to my sister who normally wears xs in patagonia: she could barely get the thing off once she got it on. I am so disappointed in Patagonia for this. For the price, I should be getting the best. This is not even close!
Thanks for reading.

I really do wear these bras EVERY DAY! LOVE Them.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: This little bra is so comfortable--it really feels like you're not wearing anything. Some sports bras start to get annoying after wearing them all day, but I've worn this on a 4 day backpacking trip--hiking, sleeping, swimming, and it never started to rub or feel restricting. I agree with the other gals--this runs SMALL. I am a 32A and usually wear a XS in Patagonia, but I have this bra in a small and it fits snug, but comfortable.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Bought 2 of these in size M, one magenta and one black.  The magenta one fits perfectly...snug, but the right amount of snug (5 stars); the black one required my best David Copperfield skills to get on/off...way small!   Had to return...will need to try on in store in future, or hope for free return shipping.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5:
Nothing worse than spending money on a bad sports bra, but since my first Patagonia Active Mesh Bra I have been a believer.  They are great for running, yoga, or just under a t-shirt around town.  I love that they come in solid colors and different patterns and it's the only sports bra I will wear now.  Take your shirt off ladies and show off that active mesh bra because it's a good one.

I would agree that this product does run a little small compared to other brands, but I order my normal size as it gives more support.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: What other pair of shorts do you really need? No seriously. These shorts are phenomenal they hit the marks in all categories. They are light, durable, stylish, comfortable, and the fit is spot on. These are great for most activities. They breathe super well and are quick drying. Great for casual wear, going out on the river, quick bike or hike.  These have begun to takeover my short quiver
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I tried on the original baggies and really wasn't sold on them, then I discovered the stretch baggies!  For someone over six feet and not a huge fan of short shorts these were just what I was looking for in a breathable and active short.  Having stretch quick drying fabric is an amazing feature.  I did find these to run a little large, I have a 32 inch waist and had to tighten the medium all the way down.  I have no problems wearing these exercising in the heat of the summer here in Salt Lake City or high in the mountains.  Perfect short for all your summer adventures!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Great shorts man!  These things are comfortable, breathable, and they look great.  These were my first pair of baggies and cannot complain in the slightest.  Actually wearing them now while writing this review.  I felt the fit was perfect, and when compared to the baggies pants that I also ordered i felt these were much more true to size.  will def order again in the future.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5:
BAGGIES with STRETCH.....if you've never owned a pair. They are Simple. Sleek. Stretchy. Scandalous? How is this not what every person in the world wears on a daily basis? How do you keep these on the shelves at all? Why are you still reading this? Baggies will bring world peace. call me and let me take care of you!
Kameron Wansel
Gearhead, Account Manager
Office: 801-619-7469
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I initially picked up the standard baggies and thought they were just ok, and wasn't sure what all the hype was about there. I thought the mesh was super uncomfortable on those. Then I stumbled upon the stretch baggies and decided to give them a try. UNREAL. That slight stretch and lack of mesh is the key. SO comfortable, lightweight, and functional and is honestly my go to short for the warmer months months. Whether we're out hiking, skateboarding, or hangin on the couch these are undoubtedly a 5/5.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: So I've had a pair of these stretch baggies for over a year now, I really wanted to put these to the test before I gave a review of them and I have to say they're pretty great! Now I'm 6'5 and I wear between a 34"-36" inseam for pants so I've got some pretty long legs, I'm also a college athlete and so don't let my elongated frame deceive you I have some annoyingly large quads and these shorts accommodate my non-standard legs almost perfectly. As you can see in the picture, when worn below the natural waist, where I feel like most guys wear their jeans, these shorts are only about an inch or two above my knees when standing. So basically as far as fit goes, whether you're a bean pole, or squat for breakfast, lunch, and dinner, these shorts should fit you well. Now as far as materials and durability I really like the little bit of stretch these provide as I think they keep things from getting uncomfortable in any position, which is great for climbing, and hiking. I also like that these shorts forego mesh liner found in other baggies models. My only concern with these shorts is that I'm not sure if they're as durable as  the original baggies, as I have had some threads pop around the pockets and it's only been a year. I don't think this will ultimately be too much of a problem because just because they aren't AS durable as original baggies doesn't mean they aren't still bulletproof as all get out. Overall I'm sure these shorts are going to be in my line up for at least the next decade and I'm still incredibly happy with them 10/10 would buy again.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: So I've always been a huge fan of wearing a certain pant/short made by another brand that starts with a P, one that's very popular with climbers.  But a friend suggested I give baggies a shot, and I love them!  These shorts fit great and look even better, hitting a couple inches above the knee when standing up.  The stretch is subtle, but great for climbing, hiking, swimming, and literally everything else.  Stop reading this and go buy a pair now!!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: there is enough stretch in the inseam that you can do yoga in the morning and swim in the afternoon. the fabric seemed stiff for a while after the purchase however, had to wear it down.
These are a little more comfortable then regular baggies. Material feels a little softer to me and they have a little stretch. Also like that there is no lining in these.
I currently own three pairs of these shorts. They dry quickly and look great!  They are my go to shorts now.. I have hiked with them several times and had zero issues ..
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5:
Loving the new colors this year! I truly wear these for almost every activity. I was in a pool 2 hours before this picture was taken, the shorts dried out long before then but, they were not affected by chlorine and most people have to change from swim trunks to climbing shorts but, not me. I have tried on the normal Baggie Shorts without the stretch and they are great but, these climb, hike, and bike way better because you cannot get hung up on the fabric as it moves with you.

34" Waist and the Large fits great after I tighten the draw strings. I have a 30" inseam and when standing still they sit right above my knee, look higher in picture as I had my leg way up to stay in that crack.

Let me know if you have any questions about these shorts or other apparel that is multi use.

Bill Porreca
bporreca@backcountry.com
801-736-6398
These shorts are great! Best summer shorts you will own.  They are light weight and dry fast so they are great for playing in the water or going on a hike.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: I've been on the fence about Patagonia stuff for a while, due to the initial sticker shock that sometimes exists. But I finally bit the bullet and picked up a pair of these, and wow, was it worth it. They've quickly become my most comfortable, versatile, and all-around favorite shorts. Looking forward to putting these bad boys to the test in the backcountry soon, I'm sure they won't disappoint.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
I loved the Stoic Thrive's been looking for something similar. Well I found something better! These stretch so they are super durable, and water resistant makes them a huge plus. Great swim trunk to use on the water. Also intend to hike, climb, and bike in them as well. They are just an all purpose pair of shorts to use. I will even wear them out to eat unless the coffee stains become too much!

34" waist and the size large is perfect. Draw string allows them to stay up just fine.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: There are very few things these shorts can't do, they make a great bathing suit, they are comfortable as hiking, running, or fishing shorts, they look good with a nice button down shirt  AND they are unbelievably lightweight, breathable and stretchy. I have worn them at least three times a week for the last month and I have been traveling all over the country from California to Connecticut.  I predict that these shorts will serve well me for many years. The front pockets are very square and short, but they fit my iPhone 6 just fine. There is one back pocket on the right side that fits a normal bifold wallet perfectly. The shorts took about two days of wearing to break in, but now I am having trouble wearing any other shorts because these are so much better. Get a pair!

column5: I think this is the best model of Baggies Patagonia offers.  Awesome stretch fabric, a little more generous inseam, and no built in brief.  Been wearing these a ton this summer and have been really psyched.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Only took five days to know I needed the other colors! Mainly because the girlfriend said I'll need to change my shorts someday. Now own every color in the Baggies. Short are great for anything the day has to offer. Fabric is light sheds water great with the DWR treatment and stretches so you'll never feel restricted. The 9 inch inseam is perfect and rest right above the knee. The drawstring helps dial in the perfect fit. The only frustrating thing I have on this short is the 2 hand pockets. My iphone tends to fallout sometimes when I sit down. They have a very large opening. Other than that a great short.

column5: I was excited to get these shorts. I should have tried them on before purchasing them on line. The shorts are great, but they were not tailored for someone with muscular legs or butt. Not at all. I'm 5'8'', 178lbs and a 32 in waist.

column5: Snagged these at the beginning of summer and love the light material. Super soft and supple.

column5: good
good

Tried on these shorts in the "Mojave Khaki" color, size 30 and they fit perfect, but weren't quite the color I wanted. So I then ordered the same shorts in the the "Forge Grey" color, size 30 and they were way too small - fit more like a 28 waist, not 30. Will return the shorts, will not re-order. This sizing inconsistency is not something I would expect from a company of Patagonia's caliber - will probably have to order/buy other brands' shorts that I know has very consistent sizing and fit. Bummed I will likely no longer be a Patagonia customer because I cannot rely on their products to fit as expected.  And to top it all off, Backcountry makes you pay a $6.99 UPS fee just to return this terrible product - I will be sure to never order another product from Backcountry!
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: The top was so cute and fit true to size, but puckered along the neckline and sagged.  Seemed like the shelf bra wasn't attached quite right.  Had to send it back.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5:
I was hoping for a more comfortable top. I tried both the L and the XL.  

The fabric doesn't have much give to it, so even the XL, being roomier, still felt a bit stiff and not conducive to movement. 

I love the design, just wish the fabric had more stretch and movement to it.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: I bought this tank for hiking.  I wanted one that had a built-in bra, had moisture wicking fabric, and was stylish.  I had high hopes for this little number, but once I got it, I felt it was too "normal".  For the high price I was willing to pay for a high end tank, this was not was I was expecting, especially from Patagonia.   It fit me well and looked fine - it just didn't live up to my expectations.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: Love the color, love the cute back, love the colors! Good support, too.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Let me start out by saying I really love the back detail and the fabric is nice, but that's where my love stops. This top is intended for running/fitness so I assumed the fit would be for athletic body types. I assumed wrong. It fits appropriately across the bust and from there flairs out like a circus tent to the hem. My dimensions are 36-28-39 so I'm a bit bottom heavy and according to the size chart should have purchased a medium. I ordered a small and this top still looked unbalanced on my body. It'd probably look great on somebody with a lot of junk in the trunk.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: This jacket is great. Incredible comfortable and great for that 60 - 70 degree nights. The only thing that keeps this from being a 5-star jacket is that the fit is a bit strange. The M fits like you think it should except in the shoulders. The L fits like it should in the shoulders, but then the stomach is more for a fella with a beer belly. I traded in my M and opted for the L because I can't stand clothes being too tight in the chest/shoulders!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I got this jacket for my husband for a trip this spring. It served him well in weather that called for layers (and, occasionally, a waterproof one on top). He was particularly fond of the zippered pockets. 5'10, 180 lbs and he took the M.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: It's a classic jacket - style and fit. Looks good with wither a dress/causal sport shirt. When washed and dry, it comes out smooth and crisp, as a pose to how it's shipped. For me, the fit is relax [I got the XL after reading reviews the says it runs small] and a bit long in the sleeves and somewhat loose at the bottom and as well as the cuffs. I'm a 5'8 with a beer and steak tummy, so the XL works well for that - though it's still loose there. I got the Black for cool days and nights - a sweater and a flannel shirt WOULD certainly work for cold days/nights. My ONLY problem is, the jacket is way over priced with zero interior lining, such as flannel or a light weight fleece, and also given where it is made for that price range. Other brands, like that famous L in Maine have a similar jacket for half the price.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: The weight of the jacket is great. The fit is pretty good, though it is a little roomy in the body. The collar is a little strange - it is kind of long, which makes it a little cumbersome when not zipped completely - can't figure out if it should lie down or stand up? I feel like it would be better if the collar were more of a "mock" length. All in all it is a good jacket, quality seems high, will wear it a lot.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: Purchased this for my dad as a fall/spring jacket and he seems to wear it all the time. He also really liked the Navy/Red color and says sometimes he wears it all day.
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This is a great jacket, I wear a XXL and it fits prefect.  I would say they run a tad short but all the other measurements fit great.  I would not say this is a "winter" jacket, but is perfect for around town and on spring/fall days.  My only complainant is that it does not have enough pockets, there needs to be some sort of chest pocket for me to give this 5 out of 5.  Other than that it is a stylish jacket with simple features.  I recommend this jacket for city use and around camp.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I have this jacket and the original Baggies Jacket. The original has two snapped cargo pockets AND two separate hand pockets AND a vertical zippered pocket over the heart. It has no lining and in addition to the full length zipper, has snaps. It was also made in AMERICA. It has long faded but I have used it for 30 years and is in great shape. This NEW version lacks cargo but adds a lining. I would trade this new one for an original any day of the week, BUT the new one is well made and gets the job done . . .with less cargo space.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: One feature that this short has but is not mentioned in the description, even on the Patagonia site, is that it has a draw string in the inside waist band like some swimming trunks have. This string (both ends) gets in the way of the zipper when you are putting it on, so you always have to fiddle with it to get it out of the way. It might be useful if you wanted to go for a swim. Swim trunks have a way of slipping down when they are wet. Had I known this string was going to be the pain that it is, I would not have purchased them. Also, the waist band material is a mesh of sorts that is rather rough and chafes when I do not have a shirt tucked in. But how often do you do that? Most of the time I am wearing a t-shirt outside of the short. On the plus side, and the thing that attracted me to the short in the first place, is the gusset, which is not easy to find.  The cut of the short is good, the placement of the pockets is, for me, excellent. I like to put my wallet in my left hip pocket and that is the side that has a zipper. And the cell phone pocket, too, has a zipper, which is great, though it would be better if the pocket were narrower. As it is, the phone can go horizontal and it can be difficult to retrieve in that position, especially when seated.  Note that the catalog photo of the pant gives the impression that this cell phone zipper pocket is narrow when, in fact, it is twice as wide. With some refinement, this short could be perfect.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I primarily use these shorts for well everything. From mountain to city these shorts are the perfect addition to a summer wardrobe. I bought a 33 waist as I usually do but wish I had bought a 32. The material stretches a bit while using. Love the shorts!

So the shorts themselves are excellent. Great look, great fit and they stretch really well while climbing.  My one knock, and it's actually a big knock, is the drawstring! Bad idea to place it on the inside and so small and flimsy. PrAna has same idea but it is a sinch cord on exterior and NOT across the opening of the shorts. I still wear them but I get annoyed by it the whole time.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I bought 1 pair of these shorts and I loved them so much I ordered every color! I wear many different Patagonia shorts and these are my favorite! The length, color and stretch are perfect!
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: I have a lot of Patagonia apparel and really love what they stand for as a company. These shorts fit great true to size, and have been really durable! I love that they have some stretch to the fabric. Definitely recommend
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: These are great for any occasion, going on a hike with the wife or a ride with some buddies, they get the job done!  Definitely going to pick up another pair for the summer now that the weather is starting to shift to the warmer months.
column8: I've used it several times

column5:
The short and the skinny is that these shorts are awesome.  By nature, I am slow to change my clothes.  My natural genetic inclination is aided by slightly awkward tendency towards idolization of items.  Subsequently, I very easily fall into a pattern of wearing the same clothes WAY longer than normal social standards allows for.  Sorry, I am an anthropologist - so you may be wondering where the heck I am going with this. Basically, if I think a clothing item is rad I will wear it non-stop until my wife forces me to bath/change clothes.  In the case of the Quandary short - every time I put it on I can't seem to get myself to take it off until forced to.  Why? Because seriously THESE SHORTS ARE RAD.  

Typically speaking I don't like synthetic clothing, but with that said these shorts are the perfect blend of fast-drying material, comfortable next to skin cotton, and stretchy spandex.  I have owned them for almost two years now and I always wear them mountain biking (zip pockets are great for keeping keys and phone in place).  Despite the repetitive pedal motion the cloth still looks great with not apparent signs of fatigue.  Honestly, whether it is warm weather hiking, playing at the beach, or just being a bum at home - when the sun is out and the temps are warm these are my shorts of choice.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: Just got these the other day and couldn't be more pleased! A little on the pricy side but worth every cent. Great Patagonia quality material and a nice "non-baggy" fit. The pockets work out great for me, open pocket in the back for my phone and a little hip pocket for my car key. I'm 5'9" and 149 lbs. and the size 32X10 works great...not too tight and not too loose. I purchased a Thomas Bates Hiker Belt separately for when I want a snugger fit. But haven't had to use it. Great purchase!
column8: I've used it several times

column5: Didn't love these. High rise, tight around the legs. Ran pretty true to size, they are stretchy which is nice, but ultimately sent them back because I wasn't crazy about them.
These shorts fit great and slightly higher. It's nice that they are stretchy allowing for more comfort.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I have been eyeing these shorts all spring and summer and finally went ahead and got them. I was so sad that they fit me weirdly! I ordered the 26, which fits perfectly around my waist (my usual pant size is 2), but the legs are so tight on my thighs! As a runner/weight lifter, these just aren't meant for muscular gals! The description says they are supposed to be relaxed, so my search continues for a good fitting pair of jean shorts! Super cute and love the fair trade/environmentally friendly aspect, though! If I sized up in these, the waist would be way too loose.
column8: I returned this product before using it

column5: Bought the size based off the sizing chart, sadly way too big! I would buy a size down if purchasing these shorts. I see the potential of them being cute but will be returning this item.

When I first looked at the photos, I thought they'd be frumpy looking but needed a pair and thought I'd try it out. Was pleasantly surprised! Not too long, the fabric is stretchy enough, and the color is awesome. Great go to pair of shorts.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: I'm 6ft 200lbs with a 35 inch waist or so and I got these in a 36.  They are nice.  A stiff polyester with no stretch.  They feel durable.  I'd say they are loose fitting except for the waist, which I'd guess runs 1inch too small.  They do fit me well for what I was looking for.  Loose and casual for the beach and pool.  They have a single zipper pocket with a key loop inside.  Colors are OK.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I love the stretchy fabric that Patagonia went with on these shorts, you hardly notice that they are even on. The fit was perfect, and they don't chafe at all so they are perfect for adventuring down a river or lounging by the pool.
column8: I've used it once or twice and have initial impressions

column5: I like the style and function of these shorts, but the sizing is just a tad off on the small side. I ordered my normal Patagonia size and these seem to be a bit smaller in the waist. Not a deal breaker, just not what I'm accustomed to. I like the length and the small pocket is an added bonus to store keys, etc. They seem to be fairly quick drying even in humid environments.  I'm 6'2" and 195 lbs. and I ordered the 35's.
column8: I've put it through the wringer

column5: The perfect summer board shorts for both size and comfort. The colors are excellent and fit a very likable product. They are a little hard to get over a cyclists thighs and butt, but once they are on it golden!
column8: I gave it as a gift but have feedback to share

column5: This are the best board shorts I've ever owned, love the fit, love the color and the best thing is they feel really light when wet, I need another pair!.
column8: I've used it several times

column5: These shorts are NOT right to size. I ordered them last minute for vacation knowing my waist size and was once again disappointed by Patagonia. I love their products as far as durability, however for some reason they always run small. I even ordered a size larger due to previous experiences with this issue, and was once again disappointed with the outcome!
They dry very quickly and hold up very well. Plenty of mobility for surfing and paddle boarding. They stretch to provide plenty of movement. they also look pretty great.
column8: I've put it through the wringer
